Raw_Narrative: Tanker 123 was dropping on the Castle Peak Fire. Lead plane reported that Tanker 123's #4 engine seemed to have smoke coming from it. cockpit indications were normal. After completing drops a precautionary shut down of #4 engine was completed and a three engine landing was made at GJT.During inspection by vendor mech. It was found that the #3 cylinder on the #4 engine had no compression. Vendor mech. changed out cylinder.  Tanker 123 says the leadplane assistance was commendable.

Upon doing pre-use inspection I noticed fuel on the ground.  After looking closer, there was a leak on the fuel tank on the support/service trailer.  The leak was located on the lower right side of the tank.  A previous impact to the tank appeared to have created a crack that had rusted and a leak start.

Upon arrival at the airport, and inspection of the helicopter, moisture was found in the fuel sensor unit.  Heavy rain from the previous day had saturated the wiring. Helicopter manager and air support arrive at the helibase and discovered N104HC wasn't there.  A phone call was made to locate the aircraft.  It was discovered that the mechanic was working to dry the wiring and associated parts.

While returning to California from the Florida Incidents the aircraft was preparing to leave Lake Front Airport in Louisiana.  During pre takeoffrunup on the engines the pilot noticed that the right engine was not coming upto 100% power.  An air deverter valve had failed which would not allow the engine to get enough air to function properly.  A certified aviation mechanictemporarily repaired the valve but would not sign off a Part 135 Cert.  ACORthe aircraft on unavilability and paid for the ferry flight back to Fresno.The Forest Service employee returned to Fresno on a commercial airline.

Upon completing recon missions of several fires managed by a complex in a B206L4, the fuel truck driver noticed a small impact area on the underside of the tail rotor gearbox cowling. The impact area had numerous small cracks dispersing from the center. Because there were no chips or indentations, it appeared to be a bird strike. Probably a small bird, sparrow or robin. No indications of a bird strike were noticed during flight and no evasive maneuvers from birds were performed. The bird strike was unnoticed in flight. Upon discovery of the possible impact area, the pilot took pictures and forwarded them to the company director of maintenance and notified the helicopter manager and helibase manager.

Helitack at the helispot loaded a firefighter into the front left seat which had the dual controls. The firefighter hit the start switch while the helicopter was running. No apparent damage to the helicopter.

While transitioning from Fresno Air Attack Base to  Ramona Air Attack Base while over Lake Elsinore, SoCal Center (FAA), advised of a Twin Otter as traffic above Air Attack 430.  Target was identified and was being watched by the crew of AA430.  SoCal Center advised the Twin Otter not to drop skydivers due to AA430 being below the other aircraft.  The pilot of the Twin Otter advised he had 3 people in free fall.  Pilot Groom spotted the 3 skydivers descending into the path of AA430.  The skydivers were approximately 700 feet above AA430.  Pilot Groom called inbreaking rightin and broke away from the skydivers.  This safecom is being filed in addition to a California Procedure 200, to advise other agency aircraft of the possibility of skydivers being dropped without knowledge of SoCal Center.

July 9, 2018 @ 935 am Helicopter NXXX was lifting to depart from the Airport for bucket work on the Golden Butte Fire when the ground crew noticed black rubber flying out near the main rotor of the helicopter.The aircraft returned to airport and landed. After landing and inspection the mechanic found that the rotating swash-plate boot was disintegrating. The mechanic cut out what was left of the boot. The aircraft was made unavailable at 10am until further notice. The manager informed the helicopter vendor director and DOI maintenance inspector, Travis Shepard. The vendor ordered the part AOG. Pilot noted that on preflight he did not notice anything odd or recognize anything wrong on the swash plate. At 12:30 the vendor completed taking the necessary parts off the helicopter in preparation to install a new swash-plate boot.The vendor advised they would be unavailable for the rest of day and possibly half the following day. The mechanic covered the helicopter head with tape and plastic to prevent rain and moisture from entering the bare open swash-plate bearing. Vendor dispatched a company helicopter mechanic the following morning with the part and tools to complete the part installation.

We were dispatched to the xxx fire in an ASM configuration. After speaking to the IC and IC{T} to determine and sync objectives, strategies, and tactics we discussed the needed tools to achieve the objectives of perimeter control {Full Suppression} with the IC and IC {T}. The fire was burning during peak burn period, in a high elevation mixed conifer fuel type with a moderate to heavy dead and down component, low to moderate rate of spread {3-5 Ch/Hr}, moderate surface fire flame lengths {2-4 ft}, isolated to group torching {occurring every 4-5 minutes}, Primary residences in the vicinity {within 1 mile}, a State Highway within 1/2 mile, a small community within 2-3 miles, and a high resistance to control due to access and fuel type {bug kill in the area}. The dew point at KXXX was -2c indicating a dry air mass in the area. The following aircraft were recommended to the IC and IC {T} based on conditions, fire activity, time to complete the retardant line, etc: 2 additional SEATS {Total of 4}, 2 Large Air Tankers, and a VLAT. We determined that based on load and return times, anticipated lag time in getting aerial assets on scene, it would take 2 SEAT loads across the heel, 8 loads per flank {16 SEAT loads total}, and an undetermined number across the head depending on timing of aircraft. To reduce cumulative transference of risk to the flight crews, increase efficiency, increase probability of success , and allow for all aircraft to be made available in a short time period we made the decision to order the VLAT with the concurrence of the IC and IC {T}. We were fully anticipating needing to double the loads needed by the time the aircraft arrived on scene. The order was placed thru the appropriate dispatch center for all aircraft and we began to work the fire to achieve objectives. We had a very candid discussion with the IC and IC{T} that if we do not get the aircraft needed we need to revisit ``the plan`` as without the needed tools we would not be able to successfully meet the objectives and there for not expose the flight crews to a loosing proposition. Approximately 1 hour after beginning retardant operations we were informed that per the Duty Officer {DO}the VLAT has been canceled. We discussed the issue with the IC and IC{T} and informed them of the fire activity, shifting winds, doubling of fire size, load and return times, cost of retardant delivered by the VLAT, and attempted to give them the information they would need to discuss with their Duty Officer. They made a few phone calls and informed us that the DO wanted some time to think about it. We informed the IC that the retardant operation would be halted until a decision could be made and offered our assistance to the ground fire fighters. During these discussions the fire activity picked up and the fire again doubled in size and began to spot short range {3-4 ch}. Due to the unnecessary delay and limitation of tools we were being allowed to utilize we began to suspended air operations and returned to KXXX for fuel. Also, during this time the winds on the fire switched 180 degrees, exhibited signs of high atmospheric instability {Rotors and whirls from the column} and the fire began to out flank our retardant line and move toward H2 which was staffed with unburned fuel between them and the main fire. Based on the lack of support and winds we halted operations to reduce exposure to ourselves and the other flight crews and recommended that the crews on H2 reassess their LCES and consider hiking off the hill. Once on the ground we made contact with the IC and they were quite frustrated and apologetic, I told them that I understand it was not their issue and we would help them in anyway we could, both the IC and IC {T} were very appreciative. While on the ground at KXXX the fire activity again picked up and a moderate to well developed column developed on the left shoulder, visible from KXXX, we were contacted by dispatch that the IC needed us over the fire ASAP. We launched within 6 minutes and were on scene. As an aircrew, it is neither appropriate or acceptable to limit what tools an IHC crew can use to construct line, we provide them with task, purpose, and an end state and allow the professionals to make the determination on how to achieve it. The reverse should be true from the ground to the air. Cost shall not be the sole determining factor when deciding what ``tool`` to use to meet the stated objectives. As a result of the above listed factors we halted aviation operations due to an unacceptable level of attempted risk transference and changing conditions.

T--- taxied out for the War Creek fire and while holding short of the runway and performing runup could not get the right jet to start. T--- taxied back to the tanker base so that the mechanic could take a look at the problem.  Due to the delay T--- was removed from contract availability.  After the mechanic removed the jet engine covers and could not find anything out of order.  The covers were  then replaced and an attempt was made to start the jet.  At that time the jet started right up and operated correctly.  ---- ------- aircraft maintenance program manager was informed of the problem with the jet and what was done.  With his approval T---was placed back into extended standby service as the contractural availability period had expired.  Dispatch was notified and T--- was then placed on a load and hold for the remainder of the evening until released.

Helicopter was lifting off helibase when front passenger door opened.Helicopter pilot noticed dooor open and radio communication was established with helibase. He informed helibase and pad that he was coming back to pad to set down and close door.

UASM saw the rotor wing aircraft fly directly over their Catch 22 LRZ within the Beachie Creek TFR heading west. The rotor wing aircraft was approximately 400' AGL and flew under our type 2 UAS. Our UAS was at 4000' AGL within the LRZ.

Pilot noticed a trace amount of oil on exterior of helicopter following a 45 minute flight from fire to Bethel, AK. Mechanic notified and discovered a small hole in the number 1 engine oil cooler input line. Appropriate notifications made.

On August 20, 2020 at 15:20 hours, Guard copter 802 hit it’s water bucket on a tree during a water dropping mission for the Butte Lightning Complex.  Guard copter 802 is a CH-47 with a 120’ longline attached to the bucket. The Lat/Long for the Cow Dip site is N 39 59.33 W 121 27.06.  We made contact with a tree while exiting a dip.  We were supporting fire “1-2”.  This was the second “dip” on a new fuel cycle.  Guard 802 had previously pulled 9 buckets from the this dip site on our first fuel cycle. 

The dip site is at an elevation of 6,200’.  The temperature was approximately 29 degrees.  Our speed over ground was 10 knots thus not into effective translational lift (ETL).  The bucket is a 2,000 gallon Tarantula Power-Fill Bambi bucket but was only 75% full.  We utilized the same exit path for departure from the pond each time.  The crew did not see the “snag” tree in time to jettison the water from the bucket and the bucket made contact with the top of the tree and tore a hole in the side of the bucket.  After briefing with the crew, it was determined/agreed that we did not climb enough altitude (AGL) prior to forward flight.  The tear is too large to patch and therefore out of service.  The crew of 802 did not feel anything in the aircraft when we struck the tree.  There was no other damage related to this incident.

At the end of the days operation, helitac crew was unloading gear at pad to RON Fairbanks. I had exited the left rear, retrived some gear on the right side and came back to left side. Rear door was cracked open with handle down. I believed I had shut it fully latched and thought to inspect if I had missed something. Glancing to the rear of the ship I saw mechanic by the cargo door but didn`t see it open. As slid the rear door open it hit the open cargo door and broke top hinge. The ship was put out of service.

Pilot's narrative 8/27/02:  On 8/25/02 after departing airport for patrol flight, I saw that there was a vapor of fuel coming off the right wing of the Cessna 182.  I was only two miles out from the airport.  After returning to the airport, another company pilot who is also an A & P, adjusted the right wing fuel cap so that it would close tighter.  Then I test flew the aircraft, and determined that the problem had been fixed.
At 1115 on 7/14 heavy helibase received a call from Air Attack that NXXXX was experiencing an AFCS service problem and was returning to the heavy helibase.  NXXXX landed at 1125 without incident.
Corrective action is ongoing.  Please see Safecom # 00-297

While conducting a review of the John Day Rappel Base the Region 6 Aviation Safety Manager visited with the Forest Service Single Engine Air Tanker (SEAT) pilot and manager; also stationed at John Day.  It was discovered that the Ayres Thrush, Model S2R-T45 was being operated without the use of aircraft performance charts developed by the aircraft manufacturer for firefighting operations.  Additionally when the SEAT is dispatched for a fire the local dispatch is not providing estimated drop area terrain elevations.Background:The RASM Council accomplished a SEAT risk assessment in October 2004.  One area identified operations at high density altitudes without performance charts as a hazardous activity.  The RASM Council recommended that SEATs not be used where performance data does not exist and forwarded this issue to the RAO Council.  The RAO Council made the following recommendations;•	Terrain elevation in the drop area is sometimes unknown on the initial response therefore, an estimate should be provided to the pilot on the dispatch order to allow computation of the allowable load. •	Pilots should be able to determine that a positive rate of climb (50 feet per minute) can be achieved on take off and to an altitude 1000 feet above the expected drop location at the response weight.•	Aircraft without performance information available to meet the contract requirement in B2.4.5 will not be allowed to operate on lands under FS protection.It appears these recommendations are not being followed at John Day.

In the early hours of Aug 8, 2000 two engines were parked parallel to a two track road (Pulled off to the right side of the road one engine behind the other).  One USFS crewperson was asleep on a cot about 6-8 feet from the engine on the opposite side of the fire.  The other crewpersons were either between the engines or in the cabs. At approximately 0400 a dozer that was working the fire was attempting to relocate to another area on the fire and was driving down the same two track road.  Because the engines were blocking part of the road the dozer left the two track and went around the engines.  His inside track hit the cot the crewperson was sleeping on and woke him up.  He crewperson rolled off the cot and escaped injury. (He did later complain about a sore calf and hip and thinks he was hit by the blade of the dozer. X-rays were taken at a local hospital and he was released).  The dozer's track rolled over and crushed the cot and the dozer operator proceeded to the fire line to continue working, never aware that the incident occurred.The crewperson received a Critical Stress Debriefing at 1700 on 08-08-00 and was back to work on 08-09-00.

After landing at KGCN for fuel the cowl of the right engine was observed to have a coating of grease that appeared to have come from the area of the propeller hub.  The aircraft had returned from spending 3.5 hours conducting leadplane activities on the Outlet Fire.

I recieved a dipatch and departed AVQ at 1343 for the Black fire. Initial contact was made with ATGS Trainee XX about 20 miles out and I picked up flight folowing with him. At 11 miles I again contacted ATGS and was cleared into the fire at 2500 ft. MSL. I arrived on the fire at the same time as Lead XX and ATGS turned me over to Lead. I followed Lead for a couple of circuits of the fire and a ''show me'' at which time I ws cleared for the drop and competed the first half of the drop across the head of the fire. Lead continued up and to the right in a wide pattern. I told lead that I stil had half a load and would continue my turn to pick up the dogleg down the flank. Lead acknowledged and said he was wide. Having dropped half of the load and light I was able to turn lower and inside Lead and continued the turn to pick up the final. As we were converging Lead said he as going to cross the saddle higher on the ridge and ''look at the line'', at this pont I had him in sight and reported that I was inside and below him. Lead reported me ''insight''. As I turned final I could not see Lead as my wing was up, but was comfortable as Lead was outside to my left, well above and had me insight. I did not see Lead at any time after turning final. After the drop I continued straight out at drop altitude over flat terrain befre climbing as I believed Lead to be above and behind me. I heard someone say ''that was a little close'' and Lead responded ''yes a little''. I had no Idea what was being disscussed. On departure I was instructed to load and return. I picked up flight following with State Fire and returned to AVQ and reloaded.Returning turning to the fire I contacted ATGS at 12 miles and was cleared into the fire at 2500. I reported again at 5 miles and was instructed to hold southwest untill the helicopter completed his drop and departed. After the Helicopter complete his drop I was cleard in and completed 3 split drops under direction of ATGS. After the drop I returned to AVQ to hold. Other than the remark of ''that was a lttle close'' there was no other discussion of what was close.
WHILE EN ROUTE TO THE NORTH FORK FIRE, #1 RECIP ENGING STARTED BACKFIRING. AIRCRAFT RETURNED TO GJT WITHOUT INCIDENT. Aircraft PARKED WHERE VENDOR MECHANICS ATTEMPTED TO FIX THE ENGINE...

On the Brianhead Incident near DP-48 a UAS was spotted by the Division Papa Safety Officer. The Division Supervisor was notified and responded to DP-48. Division Papa notified Brianhead Operations Section Chief, who notified the Air Operations Branch Director. The AOBD notified Brianhead helibase and informed them of the intrusion and confirmed that no incident air operations were currently underway. Once the Division reached DP-48 he made contact with the Drone operator. The operator was very cooperative and returned the drone back to DP-48. Division Papa was able to get the operators information and the operator left the area. Brianhead AOBD notified Color Country Interagency Fire Center and informed them of the intrusion. In addition, the AOBD notified the SLC Air Traffic Control Center.

Crew-XXX was working in Div. G on the fire helping to progress a hose lay in support of a back firing operation.  A hot shot was also on the Division calling in water drops from a heavy helitanker. Upon reaching the top of the hill, crew-XXX members asked if it was clear to come up and was given the ok from the hot shot crew. One crew member asked where the tanker was dropping and was told it was further down the line from their location. Shortly after the tanker came in for its drop and hit two crew members. One crewmember was not injured while the other sustained minor injuries to his left arm and right leg. The injured crewmember was transported to a local hospital to be evaluated. The crewmember was treated, released and put back on normal duty the following day. It`s estimated that the crewmember was hit with a split load of approximately 1,000 gallons of water.

Our Helitack crew purchased a brand new MARK V from Aerostat INC in early 2017. The machine was bench tested and seemed to operate properly. The machine was first used operationally on the Slim Fire in June 2017. The glycol pump was not functioning, the auger in the hopper unscrewed itself, and the agitator in the hopper was constantly crushing PSD balls. We contacted Aerostat and sent the machine back to be refurbished later that month. We received the PSD machine back in July. We benched tested in the fall and spring with no issues. We tried the machine again operationally on the Redondo RX in April 2018 and experienced more issues. Once installed in the helicopter, the PSD machine would trip the breaker. With further inspection we were able to find that the main motor on the PSD machine was not working. The water stored in the PSD machine had leaked and rusted the tools and the bottom of the PSD machine. Multiple electrical connections were loose and or needed to be re clamped and secured. The machine was once again sent back to Aerostat. We received the machine back in June 2018. When tested the wheel on the PSD machine was rotating in the wrong direction. We determined the main cord to the machine was wired wrong. We have yet to use the machine operationally.

As pilot was attempting to depart the Ely Tanker Base for the Hibbing Tanker base for ATGS standby support, the rear engine barely turned over and then refused to start. Light, dissimular metal corrosion was noticed where battery cable end was clamped to the cable. Cable end connector was removed, corrosion cleaned and new cable was spliced in place. Engine still refused to start. Further troubleshooting pointed to the starter as the next logical problem. New starter was ordered and arrived the morning of 06/19 and was subsequently installed by A & P soon after. Being the pilot's and ATGS's day off, there was no attempt to return to service on the 19th. At the beginning of the operational period on 06/20 the aircraft's both engines started and ran up fine. Aircraft inspector xxxxxxxx(Mr. xxx had been in the loop from the start of troubles) was called and after an explanation of the trouble and the work done he returned the aircraft to service at 0900 hrs on 06/20/02.

At 1842, aircraft was dispatched to incident #428.  Time enroute was 9minutes to the fire. Three circles of the fire were made before being clearedby air attack for a drop.      A split drop was made on a west to east heading.  After the first drop wascompleted, the aircraft circled and made a second west to east drop.  Afterthe second drop, ground personnel reported that the aircraft may have clipped the top of a tall tree on the pullup after completing the drop.    After returning to the airport,a low pass was made to check for damage,nodamage was noted. After an uneventful landing,the aircraft was inspected fordamage and none was noted. It appears that the aircraft clipped the top fewinches of a tree with a tire during the pull up after the drop.    Although the pilot was not sure he had come in contact with a tree, he still observed proper safety procedures in doing a low pass at the airport for observation before a landing was attempted.
Ignition anomaly on the number 2 engine required a jettison of the load and precautionary landing. Returned to tanker base to trouble shoot.

After coming in and refueling, helicopter left pad in route back to dip site when he realized that the fuel cap had not been reinstalled. Helicopter returned back to pad and fuel man went out and reinstalled the fuel cap. Helicopter then proceeded back on his mission, no sight of any fuel spill.
An oil scavange return line seal failed which allowed the return line to back out of the rocker cover, which in turn resulted in engine oil to flow onto the engine and ground.

During an inflight emergency ( See separate Safecom 01-373 relating to this incident)the Spotter in charge was unable to communicate with the Helibase. This was due to the fact that currently at the Helibase at John Day we are experiencing serious radio interference from an unknown source. Because of this interference our radios here at the base are basically useless. We continually have squelch out on many of our FM radio channels. We have been trying for several months to find the source of interference. Although we did not recieve the radio contact from the aircraft we did view the situation and were able to respond to the situation appropriately and without delay.We beleive that a possible source of the interference may be our local radio station broadcasting out of its designated bandwidth. Last year and this early summer our radio technician's did verify that in fact the station was outside of its normal bandwidth.

On 8/3/11 at 1100 H-XXX was dispatched to a fire for bucket work. While going into the heliwell for the second dip, the bucket became snagged on an exposed hose fitting that extended about two inches into the tank. While pulling power to exit the dip, the pilot recognized that the bucket was snagged, reduced power and was able to unsnag the bucket. The pilot did not believe there was mechanical damage to the bucket and continued bucket drops. Because of the short duration of the mission the pilot was able to finish bucket work and land safely. Upon closer inspection, damage to the bucket include: two bent support ribs, ripped suspension straps, and a six inch tear in the top of the bucket wall. The heliwell used is an in ground, fiberglass, 1500 gallon tank. The fitting on the tank included a double female on the external side and a male/female adapter that extended two inches into the tank. The purpose of the fitting was to plumb a pumpkin, allowing the tank to be gravity fed.

Helicopter lifted off from Babb HLB to insert six helitack into H-50 to mop up a spot fire. Shortly after take off, passengers in the rear on the right side noticed a strange vibration, and informed the pilot. The pilot also picked up the vibration in the cyclic. Pilot then made the decision to set the aircraft down. He notified helibase of his situation then landed at the cargo area which is about four miles south of the Babb helibase. The aircraft was landed safely with no damage or injuries. Shortly after hearing the radio traffic the mechanic and helicopter manager drove to where the aircraft had landed.

We were on our third cycle of the day on the Buzzard fire in the Big Cypress Park, when we decided to abort our bucket mission and return to Helibase. For the past several days, and the previous two cycles of the day, the Air Attack had been running the helicopters and SEATs on the rotor victor...due to the long turn around times this seemed to be working well for everyone, with the Air Attack sequencing all the aircraft together as needed. Before our last cycle, there was an Air Attack transition to a new Air Attack that apparently was not aware that everyone had been working on the same frequency...We had heard that SEATs were coming to the same area again, but were never told when they would be there. Our first drop went just fine, and during the long turn around to the dip, we never heard from Air Attack that SEATs were on station. On our second drop, during which we were talking to a ground contact and flying in smokey conditions while trying to find the drop point, we still hadn’t heard anything, so we went ahead and dropped planning on exiting off our nose and around the smoke as we had done previously. As I sat up after the drop, my copilot pointed out a previously unseen SEAT at our altitude, on our exit path, having just made a drop. I immediately turned 180 degrees away from the area and proceeded back around the column the other way. I was finally able to reach Air Attack, and he said “, Yea, he was talking to the SEAT, and the pilot could see me” and he tried to reach me on the rotor victor but I was talking to the ground, so he just went ahead and sent the SEAT in...We were monitoring the victor the whole time and at no time did we hear the Air Attack try to contact us about the SEAT. At this point, due to the lack of communication and getting no further responses from the Air Attack we decided it would be best to just depart the area and return to the Helibase. We never were able to reach Air Attack again, on the 10 mile trip back to Oasis Helibase to even tell him we that were returning to base.

Idaho City Helibase at the Idaho City Airport {U98} was supporting the Trinity West Fire. Portable fuel containment berms were deployed as requested by the Idaho City RD resource advisor. The portable berm was approximately 15` x 60`, model `Throw N Go` made by Bowhead Environmental & Safety. Type III helicopter returned to helibase from a recon mission before berm was completely set-up. Berm was not staked or weighted down and fuel truck had not yet moved to park on the berm. Due to wind shift the helicopter preferred approach path to landing took it near the berm. Based on size and weight of the berm the crew working with the berm did not anticipate that the berm would be affected by the T-III rotor-wash. Wind from the rotor-wash got under the edge of the berm and rolled/flipped the berm about 30` off the edge of the airstrip into brush. No personnel were in the area and the berm did not contact any equipment, aircraft, or personnel.

Pilot reported low fuel pressure indicator illuminated on the number 4 engine while over fire preparing for a drop.  PIC elected not to drop and returned to MFR for repairs.   Aircraft landed without incident.

On final approach back into Helibase from the Bear Gulch Fire on a cargo mission with a 100'' synthetic longline with remote hook, several people including myself noticed the longline whipping violently beneath the helicopter and after a few moments, the lonline and hook fell from the aircraft into an alfalfa field adjacent to helibase. The pilot was informed immediately via radio and was unaware that it had fallen off. A ground crew quickly went over to the field and recovered the longline and remote hook shortly after. No damage or injuries occured. The local winds at the time were approximately 20-25 mph. Airspeed was appoximately 40-50 mph. The pilot says he did NOT punch off the line accidently. We believed that the line worked itself loose from the belly hook somehow. We hypothesized that there was enough ''slack'' and/or ''whip'' in the line to make this possible.

Turbocharged 337 Cessna Skymaster pilot started the front engine without any problems. Attempted to start the rear engine but it would not start. The pilot followed other starting procedures as recommended by the owner but without success. The company mechanic was contacted and it was determined the fuel pump had failed. At 1900 aircraft was unavailable.

At 0940 hours on 7/28/00 while enroute to the Bismark Fire NXXX experiencedan instrument problem with the transmission fluid temperature gauge.  The aircraft returned to the Tooele Airport and shut down immediatey. Phil McCorkle the principle technician was notified.  A certified A&Pexamined the problem and corrective actions were taken and discussed with Phil McCorkle.  AT 1142 a twenty minute test flight was conducted.  Theaircraft was back in service at 1205.

Duplicate of 14-0414.  Aircraft was performing bucket operations on the Fire with a 100 ft. synthetic long line and 160 gal. FAST Bucket. Making descending left turns in steep terrain the aircraft went into the dip-site. Pilot watched the bucket fill and began to ascend. Pilot felt the aircraft `want to roll` and corrected for the issue initially. Realizing something was wrong pilot set bucket back into dip and looked in mirror to see the long line over the heel of the left skid. Pilot released water from bucket to minimize roll over effect and slowly pulled up out of the dip. Pilot contacted the IC on A/G, notified him of the issue and asked if there was someone at the helispot that could remove the line from the skid. Pilot flew at a reduced airspeed to the fires helispot where a helitack crew was present and mitigated the problem. While being more cautious going into the dip and monitoring the mirror closely, pilot finished fuel cycle and returned to helibase. Once on the ground Pilot notified HMGB and FAO of what had happened.

On 8/20/2015 at approximately 15:00, H-XXX was dropping water on Div. B of the fire. There were gusty and erratic ridge top winds which made water delivery difficult. H-XXX was working with a hotshot crew on the ground securing the fire line. During one of the drops, the hotshot crew member directing the water drops, saw the bucket make contact with the top of one of the trees. The view of the crew member on the ground was obscured by the trees and could not determine that the bucket was too low. After contact with the tree was made, no communication occurred between the pilot and ground crew member that the incident had occurred. The pilot did not notice the bucket come in contact with the tree. After examining the bucket on 8/21/2015, it was confirmed that contact had occurred. By chance, a conversation at dinner on 8/20/2015, revealed that the incident had taken place.

After departure left rear door popped open. A/C returned for landing and door was closed and checked.  It is believed that the pax seated next to the door accidently bumped the door which caused it to open.

On July 8th, 2006 at aprox 1450 hrs, Central Nevada Dispatch called and informed us that T-xxx, a severity SEAT based at the Severity SEAT Base, was inbound for a load/return to the fire. Dispatch informed us that this SEAT was loaded with foam and had been unable to locate the fire and now was low on fuel and needed to jettison the load and land at BAM to refuel and reload with retardant. This aircraft (and regular Pilot) had initially been into BAM AAB and received an aircraft and vehicle use inspection and pilot briefing per Interagency policy. Prior to this aircraft’s arrival at BAM on 7/8, He was observed on AFF flying to a couple of locations quite a ways from each other. The Base Mgr. called Dispatch back to determine the true nature of T-xxx’s mission. It was then learned that T-xxx had in fact been dispatched to a fire and had been the unfortunate victim of a WILDCAD mix-up and was vainly searching an area, far from the true location of the fire, long enough he was now low on fuel. The Base then unsuccessfully attempted to contact T-xxx on the National Air Tanker Base Freq of 123.975 in order to relay the Jettison Area lat/long. A quick check of AFF found him just ESE of the airport, the base staff continued to attempt to contact him and was just about to call him on the District FM freq when he was observed jettisoning his load at the mouth of Hilltop Canyon. As this is a seasonal waterway and not the approved jettison area the Base Mgr. called the Severity Seat Base and spoke with the SEMG who said the pilot was a level II relief pilot, not the regular pilot, and had in fact been briefed, as per policy, but had never been in to BAM. (Also learned in later conversation with the pilot was the fact that he had only performed aprox 20 actual fire drops in his career and was a little apprehensive about his performance. This would factor in to the reason the Base Mgr. chose to discuss the intended mission with the Smokejumper spotter.) Interagency policy states that the first time during the season a tanker pilot arrives at a Large Tanker Base he will shut down his aircraft and receive a briefing from the base staff. This was the main reason this aircraft was shut down and the pilot given a briefing. Several other factors were starting to point to the need to ensure this pilot got a thorough Base briefing. A quick list of those factors were: No contact on the National Tanker Base frequency 123.975, either when inbound or on the ground; No knowledge of our jettison procedures or location; (ie; not dropping over waterways, lakes, etc…) No knowledge of BAM Ramp Procedures; Confusion surrounding the actual location of the fire. During the time that T-xxx was getting fueled the Base Mgr. was in contact with Dispatch to determine the correct lat/long, later confirmed with the pilot. While in contact with Dispatch, he also learned that a load of jumpers had been unable to jump the same fire due to erratic winds over the jump site, and that the jumpship was also inbound for fuel and would then be headed back to the Bone Fire to staff it. The Base Mgr. decided that this was a good opportunity to touch base with the jumpship spotter, who had ordered the SEAT, and really nail down the plan for the retardant mission for the new pilot, as well as discuss the winds encountered over the fire. This was accomplished and T-xxx was returned to the retardant rotation.

July 6, 2016 a Bell 206L4 was preforming bucket operations on the BLM````s Blair Fire near Rangley Colorado. Foretasted weather for the area was a high temp of 88 degrees Fahrenheit and winds 10-15 mph gusting to 30 from the SW. Performance planning was done for 7000 ft and 30 degrees Celsius. Maximum elevation of the fire was approx. 6500 feet. All flight operations were performed within allowable payload limits. At approx. 1700, with approx. forty five min left in the fuel cycle, the pilot had just completed a water drop and was returning to the dip-site. He heard a noise that was stated as resembling losing the long line from the belly-hook. However the long-line was still attached. After assessing the long-line and gauges the pilot noticed a warning light indicating that torque limits may have been exceeded. The pilot relayed to ground resources that he had heard a noise and was heading back to the landing zone to check out the helicopter. Once safely on the ground at the landing zone the pilot communicated the occurrence to the helicopter manager. The vendor````s maintenance staff, agency contracting representative, and regional forest service maintenance inspector were contacted. Required inspections were preformed and the helicopter was approved for availability at the start of the next shift.

From Tanker Base: “Dispatch called Tanker Base by phone and asked if we still had contact with T-XX, due to the fact that they were not responding to the call out from Dispatch. I contacted T-XX on the base victor and they responded that they could hear Dispatch but Dispatch could not hear them, but they were traveling through some storm cells upon leaving the Tanker Base and would address the radio once they made it through the weather concerns.”

On 8/3/14 the helicopter experienced an engine failure shortly after leaving Helibase while en route back to Division C/D on the Complex. The pilot notified the Helibase approximately 10 minutes after leaving that they would be returning due to mechanical issues.  Upon landing, the pilot informed the HMGB that there had been a failure of the number 2 engine.  After further inspection, pieces of metal were found in the exhaust of the aircraft.  At this point it was determined the aircraft would be unavailable until the engine could be replaced.  Helibase was notified of the situation and the Regional Aircraft Maintenance Inspector was also notified.
Trouble shooting {{#}}2 RPM issue, aircraft out of service 0900 08/29/2013

WHile returning to Fairfield Airport after doing water drops on the Deer Park {{#}}3 Fire, HT had a fire indicator light come on. They made the decision to immediatlely land in a vacant field approx 6 miles from the Fairfeild Airport. Upon landing pilots verified there was no fire and the message was relayed to Fairfield airport helibase. Crew chief and mechanice drove to where HT was parked and determined that again, there was no fire and that the problems was electrical. R4 Aviation Maintenace Inspector was called and consulted. Desicion was made to fly HT back to fairfield to trouble shoot problem.

Retardant crew was loading a P2V airtanker in pit 2 when a SEAT came into pit 1 for hot load. The crew began loading the SEAT using the SEAT loading pump. This left one MXMS at the meter stand watching two meter displays while the other MXMS ran the engine driven SEAT pump. In the middle of both loading operations the retardant density on the SEAT meter suddenly increased and loading became sluggish. At nearly the same time the loader on the P2V announced that loading was sluggish as it appeared that the pump kept quitting. The MXMS at the meter tried to discover why there seemed to be an obstruction to the water flow and tried working valves etc. There seemed to be some confusion about why both loading operations were experiencing problems so the base manager radioed to the MXMS to discontinue loading the P2V and concentrate on what was wrong with the SEAT operation. All attempts to regain water by valve switching proved ineffective and the SEAT load was discontinued at 6875 lbs by the meter although visually short of a load. The SEAT then returned to the fire. Loading the P2V was restarted and without the noise of the running SEAT it was obvious now that the main pump was indeed running but experiencing the same sluggishness with an apparent loss of water. The tank light system immediately indicated with a red light that 2082 was reached and the loader stopped the pump. An aircrew member told the loader to “ignore the lights” and continue loading. The pump was restarted but still producing little flow and elevated density at the meter. So loading was discontinued at 18,065 lbs at the meter while the aircrew indicated full load had not been reached. The P2V returned to the fire. After both aircraft had left the base it was discovered that the water supply valve had not been open and the water tank had run dry. The valve was opened and the water tank began to recover. When the SEAT returned to reload, the SEAT loading pump would not recover a prime against the check valves and a decision was made in conference with the pilot to load using the main pump as it would have enough “pull” to recover a flow. This worked and the SEAT load was finished in specification and without problem using the main loading pump. When the P2V returned the reload went without incident.

While performing a longline mission, the nine pin plug on the belly of the ship detached. The plug was not originally taped per instruction of the pilot. He informed that it was not necessary for this ship as they had performed this type mission numerous times before with no trouble. The next morning, 8/12/00, during preflight, the pilot found a small ding w/ chipped paint on the belly of the ship toward the rear. It was suspected through investigation, that the damage was caused by the disconnected plug swaying loosely in flight. Later in the day, approx. 1500, the plug detached twice again even though it was taped this time.

During a post-flight inspection of the aircraft a small crack {skin} was identified on the left side of the aft section, below the {#}1 engine. Upon further inspection the inner `stringer`that`s adjacent to the crack was also compromised.

After flying 4.6 hours on the Rockhouse Fire a transmission oil pressure warning light illuminated but transmission pressure indications were normal. Warning light is turned on by two pressure switches, one plumbed to the forward transmission and one on the aft transmission. This occured upon startup after refueling.

The helicopter left the Tripod fire on the Okongan Wenatchee N.F. for the Puzzle fire on the Deschutes N.F. The flight schedule received at the Central Oregon Dispatch did not have the number of passengers or names; the only information was the pilot’s name.  When the helicopter landed it was discovered that it had 3 passengers, 1 HELM and 2 HCWN on board.

While the aircraft performing reconnaissance mission the National Flight Following frequency at the xxx Interagency Communication Center{xICC} went inoperable and xICC could not hear communication from the aircraft. A neighboring dispatch center could read the aircraft transmissions loud and clear.

During Initial Attack Rappel operations we experienced significant bleed over on our established Air to Ground frequency from the Umatilla NF who were also performing Initial Attack operations.  The interference was significant enough to affect on the ground operations for rappellers on scene.  The incident commander expressed concern to the John Day Dispatch center.  This Air to Ground frequency is shared with the Umatilla National Forest.  All Unit Fire and Aviation personnel including the Unit Aviation Officer have continually expressed a desire to have separate Air to Ground frequencies for these two units. Several years have passed without rectifying this critical hazardous issue.

Just as airtankers left the drop area, Leadplane spotted a single engine Cessna (unauthorized) enter the drop zone and circle 2X well within the TFR. Leadplane got the N # and made contact with the aircraft. Determined the next step for the aircraft. Notified Springerville Dispatch. The pilot refused to acknowledge the TFR when guestioned via the radio (victor) by the ATGS.
1833 hrs during run up pilot noticed that the right engine left magneto was not functioning. Taxied back to ramp and called RAMI to inform him.

At approximately 1700, flight crew for AA-OWF arrived at the ramp trainer needing lunch.  They had been airborne from approximately 1100 TO 1600.  They had not received lunch.  We had run out of meals due to unexpected aircraft and flight crews arriving on the base. I filled out an emergency meal order for two lunches from Wendy's to get them quick fresh meals.  The request was denied by the Asst. Dispatch Manager.  Five minutes later I received a call from the Air Center Manager wondering why I was ordering meals in the middle of the day.I explained that they had not received lunch and needed meals, as they were requested back over the fire at 1800 and dinner would not arrive until 1900.  I was told by the Air Center Manager inWhy can't they just eat some of the leftovers.  We have plenty of food in the fridgein.  These leftovers consisted of night before's dinner, day before's lunch, etc., from previous meal orders.  The pilots had just come off a five hour flight and were preparing for their next mission.

NXXX flew through the cooney ridge complex TFR at 1620on 08/20/03. The Bell was flying north just east of the helibase. Helibase attempted contact on the fires air to air frequencies. Air attack was notified of the intrusion. Two light aircraft involved in an ariel ignition at the time of the intrusion were on the ground at the helibase.
Number Two Generator Malfunction

NXXXX with Manager onboard landed at the Pine Airport after returning from Boise, ID for fuel.  In flight I advised the two Helitack crew members at the Pine Airport that NXXXX would land and we would connect the bucket and longline with rotors turning.Upon landing myself and the crew members connected the bucket and performed the manual and electrical checks for the hook and the bucket successfully.  Pilot was given inthumbs-upin and marshalled off the pad.  At approx. 10'up the longline released from the hook with the electrical plug still connected.  The marshal gave the hold sign to the pilot which was not seen and radio contact was attempted but was unsuccessful as well.  At approx. 25' the electrical plug disconnected from the helicopter with the bucket still on the ground.  NXXXX landed and the electrical connections and the longline were inspected with no damage noted.The longline and bucket were reconnected to the helicopter.  Manual and electrical checks were completed successfully.  NXXXX departed for bucket mission without incident.After discussing the incident with the pilots and the crew it was determined that the crew member resetting the hook did not get it completely latched.

Commander NXXXXX was refueled at Bettles airport by the vendor.  I called in on frequency 122.77 the day before and asked the vendor if they had inJet Ain fuel and they replied that they did.  On 7/14/99 just shortly after 1700 hours, I landed the aircraft at Bettles to refuel.  The vendor's fuel truck drove from where it was refueling turbine helicopters, to my location on the west side of the runway.  The truck was marked inAviation Gas.in  The vendor owner physically fueled the Turbine Commander (262.5 gallons), which had placards at each fueling port labeled inFUEL JET A ONLYin in bold lettering.Upon take-off from Bettles, the right engine did not develop normal RPM (98% as opposed to 100%).  In cruise the engine parameters appeared normal, but I elected to remain at altitude and not descend to perform inshow-me'sin or leads to the Tankers we were working.  I called back to Bettles and asked the vendor what kind of fuel he pumped into my tanks and he responded with inJet B.inAfter returning to Ft. Wainwright the mechanic checked the engines for discrepancies and found none.  We added 2000# of Jet A to the remaining 400#  in the tanks and flew the aircraft.  The engines performed within normal parameters.

After a Ferry Flight lasting 30 minutes, and during post flight inspection performed by the mechanics, a blade delimitation {a bubble approximatly 8 inches long by 3 inches wide} was found at the underside and outer 1/4 of the right blade. The inspection revealed the delamination was due to what appeared to be a manufacture defect. The Pilot was consulted and reported no unusual or abnormal flight characteristics during the ferry flight. Mechanic informed the Helicopter Manager of the situation and made the aircraft unavailable.
Air line to torgue pressure transmitter loose and seeping oil.

While delivering a sling load consisting of a 132 gallon blivet tank and two boxes of MRE rations,(rations were packed in a 300lb.rated, white nylon colored intuna netin, NFES 0795)to the xxxxxxx Inc. the pilot glanced down at the external load to check its condition in flight and found the load to be flying satisfactorily. Approximately 10 to 15 seconds later he looked at the load again and noticed the two boxes of rations gone. Knowing the approximate airspeed and heading to the helispot, the location of the rations is believed to be approximately T25n, R11E, sec. 29, sw 1/4 which is a remote,unpopulated,unroaded area on National Forest lands. Upon inspecting the net, it appears the corners of the MRE boxes chaffed through several cords and allowed the boxes to fall through the hole. The age of this particular net is unknown but was still in it's orginal packing box and this was it's first use. At this point I will not use anymore of of these nets to fly cargo until it is determined what caused this particular net to fail. I will ship this net to MTDC for their evaluation.

When T-XX was returning off the Bruneau fire PIC reported a bird strike. Upon landing in TWF, crew chief conducted an inspection. Bird remains were found on the 2nd right pylon. Crew Chief pulled the panel to ensure no damage. COR notified and COR Contacted AMI. No damage was found during inspection. Maintenance inspector returned aircraft returned to service @ 1530

After returning from the XXXXXXX Fire, the pilot fueled the aircraft and then proceeded to taxi across the runway to the Tanker Base. During the taxi, the right engine stalled. A restart was attempted and failed. Subsequent inspection revealed that 2-3 wires were burned and arced inside the engine compartment apparently from exposure to extreme heat from the turbocharger. On 7/28/2004 The wires were replaced and re-routed away from the turbocharger to prevent additional occurences. A test flight was attempted but the right engine mag test failed. Subsequent tests revealed that some spark plugs were fouled/replaced and the test flight was accomplished. Upon return from the flight the pilot opened the cowls for an inspection and discovered hot air coming from the side of the turbocharger waste gate (possibly the original cause of the burned wires). The FS Mechanic Inspector was notified and recommended a closer look at the exhaust components. It was found that the crack in the right engine turbo waste gate was adjcent to an old weld repair. Further inspection from the FS Mechanic revealed no heat shields installed and several repairs were evident on the existing exhaust parts.

After start up of the helicopter for an air attack/HLCO mission, the helicopter initiated a communication check with the helibase. The pilot and A/A noticed that there were no communications and shut down the aircraft.

Around 1745 Helicopter was filling bucket at the dip-site with a power-fill bambi bucket, pilots noticed a flash of spark at the end of the long line. Pilots  continuing to attempt pumping water and noticed that it was no longer filling the bucket. Figured they shorted out the pump. They started to release the water in the bucket, and that worked fine. Pilots returned back to heli-base to further diagnose the problem. Landed with no further issues

Original Text:Tested Premo machine at helibase before loading in the helicopter. Everything ran fine. Landed at helispot and shut down. Took doors off helicopter and mounted Premo machine to the helicopter. Had the pilot turn on the battery to test machine for the go/no go checklist. Everything was operational. Turned off the machine, filled out the paperwork, and waited for the call from the DFMO to start aerial ignition. At 1335 the DFMO said he was ready for the helicopter. Flew to the burn, reconned, and made a plan for ignitions. Firing Boss gave me the go ahead to start firing. Turned on the Premo machine and it ran for a short period{2 seconds}. The drive line quit running so I notified the pilot then pulled out the knob and manually turned it figuring there was a jam. I dropped a couple of balls and let the knob pop back in. The machine still wouldn`t run so I checked the switches and pop out circut breakers. There was no lights on but the water pump would still work. Couldn`t find anything wrong with the machine. Decided to set down to look at the machine better. The pilot set down on the dam adjacent to the burn. Took top off the machine and couldn`t find anything wrong. Then I could tell the 5 amp fuse was blown. Had to go back to the helispot where the equipment was for the machine. Landed there and tried 2 fuses and blew both of them. Had the pilot shut down the helicopter to look more thoroughly at the machine. Took the top off the machine, unplugged the power supply wire and plugged it back in and put another fuse in the 5 amp. Had the pilot turn on the battery and instantly the connection on the back side of the switch panel went to smoking. Checked the wires and couldn`t find any bare spots where it could be grounding out. Decided to go back to Helibase to swap machines and work on the broken machine. Hooked drive motor up to inverter and instantly it blew the fuse in the inverter. Found corrosion around the connections on the back side of the switch panel box. Took the 3 prong connection{`IN` wire} loose from the switch panel box. Realized the prongs were burnt and the connector was cracked between 2 prongs.

I advised the Unit FMO (Montrose BLM) that aerial supervision resources for the incident (FS jurisdiction) should be requested in view of ongoing and anticipated tactical use of aviation resources (multiple airtanker missions, one helicopter and expected media interest).  At the time of this discussion, I was unaware of the status of any outstanding resource orders for either a lead plane or air attack.     While assigned to an adjacent unit (GJD), I completed a partial fuel cycle over the incident later that afternoon, but was dispatched to another incident for initial attack.  The status of aerial supervision assigned to this incident is unknown.The Unit FMO was engaged in extended aerial observation missions over the incident using a local vendor and a portable handheld radio.  The intent of this SAFECOM is to again point out a situation which has been documented over the last several years in Western Colorado/Eastern Utah regarding the short term unavailability of adequate resources and equipment to conduct aerial supervision over an incident.In some situations, fire managers are continuing to 'make do' with regard to the ability to provide aerial supervision in a timely manner.  This situation is incompatible with the interagency emphasis on addressing safety.

During an exotic tree removal flight, crewmembers left a small light weight herbicide basket unsecure in the rear cabin. During the drop off and pickup of personnel, the light weight empty basket flew out of the rear cabin. The basket exited the cabin without the pilot or front crewmember’s knowledge. When the aircraft landed to pick up the first crewmember, that crewmember asked if we knew the basket had come out. The pilot and the crewmember said no. The crewmember advised that the basket flew out without hitting the aircraft. The aircraft proceeded to pick up the other two crewmembers. Once the aircraft had landed, one crewmember asked where the basket was. Crewmember advised them that it flew out. The pilot flew a small circle to pick up the basket. Basket is used to secure 4 small herbicide bottles: this prevents the bottles from tipping over and leaking during transport. **Problem- basket was left empty in rear cabin: the front crew turned around to check if the seat belts where secure, but could not see the basket on the cabin floor.

Fire was located near the border between the Boise BLM and Twin Falls BLM districts. There was some confusion on whose ownership the fire fell under. The Idaho State Aviation Plan, along with the National Aviation Plan, states that when a dispatch center dispatches an aircraft within 5 miles of another boundary, the originating dispatch center notifies the adjoining dispatch center. This procedure was not followed on the Sandy Cove Fire. Two aircraft, a type III helicopter and an air attack plane, were sent over the boundary from Boise to Twin Falls District without a positive hand-off. South Central Idaho Interagency Dispatch Center was not aware that the aircraft had been sent until the following day.

TXX leaving loading pits,turned right for junction with Golf taxiway; jumpship was coming in to Forest Service ramp on Golf did not stop for T-XX.  T-XX had to stop and wait because jumpship got in  front of tanker.  Jumpship then turned right toward the Public Safety Building and began to do a U-turn.  Tower then informed the jumpship it could not turn there so the jumpship went all the way to Minuteman to turn around and wait for T-XX to taxi by.  The jumpship then came back to the Forest Service ramp.

While taking the first load of the day out of BAM, T-XX requested 3,000 gallons of retardant. 

As the loaders signaled that the load was nearly complete, approximately 10-20 gallons of mixed retardant overflowed from the top of the tank. 

A check of the load printout showed 2991 gallons loaded to the aircraft. Initially, T-XX reported that their computer showed 3026 gallons loaded. Shortly after, the pilot reported that they had corrected their computer and were showing 2997 gallons. 

After discussion with the retardant crew chief, base manager and T-XX pilot, T-XX declined to offload any retardant and the mission was continued as normal.

We lifted off the Helibase headed for a reported smoke.  When we got inthe air we smelled fuel in the cabin.  We returned back to the Summit, landed and checked for any leaks.  We didn't find any and lifted off the helibase.  When we lifted off, we could smell the fumes agin. the ship returned back to the base and shut down.  When the pilot was shutting the ship down he noticed the fuel pressure guage wasn't going down.  The pilot and mechanic checked out the system and called the maintenence at the home office.  They checked the system again and took the ship for a maintenance test flight.  The system was working correctly and the smell of fumes were found to be from a saw bag in the cargo hold.

Craig Dispatch Center (CRC) was asked to flight follow with J-13 as it waspassing through to Casper,WY.  The first contact CRC had with the aircraft was at 1540 via the Juniper Flight Follow.  Fifteen minutes later we were still able to contact them on the Juniper repeater.  However, as they traveled Northeast and away from the Juniper repeater, we were unable tocontact them on the Mt Werner flight follow, as it was not functioning.  Icalled Rawlins Dispatch Center (RWC) to see if they had contact with the jumpship. RWC's flight follow was also down. The jumpship was out of contact for 27 minutes, since their last check in, before Casper Dispatch Center was able to pick them up. This communication problem was not due to the aircraft, rather the repeaters used for 168.650 were inoperable.
Helicopter door assembly, nose.  Open while in flight.  Aircraft landedwith out incident.

Load calculation performed by relief pilot did not match the load calc posted by the previous pilot{same altitude and and temperature}. Manager and relief pilot reviewed the charts and concurred that the relief pilot calculations were correct. The relief pilot discussed performance charts with the previous pilot and determined that new load calc. was correct. The regional helicopter program manager also confirmed that the relief pilot was using the proper load calc.

Right brake failed after landing. I informed the tower of limited braking, but shouldn't be a problem for stopping because I had reverse. The tower asked if I would be able to clear the runway. I told the tower I wouid try and clear at taxiway C . Using my left brake and reverse in combination, I was able to clear runway 10L. I asked the tower to send a ground man to push on my left wing (because no right brake) and I was able to taxi the short distance to the FBO. Just a quick note: once you release the tail wheel lock pin the only way you can steer is with brakes. I then called the tanker base on ramp frequency and gave my stop time. I was able to get the (on call) mechanic to look at the brake, and he determined that the brake was leaking only under pressure. I then called the Billings tanker base by phone and went out of service.

During PSD operations, a couple of issues arose will on an Rx Burn on the Angelina N.F. The first issue was during a 2 hour fuel cycle of firing operations. The PLDO had to be prompted by both the pilot and the Ignitions specialist to verify that he had complied with the orders of the ignitions specialist, such as, “ready to start: start firing # chutes and speed: and to stop firing. The PLDO had to be prompted to reply back the orders given so the ignition specialist knew when the machine was firing and when it was cleared. Also sometime during this same flight the PLDO vomited into the hopper of the psd machine and did not tell anyone. The pilot had viewed thru his cargo mirror that something else was coming out of the chute of the psd machine, but didn’t know what it was. He asked the PLDO, ''What is going on with the (psd) machine?'' The PLDO didn’t respond. The pilot repeated the question, the PLDO this time didn’t respond with a realistic answer. When asked again, the PLDO then said he was “putting some water thru the machine”. The machine appeared to be working properly as the pilot could still see the spheres dropping and he decided they could finish ignitions. The PLDO didn’t inform anyone of the situation until they had landed back at the helispot. The pilot later informed me (HELM), that for a second that he thought it might have been smoke or something coming out of the chute, but with nothing being reported by the PLDO of a malfunction or jam he continued with operations. My concern is that no matter what the situation is or how embarrassing it may be, the pilot and aircrew need to be informed. The pilot has many responsibilities and needs to be paying attention to flying the helicopter. If the pilots'' attention is directed at something else rather than flying the aircraft, something is wrong. Here the pilot is trying to decipher confusing information that should have been clear and concise, which took away from the pilot’s concentration of flying that aircraft in a flight profile that is low and slow, even if it only was for a few moments. Finally, if the PLDO is getting sick than they are not functioning at 100%. If their attention isn’t on the psd machine and the firing operations. There is a chance that something could go wrong and not know it because they are concentrating more on not getting sick than doing their job.

Work on a progressive B2 schedual was finished up in the morning @ hobbs 7.6 at 1730 hrs.  While the pilot was landed for fuel and ready to shutdown, the #2 enging chip light went on.  The pilot shut down.  hobbs 12.5

While NXXXXX was doing water drops, the ship experienced a compressor stall.  The pilot jettisoned the external load, then did a precautionary landing near the fire line.  Pilot inspected the ship and then flew back to helibase without further incidents.  Mechanic determined that compressor needed cleaning.  Mechanic performed a compressor wash, checked inlet guide vanes and bleed air actuator.  This was followed by an operational flight which showed satisfactory results.  Ship was returned to available status per Rick Watkins.  Mechanic also cleaned partical screens.

Redmond SEAT departed for incident {#} 215 at approximately 1900 hours. The wind had recently shifted from the south to directly out of the west at 35 mph. The pilot opted to depart loaded on north-south runway {17} which was slightly uphill and directly crosswind at the time. The Base Manager observed the aircraft use almost all available runway and slowly climb above raising terrain.

The incident occurred on the Hastings Fire at the Moose helibase outside Fairbanks, AK. The location of the incident was Pad 5 which had been used by the aircraft in previous days. The aircraft had one Bambi bucket, one 150’ synthetic long line and one 100’ steel cable long line with remote hook staged at the pad. The aircraft flew into the helibase from Ft. Wainwright on the morning of June 5, 2011 and landed at its assigned Pad 5. Upon arrival on the fire, the aircraft landed at its pad and was shut down to await an assignment. The helicopter manager  and helitack came over to the aircraft to brief the pilot and orient the helitack crew member on the aircraft configuration. The steel cable long line was where it had been left the day before with the end of the cable/pig tail laying next to the pad marker. While looking at the long line, it was noticed that there were fresh {wet and muddy} tire tracks across the end on the long line, pig tail and a portion of the cable ~8’ from the end. The end electrical connection had mud in it, the eye was bent and the end of the cable/splice was opened. The long line was not damaged when the crew left the pad on June 4, 2011 and the pad was not occupied by helitack until the aircraft arrived in the morning. At the time the aircraft arrived, no water tenders were at the Pad 5 end of the helibase. The helibase Deck, helicopter manager , Pilot, helitack and Safety Officer  indicated that from an inspection of the scene that it appeared that a water tender had caused the incident.

On May 23, 2011 while performing ATGS mission on the Horseshoe 2 fire right engine indications made it necessary to divert from mission and return to Bisbee Douglas Airport. At the time of decision, aircraft was maintaining 10,500 ft msl over the fire. First indication of possible problem was a reduced fuel flow indication. All other indications were normal and well matched with left engine. During decent to KDUG oil pressure indication decreased to low normal range. Approximately 5 miles from airport right engine failed. Engine was secured through emergency procedures, followed up with checklist. Normal landing was performed on runway 17 Bisbee Douglas airport. subsequent inspection found engine driven fuel pump shaft spined sheered. Fuel pump was replaced and aircraft was flown to Safford, Az. for further maintenance evaluation and returned to service

The helicopter departed helibase on a mapping mission of the fire. Communication with air attack was established on the victor frequency and the plan for the mission was stated and acknowledged. Approximatly 5 minutes into the recon we were flying a ridge along the fire''s north flank when the pilot spotted a lead plane flying an opposite course in close proximity. Both aircraft altered course immediatly to allow safe passage. The helicopter contacted air attack and was informed at that time that retardant operations were beginning on the flank, and that air attack had not expected the recon to have progressed into the area that quickly. The helicopter finished mapping the opposite flank of the fire and remained well clear of the retardant operations.

While doing bucket operations on the South Fork fire the second in command pilot noticed that the aft LCT was not functioning properly. The ship ceased bucket operations and returned to the Mariposa airport, at approximately 1800. This is the fourth time that the aft LCT has failed on this aircraft since the 13th of July 2017. Talking with region 5 maintenance inspector and the aircraft COR it was determined that a SAFECOM should be filed to inform other Boeing CH47D users of this potential problem. Three of the four failed LCT have been from the same repair station.
During Cargo letdown operations, I was not connected to the safetytether.  External sling load attached and rappellers not completely configured forrappel operations.

While lifting off from an improved helispot on the Mescalero Reservation, a helitack member noticed influidin leaking from the helicopter and notified the pilot.  Upon returning to Apache Summit, the mechanic looked at the ship, and declared the helicopter ingroundedin as it had a fuel line leak.  The mechanic suspects a inhairlinein crack in the weld near the coupling on the fuel line.

Takeoff aborted prior to V1 due to illumination of a master caution and door unsafe warning lights. After exiting the runway and stopping the aircraft, the warning system protected doors were cycled one at a time until the warning was extinguished. The forwrd left door proved to be the culprit. Proceeded with mission.

On September 22, 2020 Air Attack was operating over the Auld fire 2.5 to 3.0 miles north east of the French Valley Airport. We had been on scene for approximately 20 minutes and dropped one air tanker on the fire. After the first tanker dropped, we canceled the remainder of the aircraft response and remained on scene assisting ground units with access. While operating over the fire we had been communicating on French Valley Unicom (122.8) announcing to all aircraft our location in both reference to the airport, as well as the local ground reference (Lake Skinner Dam), as well as altitude.  There were approximately seven to ten aircraft that had either entered, or exited the pattern during this time. All aircraft except for this Bonanza stayed clear of the working area and created no issues. We observed the Bonanza in question passed over the fire and 500’ underneath us. As he approached us we called him by N-number, which we obtained via ADS-B. Bonanza did not use his N-number when making calls on Unicom, his communication was incoherent at times, he had difficulty entering the pattern and maintaining spacing with other aircraft in the pattern.  His response was that he saw us and that he was not a factor. If we had other aircraft on scene with us he would have flown through their operational altitude with no regard or understating of what was taking place. By monitoring the Unicom and with the situational awareness gained by watching ADS-B we could maintain separation.

Prescribed Burning on the National Forest with other agency Exclusive Use Helicopter. The pilot informed us that he had an Engine Chip light and we returned to the Helispot. Pilot pulled the plug and found small sliver. Plug was cleaned: maintenance inspector was called and advised of situation. Run up was done and everything was in order. On next flight approximately 28 minutes into flight we had a second Engine Chip light and we again returned to the Helispot. Same procedures were followed: helicopter was released back to other agency and encountered no further problems.

Aerial Ignition (Helitorch) After Action ReviewCrazy Horse Fire – MT-FNF-0092 - September 03, 2003 On August 30 & 31, Chrisman’s IMT prepared a tactical assessment of Hemlock Creek drainage and confinement options for the Crazy Horse Fire.  The selected alternative set trigger points to implement an aerial ignition (helitorch) burn-out operation west of Hemlock Lake and at the head of Red Butte Creek (perhaps as soon as September 01).  This tactic was selected as a low risk, low cost means to secure the fire from burning across the ridge into the Crazy Horse or Elk Creek drainages by spotting or surface fire. Helitorch ignition was selected to ignite relatively sparse, heavy fuels when ignited.  The pre-determined trigger point necessitating a burn-out was reached August 31, when the fire passed west of Hemlock Lake. The following discusses the operational and safety components of the action, and captures the critical elements of the After Action Review held on September 2, 2003.PlanningCritical elements of the Aerial Ignition Plan included:·	Preposition resources to implement the aerial ignition plan (Complex Prescribed Fire Burn Boss (RXB1), helitorch, Type III helicopter and module).·	Preposition air resources to use water drops to control flare-ups or spots across the ridge (Type I and II helicopters).·	Discrete communications channel would be assigned to facilitate ‘Air to Ground’ (helitorch platform to helitorch base; Burn-boss air platform, helitorch base, and Division); and helitorch ‘Deck’. ·	The Plan was focused on establishing a fire perimeter in Hemlock drainage that could be held with subsequent helicopter water drops.  Firing was also planned in Red Butte drainage to strengthen the hand ignition done there on August 29 and 30.Implementation – Monday, September 1, 20030700 – Daily operations briefing at ICP, which included notification that the helitorch operation would be conducted this operational period.0715 - Daily operations briefing at helibase, which included notification that the helitorch operation would be conducted this operational period.0830 – Helitorch Manager and Prescribed Fire Burn Boss briefing at helibase to all aerial ignition personnel; assigned discrete radio frequency confirmed/cloned/operational.1015 – Helitorch Manager briefing with helitorch staff, helitorch pilot, IC, OSCs, and Safety Officer at Helitorch Base (DP 8).1145 – Helitorch Manager and Parking Tender brief helitorch pilot.1210 – Operations and Prescribed Fire Burn Boss flies with 16K pilot for orientation and recon of the ignition patterns and sequence of firing. 1225 – Commence burning operation in Hemlock Creek, Operations Colla and Burn Boss Orton in Helicopter NXXXX, Flathead National Forest Lama which is the observation platform.  Helicopter NXXXXX, a Bell 206-L3, is the helitorch platform.Outcomes1)	An Aerial Ignition Plan was prepared and approved by the Forest Aviation Officer. 2)	Operational and safety briefings were conducted by Prescribed Fire Burn Boss and the helibase manager and by Div Z supervisor at H5.3)	During the recon flight, the proposed burn areas in Division’s A and Z  weresurveyed for personnel that could be threatened by the operation. Line personnel were not a factor in Div A since it was unstaffed that day. The ignition sequence and pattern was determined jointly by the Prescribed Fire Burn Boss and OSC, and identified to the ignition pilot during the recon flight. 4)	Div Z was staffed on that day with instructions on the IAP of:  “7. Control Operations. Continue to secure and mop up ridgeline to DIV Y break.  Portions of the division may be ignited per the Aerial Ignition Plan.” And“8. Special Instructions.  “…Operations will coordinate burn out with FBAN and Safety. . . . Notify adjacent Divisions prior to initiating the burn out.”Fireline personnel that were observed from the air appeared to be clear of the ignition area.5)	Personnel assigned to the helitorch operation were verified by AOBD and a Safety Officer as certified for their role. The helicopter pilot and all operational personnel met agency certifications and approvals for their respective positions.6)	During helicopter operations, the pilot, helicopter manager and Prescribed Fire Burn Boss are responsible for following all operational and safety rules. Operational, alternate and emergency helispots were also identified prior to operation implementation.7)	Burn-out and operational objectives were accomplished successfully.  These actions will potentially secure the fire in both the Red Butte and Hemlock drainages that will facilitate containing the west flank of the fire.  Issuesa)	Daily helibase debriefing at 1930 on September 1 and the September 2 After Action Review revealed:·	An unexpected short-burst ignition or residual hanging gel from the helitorch occurred within  a reported 50 to 60 feet of some of the helitack crew in Division Zulu.  This was within their assigned work area.  ·	Conflicting crewmember statements indicate that others of the crew may have been outside their designated area at the time helitorch ignitions were preparing to commence.  L&C Hotshot Superintendent reported some helitack crewmembers well downslope of their designated area. Instructions in the IAP were: “7. Control Operations. Continue to secure and mop up ridgeline to DIV Y break.”  Personnel had been specifically told by DIV Z to mop up one chain (66 feet) from the ridgeline. ·	Ground Spot weather observations recorded winds at 30 mph for approximately 1 minute when helitorch operations were underway (30 mph winds pushes limits for a Type 3 helicopter such as the L3 Jet Ranger).  Further conversation later between the AOBD and the helitorch pilot indicated the pilot was comfortable with the helitorch weight and the occasional wind effects on the flight characteristics of this helicopter.  He stated: “I would not have hesitated in the least to shut down the operation if I had felt at any time that I was outside either my comfort level or the capabilities of the helicopter.”·	Communications from Operations in the Lama observation platform (NXXXX) to Division Zulu were initially garbled due to wind in the cockpit (the Lama was flying with its doors off).  Helitack crew stated they did not receive clear communications from Division Z that the firing operation was to commence in DIVS Zulu. The Lewis and Clark IHC crew who were assigned to Zulu stated they were well-advised.·	There was significant traffic on the discrete air to ground channel (9) such that the Helitack Crew Boss quit scanning air to ground to pick up the tactical and command traffic.   In the AAR, it was determined that the assigned Air-to-Air frequency 120.675 was not used between the OSC/Burn Boss in NXXXX and the helitorch pilot in NXXXXX.
