They instead used the discrete Air/Ground frequency of 165.825, contributing to the congestion on the discrete air-ground frequency.b)	At least one over-flight of personnel on the fireline with helitorch (unlit) during ignition period occurred. This may have been due to the pilot dealing with the wind along and just below the ridge while setting up to make a run into the canyon below.c)	Additional personnel working in the Division (five person Helitack Crew) were not identified or accounted for in the Incident Action Plan.  This crew was briefed at the Helibase, but did not attend the general briefing where it was clearly stated that burning would be implemented in both Hemlock and Red Butte drainages if conditions allowed.  These resources were known to and requested by the Division Supervisor and briefed with the other Crew at the Divisional briefing.  At this briefing they were informed of the probable burn out of Division Zulu.d)	Division informed personnel that the helitorch was incoming, but there were conflicting statements about when this notification occurred. All Division personnel were instructed by Division to be within one chain of the ridge at the Division briefing in the morning. Division believed all personnel were operating per instructions but did not specifically confirm that all personnel were clear of the ignition operation.e)	Prior to ignition in the second operational area, a dry run was conducted by the Burn Boss and OSC in the Lama and helitorch pilot and witnessed by Division personnel, although there are conflicting statements about whether all ground personnel (e.g., the 5-person helitack crew) witnessed the dry run before ignition.f)	Concerns for wind effects on helicopter flight were neither noted nor addressed during mid-ignition helitorch operations. (Further conversation between AOBD and the helitorch pilot indicated the pilot was comfortable with the capability of the Bell 206 LR3 to carry the helitorch weight and with the occasional wind effects on the flight characteristics of this helicopter.  g)	The pilot also indicated he had checked the helitorch over the hard black and that it worked “pretty darn good.”  The pilot further stated that he had checked the torch for residual gel prior to transiting from Div A to Div Z and that it was clean. He also stated that he did not knowingly test fire or otherwise activate the helitorch on his first approach into the head of Red Butte Creek near the helitack crew.  h)	Neither the  Helitack Crewmembers nor their supervisor in proximity to the short burst reported the incident to their crew boss until later in the afternoon, and the incident did not surface outside the crew until 1930 at the helibase debriefing.

On starting engines on Friday morning, the #2 engine started normally and #1 made a loud noise and rapid increase of RPM.  Pilot made two attempts with the same result.  Houston Helicopter mechanic summoned and he determined the govenor had failed.

At 1751, MDC called and told me T-xx was en route from WYS to the incident, but that the fire had cancelled them. They wanted HLN aircraft to call T-xx and have him go directly to MSO instead of to the incident. AFF showed T-xx just SW of HLN. I called him on National Flight Following - no response at 1752. Tried again, 1753 - no response. 1753 - AIR GUARD contact attempted. No response. 1754, Tried contact on National Flight Following and again on AIR GUARD - no response. Icon went red on Automated Flight Following (AFF) screen. 1757, tried AIR GUARD again. No response. Called the HLN Tower. They had not seen T-xx in the skies (HLN tower does not have radar). A leadplane tried to raise him on NFF and on 125.125 (receiving incident''s Air-Air). I told Leadplane that the last point I had him on AFF was at 1739 (note time there - it is now 1758 on the clock), and relayed the last known position check: lat/long, heading 337 degrees @ 247 mph. Had MDC on the phone (to check the status of T-xx as far as they knew). They reported T-xx was ''yellow'' on their screen - relayed to leadplane. Moments later, MDC reported he''d gone ''red'' on her screen too. Relayed to Leadplane. Moments later, the lead successfully established contact with the tanker, who reported he was almost to the fire. HDC dispatcher checked with our Forest Aviation Officer, the GACC a/c desk (NRCC), neighboring dispatch center involved (MDC), as well as my center manager (HDC). All suggested a Safecom be filed for a number of related reasons, all centering on the fact that Air Guard is to be monitored at all times in aircraft, even when said a/c are employing Automated Flight Following.

Arrived at lat/long on dispatch. Upon arrival to fire, noticed 1 large helicopter dropping on fire. After communication with air attack we were informed this was the wrong area. We were then advised to fly to a another fire approximately 8 miles away.

Upon departure from 6D9 to return to CAD (home airport) after Forest detection mission, pilot observed and reported to Forest dispatch a wildfire occurring south of Sand Lake.  The fire was approximately one acre in size, burning in grass and hardwood litter.  Ausable Task Force and Pine River engine were dispatched for suppression.  Due to the inoperable radio system in using command and repeater frequencies, Huron dispatch kept the patrol plane over site of fire and relayed and received through Huron detection frequency via the pilot all communication with ground resources.  Dispatcher also communicated via cell phone with L.E.O. 3520 with very poor cell reception.  Suppression mission was accomplished, but the safety/comfort communication zone was absent, causing concern and apprehension.On Monday, April 28th, the Huron National Forest's task forces (Mio and Huron Shores) responded to six fires (including one at 531 acres, one at 150 acres and one at 50 acres) with the same communication problems and again Huron dispatch had to rely on the patrol planes (2) for communication with ground forces.  There were also fires on April 25th, 27th, and 30th with the same communication problems.
Post flight check noticed number 2 flight hydraulic accumulator Gauge was not indicating correctly.Ship out of rotation for rest of day.
On the last load for the day, the starter on # 1 engine failed. T-XX taxied to the North ramp. inspected, the starter shaft sheared. R-4 Asst. Airworthiness Inspector contacted.

After loading airtanker for fire dispatch @1200, drop doors malfunctioned. 3000 gals of D-75F retardant was dropped on the ramp. Aircraft was removed from contract availability. Mechanic worked on doors and had them fixed at 1600. Call was placed to R-8 Mechanic Inspector XXXXX XXXXX. Ok was given to return to contract availability.

Helicopter had flown 3 cycles, for 5.3 hrs. and shut down for night at 1945. Menchanic upon doing cleanup/inspection of tail rotor found crack in one blade: notified manager at 2100 that aircraft would be out of service tomorrow morning for balancing, tracking and check ride prior to being available. HEB1 notified at 2100 of delay to use helicopter the next day. Mechanics replaced tail rotor blade. 09/02 0830: HMGB called AMI and informed of repair.

As fast moving inclement weather was approaching the helibase, the plan was to reposition aircraft to airport `B` close by. Two of the three helicopter support vehicles were staged at airport `A`, which was inaccessible because of bad weather. Aircraft were launched to avoid the storm. A 15 minute flight was estimated to airport `B`. Five minutes enroute, severe bad weather was reported at airport `B`. Aircraft were turned around back to helibase, leaving one of the three helicopters without enough fuel to make it back to its support vehicle without going below the thirty minute reserve. After about one hour a break in the weather opened, and all helicopters flew to airport `A`. The helicopter that was low on fuel borrowed some from a support vehicle at the helibase.

XXX ordered from the Silver City Dispatch Center an air attack and platform to go to the Cat and Head fires E. of Socorro. Air attack headed that way and prior to reaching the fire area, tried contacting the fire IC''s on the frequencies the Dispatch office gave them. No contact could be etablished. When the air attack could not reach the fire, they went to the Socorro Airport, landed and called dispatch for frequency varification.

Upon arriving at the Lenora Fire on 3/28/16 I was notified by the IC there was a helicopter performing seismic work two miles south of the incident. Our TCAS picked up the aircraft however, we could not make visual contact. We repeatedly called in the blind on several different freqs to make radio comm with the helo to no avail. I notified the IC of the safety concern I had with the helo being in the area since we had two SEATS inbound to work the fire. The IC provided two FM freqs he thought the helo may be operating on, but no commo was esrablished. After time passed 10-15 minutes the IC notified me that he had communications with another person that was in commo with the helo. I asked them to tell the helo pilot to come up on 122.850 {assigned to fire}. During this time we noticed the helo equipped with a bucket fully engaged in water drops on the right flank of the fire. During this time helicopter came on-line and we established positive commo. We were later notified he was providing protection to their companies seismic equipment. There were no issues between the SEAT operations and the helo working the fire since it was towards end of the day and the helo was on scene no more than :30 minutes. Two SEAT drops were completed while the helo was in the area and one after the helo left.

Upon taking off of an type II helicopter from Home heliport in route to an incident, a piece of asphalt from the helipad had melted to the left skid of the helicopter. The helicopter had trouble taking off initially but eventually broke free from the helipad, taking with it a large piece of asphalt. The parking tender tried to have the helicopter hold hover but was unsuccessful and the helicopter took off with the piece of asphalt attached to the skid. The parking tender tried contacting the helicopter by radio but was unsuccessful due to fire traffic.

Upon completion of fuel cycle performing water drops on the fire the aircraft returned to helibase and shut down. An after flight walk around and visual inspection by crew chief identified a hydraulic leak from the tail gear box servo. The crew chief informed the helicopter manager that the aircraft needed maintenance and would be out of service. The tail gear box was replaced. A post maintenance ground run and leak check identified no further issue. A maintenance test flight was performed and the aircraft was returned to service.

We had fiished dropping the last load of practice jumpers and there were 4 jumpers still in the air.  A small aircraft came into our operation airspace.  He never came close enough to pose a direct hazard to the jumpers but he should not have been anywhere near our operation.  /s/ Fred J. Hernandez

Forest Helicopter Manager took a trainee out to the helicopter to familiarize him with the equipment. The battery and radio equipment were turned on without the knowledge or permission of the pilot. When the pilot saw the strobe light on he went to the helicopter to find out what was going on. The personnel were informed that operation of any of the switches in the helicopter is not permitted without the pilot present.
Helicopter was dispatched for intial attack at 0928, at 0945 it was determined that the second engine would not start. Mission was aborted to determine mechanical issue.

Verbatim narrative from the reporting individual follows:***************************************************************************************************************** “At approximately 1400, the UH-60A was performing bucket work on the east flank of the West Mims fire. The aircraft moved interior for a bucket drop as a part of the directed mission from ATGS. There was no ground contact in the area. Heavy smoke required lowering the bucket equipped aircraft to locate the target. As the pilot turned the aircraft to sight the bucket {Bambi, 900 gallon power-fill, 150ft longline} in line with the target the bucket settled into the top of a tree. The pilot implemented immediate corrective action and was able to continue on and perform the bucket drop. Upon attempting to fill the next bucket it was discovered there was an issue with the bucket`s ability to hold water. The aircraft returned to Helibase to swap buckets and the pilot immediately reported the incident to the manager and trainee. The Helibase manager was further notified by the manager trainee and proper notifications within the aviation operations branch were made.”

3 rappelers were assigned to initial attack a new lightning fire on the Monture complex. Normal operations were conducted in preparation to deploying rappelers. After all pre-rappel checks were completed, A/C moved into chosen rappel site. IC for the incident was the first rappeler out. Exit was OPS NORMAL. As rappeler neared the ground I was expecting to see a complete stop before contact with ground. Rappeler failed to arrest descent and impacted the ground with more than desired (and trained) force. Rappeler gave OK signal and cleared rappel site with noticeable limp. Rest of deployment was uneventful. I contacted the IC via radio and no indication was made of any injury. When crew was demobed from incident the next day, crewman complained of a sore heel. Medical attention was provided and it was determined that the right heel was badly bruised. Rappel procedures were reviewed with the individual. At time of this submission employee was still on light duty. My personal feeling is the individual will get an eye exam before resuming any rappel activities, as I suspect a depth perception issue.

While flying the fire pilot and myself noticed a slight burnt wire smell which lasted for a couple seconds and noticed that the FM {{#}} 2 Technisonic radio had gone black. Radio was turned off and the remainder of low complexity mission was completed using FM{{#}}1 radio. After landing, dispatch, AOBD, COR, and aviation maintenance inspector were notified and aircraft was taken out of contract availability. New radio was sent UPS overnight, radios were changed out and aircraft placed back in service by maintenance inspector.
While performing bucket drops on the Balls Canyon Fire, a military C-130 was observed by ground personnel flying low level through the fire area. A TFR of 10,000 feet by 5 miles was in place.

On Saturday, 7-7-2012, an Air Attack platform arrived at the Navarre Fire at approximately 1330. We had been working this fire for two days utilizing the DNR Air-to-Ground frequency for communications during suppression activities. This air attack began using the frequency for his `In-Brief` to gather information for the fire, stating he did not have the tactical frequencies and interfered with our normal ground communications. CWICC was attempting to establish contact with him through Badger Repeater, which he did not have. The frequency was transmitted and he indicated he would program the radio. Later, when the air tankers arrived, he decided not to use their frequency but remain on the tactical DNR air-to-ground channel.
The aircraft was 30 minutes in to a cycle when the pilot observed the engine chip light had illuminated. The pilot notified air attack and returned to the heli-base.

ASM Bravo 3 was flying the Big Coulee Fire on 7/19/03. At 2120 hours, Bravo 3 requested enlargement of existing TFR from 5 nautical miles to 10 nautical miles based on fire perimeter exceeding original TFR boundary. Aircraft Dispatcher conferred with complex ASGS, the UAO and submitted new TFR request to Billings Dispatch Center via fax at 2230 hours. Subsequent fact finding revealed NRCC closed for the night at 2230 hours. NRCC did not confirm the new TFR with NOTAM until 7/20/03 at 1330 hours. Air operations over the fire commenced at 0900 hours on 7/20/03.

We departed helibase to go back to the airport for the evening, about a mile away when the transmission warning light came on.  The pilot immediately turned around and went back to helibase and landed.  Mechanic removed bottom sensor and cleaned and replaced it.On 03/07/02 pilot ran ship for 20 minutes, after shut down mechanic did a leak check system was working properly mechanic put ship back into service.John Nelson R-3 aviation maintenance inspector was notified he said, if no problem with the 20 minutes run up ship is good to go back in service.
Aircraft started it`s run up for a proficiency flight. Number 2 engine displayed a problem, pilot shut down and started trouble shooting the problem. Contacted RAMI.

While flying an air attack mission on the Complex, I was contacted on our assigned helicopter victor frequency by a helicopter that was not assigned to the incident.  They asked to do a recon flight of the southern area of the complex. The request was denied.  They then asked where they might be able to go on the fire that they ``would not be in the way``.  I denied entry and told them no unassigned resources were allowed in the TFR. At this point all communications stopped.

On 04/28/02 T-xxx arrived at the Pueblo Reload Base at 1808 for a reload to the Black Squirrel Fire.  After loading, No.2 engine indicated no oil pressure.  T-xxx could not respond to the fire.  H&P mechanic arrived that night and determined that the No.2 oil pump was not priming.
While departing helibase, radio suddenly failed to transmit. A/C returned to base

Tanker was dispatched to the fire. After Take-off, right main boost pump circuit breaker popped, eliminating fuel pressure delivered to to the right jet by that pump. Retardant load was jettisoned in predetermined jettison area.

At 1545 aircraft H-XXX was requested for a cycle of buckets on the Royal Gorge Fire, Division H, contact Pike IHC. On aircraft start-up checks, mechanic found crack on left hand side of diffuser. Mechanic notified pilot, shut down aircraft. On further inspection mechanic stated crack had developed through weld. Helibase Manager was contacted along with Contract Representative Officer {COR} and Region 2 Maintenance Officer. Aircraft was taken out of service and made unavailable till replacement engine could be installed.

On 5/15/2012 while conducting a helitorch burn, the mixing crew experienced a blown hose. The hose came apart at the Scovill fitting {as seen in Figure 1}. The crew was utilizing the mix transfer system, with a Briggs and Stratton 8hp ohv pump{Figure 2}. This pump while operating at the lowest idle setting has enough pressure to move gel from the mix transfer system through the pump to the discharge side of the pump. Other operations utilize a less powerful pump the Honda GX-160 5.5 hp {Figure 3} which does not move gel to the discharge side of the pump at a low idle. When the pump {Briggs and Stratton} was fired up with no gel being transferred to the helitorch, the pressure release valve never operated which then caused the hose to break away partially from the dry break within 3-5 seconds of starting the pump. Gel did not come in contact with any personnel, very minimal spillage, all PPE was in place and no injuries occurred.

A commercial Piper Navajo flew through the Hastings Fire TFR at 1247 on June 10th, 2011. They were at approximately 3000-3200 feet which is 3000 feet below the TFR ceiling. They did not attempt to make contact on the TFR Frequency.

While performing a routine maintenance inspection on the aircraft following a water dropping mission on the fire the mechanic discovered that the tail rotor box on the aircraft was cracked. The aircraft was made unavailable until a new tail rotor box could be installed.

T-XX first re-load took 2156 gallons of retardant until it was full.  On the 2nd re-load it took 1520 gallons of retardant and it was full. Retardant ran out of the fill plugs both times.   This was measured with a Micro Motion, which was calibrated on May 24, 1999 by F.S. employee.
On runup of engines prior to takeoff for Yance Fire experienced problem withprop on #2 engine.

Tanker-XXX departed the tanker base for the fire when we experienced on engine low oil press {{#}}3 master warning after takeoff. we had departed vfr flaps 30 toga max from rwy 14 with a right 270 overhead the field for an easterly departure. after completing the after-takeoff check list the warning light illuminated. standard calls and procedures were followed and the checklist drove a shut-down of the number three engine. the oil quantity was low and the pressure was last seen in the yellow arc. while the first officer {fo} handled the appropriate checklists the captain took over communication with atc and the tanker base. the automation was brought on to unload the fo until the checklists were completed. we established communication to tower and asked to remain in an orbit at 7,000ft in case there were any other issues that required an immediate landing. once checklists were completed we proceeded to the jettison area with flight following from ATC and safely jettisoned the full load of retardant. once returning to the tanker base a normal landing was conducted and we went out of service. while taxiing into the tanker base it was noticed that the aircraft had been leaking oil as we taxied out. several folks on the ground had noticed something leaking from the aircraft but thought it was potentially water from previously washing the plane earlier. we observed no indications in the aircraft of low oil until after takeoff.
07/18/02 1758 T-443 landed at Craig Airport and as aircraft taxied past me, I noticed the pilot was not wearing a helmet, but, rather, was wearing a headset.

On 8/7/2015 at approximately 17:40 a helicopter was working in Div A of the  Fire. The helicopter had already made a couple of drops for ground resources in the area. When returning from the dip site the pilot was asked to adjust the direction of the next drop on a south facing slope. One dry run was made and the pilot was told good location just slightly to the right for your live run. When maneuvering back around for the live run, contact was made with the adjacent north aspect. The bucket drops were being made in a steep box canyon. At that time of day, smoke and shadows where starting obscure vision to do to time of day. When contact was made a small amount of water came out of the bucket and the aircraft was able to continue on its line and made a successful drop. After the drop the helicopter returned to the Helibase for inspection and there was no damage to the aircraft or bucket or personnel near the drop area.

I was air attack Group Supervisor (AA6) flying over fire B441 talking to jump 17. We assigned them an altitude to come over the fire for a streamer pass while the air tanker was reloading. Jump17 finished his streamer run and started to climb without talking to us. We had jump 17 in sight at all times. Jay requested the pilot to notify air attack prior to changing elevations.

Working on the Long Mesa Fire in Mesa Verde NP, was approached by Type 3 Operations Section Chief, who wanted to talk to me about a previous flight he had taken two days before.  He stated that he didn't appreciate me asking him the nature of his flight when he arrived at the helibase, or if his passengers were necessary to the mission.  He stated that it was unprofessional and unwarranted.  He stated that he didn't know how much experience I had in fire or aviation, but that I should know enough to know that his position in itself is enough to validate any flight without question.  He stated that as inOperationsin, if he orders it, then it's necessary.  I replied that in the performance of my job, it is my duty to all passengers as well as the pilot to do a risk analysis of each mission, and part of that analysis is asking questions to ensure there is not a more appropriate ground alternative to the flight.  I stated that it's in our policy to ask inIs this flight necessary?in  inHave ground alternatives been considered?in  inAre all passengers necessary to the mission?in  I stated with this year's increased accident occurrence, I was even more scrutinizing of every mission to ensure a safe flight for everyone.  After hearing my reply, he stated again that as inOperationsin, if he orders a flight then it is necessary without question.  Conversation was terminated due to a fire dispatch.

On initial taxi, pilot noticed unusually high power settings(~15% to start moving), stopped, cycled the parking break a few times, noted normal taxi power settings and continued to the runway.  On the takeoff roll, pilot noted 10 kts below the local S-2 minimum acceleration check speed but elected to continue the takeoff.  At rotation and during the initial portion of the upwind leg, the pilot faintly smelled hot brakes then at ~500 feet lowered the gear to cool the brakes and prevent the possibility for a nacelle fire.  The pilot then cleaned up and jettisoned the retardant load at the nearest jettison area, declared an emergency with NORCAL In order to have crash response available at at KMCC and proceeds to KMCC in a dirty configuration to increase fuel burn and land light.  Pilot touched down as slow as possible.  Rollout and taxi to AMU were uneventful.  Pilot terminated emergency response with ARFF 1 while rolling out.

At approximately 2030 hrs on 6/23/08,during initial attack of the Piedra fire {CO-SUA}, one of the six smokejumpers being delivered to the fire was severely injured. Initial reports were a fractured femur with possible tissue/artery damage. Smokejumpers on scene were rendering medical aid and requested a medevac. At this same time, NPS exclusive use helicopter and module {NXXX} were departing this same fire for base and responded to the jump spot. Local EMS helicopter ordered at same time. Once over the jump spot, it was determined by the pilot and helicopter manager that the site was a no-go for the inbound EMS helicopter {Agusta A119}. This was due to the small size and slope of the potential helispot. After weighing the options, NXXX and crew landed and configured aircraft with litter kit. Helicopter then returned to jump spot with HMGB and HECM {both EMTB} to attempt a landing and patient retrieval. Once over the site, the pilot and manager evaluated the situation and due to the significant risk to the patients life, time of day and no ground options for evacuation, it was decided to attempt a landing in this marginal site. The pilot was able to maneuver the aircraft onto the one possible landing site, however the slope exceeded the limit for the NXXX. The pilot brought the aircraft onto the spot, but needed to maintain full power with the back half of the skids off of the ground during the loading of the injured firefighter. Once on the ground, the HMGB and HECM exited, briefed the 5 other jumpers on scene about the loading process and the patient was loaded on aircraft. Helitack crew boarded and the aircraft departed the spot at approximately 2050 hrs. Patient flown directly to Mercy Medical Center in Durango, arrival 2100 hrs. Patient and helitack crew offloaded and NXXX departed for airport, arriving at approximately 2110. As the Helicopter Manager, I feel that the pilot did an exceptional job during this emergency situation. He was able to skillfully pilot the aircraft into a very difficult spot, during low light conditions and successfully retrieve the injured before dark. This injured smokejumper was delivered to the hospital less than one hour after his injury. There were several deviations from policy and SOPs during this operation due to the emergency situation. These were all discussed between pilot and Helicopter Mgr. prior to completing the medevac. These include: - Landing was close to a toe-in situation and required full power to maintain aircraft position during extrication. - Patient transported without full PPE due to injuries. - Aircraft landed at airport past day VFR time. {21:12 vs. 21:06}

Aircraft was observed flying from the Northwest, divert directly over the fireon one wing and depart the area to the southeast. Altitude was approximately 1000' AGL or 6000' MSL. Air tankers were working on the fire. The Roosevelt A & B MOA curently extends from 11,000' MSL to Fl 180.Aircraft obviously deviated from original flight route to investigate the fire (against AP-1B instructions).Aircraft was obviously well below the floor of the MOA.

While conducting a Maint test flight after an air-conditioning repair BXX Crew heard Firegaurd 1 directing Firegaurd 3 on 122.925 over a fire on the XXXX NF.  They were giving altitude separations instructed to take a lap around the fire and they would get them lined out after.  The only qualified Aerial Supervision platform in the state was mine.  The ATS on board contacted Firegaurd X on the air to air to see what they had going and if they needed assistance.  he stated we had a 30-50 acre fire on the forest and we were told our assistance wasn’t needed.  Before landing we heard a third aircraft over the incident.  The third aircraft cannot be seen on AFF because it was a state resource and they are not part of our AFF system.  Upon landing I called and left a message for the RAO, ZAO and spoke with XXXX at XXXX dispatch, XXXX at XX Dispatch and XXXX at GACC and informed all of the situation.  XXXX at XX Dispatch confirmed the third state fixed wing aircraft over the incident.  I include the following for reference from the Red book.  Chapter 16 page 330 2017 version.  26 The response speed of aerial supervision resources contributes greatly to 27 established aggressive initial attack doctrine and should be utilized accordingly.  28 Aerial supervision resources will be dispatched when available to 29 initial/extended attack incidents in order to enhance safety, effectiveness, and 30 efficiency of aerial/ground operations.  31 When aerial supervision resources are collocated with airtankers, they will be 32 launched together to maximize the safety, effectiveness, and efficiency of 33 incident operations unless aerial supervision is currently over the incident.  Additionally, in the fuel types of XXXX with limited elevation on the ground it is impossible in most situations to gain a vantage point which to serve as an adequate lookout.  This eliminates the ability to maintain LCES.  An aerial supervision module platform is staffed with a qualified lead plane pilot and an Air Tactical Group Supervisor, who is also minimally qualified as a Division Group Supervisor and IC Type 3.  This individual is well qualified to serve as a lookout, as well as function in the aerial supervision role.
On 8/2/07 upon returning to Moses Lake from Incident 408 pilot advised that he had shut down #2 engine as a precaution.  The aircraft landed without incident and pulled into Pad 3.

Cyclic mounted push to talk switch became inoperative during water bucket operations. The aircraft was returned to helibase and placed unavailable. The switch was replaced,tested and the aircraft returned to service the following day.

Air Tanker pilot did not communicate his/her arriving at the fire to Eugene Dispatch (OREIC).The incident commander of the Minute Fire on the Willamette NF, Middle Fork Ranger District on August 13,2001 at 0911 order redardent through OREIC.The order was placed for a lead plane and air tanker through Central Oregon Communication (ORCOC).T-67 out of Redmond Tanker Base was assigned. Since a lead plane was not available and no air attack was assigned to the fire T-67 would be working in initial attack mode. The last communication with T-67 was at 15 minutes out at 0944. That communication was relayed to the incident commander by the dispatcher.At 1005 the incident commander contacted OREIC that T-67 arrived and was completing drops, and IC would advise when completed.The dispatcher at OREIC was not aware that T-67 was at and already working the fire.At 1029 IC indicate T-67 had completed mission and was being released.OREIC main concern is for aviation safety and to make any last minute deconflictions, and address any additional hazards that may have come up since the last checkin by the air tanker, since there was no lead plane or air attack to do so.

On 7/22 while doing a water dropping mission on the Poe Cabin Fire, aircraft experienced a mechanical problem with the ag air simplex system. Jeff Holwick, region 1 maintenance inspector was notified of the problem and that the a/c had been in region 5 with the same issue and that region 5 maintenance inspector had been notified previously.

IHC Superintendent observed a drone in the vicinity of Division Zulu. IHC Supt relayed the info to Air Attack who subsequently communicated to working helicopters to return to Base. Air attack ceased operations and communicated to operations and incident communications the event and returned to Base. Information was relayed to AOBD, and Law enforcement. As of this safecom the operator has not been located.

On my flight from Redmond to Missoula I continuously heard regular business, ground asset dispatching, equipment ordering, and just general chit-chat being done on the National Flight Following Frequency (Come to think of it the frequency could have been the Guard Frequency ).  This use of one or the other frequency is not authorized and did not cease until I was well into Idaho.

Original Text:Pilot''s narrative: Long Line - removal of smoke jumpers gear. Clear skies - wind NNE 5-10 Slung empty cargo nets to jump site. Set nets on ground - pressed hook release and long line released from ship. No one under ship. No damage. Found that mechanical release had reset only half way. Pushed lever back to original position - picked up long line and continued mission. No other problems encountered. Smokejumper''s narrative: Helicopter 185 was delivering cargo nets to the jump site with the long line. The pilot placed the nets on the ground and attempted to release them from the long line. Instead of releasing the nets the long line was released. The pilot asked if I could do a hover hookup to re-attach the long line. The pilot came down into a hover and I walked under and attached the long line to the belly hook, leaving the electrical connection undone. The pilot lifted up and flew back to the helibase.

After run up of the helicopter pilot noticed that the rotor brake light remained on . Shut down aircraft to inspect rotor brake.It was found that rotor pad was in contact with rotor disk all the time. Ship was grounded by pilot until mechanic could inspect rotor brake.

On 7/13 Air Attact (AA) was ordered for a multiple lighting event on the MT Hough District of the Plumas National Forest.  AA- was ordered with one air tanker for the Chance incident.  After AA- ETA to the Chance Incident had passed, Plumas ECC requested me Battalion 21 to attempt contact with AA. I tried repeatedly to contact AA  on our designated command and air to ground frequency. No contact was made.  AA  (now apparently over our forest) contacted recon 40 and ordered 4 heavy airtankers and 2 more helicopters.  Recon 40 relayed this info to the Plumas ECC.  These resources where not requested by myself or Plumas ECC.  Again Myself and Plumas tried repeatedly to contact AA-.  I contacted Jumper 52 (Jumper 52 was over the Chance Incident) I asked them to make contact with AA-and get him to contact me on our command frequency.  Jumper 52 called me back and said that he had contacted AA- and relayed my request. Still no contact from AA-.  Finally I contacted AA- on Air-to-Ground and told him to come up on our command frequency and contact Plumas ECC concerning resource orders and stay in contact with me on our command frequency for setting resource use priorities.  AA- had to ask what our command frequency was. I gave him the frequency.  Approximately 15 minutes later I called AA- on our command frequency, still no contact.  I tried again and made contact on Air to Ground.  AA- told me he could not contact Plumas ECC on our command net.  I told him to at least stay on Air To Ground to maintain some communication.  Shortly after that I contacted AA- to send one airtanker to the Sage Incident.  He said he would send an airtanker to that fire but I would have to direct the airtanker to the incident. I told him I don't have the time to do that, it's your job to handle it.  AA-did send lead 71 and one airtanker to the Sage Incident, however he told Lead 71 to stay on our command net to direct the airtanker.  This caused increase and un-needed radio traffic.  I tried repeatedly to contact AA- and lead 71, in attempt to get lead off the command net, I was unsuccessful.  Soon after that AA- called me and said he could not contact Plumas ECC and that he had returned the airtankers to their bases (load & hold).  I contacted Plumas ECC and relayed that information.  Soon after that Plumas ECC released AA-.

While over the Horseshoe II Fire, the smell of something burning filled the cockpit. No smoke was seen, no hotspots were identified. Radio calls were made and nonessentinal electrical equipment was turned off. We left the fire and went to Douglas Bisbee airport. A call was given to R-3 Aviation Maintenance Inspector
Helicopter NXX, after bringing first load to H-3 returned to helibase for second longline mission. While hovering over cargo area, pilot accidentally released the longline from the belly hook.

Helicopter was performing Longline operations under an approved plan for no swivel. On the 50th load of the day, when the pilot released the gate of the remote, the static line and nap strings were twisted around each other and the net could not open. The Longline was also twisted, having coiled above the remote. The Longline was put out of service with damage being two kinks. All previous loads were configured the sam and flew without incident. A gust of wind is the suspected cause for getting the load spinning.

during flight pilot notified hmgb that “restart fault” light came on.  pilot and hmgb discussed and agreed the light was not a safety of flight issue and continued on mission with the understanding the aircraft needed to return to the airport for shut-down at end of fuel cycle.  after cycle of bucket support pilot and hmgb returned to KXXX.  hmgb notified Regional ami.  pilot and company apprentice mechanic contacted director of maintenance of vendor and troubleshot issue by going through maintenance terminal lights.  no fault lights present.  vendor opted to do 0.5 hr maintenance flight. still no fault lights present.  following day aircraft was requested to fly to KYYY, land and shut down, and be on station to support a burnout operation with bucket support if needed.  while doing bucket work restart fault light returned.  pilot notified hmgb and returned to KXXX and shut down.  hmgb notified dispatch aircraft would be unavailable until further notice.  hmgb notified Regional ami and discussed.  pilot and apprentice mechanic cleaned cannon plugs and troubleshot maintenance terminal light system checking for issues.  no fault lights present.  vendor requested to do 0.5 hr maintenance flight to see if light would return.  no light present during or after maintenance flight.  returned to contract availability per Regional ami.  aircraft flew to KYYY picked up 2 pax for recon, on return flight to KXXX light returned.  once on ground at KXXX pilot, Regional ami, and company director of maintenance agreed aircraft would be unavailable until issue resolved.

Upon entering aircraft, manager placed an tablet on the dashboard while fastening seatbelt. During startup, ground resonance caused the tablet to slide off the dashboard and subsequently fall onto the left chin bubble, cracking the glass.

After taking off from Krassel HB, I noticed that the collective friction was too lightly adjusted. Enroute to H2 at approximately 8,500` I thought I was adjusting the collective friction when the yellow twist grip and governor caution light came on. I lowered the collective and realized shortly thereafter that I was adjusting the throttle friction and not the collective friction. My hand accidentally rolled the throttle down causing the caution lights to come on. I rolled the throttle back up, caution lights went out and controlled the mission. On landing back at Krassel I reported problem to manager and mechanic. Mechanic confirmed problem of adjusting wrong friction on collective.
During start-up the TOT start limitation of 850 c was exceeded for over 10 seconds, TOT light illuminated.

The helicopter tanker was ordered for water drops on the Gnarl Ridge Fire. On their first dip from Badger Lake the Snorkel V Band and snorkel separated from the Fire king tank assembly. The tanker contacted Air Attack with their trouble and returned to helibase with the snorkel attached under the ship by the hydraulic lines. A phone call was made to the R6 Maintenance Inspector who requested their maintenance logs be faxed and a Safecom written.

T-99 requested to reload at Lake City.  After landing at LCQ at 1953 EDT the right main tire was flat.  In looking at the runway at Lake City, it was suspected that the tire was flat prior to the landing.  A puncture was found in the face of the tire.  The pilot and co-pilot believe the tire was punctured during take-off in TLH.  Tallahassee was contacted to check the taxiway and runway for debri that may have punctured the tire.  The pilot was able to taxi off main runway without damage to the aircraft or runway.

At the end of the operational period the helicopter was secured in a private field. The local LEO was parked next to the helicopter. The Bambi Bucket was laying approximately 25'' in front the helicopter. Sometime around 0030 the Bambi Bucket was ran over by a dozer, tracking across the field to his transport. The Bambi Bucket was damaged beyond repair.

Upon being released from a fire, helicopter came into Alturas for fuel. Helicopter manager noticed hydroloc fluid on the right side of the ship. Mechanic inspected aircraft and determined that it could not be fixed this evening and ship must stay overnight. Helicopter Manager is hopeful that the helicopter will be repaired in the morning.

On Monday, August 26, 2002 I was ATGS on 58CK, a twin engine Beech Baron, with pilot XXXX XXXXXX. We departed Pueblo at 13:21. We were doing a routine reconisance flight for fire detection when the right engine was shut down. We had been flying for approximately one hour. The pilot told me the right engine was shut down and we were going to have to make an emergency landing. The plane started loosing altitude. I notified dispatch of our situation. I gave them our position. The pilot said he was going to land on the highway (hw 285 south of Fairplay, CO). Then he said we were not going to make the highway because we were losing altitude too fast. The pilot then said that we were holding altitude at 11,000 feet. There was too much traffic on the highway to land. We were both looking for a road to land on. Just east of 285 was a dirt road running east/west. XXXX said it looked pretty good to him. We made a low pass over the road to look for any problems. It looked doable so XXXX came around to set up on final to land. I called dispatch to let them know our position and that we were landing on the dirt road. XXXX XXXXXX did an outstanding job of landing on the dirt road in an emergency situation in a calm, cool, and professional manner. Once we landed I got out of the plane and called dispatch on my cell phone to let them know the landing had been successful. There were no injuries and no damage to the aircraft. The time when we landed was 14:42.

TXXX received a dispatch to the Clark Butte Fire (DNQ1) for 1 load of retardant for structure protection. The Aircraft Dispatch form was faxed to Burns SEAT base with Lat (43° 25”) x Long (117° 20”) with Air-Air frequency of 125.075 Tx/Rx, Air-Ground 166.675 Tx/Rx, flight following frequency of 166.375 Rx 166.975 Tx with a Tone 123.0, Ground contact of XXX. Pilot made initial contact with Vale Dispatch to start flight following and asked if there were any other aircraft on the incident. Dispatch replied that helicopter XXX was on the ground for fuel and no other aircraft were on the fire. Pilot made a blind call on air-air when 15 minutes out from original lat and long. The only response was from recon aircraft (XXX) saying that he saw no other aircraft and could not raise anyone on air-ground. TXXX arrived on original Lat and Long (there was no smoke visible) and notified dispatch and was given new Lat (43° 02.9”) and Long (117° 3”). TXXX talked to recon XXX on air-air and he gave the T491 Lat (43° 04”) and Long (117° 12”) for the fire. After arriving at the fire, he called on air-air and air-ground with no response. TXXX spotted an airborne helicopter and left the fire due to no response on air-air or air-ground. While leaving the fire to the West, TXXX called dispatch and told them that he could not get ahold of anyone on either FM or AM and was returning back to Burns. When TXXX was 15 miles from the fire Air Attack XX called on Air-Air and asked if he would return to the fire and that he was 6 minutes out. TXXX returned and held out of the FTA until Air Attack XX called him in. He made the retardant drop and returned back to Burns.

At 1627 Tanker 06 took off from the Greybull Tanker Base in route to the Blondie #2 fire.  At approximately 1630 Tanker 06 lost an engine and had to jettison his load.  The load was dropped over an area of scattered residences.  Three homes, a few horses and cars were hit with retardent.  No known damage to houses, cars or animals was reported.   The Greybull volunteer fire department responded to wash everything down to prevent staining to paint on houses and cars.  Tanker 121 was in route to the Greybull Tanker Base at the time of the incident.  Tanker 06 did and exceptional job of dealing with the emrgency.

On July 24, 2017 the flight crew of a Helicopter on an exclusive use USFS contract was working the Preacher fire near Minden, NV and heard radio chatter between Lead {Bravo} and Air Attack about the status of a crew lookout. After significant and sudden growth of the fire there was confusion about the lookouts location. Eventually aerial supervision got a hold of the lookout but they were still uncertain of his exact location. Two helicopters, a CH-47D and a K-Max were just off the drop heading back toward the dip site as Bravo requested one of the helicopters to help locate the firefighter {lookout} in trouble. The CH-47 having 3 crew members decided to take the mission and headed towards the south flank of the fire. The flight crew had just previously watched the fire make a one mile run in under 10 minutes and the fire behavior of the south flank was just as extreme and moving rapidly. Eventually the pilot got into contact with the lookout who said he lit two spot fires to help find him. He didn`t have a signal mirror because he ran from the fire and had to drop all his gear including his fire shelter. The third crew member looking out the back of the aircraft spotted the two small spot fires which grew rapidly in the high winds. Bravo above, watching the fire moving rapidly towards the firefighter {lookout} {it was about 400m from his location} asked the helicopter pilot and the firefighter {lookout} if they were both comfortable utilizing the 2000 gallon bucket as a rescue option and everybody agreed giving the current life threatening situation. The flight crew found two potential landing zones but the spot fires grew too rapidly turning them into unsafe options. Trying to exhaust all options before loading the firefighter {lookout} into the water bucket the crew then considered a two-track road in the immediate vicinity of the firefighter {lookout} and landed safely to load up the firefighter {lookout} internally. We then transported the individual back to the Minden airport where we met an ambulance. An After Action Review took place with the helicopter manager.

While on the fire around 1745, my pilot saw something out the left window of the plane. After a few seconds we made the decision that it was an unmanned aircraft. We watched it, and it seemed to be circling the fire area where we had finished the retardant line on the heel and left flank of the fire. Tankers were on a load and return. The Leadplane was low level, making runs and getting ready for the tankers to return. It seemed to me the way it was flying, that it was able to penetrate the winds which were quite strong coming from the south west. It seemed to be looking at where the retardant line was and looking at where the proposed hand line and hose lay may go.

A Hotshot Crew was requested to be flown into the Hunter Peak Fire to establish a spike camp. The crew wanted to be flown in first and their overnight gear, firing supplies and miscellaneous other equipment was to be slung in {external load} after the crew was on the hill. The crew was flown onto the hill without incident and the sling loads of gear were soon built. One load consisted of 19 overnight crew bags and 2 bundled briefcases, in a 12x12 cargo net with a tuna net of 2 additional helitack overnight bags attached to the same swivel. Another 12x12 net filled with hazmat was attached below the load of bags with a lead line and swivel. The entire load was inspected several times by helitack personnel and was deemed sound and ready to fly. The Bell 205 A1++picked up the load and everything looked good but as he began to increase his forward speed, the tuna net adjacent to the 12x12 cargo net began to spin. It was discussed between helitack personnel but was deemed not to be of much concern. The load was delivered but shortly thereafter, we began hearing reports of a bag falling from the net. Upon returning to their gear, The Hotshot Crew confirmed that a bag was indeed missing. The overnight bag was missing from the 12x12 cargo net.

Noticed substantial amount of oil on wheel of aircraft and on ground under right engine. ATGS expressed concern, called Regional Aviation Safety Inspector who recommended taking aircraft to local maintenance facility, or having chief mechanic from vendor take a look and try to determine source of oil leak. ATGS called local dispatch and made aircraft unavailable until problem was identified.
Upon shut down a warning light came on indicating a potential problem. After trouble shooting mechanic deemed the problem to be a defective potentiometer switch and connections.

We departed RWL en-route to a fire, and about 25 minutes in flight our pilot tried to turn on auto pilot when he noticed the DME circuit breaker was popped. He reset the circuit breaker, and noticed smoke coming from the DME. The circuit breaker popped again, so we returned to RWL, and landed without incident.

Tanker XXX was out of service for 1 hour due a problem with venting opening system. Had to re-drill a new hole to re-attach the vertical vent rod {pogo stick}. Called OAS inspectors when the SEAT was taken out of service, pilot and mechanic corrected the problem, faxed the work order to the inspector and the SEAT was returned to contract availability

As Helicopter NXXX was on approach to helibase from a recon mission, helicopter manager noticed the left rear door was open. Only one passenger had been loaded and that was in the front seat. The door had been checked by pilot and manager during preflight. Latch was shut, door looked closed. Unsure if door was actually not latched completely or if it came open during the rough flight.

Immediately following the controlled water release from the Bambi Bucket, the pilot experienced turbulent air and quickly grabbed onto the cyclic of the aircraft for control, inadvertently releasing the bucket and longline.

During a mission to backhaul cargo off of H-xx, the helitack on the helispot observed two military jets low in the canyon traveling west to east through the TFR, and over the spot. The helitack contacted the helibase and reported the intrusion. H-xxx was enroute to the helibase with an external load, so was not in the area at the time of the incident. There is a MTR in the area, so the Helibase Manager contacted the scheduler to report the intrusion. There were no flights scheduled for the route on that day. AOBD was advised.

While doing bucket work on the Rocky Point fire, the pilot stated that a chip light came on. Pilot returned back to the helibase, prior to landing chip light went off. Pilot removed both plugs and found a small piece of metal on one plug. Pilot cleaned both plugs and reinstalled them. Pilot did a 30 minute ground test, then removed the plugs again. Both plugs were clean and free of any debris. Regional maintenance inspector and COR were notified. Maintenance inspector talked with Pilot, and returned Helicopter back to contract availability.

I was contacted by staging that a plane was missing. She was called by RMACC, who was looking for A/C. EGBCC had no record of flight except for a DOT.MOB stating his A/C was delivering pax  for a fire assignment on the Davis Knoll Complex. The last RMACC heard from the A/C was when it left Craig, CO at 1800, and it’s ETA to SLC was 2045. I contacted the SLC ARTCC at 2141 and their records showed the A/C was on VFR flight plan but canceled it with DEN ARTCC at 1947. They had no record of A/C going to SLC. I told RMACC to contact vendor and check if they have had contact with pilot. Vendor said the A/C arrived, but it was unknown at which airport. I contacted the SLC ARTCC again and the A/C had made contact at 2049 concerning approach. The A/C landed, dropped off the pax and was clearing for take-off at 2205. The ARTC said this A/C never re-filed a flight plan from Craig to Salt Lake after canceling it’s VFR flight plan with DEN ARTCC. The aircraft flew with no flight following in place. There were many scattered thunderstorms across northern Utah during this flight.
After finishing Prescribe Burn and while landing at the Helibase and shutting down the Fadec Degrade Light came on.

J15 departed Missoula on 8/21/00 @ 1735 MDT with 10 jumpers, 2 spotters and 2 pilots on board for the Washout Point {#}4 Fire on the IPF.  The jump aircraft arrived over the fire @ 1837 MDT.  The jump spot was located about 400 yards down in a bowl with continuous timber cover around the spot with tree height between 80-120 feet, and a couple of trees in the spot.  The spot was approximately 1/2 acre in size.  The streamers showed about 150 yards of drift across the slope.  Single person sticks were utilized because of the small spot.  The first jumper made it into the spot ok.  The second jumper, made an appropriate approach and descent into the spot and brushed a tree.  His chute collapsed and he fell between 30 and 50 feet.Jumper immediately complained of lower back pain.  The rest of the load jumped to help with the injury and evac.  A helispot was selected on the ridge top and improved for the medical helicopter.  The copter arrived at about 2046 MDT and the injuried jumper arrived at the helispot at about 2115 MDT.  The copter landed at Kootenai Medical Center in Coeur d` Alene Idaho at 2155 MDT.Jumper substained a burst fracture of the Lumbar {#}1 vertebra and possible damage to the L-5 vertibra.  Surgery is scheduled for the L-1 vertibra.

After dropping retardant on the Poe Cabin Incident the pilot of T-XXX reported a chip light and power surge indicating that there may be a problem with the aircraft power plant.T-XXXwas also over the Poe Cabin Incident at the time. The pilot of T-XXX radioed the Incident heli-base to request a helicopter be put on standby if the situation warranted the need. T-XXX escorted T-XXX back to S80. T-XXX landed without incident. T-XXX was put out of service until the problem could be investigated. A Kudo for the pilot of T-XXX for notifying the Air Attack, Dispatch and heli-base to request a helicopter, with a chance that the situation at hand could go South at any time.

Went up to transition the North zone airattack at 1730, on the fire, and when into our shift the pilot noticed that there was a problem with the Oil gauge and said we needed to return to get it checked. He did a great job and very fast notice to the nature of the problem, the oil gauge went in to the red and stayed there for about a minute or so when enroute back. Then the gauge went back to normal, so it was better to be safe than sorrow. I contacted helibase to let them know that we had to go back. There was only 2 helicopters in the air so I told the not to put anymore up. They did a good job going by what need to be done .

On 8/11/96, T-00 was dispatched to a wildland fire on Roosevelt NF. Once T-00 was airborne, the pilot informed dispatch that he had filed an FAA flight plan. Dispatch informed T-00 that 15 minute check in were required on Colorado flight following frequency (168.650). T-00 reply was that he did not want to argue the situation over the radio and that it was either agency or FAA flight plan. Dispatch requested that T-00 flight follow with agency. T-00 had no response. T-00 did respond to dispatch first required check in call. Rocky Mountain Coordination Center was informed of the situation. T-00 did not respond to calls at his 2nd required check in.

Soon after take off from RNM the #1 engine began vibrating. The retardant load was jettisoned, the engine was shut down and we radioed back to base that we were having engine problems and were returning.

A FLIR flight had been scheduled @ 0800, operator arrived with a harness but no tether strap attached to the harness.  I allowed the flight to be flown, after the pilot, the flir operator, and myself agreed on procedure.  I used a 3,000 lb. lead line attached to the harness safety clasp and attached the other end, to the aircraft hard point.  I knew this was incorrect procedure, canceling the mission would have delayed the flight 24 hrs. and the team wanted to wrap things up asap.  Would suggest in the future that FLIR kits have an approved harness with the strap to prevent delays.

While flying Air Attack over the Fire, pilot noticed EGT increasing. Richer mixture lowered temp temporarily but then EGT continued to increase. Decision was made to return to airport, on way in EGT hit redline, then began to decrease. Aircraft grounded at ABQ until cause of problem could be determined.

With 728 gallons on board T-XXX departed to the XXX Fire, made two drops, then returned to the Tanker Base for load and return. Aircraft taxied to pit two. Pilot attempted to raise flaps, but could not. Requested to exit the pit to remedy the problem. Fixed the problem and re-entered pit two to reload for the fire at which time retardant exited through the vent on top of the hopper and also the overflow vents. Pilot activated the emergency drop and released approximately 700 gallons of retardant on the ramp. Ramp Manager requested aircraft to be moved to a different location to remedy problems. It was noted that pilot overloaded aircraft earlier that day with a 807 gallon load, of which 70 or more gallons of retardant had to be dropped on the ramp. Also noted that relief pilot had trouble with the flaps. Upon reviewing the circuit breaker was the cause of the malfunction with the flaps. Also after calculating retardant loads prior to the overfil it was determined the pilot returned and landed with a full load of retardant.

While flying recon on the Plumas NF I was about to call dispatch with adirection change when I noticed that radio #3 had gone off. I then triedto talk to the pilot and was unable to. I got his attention and then wenoticed that radio #2 had gone off. We then noticed the victor radio wasoff. We then started checking and found that the amp guage was showing adischarge. I called dispatch on my hand held radio and informed them thatwe lost the aircraft alternator and were in route to Quincy (Gansner)airport. The pilot turned off all other unnecessary electrical equipmentto save as much battery life as possibe. We were able to make a safe landing at Quincy airport even though we did not have any flaps.

On 5/25 aprrox. 1300 on the Bluff Fire B.D.F. I observed Helicopter 554fly over Helitanker 792. It looked like Helicopter 554 and Helitanker 792were going to collide, Helicopter 554 with the jettisonable bucket over flewHelitanker 792, from my vantage point it looked like the bucket of 554 over flew Helitanker 792 within 20 feet.
After preflight and engine start while taxing a bug entered the pilots pitot tube. Fluctuations were noticed during taxi checks. Aircraft was taxied back to parking and Maintenace was notified.

While performing a low level reconnasaince mission on the Rat Creek Fire Air Attack entered flight below 500'' AGL with no prior notification to aircraft operating in Division G. No communication was established between the fixed wing and any other rotary wing aircraft operating in the area. In order to avert a possible collision the helicopter was able to maneuver from its original flight path.
Aircraft had an ‘Engine’ chip light starting up at Spring Creek Helibase and immediately shut back down.

Shortly after taking off from the helibase to support an initial attack fire with bucket work, the aircraft had a chip light come on requiring a pre-cautionary off-site landing was made in a field about 10 nautical miles from the helibase near a highway.  The manager and the mechanic arrived shortly after.  The mechanic checked the chip light detector and found no debris and deemed that it was a faulty chip detector.  The regional maintenance inspector was contacted and the aircraft was returned to service after the mechanic replaced the chip light detector.

During a longline mission on the Thomas fire the longline sheath, that protects the synthetic rope and electric cord, slid 5ft down the line causing the power cord to disconnect underneath the belly cargo hook. Pilot was lifting the last load of external cargo backhaul with a 100ft longline. When he arrived at the backhaul drop off location he was unable to release the load off the external cargo hook. Helitack personal sent in a hitcher to manually release the cargo net. Helicopter landed to extract helitack and while stowing the longline helitack noticed the sheath slid down the line and the power cord was disconnected

During a routine preflight inspection in the morning 7/26, I noticed a divot in the left propeller. The divot was located on the leading edge, approximately 5 inches from the prop tip and was roughly the length of a penny in width and half a penny in depth. I grounded the aircraft until further notice and reported the discrepancy to my supervisor and the persons responsible for maintenance of the aircraft. I believe the damage was caused from a rock or bolt making contact with the prop during landing or taxi. A factor which likely contributed to the FOD damage was darkness, as I landed 20 minutes after sunset the previous night. Exacerbating the darkness factor are the lights in the Cedar City ATB light fixed wing parking area, which shine from the ground up, directly into the pilot````s eyes during taxi/parking operations. A parking tender was present, which helped. A factor which may have led to the FOD in the first place may have been the path used by vehicles between the main tanker base vehicle parking lot and the light fixed wing ramp. The path short cuts the paved route to the ramp via a loose gravel two track. See attached images for FOD damages and dirt path shortcut.

I responded to the Douglas fire via GOV. One load of smokejumpers had been dropped and a lead plane was working with a P-3. I tried several times to contact the lead using the designated air-ground frequency with no success. I contacted the jumpers on tac and learned they were using a different air-ground. I changed to that frequency and was able to contact the lead plane.

Helicopter NXXXXX showed up at Minden airport per instructions to meet up withhis Helicopter Mgr before going to the Genoa Fire which was only two miles away. No Manager was present so he contacted Minden Dispatch through the Air Tanker Base personnel and was told to proceed to the Genoa fire where his Mgr was supposed to be waiting. He proceeded to the fire and was told to go back to the airport and stand by. The fire called and said they wanted him back there so he hooked up his bucket and went to the Genoa fire where he made about 30 drops before being released back to the Minden airport. The next day he was dispatched to another USFS fire down by Markleeville and proceeded there to work the fire. He had still not hooked up with a manager as of yet and Dispatch became aware of it and sent a Manager to tie in with him at Minden Airport where he went through his briefing and had his cards checked. He continued working that fire for the rest of the day and the next day proceeded to a BLM fire where he worked the next two days without incident.
While heading to Chehalis for fuel, pilot noticed that he could not talk on his intercom or radio. Circuit breaker would not reset, aircraft returned to Randle Helibase and shut down.

Our helicopter and crew was dispatched to IA a fire on the north end of the District. Upon arrival we discovered 2 civilians near the heel of the fire, along with a vehicle inside the fire perimeter that had been consumed by fire. After landing near the two individuals, I asked them about the situation, I was informed that their vechicle had started the fire. I made the decision to fly them off the fire to the Carey airstrip without full PPE(except for flight helmets) because of several reasons:(1)they were in danger of being over-run by the fire,(2)they were experiencing health problems, probably due to dehydration and (3)they were in the middle of the desert without food, water, or transportation.

Upon completing a crew shuttle, to H-6, Helicopter 23V returned to the Oxbow Helibase and shutdown.  The mechanic was looking over the ship and noticed a little fuel around the engine area.  After checking further, he found the fuel line to the #2 engine was dripping fuel.  Pilot informed me of this and 23V was made unavailable.  This same line was replaced 2 or 3 weeks ago.

Flight following was not initiated after takeoff by the relief dispatchers during the dayshift while I was onboard. I didn't notice the time intervals myself till I was finished mapping or else I would have called in. Looking in the logbook total time of flight was about 55 minutes.

Tanker 126 departed for the Big Elk Fire at 1409.  Pilot called for gear upafter take off.  Shortly after command was given, hydraulic fluid mist was noted throughout the cockpit and the gear was not in transit.  The gear leverwas immediately placed in the down position.  The load of retardant wasjettisoned.  After confirming all gears were down and locked, an uneventful landing was made.The cause of the hydraulic leak was determined to be a parts box that didn'tget secured by the crew or mechanic after maintenance was performed the previous evening.  Hydraulic lines were replaced and system checked. Paul Markowitz returned the plane to contract availability and copies of the maintenance log faxed to him.

N868 is the helco machine. Helicopter 511(212) was coming out of his dip site when Helicopter 726(Sinton Helicopters)flew across in front of 511 with only .3 of a mile separation. As the helco on site, I had given him clearance to stay one mile off of the fire edge which he ignored.

Right main gear light remained in a inredin unsafe gear condition after selection of gear down during approach to landing at West Yellowstone, MT. The gear selector was operated to the up and down position numerous times (8-10) with the red unsafe gear condition light remaining on. Emergency checklist items were complied with and an unsafe gear condition was indicated. Recommended landing procedures were complied with and an uneventful landing was completed. After landing the red light extinguished and a green gear down light was observed.

After leaving Ramona air base pilot noticed the #3 engine starting to backfireall temps and pressures normal, reducing power didn't help.  Feather engine, drop 1000 gallons of retardant,and returned to Ramona AP out of service at 1827.

While aircraft was in the pit doing a hot reload, pilot inadvertantly hit switch to release load. Approximately 740 gallons of retardant mix was discharged onto the ramp area. Aircraft was reloaded and returned to the fire. Ramp crew quickly washed the ramp clean to the Airport Manager''s satisfaction and returned to normal operations.

During bucket work on the south side of the Rattlesnake Fire, pilot encountered a black drone at eye level as he was coming out of the dip. This was during the initial attack phase of the fire. The dip site was in the Little Salmon River next to Highway 95.

We departed Santa Fe Airport westbound. As we were climbing, the rate of climb was about 60% what it should be.  There was a fluttering noise apparent in the cockpit. The pilot turned off the Air Conditioner but the flutter continued.  The gear down indicator lights were not on but the pilot checked the gear up lever and found it was not fully engaged in the upright position.  He pushed the gear lever into its full upright position and the fluttering stopped.  Apparently the nose wheel did not fully retract until the gear lever was fully in an upright position.  The aircraft resumed its normal rate of climb after the nose wheel was fully retracted.  We continued with the mission.  The gear down lights were operating when we returned to the airport.

Upon entering the pattern for landing at BJC, the pilot noted that the landing gear lights were not illuminated.  Recycling the gear several times was ineffective.  A low pass, past the tower, confirmed the gear was not extended, but the nose wheel doors were down.The pilot and air attack cranked the gear into place and a second low pass was conducted to visually confirm the gear was extended.  The aircraft landed without further incident.

N411FS was returning from the Fridley Fire.  As the pilot set up for landing, he lowered the landing gear which resulted in sparks coming from the landing gear lever area.  We could smell smoke in the cockpit.  Panel and other lights went out.  Breaker for the lights had blown; we completed landing without further incident.

on august 3, 2011 a state of montana mt205 was dispatched to initial attack a fire 12 miles northeast of bonner, mt. upon arrival at the fire {rainbow bend 961001} the helitack crew attached the bambi bucket to the aircraft and began to fight the fire. the pilot proceeded to the blackfoot river, about ¼ mile north of the fire and commenced bucket operations. following the fourth bucket drop, the aircraft was returning to the river and was in a left turn when the pilot experienced the following: 1. grinding noises coming from the engine/transmission area. 2. excessive vibration. 3. a droop or reduction in rotor rpm. 4. surges in engine rpm. the pilot elected to perform a precautionary landing based on the aircraft behavior. landing options were extremely limited in the area. the pilot initially considered landing on highway 200 but the traffic was too heavy. adjacent to the highway was a small parking area used to access the river. several vehicles were parked in this area with people present. the pilot opted to split the difference between the parking area and the highway and landed on the turn-off area leading into the parking area. this turn-off area resulted in the aircraft landing with 9 degrees of lateral slope from right to left and 4 degrees nose up. the pilot did not jettison the bambi bucket on approach to the landing area, which resulted in his making a near vertical descent to the landing. the bucket was located to the left rear of the left skid, down slope from the aircraft. the bucket cables and bucket position indicated the bucket was placed and not dragged during landing. during the landing the aircraft moved forward about 18 inches from the initial touchdown point of the right rear skid tube. as the pilot placed the aircraft on the slope the aircraft slid about 16 inches down slope as the aircraft came to rest. there was a curved guard rail immediately aft of the aircraft. the final position of the aircraft resulted in a 20 inch separation of the tail skid and the guard rail. evidence suggests that the tail skid and tail rotor were over the guard rail during the landing event. no contact between the aircraft and guard rail occurred. the pilot attempted to perform an emergency engine shut-down following the landing, but failed to move the throttle past the idle cut-off position. the main fuel, and battery switches were placed in the off position. the pilot safely exited the aircraft, retrieved the fire extinguisher. the aircraft produced smoke from the engine/transmission for about 20 minutes after landing.

T-XX had just been loaded and was headed to the Sun Dog Fire on the Flathead N.F. T-XX had a very close encounter upon takeoff from runway 05 at COE with a Cessna 172 that was taking off on runway 01 (the two runways converge at the north end of the field). During this timeframe there were as many as eight aircraft on the airport in various stages of: taxiing, taking-off and/or landing. Two witnesses report that if T-XX had not made evasive manuevers (a left bank at perhaps as little as 100 ft AGL) while fully loaded there would have likely been a collision. The Cessna was also observed making a right bank to avoid the larger aircraft. It appears that the Cessna was not aware of the larger aircraft taking off on runway 05 until the last possible moment. T-XX did announce intentions on unicom. Workers at the airport report that the C-172 did also announce their intentions on unicom. Witnesses report that there may have been as little as fifty feet of horizontal separation between the two aircraft.

On 06/21/2004 aircraft Nxxxx was dispatched for the scheduled afternoon recon. All systems checked OK during the run-up check. We departed at 1552. About 25 minutes into the flight, a slight engine inmissin was observed. At 29 minutes (2 minutes later) a inroughnessin in one of the engines was observed. It was determined that the right magneto on the right engine was suspect. (There are 2 magnetos per engine for safety reasons, the aircraft can safely fly on 1 magneto). The mission was aborted and the aircraft was safely landed back at Flagstaff airport.

On August 23, 2011 @ 0851, an ATGS order was filled through BDC for the Water Hole Fire:   The Air Attacks dispatch form listed the Air to Air Frequency assigned as 124.9750, however, the correct frequency was 123.9250. ATGS was unaware of the mistake and began working within the Fire Traffic Area without being notified of the error. At approximately 1100 hrs, a local agency Helicopter was informed that an Air Attack was working within the area.   While continuing on with the reconnaissance flight helicopter entered the FTA without proper clearance from the Air Attack. The ATGS was able to establish contact with the helicopter and the local dispatch on other frequencies and resolved the issue by re-establishing correct frequencies and procedures.

After the second fuel cycle during initial attack on the Belli Ranch fire the pilot informed me that during structure protection water drops, he dropped on power lines causing them to arc. I heard the radio traffic prior to this incident and ground forces repeatedly requested the helicopter to drop in this area due to the eminent threat to the structures.

During the ground roll departing runway 29 at KMSO, the flight crew aborted the takeoff due to an apparent compressor stall with the left engine. The non-flying pilot noticed an abnormal indication with the left engine auto-ignition annuniciator and called for the ''''abort''''. At about the same time, the flying pilot noticed the left engine exhaust stack was flaming. After the aborted takeoff, the flightcrew taxied the A/C to a taxiway and ''''ran'''' the left engine up. The auto-ignition light began flicering off and on, the engine was making a ''''popping'''' sound, and a flame was observed coming out of the exhaust stack. The flightcrew then taxied the A/C back to the FBO and conducted one last engine run-up. The non-flying pilot observed the engine instrument gages while the flying pilot watched the left engine. At approximately 1000 lbs. of torque, the auto-ignition light started flickering off and on, the torque gage varied rapidly from 1000 lbs, to 200 lbs. of torque, and flame was again observed from the left engine exhaust stack. The A/C was then shut down and maintenance and management was notified of the problem.

At 1450 on June 29th as aircraft was preparing to launch to a fire, hydraulic fluid was noticed seeping out of the hoist filter hydraulic line during routine inspection. FS Maintenance inspector informed.

Tanker 14 was responding to the Silent fire (RRU-47545) and developed an oil leak at the number three engine.  Tanker 14 then returned to SBD Tanker Base.  After inspection it was noted that an oil line was loose.  Oil line tightened, and aircraft put into contract availability.Gerry Burney notified and approved.

After Landing @ Heber we observed oil dripping from engine compartment. Aircraft was 2 qts. low. Oil was coming out of an overflow tube. After discussion with company mechanic the problem was determined to be a stuck turbocharger wastegate bypass valve.  Based upon the diagnosis and with our concurrance we ceased our airattack mission and returned to Ogden. I rcvd a call the next morning that the problem was corrected. Regional Mechanical Inspector was notified and OK'd aircraft to return to contract service.

After approximately 3 flight hours conducting aerial observation over the Forest, the tachometer stopped indicating RPM. Per FAR 91.205 the aircraft was immediately placed on a heading to the nearest airport and landed without incident. After taxing to the ramp area a magneto check was performed and it was determined the magnetos were operating normally.
On termination on approach to dip site as power was applied #2 engine experienced a soft stall. Aircraft flown out of dip site and engine secured. Aircraft returned to Missoula on one engine.

We were dispatched to a fire in the blue range wilderness section 31 at approximately 1330. We arrived at the fire and were beginning smokejumper operations when we noticed traffic on our TCAS. A lookout also reported a military C130 south of our position. One minute later, the military C130 flew under Jumper aircraft at 200 feet AGL. The fire was located in the Reserve MOA and there is a military training route south of the position we were operating. The reserve MOA is depicted on the sectional and states that military aircraft will be operating from 5000 ft. AGL up to FL180.

The incident occurred during a recon flight out of Gillespie Co. TX airport {T82}. At about 1025 the GPS went off. The pilot recycled it and got it back on, but it went right back off. The pilot checked the alternator gauges and they showed no charge. He also checked circuit breakers and everything else he could think of but nothing worked.
