We then determined we had a complete electrical failure. We decided to return to T82. I made attempts to contact Air Ops and dispatch, but had no cell coverage at our present location. At about 10 miles from T82 I was able to reach dispatch and advise of our situation. We attempted to lower the gear but could not get it all the way down so had to crank it down the rest of the way. We ask the SEAT manager to observe the gear as we did a fly by. He and one of the SEAT pilots observed and said it looked like it was down and locked. We then came back around and landed without incident at 1101.

On fire response from Sonoma Base, #2 engine EGT limit was exceeded by 13 degrees C. on second start attempt.

#1 engine start was uneventful. Left generator was on-line and amps & volts within limits for second engine start. On second (starboard) engine start, engine acceleration above about 30% was below normal and concurrent with rising EGT. # 2 engine start was aborted without exceeding limits and motored for residual engine cool down. On second start attempt, acceleration seemed normal, however EGT rapidly spiked and while initiating the abort max EGT was exceeded by 13 degrees C.

While on a routine aerial detection flight, Air-1 the Cessna 210 owned / operated by Smith Air out of Hindsville, AR. was circling to the right over a water source on the Ouachita National Forest @ about 1245 hrs. when the engine started to sputter. The aircraft was immediatly leveled out and the pilot XXX XXXXX adjusted a fuel switch and the engine returned to normal. No other problems were encountered the rest of the flight.

Pilot was performing bucketing on Derby Fire when chip light indicator came on for transmission. After landing at Big Timber Airport mechanics found small metal debris had tripped indicator.  Aircraft Maintenance inspector was informed of situation and aircraft was put on unavailability.

This is being filed in response to 05-0595. I am the Assistant Center Manager in the Burns Interagency Communication Center, I wanted to clarify some of the coorination that was happening in the back ground of this incident, that may not have been passed onto the air attack. We had a report of an incident out in the Wagontire area, all of our available aircraft were responding to another incident, so we contacted the shared resources desk at Central Oregon Interagency Dispatch Center. The requests on the aircraft order included 1 Type 3 Helicopter, and 1 SEAT. Confirmation of frequencies were passed onto the center verbally. The order was placed at 1744. At 1752 Central Oregon called to let us know that they would be filling the order, and that they had additional ground resources enroute. At 1819 XXX from Central Oregon called to confirm the command frequency for this fire, it was Dry South. H-XXX contacted Burns Dispatch on the command frequency at 1828, frequencies were again given to the helicopter. At 1848 H-XXX called to let us know that T-XXX may have dropped on another incident but they are in touch with Central Oregon dispatch. At 1902 T-XXX called into Burns Dsipatch letting us know that he had dropped on a fire at 43 19 32 x 120 09 47 which was not the original fire that they were dispatched to, he gave the size up to Burns. When we plotted the fire we were coordinating with COIDC and LIFC as to who''s fire it would be as we all knew that it was a boundary fire. I was on the phone with LIFC to obtain what resources she had responding to this new fire, and what Air-Air Frequency they were operating on. Air-Attack XXX called into BICC to obtain the Air-Air Frequency 125.075. COIDC called to let us know that H-XXX had set down due to wx and gave us an updated lat long of the set down location. We advised Air-Attack of this information. We advised AA-XXX of the Air-Air frequency that the LIFC air resource were operating on as well. There is always a lot of coordination going on in the back ground when we have boundary fires, and the dispatch centers are working with each other to ensure the safety of the fire personnel on the ground and in the air. H-XXX called into Burns Dispatch to let them know that they would be setting down due to an active cell in the area and gave us a location of where they would be setting down.

Dispatched as initial attack to a fire. Started acft engine and all appeared normal until the gas produced tachometer (N) went through 40%,I released the started switch and the engine flamed out, all indicationsof the start up to that point were normal.I contacted the DNR mechanic supervisor and he thought that perhaps thethrottle was rolled back a little to far off the detent to continuestarting sequence. Also, he said that there was the possibility of something similar to a vapor lock (air bubble) may have occured.I attempted a restart at his request and everything performednormally.After the restart Helicopter Manager contacted DNR Mechanic Supervisor once again to obtain clearance to resume operations. Clearancewas granted by mechanic.Helibase Manager contacted USFS to discuss start difficulties. After a conference between FS and DNR representatives Rotor 338 was fullyoperational.

On 8/20/20, I was enroute to the Walbridge fire from STS. The work area and IP were 14 miles from the airport. I checked in with the ASM and was cleared direct to the work area at 2500. Enroute, during the climb on the east side of HWY 101 I received a TCAS over Fitch Mountain (Healdsburg), acquired the target and maneuvered around it. It was a helicopter westbound at my altitude. Shortly thereafter, I heard someone trying to get clearance into the FTA on 122.92. Although Fitch Mountain and Healdsburg are not in the TFR, they are well within the FTA, and 8 miles from the IP I was given. 

After the drop and during the exit, I received another TCAS. I acquired the target and pointed it out to the ASM. The same helicopter I almost ran into over Healdsburg, was now flying up the retardent line where we were working. 

I was caught by surprise because I wasn’t briefed about any other aircraft in the area. The helicopter wasn’t in the area he was supposed to be and the ASM was also caught by surprise.

Flying Fire Managers on Pattengail Fire Recon. Air Attack~above helicopters~air attack complained they could not see me on TCAS, but could see the helicopters below me. Reason is the helicopter''s transponder attenna is housed in plexiglass nose which transmits through. My transponder attenna is on the bottom of my fuselage. Air attack above me could not see me on TCAS as signal won''t go through aluminum fuselage.

Had a second veg. fire in close proximity of Rancho Fire. Rancho Fire assigned frequency is Service Net LaCumbre, dispatcher assigned Davey Fire to Tepesquet Repeater on Forest Net because LaCumbre Forest Net which covered the area has been none operational since early June. Radio communications were directley effected forcing many of the ground and air resources on the Davey Fire to switch to service net LaCumbre causing 2 incidents to operate on the same frequency. At 1514 we broke the Course Fire which was in close proximity of the Rancho Fire and the same scenerio happened.

No. 1 engine gave a fire warning light in zone #1 while on take-off roll. Take-off aborted and tanker returned to airtanker base. Mechanic determined a crack in the housing for #2 power recovery turbine caused fire warning. Change out #2 P.R.T.

On August 26th during bucket operations on the Sambrito 2 fire, Hxxx experienced an engine chip light and returned to the Sambrito Helibase and landed without incident. Manager notified maintenance inspector and Hxxx was place out of service. An inspection of the lower chip light plug near the compressor revealed minute metal fragments. The plug was wiped clean and a 30 minute run up was conducted. Approximately 5 minutes into the run up, the engine chip light came on again. The helicopter was shut down and the same plug re-inspected, showing a few more minute metal fragments. Mechanics were called in who inspected the front side of the compressor and discovered that one of the bolts had broken its weld. It was decided to replace the engine.

At 1715, the helicopter returned to the Helibase from a water drop mission to the fire. No issues were reported during the flight. The lead aircraft mechanic did normal post flight check of aircraft systems. At 1730 he reported to me the helicopter was out of service and in need of a gearbox replacement. In a normal check of fluids he discovered metal shavings in the gearbox lubricant. I reported the issue to the local dispatch office and to the Aviation Officer

On the morning of September 18th, 2014 the aircraft dispatcher at LIFC called Kingsley Field Oregon Air National Guard operations to report that the Klamath Falls Air Tactical Group Supervisor {Air Attack} and Single Engine Airtankers {SEAT’s} would be operating from Burns and Lakeview in support of Bone Creek Basin and Blitzen Fires near the Steen’s mountains. Kingsley asked what the flight level for of the aircraft would be. Per the Klamath Falls Air Attack and the Lakeview SEAT Manager, the aircraft would be flying around 7,500 ft. MSL when enroute to the incident and 8,500 coming back to LKV. Kingsley said that would work for them as the floor in the MOA is 11,000. After speaking with Burns later in the morning the LIFC aircraft dispatcher found out the heavy airtankers would be flying also and relayed that to Kingsley Field. The de-confliction report that morning indicated that Juniper / Hart and Goose MOAs would be active with a floor of 11,000 feet and the following footnote **notified of heavy activity throughout day**.  At the Klamath Falls ATB {LMT}, tankers were on and available. Both aircrews were given the de-confliction information with the morning briefing materials. Both airtankers launched to the Bone Creek Basin fire at 11:30. Airtankers had already launched to the fire from RDM at 1030. It is unknown if those aircrews received de-confliction information at that time. The four airtankers proceeded to load and return from LMT. Tankers 161 and 41 did not receive deconfliction information on the MOAs from the airtanker base at this time. At 1545 the LIFC aircraft dispatch received a call from a Lt. Col from Kingsley stating there was almost an incident within the Juniper Hart MOA. He said that they didn’t know we {federal airtankers} were in there and if the tankers were flying VFR they must have been penetrating the clouds. One of the military planes got close to one of the tankers and they were concerned. The aircraft dispatcher gave the Lt Col the Klamath Falls Airtanker Base Manager’s number as well because he wanted to relay the information to them. Both aircraft dispatchers deconflicted the day prior and in the morning of the 18th.  Another phone call was made to Kingsley on the morning of the 18th to notify of the planned Air Attack flights to Burns from Klamath Falls. Kingsley was updated about the additional orders for Airtankers/SEATs that would be operating to/from Klamath Falls. The Burns Interagency Coordination Center was also notified of the military traffic in the MOA. The Klamath Falls base manager received a call from a Lt. Col. at Kingsley on the afternoon of September 18th. He was concerned that F15’s from the Kingsley base were operating in the Hart South MOA and that airtankers supporting the Bone Creek Basin and Blitzen Crossing fires were crossing the MOA at approximately 13,000 ft. He said the airtankers were “in weather” with low visibility and that there had been a instance where aircraft had been in close proximity. The Airtanker Base manager told him that he would speak to the aircrews and let them know that the MOA is active and relay his concerns. He asked the Airtanker Base manager to send him an email letting him know that he had done this. The manager spoke with each air crew that day which consisted of {3} Tankers. Tanker XXX at this time was already heading for RDM. T XX had been operating across the MOA at about 7500’ and TXX and TXXX had been operating at approximately 13,500’. The TXXX crew mentioned that they had been “on top” of weather on their way over. I told them the MOA was active and expressed the Lt. Col.’s concern. I sent an email to the Lt. Col. letting him know that I spoke with the aircrews. By this time, the airtankers were on hold. They did not go back to the fire.  In the afternoon of the 18th, after all airtankers were on hold, both the LIFC dispatch office and the LMT airtanker base received calls from Kingsley Field. They were concerned that the heavy airtankers were flying at 13,500 and in the clouds and he thought that should be an IFR flight and wasn’t sure why they were flying that high. The Assistant Tanker Base Manager was contacted by Kingsley field who reported an airtanker observed at 11,000 feet in the clouds. The Assistant Airtanker Base Manager mentioned to the officer, that de-confliction information was received and relayed to the pilots of the active MOA’s. The Assistant Airtanker Base Manager then spoke with the aircrews. The pilots stated they had already lowered their routes and had to get around the weather. The Tanker was able to lower his flight paths to 7500. A couple pilots mentioned getting T-CAS hits from jets far overhead. There were no further flights to these fires that day or after. The airtanker base has received word from the National Airspace Program Manager that the military had notified the FAA of these events. On Monday, the 29th of September, the National Airspace Program Manager called the Unit Aviation Officer asking for clarification and information about the events of September 8th, as the FAA was asking if there was a mutual agreement to fly at 7500ft.

As the aircraft descended for his tenth load, the pilot reported watching the bucket continue to sink into the water and go out of sight. When he returned to pick up his crew the hook was open and all electrical wiring below the two pin connector was missing. According to the pilot write up, ''''The cargo hook opened without pilot action during sling operations. Bucket jettisoned''''. The hook is part of the ''''Onboard cargo suspension system'''' and requires the hook to be opened in order to attach any load {it does not have the typical spring loaded keeper}. Nothing unusual was observed while deploying the bucket. Maintenace checked the system and could not duplicate the problem.

Tanker was on LCQ taxiway doing a pre-flight run-up prior to take-off enroute to Grand Junction CO to support Whittaker Flats Fire. The tanker was not loaded with retardant. First leg of ferry flight was to Amarillo, TX. The instrument light for ''Fire Warning'' came on. Tanker taxied back into the tanker base and shut down. Mechanics evaluation revealed the Fire Warning Loop (wire) had gone bad.

While snorkeling water, pilot noted torque split.  Pilot released the load by the emergency dump on the fixed tank.  Pilot put #1 engine into manual to bring #1 torque back.  Pilot flew aircraft back to Bruce Meadows Helibase.

Operation on the Six Rivers National Forest, Young Fire began on 8/18 with the DOI agency FireFly VTOL UAS. The 8/25 afternoon IR reconnaissance flight landing concluded with a propeller strike. The approach was set in guided mode with an automated RTL landing. Within approximately 5 meters from the takeoff location a side gust of wind pushed the UAS off target completing the landing 12 feet from center point where the ground was struck breaking the tips of two of the six propellers. No other damage occurred to the UAS.

While enroute to a Southwest Region (R-3) assignment as a prevention officer, an employee’s checked baggage was subjected to a random search. After the security inspector opened the bag a group of “strike anywhere” type stick matches ignited in the luggage. The inspector was startled and there was minimal damage to the luggage contents. The employee was allowed to continue on their trip.

Engine #4 fuel pressure dropped from 25 psi to 19 psi and red warning light came on 48in map on take-off.  Tried high boost - went from 30 psi to 19 psi at 48in.  Aborted take-off.  Removed engine-drive fuel pump and replaced it.  Engine operates normally idle through max power and leak check are okay.

At 1510, shortly after Air Attack change over, a helicopter that was not assigned to the incident was observed at about 500 ft AGL over the eastern portion of the fire. Air Attack 66M followed the helicopter as it flew to the west towards Knoxville. While the helicopter was over the fire, contact was attempted on the fire's assigned victor and on guard. No contact was made and the helicopter departed toward Knoxville. Contact was then made with Knoxville Approach who stated the departing helicopter was Lifeflight 2. Lifeflight 2 then came up on the approach freq. and stated that they had picked up a medivac off the fire and were enroute to the UT Med Center. The ASM pilot (B-2) who had been just relieved then came up on the approach freq (he had already made contact with Knoxville Approach)and told Lifeflight in the future to make contact on the assigned victor. Lifeflight stated his office had called the phone number on the NOTAM. The ASM pilot then gave the assigned Victor to both approach and the Lifeflight pilot.
During engine runup, pilot experienced a firelight for number 1 recip engine. Pilot turned back into the pit and the light went off. Pilot shut down aircraft.

Landed at H-22 to pick up 2 pax for recon of Poet Fire.  Pilot shut down a/c at request of pax to give them time to review maps delivered by ship and give pilot briefing of mission.  Pilot began to start a/c but stopped, saying if he continued a/c would experence a inhot startin and the ship needed 10 more minutes to cool down.  He said that elevation was the reason for the problem. (7,150' msl). Pilot waited approx. 10 minutes, then attempted to restart.  He stopped and said he'd had a inhot startin and that we needed to call the mechanic.

While performing initial attack activities on the Cypress Creek Fire, the pilot had to land at the helispot for additional fuel. Once the refueling was complete, the pilot was to return to the fire to perform bucket drops.When the pilot initiated the starting sequence, the engine failed to start. The pilot attempted a second time to start the engine and it once again failed to start. With a second failure, the pilot decided not to try again until the problem was looked at by a mechanic. At this time, I informed the pilot that I did not hear the usual 'clicking' sound that the ignitor makes on a normal start. About this time, the mechanic for a Bell 212 assigned to the fire arrived at the helispot. The pilot, which is also the owner of the aircraft, asked the mechanic to take a look at the helicopter to see if he could find out what was causing the engine not to start. The mechanic started by removing the ignitor plug to see if it might have some carbon built up on the end, not allowing it to operate properly. Once it was removed, I, along with the mechanic and the pilot, observed only a small amount of carbon deposits on the end of the ignitor. The ignitor was cleaned and replaced in the engine, and the security wire was replaced. The pilot then tried to start the engine resulting another failed start.At this time, I made a call to Region-8 maintenance inspector Bill McMillan to inform him of the situation. With very poor cellular service on my end of the call, I was able to understand him enough to hear that it was alright to proceed, but that when I was able to get to a hard line phone, I was to call him and let him know what had happened.I knew that the mechanic was not a 407 mechanic, but I did allow him to proceed because what he was doing, in my opinion, did not warrant the necessity of a 407 mechanic. I was later informed by Mr. McMillan that this should not have been allowed because the 407 is such a new type aircraft and  that with the 'FADEC' system problems that occur might not be what they seem and need to be checked out by a qualified 407 mechanic.--Lesson learned.  The mechanic then decided to try and clean the fuel nozzle to see if this would help the situation. Once this was done, another attempt was made to start the engine which proved to be successful.The helicopter started each time necessary the rest of the day without fail. The pilot/owner of the aircraft decided to fly his mechanic in to take a look at the helicopter. The mechanic was at the helibase the next morning, Wednesday, April 21. He added a shim to the fuel nozzle and checked out the aircraft.  The aircraft started without incident. A call was made to Bill McMillan to inform him of the situation.  Mr. McMillan released the aircraft for work and told me that if the problem occurred again, that I was to make the aircraft unavailable and stop it from working. Once we were released to work we were dispatched back to the fire. When the pilot tried to start the engine, it once again failed to start. When this occurred, the mechanic tried changing out the ignitor plug and adding another shim to the fuel nozzle. This proved to be ineffective. At this time, I declared the helicopter unavailable and made a call to Mr. McMillan to keep him apprised of the situation.

At 1500 a citizen called the front desk at King City, LPF, the call was forwarded to the Forest FAO who gave the citizen a telephone number to South Kirk Complex Air Operations director.  At 1515 Air Ops received a phone call from the citizen, stating that inan air tanker had dropped retarded on their trailer and vehicles. The citizen also said that it was a 4 engine aircraft but could not give any further description.  They said that their house is located on Plaskett Ridge, about 5+ miles from the fire.  Air Ops advised the person to wash the retardant from vehicles and building and that a representative would contact them from the incident.

UPON START UP MAJOR HYDRAULIC LEAK DETECTED WITH THE {{{{{{{#}}}}}}}2 STARTER. NEEDS REPLACING. FLUIDS LEAKING OFF AIRCRAFT LEG IN 5 GALLON CATCH BUCKET.MECHANICS TO ORDER AND REPLACE STARTER. RAMI NOTIFIED DOCUMENTED.

While responding to a fire dispatch on a neighboring unit, our pilot stated that we had an indication of a vacuum pump failure. He asked what I would like to do, adding that we could continue the mission provided we remained in day VFR conditions per the provisions of the aircraft Minimum Equipment List. We continued the mission without incident, and after a fuel stop returned to our home airport. The regional Aviation Safety Inspector was notified, and the airplane removed from service pending clarification of the provisions of the Minimum Equipment List.

Tanker XXX while on BLM ramp the SEAT pilot attempted to start aircraft twice after cleared. BLM Ramp Manager informed pilot of fuel leaking out of aircraft overflow. The SEAT aircraft could not be started and had to be moved off the BLM ramp to general aviation for maintenence. After inspection the mechanic determined the problem to be a bent pin on the ignitor cannon plug. For temporary correction the pin on the cannon plug was bent back into place to ensure proper connection to the ignitor box. Tanker XXX back in service after successful maintenence check.

On August 28, 2013 a cargo mission involving multiple loads delivered to multiple helispots was initiated by a handcrew’s request via cell phone to the Air Ops. At the time, the type 2 helibase had four helicopters, a USFS exclusive use AS350-B3 with crew, a National CWN 214 with a CWN crew, a National exclusive use S-61 with manager, and a National CWN UH-1H {restricted} with a manager and manager trainee. Other HECMs on base were assigned to ABRO, ABRO trainee, and cargo. Supply dropped off the cargo midafternoon and loads were built in the designated cargo area using the HOGE-J allowable from the 214’s load calc. At some point it was decided by HEB2 that the loads should be shared between the 214 and the UH-1H. Helitack in cargo divided up the loads between the two ships according to the receiving crew’s point of contact. It was determined that the 214 would deliver three loads, the UH-1H would deliver two loads, and whoever returned first would fly the last load {total of 6 picks}. The manager and pilots of the 214 were fully aware of their mission and already spooling when an individual came to the managers of the UH-1H with two pieces of paper containing a lat/long, contact, and weight for the two loads they would take. They were told each ship would fly two loads and that there was a fifth load going with the first aircraft back. The managers briefed their pilot, discussing a number of concerns, but determined that the mission could be carried out safely and that they would proceed. The first red flag was that the HECM who brought the load info from cargo did not know the weight of the last load, but that would be easily resolved with a radio call prior to the final pick, and because the 214 would be the first one out they would probably be the first back thus taking the load in question, making the concern irrelevant. The second topic of concern related to the fact that the first pick would not only be the heaviest, but its weight was actually 2 pounds above the UH-1H’s allowable for the day. It was determined that taking a load over allowable was mitigated due to the pick-up and delivery locations being much lower in elevation than the load calc was completed for coupled with fuel burn from a maintenance run-up and power check completed prior to the mission. All involved agreed the mission could be safely completed. As the 214 called deck to lift and the UH-1H began his start up, ABRO{t} called cargo asking for manifests and other info relating to the mission. A very confusing radio exchange in which cargo told the ABRO{t} “load 3 will be {{{{#}}}}1 going to ____, load 1 will be {{{{#}}}}2 going to lat/long with a contact of ___, BREAK.” At which point ABRO{t} stepped in saying “all I need to know is what is the first load out, and who is it going to so I can inform Div.___,” and to “please bring the manifests for each load to the box.” After the 4th pick, the UH-1H managers saw that there were actually six loads… not the five they were briefed about. Due to a seemingly large amount of confusion at the helibase for a simple cargo mission, the UH-1H manager decided to walk down to the box and look at the manifests and posted load calcs. He discovered a number of discrepancies in the numbers on the manifests. The allowables for all manifested loads were based off of the 214’s HOGE-J, which was 376 pounds heavier than the UH-1H’s. The manifest showed a remote hook with longline at 60 pounds, when the UH-1H hook and longline combined weight was 91 pounds. Although the cargo area was too far from their pad too see all the equipment clearly, the manager could tell each load consisted of three daisy-chained nets or blivets, which should’ve used two leadlines and three swivels. The manifests did not show the appropriate weights for that combination of equipment

On 3-27-2012 at 18:15 T-xx was taxing {while loaded with retardant} on the former FBO ramp just east of the Airtanker Base. While maneuvering on the ground the Right Main landing gear tire broke through a drainage grate and sliced the tire. The Pilot continued forward away from the broken grate, shut down the aircraft and called for the Mechanic. After inspecting the aircraft the Pilot and Mechanic saw no further damage beyond the R/H tire and requested a maintenance break to have the tire replaced. The pilot stated that during taxiing operations the grate was not visible from his vantage point in the cockpit. The Airport Operations Manager was consulted and the load bearing weight was confirmed to be above that of a P2V Neptune at full takeoff weight of 80,000lbs and single wheel. Upon closer inspection the airport found no obvious flaws with the broken grate. The airport has inspected the remaining drainage grated in the ramp and found them to be in good condition.

On July 7, 1999, Helicopter 193 EH was doing bucket work with the relief pilot on the Wah Wah Fire in SW Utah. It was about a 12 min. turn around from the water source to the fire.Attempting a drop, the pilot couldn't release the water and noted that the pigtail had come off. He reported this condition to the helicopter forman(who was also the IC) and who, at that time was at the helispot with two crewmembers.The ship approached the helispot, didn't land but remained in a hover instead with the bucket on the ground. The forman went under the helicopter and was holding on to the bucket, while the one crewmember grabbed the pigtail and plugged it back in. The second crewmember was standing to the side of the ship, caught by suprise by what was going on, because he expected the ship to land so the pigtail could be retaped.The helicopter flew to the fire, released the water and flew back to the helibase, where the pigtail was retaped.

As pilot and manager lifted off airport for recon, ``FADEC FAULT`` light came on, and we sat back down at the airport. Upon landing and rolling throttle to idle `` FADEC DEGRADE`` illuminated in addition to ``FADEC FAULT``. Shut aircraft down and called for maintenance. Mechanic changed out ECU and went through proper checks and test flight. Aircraft was returned to contract availability by regional maintence inspector.

When pulling pitch for the fifth mission of the day a chip light came on. The mechanic reported ferrous fuzz and several flakes on all plugs. The mechanic cleaned the plugs and flushed the system. The pilot performed an operational check flight for 18 minutes and landed. When the mechanic rechecked the plugs there were more flakes on the plugs. Ferrous fuzz was found on the oil output chip plug 2 days ago {8.1 flight hrs.} as reported on SAFECOM 09-0454.

On tuesday afternoon May 17 2011, the Maintenance crew on Tanker during routine inspection noticed a crack in the left outboard wing flap track. Upon further inspection and discussion with company`s maintenance control, it was decided to place the aircraft out of service thursday afternoon to address the issue.
Foward rotor head horizontal pin bearing inspection due.

We started the RX burn around 12:30. Everything was going fine with no problems. After about 1 1/2 hours of firing we went back to the helispot to refuel, eat, and warm up. We were down approximately 30 minutes. We left the helispot around 14:48 to finish the RX burn. We had been firing about 20 minutes when all of a sudden the machine lost power. I immediately told the ignition boss and the pilot that the machine had lost power and I was accessing the problem. I closed the feed control and turned the control panel to the off mode. I looked to make sure the power cable hadn`t come loose. Everything was connected. I started turning the manual assist to get any balls out of the exit chute. A couple of balls exited but I was having problems turning the manual assist. At that time I noticed a glow around the feed control and exit chute. I immediately pushed the water button on the control panel extinguishing the fire. At that point I told the pilot and ignition boss that I had to use water to extinguish the fire, we still had no power and we needed to go back to the helispot. We landed at the helispot at 15:25. Once we took the hopper off we saw that the third needle had been bent up and to the right and there were two balls jammed in the block. Were the needle was bent this was not allowing me to use the manual assist which caused the fire. We replaced the needle and once that was done then the plunger/guide would not move.
On startup to head to a new start a chip light was detected on the main gearbox.

At approximately 13:45 a light helicopter patrolling power lines for PG&E flew through the middle of the Twenty fire FTA without clearance. Ten minutes prior I was warned that a PG&E rotor-wing aircraft might be in the area, and was advised of their tail number and the frequency they would be monitoring. The heli-tack crew at the heel of the fire {under the power lines} warned me of the approaching aircraft, but I was unable to contact them on any A/A frequency. The EU helicopter assigned to the fire was engaged in bucket operations, and the route between dip and drop crossed over the power lines that the unannounced aircraft was patrolling. Luckily, the fire helicopter had a frequency used by PG&E and made contact with the utility helicopter after the intrusion. I did the same after getting the frequency, then relayed the incident to my ECC. See attached photo of fire, power lines, and dip site.

After landing from the last Air Attack flight of the day at 4SD it was noticed upon exiting the Aircraft,it was listing to the left. It was then observed that fluid was leaking from the main left strutt & and down on the left wheel.

When attempting to contact McMinville radio for a special clearance to land under conditions, the main radio malfunctioned and the pilot could not get through.  All other radios were working, we could still talk with BLM dispatch and the but when the VHF was keyed it would only static.  We contacted CBD dispatch and told them we were landing on a high point to wait for the fog to break.  While the pilot pulled the radio in and out of its mount several times then fastened several hours later we lifted off and when the pilot tried the VHF it worked.  He told me later that he has tried every way he can think of to get it to not work but it has been flawless every since.

During Helitack operations we noticed the neighboring forest was using the same air-to-ground frequency as we were.  We were experiencing difficulty making contact with personnel on the ground due to bleed-over from a nearby fire on the other forest.
The Sikorsky was leaking from the Belly Tank during a fire mission on the Blossom Fire.  After finishing the mission the helicopter return to base to investigate the problem.
The number one engine was started with the tail-cone {exhaust} cover installed. No damage or injury.
Upon taxing for take-off the #1 engine would not start.  PIC radioed tanker base to return for mechanical.

At 1145, helicopter was dispatched to the Pigeon Cove Fire. Upon departure of the Brown Butte Helibase, a chip light came on saying FADEC fail. The manager and the pilot discussed the issue and decided to land as soon as possible. They set down at the heel of Brown Butte Fire in a safe area. The manager instructed the two crewmembers to exit the aircraft to a safe area. The pilot tried to roll the throttle to idle, but the throttle stayed open at 100 percent. They then looked for popped breakers, none were found. The pilot could not shut down aircraft and we discussed the issue over the radio with the mechanic. The mechanic and pilot decided it would be best to fly to the Twin Falls Airport to further address problem. They made the decision for the manager to exit aircraft and drive to the airport. The pilot made it back to Twin Falls safely and was able to shut down by going into manual mode and shut the fuel down.
Transmission chip light came on at take off. Landed back on the pad and called the Maintenance Inspector. Mechanic pulled the chip detector and found 2 very small metal flex.

While performing water bucket mission copter xxx experienced a near miss incident with another incident assigned heicopter. Copter xxx was assigned to hold the ridgeline west of Indian Creek drainage. On final to the drop, ''xxx On the drop'' was called. While coming off the drop, xxx came within 100 yards, converging course with another assigned copter. Copter xxx went to full collective to maintain seperation. The other ship was called with no response. Contact was made with Helco and the other copter then responded to the call.

Door opening in flight - Pilot and ATGS had boarded the aircraft through the right forward door, ATGS secured the door after boarding. Approximately two minutes after take-off, the door came open. Pilot communicated to the tower that we would be returning to the airport for an open door. The aircraft was landed, and the door secured. The aircraft taxied back to the runway, took off, and completed the mission as planned.

While assigned to an incident the pilot of a type 3 helicopter was directed to conduct bucket drops in a problem area of the fire. After completing the first drop and refilling the bucket, the pilot was directed by the ground contact near the target to perform a spot drop on a second target approximately 100 yards from the original target. There were no ground personnel in the immediate vicinity of the second target, which was a burning log about 20 feet long. The pilot performed a recon, noting a snag adjacent to the target, and began a slow descent. As the drop was made, the pilot saw the bucket brush up against the snag. {The pilot stated that the helicopter was descending slightly and moving forward at a ground speed of 3 knots per hour at the time of the drop} The pilot perceived the impact to be minor enough not to have damaged the bucket. As a precautionary measure, the pilot notified the Helibase that the helicopter would be returning there to have the bucket inspected prior to continuing any operations.

While doing the morning fuel testing it was found that there was rust in the fuel. A new fuel truck was brought out that same day and when the mechanic checked the fuel in the new truck it was found that the fuel in the replacement truck had more rust in it than the original truck.

T-XX was experiencing starting problems on his number 2 engine after reloading at the McCall Airtanker Base. After getting started he flew to the Crystal Fire on the Salmon-Challis Forest and made a successfaul drop. He then flew on to Missoula and made repairs and became operational the following morning.  There was no loss of availability and no problems completing the mission.
Aircraft had an input module chip light illuminate during in-flight operations.  Pilot immediately found a safe place to land the aircraft in an open field.
Intermediate gear box chip light came on, pilot returned to helibase and shut down.

Statement by the Helicopter Manager and Pilot:Helicopter 5738Y was assigned to fly the Isabel fire 20 minutes SW of the Needle Fire. I asked the pilot if he needed the communication information and he said that the Situation Unit Leader made the arrangements to go to the Isabel fire. Prior to departure, the pilot stopped by the Foster Helibase communication trailer to inform them he had been ordered to IR map the fire, Isabel. He was asked if he had the frequencies for the Isabel. He said he had received them from the Needle Air Attack the day before (on 9/14).5738Y departed the Foster Helibase at 1330. In route to the Isabel fire until 1405. 8 miles out, 38Y attempted to contact Salmon Helibase on the given frequency with no result. The pilot tried again a second time again with no avail. 38Y pilot then tried a secondary frequency (not utilized the day before) given to the pilot by the Needle Air Attack. On that frequency he communicated with the Salmon Air Attack and discovered that he had flown into an active air operation.Note: On 9/14 the previous day, 38Y was dispatched to the same fire and the Foster Helibase communications said there were no air operations taking place on the Isabel. Arriving on the fire, there was one type 2 on the ground at the Salmon Helibase.Corrective Actions:Situations needs to go through the proper ordering channel by using the Air Operations Branch Director to place the order. By doing this both Teams will know what aircraft are being used on that incident and can give permission for the flight.Statement by ATGS on 9/15:On 9/15/03 received a request at approx. 10 am for ATGS mission on Isabel fire #637. Aircraft Dispatcher, XXXXXXXXXXXXX, was told at time of request about a new air-to-ground and new victor frequency that he mentioned to me he was unaware of . The requests had not gone thru proper resource order request channels. He spoke with requesting resource about this.During ATGS mission over Isabel at approx. 1400 I spotted a jet ranger in the fire airspace over a ridge where Lead 69 and air tankers were working. I immediately notified Lead 69 and inquired at Salmon helibase if they knew about this helicopter. They did not. Soon after that 38Y identified himself saying his mission was mapping. I told him that would not be possible at this time as we had T-62 about 2 minutes out and another tanker soon after. I moved him east of the fire camp area or said he could set down at Salmon helibase. I told him to stay below 7,000’. Lead 69 then requested he move north and east of the fire camp as directly east would be “the down and out” for the tankers how he was setting that up. 38Y stated he had tried to contact the fire using yesterdays frequencies and when no one answered, assumed on one was over the fire so came on into airspace. I gave him the correct (new) frequencies and both Lead 69 and myself discussed the situation that had occurred with him over the radio as we were departing fire, mission complete.Statement by Aircraft Dispatcher:At 0946 received a radio call from Air Ops requesting our Air Attack 634CT to come to Isabel Fire to access need for Air Tankers on incident. At that time he gave me new victor Freq. and new Air Ground Freq. I asked him where they got the new Freqs, since I had no request from ICP for new Freqs for the incident., he told me he got Freqs from the  communication unit leader. I then called the Communication Unit Leader and asked him where he got the Freqs and he told me he called NIC and got them from them. I then told him since I had the Aircraft Orders for the Incident and that the orders needed to come through me at CWICC so I could track them in Ross and coordinate those freqs with our responding  aircraft.  I knew nothing about the Isabel Fire contacting the Needle Fire and requesting the use of a helicopter, which the order should have came through me at CWICC since I have all aircraft for both  Incidents and they need to be tracked in Ross for proper payment and tracking of aircraft use. If the proper procedures would of been followed the Freqs would have been passed on to N38Y before he was dispatched to the Isabel Fire.  I knew nothing about the near miss over incident until later when XXXXXXXX -Helibase Manager for the Needle Fire called me and told me about what happened.Statement by XXXXXXXXX, ASGS Isabel:Helicopter 38Y departed the Needles fire to map the Isabel fire without the proper radio frequencies. 38Y failed to establish contact at 12NM from the Isabel fire and did not hold at 7NM when contact was not established with Air Attack or the Helibase.The first contact with 38Y was with Air Attack as 38Y flew into the fire area. The other aircraft over the incident were Lead 69, tankers 62 and 66 and SEAT 185. The presence of 38Y unannounced over the fire during tanker operations created an unsafe working environment and could have resulted in an aircraft mishap. Wenatchee Air Attack and Lead 69 did a very good job of keeping control of the airspace and keeping 38Y in a safe working area away from the tanker operation.

Mission - fly to a remote gravel pit and use it as a base of operations for aerial ignition RX burning ops nearby. What happened - Enroute to gravel pit, the securing nylon strap for the Plastic Sphere Dispenser {PSD} slipped through the buckle and about 8 feet of the strap was ripped out of the cabin by the air friction on the strap and consequentially, the strap dangled under the belly of the ship during the remainder of the flight. Pilot could see the strap with the skid mirror and determined there was no factor with the tail rotor. Background - The PSD machine was secured to the floor of the aircraft with a seat belt-size nylon strap that ties one side of the PSD to the other by routing the strap under the door around the belly of the ship and back to the opposite side of the PSD machine. The buckle had blunt or rounded ''alligator teeth'' that were supposed keep the strap from loosening. In this case the buckle allowed the strap to slip through.

Low Fuel Light While returning from the Xxxx Fire, which was 14 miles south of YYYYYYY, my low fuel light came on. I was approx. five miles south of YYYYYYYY airport. I thought about flying on to the airport, but it occured to me that the nice big meadow below me would be a good place to land while awaiting the fuel truck. The nice thing about flying for the last 37 years is I don''t have to prove anything about my flying skills. So, land and confess, thats what I did. When the fuel truck arrived about a hour later,I topped the fuel tank. It took 173 Gal. The tank holds 217 Gal., leaving about 44 gallons on board, due to uneven ground this could be off five or so gallons. The fuel low light funtioned properly. Better fuel planning is called for on my part. The Bell 212 worked as advertised. I did my part by landing in the big meadow and awaiting the fuel truck. Air attack was over head in just a few min. Thanks Air Attack.

While flying an air attack mission inside an established TFR we encountered a single engine low wing aircraft within 1/2 mile of us and a helicopter working the fire. The unauthorized aircraft was at our altitude, 1500 ft. I asked the Flagler Helibase to notify FAA - they reported back that FAA was tracking the aircraft and would contact the pilot when the aircraft landed. Was later informed that the FAA in Daytona Beach decided to not pursue any action against the pilot since he was on a filed IFR flight plan and inwas a little lost.in At least one other non-fire aircraft was seen in the same area the same day, and aircraft were seen taking off and landing at OMN which the FAA said was fine even within the TFR as long as they were under IFR flight plans, and even without our concurrence or knowledge.

While flying from Hope, Arkansas to Brookhaven, Mississippi the pilot observed the #2 hydraulic warning light. The pilot landed at the closest airport which was Bastrop, Louisiana. The mechanic found that the retaining clip in the #2 hydaulic pump had failed allowing the pump shaft to work its way out of the pump causing loss of hydraulic boost to the collective.

Aircraft was en route from MAF to the Big Trickle Ranch Fire with ATGS as relief for the ATGS currently working the fire. Radio contact was made twice with the Midland TFS dispatcher who informed us we were AFF positive. When it was attempted to contact other Dispatch locations it was discovered that both Technisonic TDFM-136 FM radios were malfunctioning: they did not transmit {or receive, it seemed}. It was quickly seen that the transmit frequencies displayed on each channel were not those that were previously programed. All frequencies for this Incident {West Texas Initial Attack 2011} had been verified by the pilot and ATGS the day before. The radios would not accept reprogramming of the frequencies: and it looked like the transmit frequency was defaulting to the receive frequency when reprogramming was attempted.

A TFR 91.137 violation was reported by helibase manager and helicopter NXXX.  A yellow SuperCub landed at Spanish Fork Airport (U77) and was ingreetedin by the ASGS for Type 1 Team.  I asked the pilot if he was flying over Payson Canyon and Walker Flats.  He admitted he was, but when he saw the helicopter he left the vicinity.  He further stated that he thought the fire was out.  I asked him if he circled over Payson Helibase and he said no, it was a white Husky.  I then asked the NYYYY pilot if he had checked the NOTAMS for TFR's.  He said no, he had not checked any NOTAMS.  I then stated that it was required the myself, as the ASGS, to file a SAFECOM for the incident.  The pilot said inFine, notify the FAAin, inBring 'em on!in.  I further stated that TFRs are in place for your safety, and the safety of fire aviation personnel, both in the air and on the ground.  He then proceeded to turn and walk away.

While conducting water bucket operations I was climbing up the Mule Creek drainage from the Muriel Dip site with a 3000 lb bucket of water in 1/4 to 1/2 mile visibility when I met Air Attack in helicopter flying down the Mule Creek drainage. I took evasive action and moved to the opposite side of the drainage to resolve the airspace conflict. I never heard Air Attack announced his intentions to do a low level recon. It was my understanding that it was an Air Attack, not a HELCO. Per USFS policy and our pilot national safety briefing, we are to follow the Fire Traffic Area airspace layout which establishes Air Attack 1000'' above fire suppression aircraft. Air Attacks low level flying lead to poor radio communication with the other helicopters on the fire resulting in a loss of situational awareness by air attack. This was evident by the number of radio calls air attack made to reestablish where his helicopters were working after his low level flights. The Mule Creek drainage is very narrow. Climbing up hill, in low visibility, with a 1 1/2 ton load and taking action to avoid air attack is unsettling at best. I expect a higher degree of professionalism and flight discipline from the air attack platform.

A HMGB from an exclusive ship parked on an adjacent pad noticed some flame out of the left exhaust during the first start up in the morning. He walked from his pad toward the ship approaching from the rear of the ship, out of view of the pilot, while the rotors were turning. The marshaller was trying to get his attention to stop as he approached the ship. The mechanic was also out by the ship monitoring the start up. I finally got the attention of the person approaching the ship as he made his way towards the front of the ship, within the safety circle and had him progress over to the marshaller. We then went over to notify the pilot, approaching from the front of the ship.

Approx. 1630 hrs Blade 52 was performing bucket water drops using Kennick Dip Site.  On a fill out of the dip tank, the bucket snagged the 11/2in hose that was over the top edge filling the tank.  The ship held hover while dip site helitack personnel successfully released the hose from the bucket.  Operations continued as normal.

This is to doument Tanker 65 being unavailable for dispatch from 1550 to 1740.Panel engine gauges.  The power cable for this was left off the breaker whena new light circuit breaker was replaced in the panel.  A & P mechanic Norberg made the repairs.

While operating the PSD machine on four fast, the operator noticed a ball jam. The ball appeared to be stuck at the bottom of chute 1. The operator, attempted to clear the jam by turning the manual assist wheel. However, the wheel spun freely. After, trying the manual assist wheel, the operator took another look at the sphere placement and noticed that it appeared to be stuck in the chute above the slipper block. During this chain of events, approximately 30 seconds had passed without the ball catching on fire or smoking. The operator then notified the ignitions specialist and pilot that there was a jam in the machine and only three chutes were functional. The operator also stated that the jammed sphere was not igniting. A few more passes were completed, and then the helicopter set down at the helispot to refuel and clear the jam. While on the ground, the hopper and chute were removed from the helicopter to examine and clear the jam. Upon closer inspection, it was noticed that the sphere had half of another sphere stuck to it. The extra half a sphere prevented the sphere from falling down the chute into the slipper block, thereby creating the jam. The jammed sphere was shaken loose from the chute and the machine was reassembled and ready for continued operations.

The second cycle of the day: as the wind velocity picked up on the last dip at the end of the fuel cycle, the PIC felt a ''shuffle'' in the rotor system. He was not sure if it was a strong gust of wind or a weak dampner. After the last drop as we crossed the ridge to HLB, we felt a shuffle again. Upon shut down we found hydraulic fluid to be leaking from where the main rotor damper jam nut should have been.

Aircraft pilot inadvertently released the bucket over the fire returning to reload with water, no one was working this area. There was a problem with the electrical system with the first bucket,there was a change-out to this bucket. The first one had some electrical problem at the remote head. Not sure this caused the problem.

AT 1800 we were dispatched from the Tanker Base to a fire on state protection. The other helicopter on the base NXXX launched before us and as manager asked the pilot to follow them to the fire. After clearing the airport traffic I tried contacting dispatch. I could not establish radio communications with dispatch on the Forest direct frequency that is usually used for aircraft in the valley. I had just arrived as Helicopter Manager and had taken over the Manager position from another HMGB. He had informed me all frequencies were in the aircraft and it was ready to go. I did not check before lifting off, as the Helicopter had flew the day before. What I did not find out till later was that they were transmitting OK, but were not receiving well. I tried a few other frequencies then dispatch did hear me on the state repeater, by then we had established VHF-AM radio communication with Air Tactical and the 4 other Helicopters on the fire. Traffic was getting congested so we landed at the Fire Helibase and found a receive tone programmed into the Direct Frequency we were trying to use in the radio. Another potential problem was that I may have also been using the intercom button rather than the transmit button on the radio controls that may have further hampered communications. When landing on the Helibase the Helibase Manager said I was coming through the Air to Ground frequency while instructing the helitack crew to get the bucket ready on the belly rather than a long line. I called dispatch to let them know we were on the ground with 5 souls and everything was OK. They had been tracking us on AFF, so did not worry about the lack of communications. Dispatch did not have a victor radio to hear that traffic. After talking to dispatch and Air Tactical they all felt that we had enough communications to not cause a safety hazard and the pilot and manager are now more familiar with the radio controls. For the Manager both previous CWN assignments were with restricted aircraft and not passenger hauling, so the manager had not used the TDFM for 6 years. Also dispatch did not have National Flight following capabilities out of the valley which was another one of the frequencies that the manager had tried to use to reestablish communications.

Helicopter 3128G took off on a GPS mission to varrious sites on the Deadman Complex - Some more than 30 miles from the helibase.  After initial radio contact - no position check was received for 20 minutes.  Helibase tried all frequencies, then finally called the forest Dispatch, who reached the pilot on air-guard immediately.  Communications unit agreed to let us (helibase) use command repeater for flight following on more distant flights.HEB2After Helibase manager brought the flight following incident to my attention I checked with the communications unit to use the command repeater channel for flight following to the remote fires in the complex. This request was granted by COML and OPS2 as an up-link was not available for aircraft VHF system.  All pilots on the complex were imidiatly briefed to, inpop upin, gain altitude and call in if a 15 minute check was overdue.  The Guard Blackhawk on the complex is using this system to maintain flight following contact.  De-briefing this evening will again cover this procedure and it will be added to the 220 for tomarrow.ASGS

During operations on the Sand fire this morning as pic of HT-xxx I want to say how well air assets were handled by air attack and especially Bravo x. With minimal radio chatter they set up safety fences and routes for several aircraft in less than prime conditions so that all could maintain operations with very minor delays in any action. I fully understand that this cannot happen all the time but I am seeing a trend by all lead and bravo assets to allow at least the heli- tankers to stay more involved rather than holding someplace else when conditions allow this to happen. I felt this was important to relay and once again very well done.

Pilot was performing backhaul off H 6 to helibase.  Load was released approximately 1.5 miles from helibase approximately .2 miles from Cherry Lake Road downhill.  Pilot hit release when switching to appropriate frequency (tone) for helibase.  Load consisted of approximately 10 gallons of fuel and left over food.  I retrieved both nets and brought supplies to helibase.Note:  Pilot was flying out of left seat and switched hands to switch radio frequencies.

This incident occurred on a proficiency jump mission. The smokejumpers were using a jump spot used frequently for refresher jumps and training. After wind drift was determined with an initial and check set of streamers the 1st stick received a pre-jump briefing and were placed in the door after turning on base for final. Shortly after the command, “On Final, 1500” was given, the co-pilot recognized the aircraft was not at jump altitude and told the pilot to “standby we are not on our altitude. The spotter did not hear this communication as his head was out of the airplane to line up the spot. As the spotter brought his head back in, the slap was given after the command to “Get Ready” and 2 jumpers exited the aircraft. While slapping the 1st jumper the spotter heard “standby” not knowing why it was given. The pilot informed the spotter that they were not at jump altitude. It was estimated that the jumpers went out at 1300’ AGL. Once the correct altitude was determined, jump ops continued.

At approximately 1045 the Wiens HB TOLC overheard radio traffic between helicopter 02W and North Hayman Air Attack (1AB) on 123.725.  Air attack advised TOLC 02W was inbount to Wiens helibase.  At 1050 the base TOLC was in communication with Air Attack as well as helicopter 790, 661, and 48Y who were inbound for fuel.  At 1056 the TOLC confirmed that 790 had landed and was refueling when he noticed 02W hovering over the dirt road at the north end of the deck.  The TOLC tried repeatedly to raise 02W on air to ground (169.200) with no response as well as on victor frequency (123.725 with no response.  The deck manager provided direction on which pad 02W should land on as well as a marshaller.  Just prior to this landing the same pad had been designated for helicopter 12WW who was just departing the Hayman North incident.  12WW had to be diverted to a pad at the south end of the helibase.  At approximately 1120 the pilot of 02W entered the communications trailer asking about a takeoff and landing frequency.  He told TOLC and ABRO that he had been given the frequency of 169.100 as our air to ground.  He was advised of our correct air to ground/TOLC frequency of 169.200 and departed safely.  At 1200 the pilot phoned the Wiens helibase to further clarify frequencies.  He had been give an IAP at Lake George Helibase and assumed the frequencies were the same.  I explained that not only did we have different frequencies but the Hayman North and Hayman South were two distinctly different fires with different teams.  I also spoke with the HCWN and faxed him our 220 and airspace coordination guidelines.

Aircraft arrived at Grand Junction to fuel and load retardant. While shut down in the pit, the parking tender attending to the aircraft spotted a broken center hinge on one of the left main gear doors. Parking tender notified the crew and vendor mechanic replaced the hinge on the spot while aircraft was on hold.

The helicopter departed CKX and upon arrival at the fire several warning lights{particle separator, rpm, engine 1 out, and engine 2 out} became illuminated. The pilot immediately began maneuvering toward the nearest landing spot, but all other gauges read normally & we could still hear the engines running, so we returned to CKX. Enroute all warning lights except one paticle separator light went out. The helicopter landed without incident and the mechanic, IC, and AMD maintenance inspector were notified of the problem.
On Runup to respond to the fire, {#}1 Jet would not start. Taxied back to base informed base manager of problem. AMI was notified.

The County Sheriff - Raven 3 Helicopter, which is not carded by AMD or the Forest Service, entered the airspace of the Peterson Fire without being ordered or making contact with Air Attack or fire personnel. After notifying Air Attack about Raven 3, Raven 3 came up on air/grnd. Air Attack then contacted Raven 3 and gave them the Victor Freq to talk. Air Attack talked to Raven 3 on the Victor and determined that he was not carded and asked him to leave. Raven 3 left the fire shortly after

While descending over a small ridge to deliver a water drop, bucket struck a snag that was sticking up from the top of the ridge. Water immediately began to leak from the side of the bucket. A/C returned to helibase and shut down. Upon inspection, an 8'' tear was found in the sidewall of the bucket. Pilot said that due to an impending tanker drop, Air Attack had asked him to approach his target from a different angle. He thought for a moment about abandoning the drop and clearing the area,then decided to proceed. It was smoky in the area and Pilot did not see the snag. Bucket was on a 100'' line. A/C did not have sufficient height to clear the snag.

WHILE PERFORMING TYPICAL TERRAIN TRAINING RAPPEL, WITH RAPPELLERS ON THE SKID, HORN LIGHT CAME ON, INDICATING POSSIBLE ENGINE FAILURE.  PILOT NOTIFIED SPOTTER, AND SPOTTER GAVE THE SIGNAL TO BRING RAPPELLERS IN.  RAPPELLERS RESPONDED, AND SPOTTER AND PILOT MADE THE DECISION NOT TO CUT THE ROPES, BUT TO FLY THE ROPES BACK TO THE HELISPOT, APPROX. 1/4 MILE AWAY. ROPES FLEW WELL AS THE SPOTTER WATCHED ALL THE WAY BACK, AND HELICOPTER LANDED WITHOUT INCIDENT.  AFTER INSPECTING THE INSTRUMENT PANEL, THE MECHANIC AND PILOT THOUGHT THAT THE SWITCH WAS BAD.  I SPOKE WITH REGIONAL MAINTENANCE INSPECTOR, WHO ADVISED THE MECHANIC TO REPLACE THE SWITCH, AND PERFORM A POWER CHECK.  IF ALL WENT WELL, AIRCRAFT COULD BE PLACED BACK IN SERVICE.  THE SWITCH WAS REPLACED, AND POWER CHECK PROVED CORRECT.  AIRCRAFT WAS MADE AVAILABLE.

On the Oak Flat during the second trip of a troop shuttle into H-1, the helispot manager noticed that the right front door handle was missing. Pilot was notified, and it was verified that the door was secured in the lock position. The pilot cancelled the troop shuttle and flew the aircraft back to helibase. There was no vibrations noted in flight. The mechanic inspected the aircraft to ensure that the handle did not strike any part of the aircraft. It was determined that the door handle spring assembly had failed. Mechanic installed a new handle and maintenance inspector was contacted. Inspector approved the repair and aircraft placed back in to contract availability.

Experienced an inflight loss of gear box oil pressure associated with negative G condition.  Per the Aircraft Flight Manual, the crew shutdown the engine and attempted an air-start.  Oil pressure fluctuation persisted after air-start requiring shutdown #4 prior to an uneventful landing at San Bernardino.

During water dropping operations on the Dolan Fire in division W a sun shade blew out of the back of the helicopter. The ground resources relayed this information to the pilots and they were able to determine it was a sun shade that came out and that the other one was properly secured. Water dropping missions continued as it was determined to be safe to proceed by the pilots.

On duty at 0900, this would be day 3 for mission over site for the Fire within the Zone. At 0920 we did a aircraft systems check before departure and all ops normal, at 0941 we departed airport for the incident with: two souls, 4 1/2 hours of fuel, on a heading 214 degree`s for a 22 min, ETE to the incident. at this point all operations were normal and during this time was calculating the times for relief air attack over the fire. At 12 miles from incident contacted IA helicopter on victor for entry into the airspace of the fire TFR in place, we proceeded into the area at 10,000 dropping to 9,000 ft all ops normal. Established ground contact with operations and IC for operational update and reconfiguration of divisions from the previous day. ordered up fixed wing aircraft: 2 seats for retardant line across the west flank of the fire towards the head. All ops normal. about 3 3/4 hours into the flight the pilot noticed that the fuel use gauge that reads pounds of fuel used per sec was not operational for the right engine, the engine never quit running. The pilot re-calculated the weights and measures for passenger, fuel and cargo, determined that it was either a gauge failure or sending unit and we had plenty of fuel. At 1348 air attack relief was over the fire, did a brief on the tactics and division break downs and handed off to the relief air attack. We proceeded back to The designated base, all ops normal except for the faulty reading of the right fuel/use gauge. Landed safely, notified UAM and Dispatch that aircraft was unavailable due to gauge failure.

May 16, 2001During flight operations over the Hurst Hammock fire the air attack pilot and the ATGS observed an intruder helicopter at their altitude (2000 ft MSL).  Sudden maneuvering was required to avoid collision.  The intruder aircraft then descended to 1500 ft and into the path of the lead plane.  The lead plane pilot then maneuvered to avoid collision and contacted ARTCC and asked if they were working a helicopter in the vicinity of the TFR over the fire.  ARTCC stated that they were not.  Lead maintained visual contact with the intruder aircraft and tanker operations were suspended until the intruder departed.  The aircraft maneuvered unpredictably in the vicinity of the fire, following the participating aircraft.  Positive identification was made that the intruder was a media helicopter and it was determined that he/she was maneuvering to photograph firefighting operations.  At one point the intruder departed the fire to film a fire-fighting helicopter dip water and then he/she chased the firefighting helo at the same altitude to the drop site.  All fire-fighting operations were ceased and the intruder departed.  Lead followed the intruder to class C airspace (approximately 2 mile to the East) and ensured that approach control had radar contact with the intruder aircraft.  Lead then coordinated with the fire and ATC to return to Pensacola Regional Airport to meet with the ARTCC supervisor.

After being dispatched to the 58 Fire I asked for other aircraft assigned to the fire. I was informed two airtankers and air attack 490 were on scene. As per normal operations I tried to contact air attack 10 miles from the fire. I tried at least seven times to contact air attack on the assigned victor frequency for the area. I then tried my air-to-ground frequency assigned to this area with the same results. I finally contacted air attack on Air Tactics. I informed him we would be on victor because of airtankers on the TAC frequency. Air attack asked what the victor frequency was for the area. I informed him several times our pilot could not reach air attack because he was on Kern Co. UHF frequency most aircraft in the Interagency world do not have this capability. Communications are essential to safety. Before aircraft launch they better have a good idea of what frequencies are to be used in what area.
After landing to get the helitorch barrel refilled the pilot got out of the helicopter with the blades still turning and power to them to go to the bathroom.

On 4/24/09 I was dispatched to and flew as a leadplane on the McElroy fire in Texas. The FM number one radio on N224JE would not transmit or receive. I notified the Air Attack over the fire and dispatch. I reprogrammed the number two FM with the fires frequencies, and had positive communications with the number two FM radio. After dropping the tankers, I returned to Midland, TX. I called Maintenance, the COR and the contractor.

At end of shift on 9/12 fuel truck driver refueled helicopter & departed helibase to refill fuel truck in Winnemucca. Helicopter Manager + 5 helitack crewmembers boarded aircraft and flew from Mahogany Helibase to Winnemucca, NV. Upon arrival at Winnemucca Airport, helitack crewmember discovered that fuel cap had not been secured prior to departure & was hanging by chain.

While working the Long Valley incident our aircraft struck two birds. One bird struck the nose of the aircraft, resulting in no damage, one bird stuck the left wing, resulting in a small dent. We left the fire and returned to base to have maintenance inspect the damage on the wing.

We departed KSBA at 0830 on an infra-red flight over the Xxxxxxx incident. The weather at departure was IFR, light wind out of the west, 5 miles visibility and a ceiling of 500’ with tops reported at 1500’with VFR conditions on top. The mission took roughly 45 minutes over the incident, and we returned to KSBA under VFR conditions. Weather at the time of landing was reported at 6 miles visibility with ceilings of 600’ tops remained at 1500’. After receiving an IFR clearance, we were cleared for the ILS 7 approach to KSBA. I armed the approach mode of the flight director while hand flying the aircraft. The flight director did not seem to capture the localizer, and I intercepted the course with the HSI. Glide slope information appeared normal. I informed SBA approach that I may not have a good signal. At this time I was handed to tower and cleared to land. The tower informed me that I was slightly right of course; this appeared to agree with the GPS moving map. However, this information conflicted with both the flight director and the HSI which were showing opposing information and large fluctuations in course corrections. At this time the TWAS issued a “terrain pull up” alert at 1100’AGL. I initiated a missed approach and climbed back up to VFR conditions diverting to KPRB. Some fluctuations in the HSI were observed while in route, and the landing was without incident. R-5 Aviation Maintenance Inspector was called 7/3/2005. R-5 Contracting Officer was called 7/3/2005. The plane was later ferried to KFAT under VFR conditions for maintenance.

During initial takeoff to the response of the fire the helitanker pilot had to make a left turn out to avoid a fixed wing aircraft rolling for takeoff. The helitanker pilot indicated he had made a call out on the unicom frequency indicating his takeoff intentions. Once the helitanker was in a hover preparing to depart, direct to the fire, the pilot noticed the fixed wing rolling for takeoff and had to divert to a left turn out. The helitanker pilot said he had not heard a response from the fixed wing after the unicom call, however at the same time the other radios in the aircraft were active with fire radio traffic. The helitanker was able to continue to the fire without further incident.

On 7/3/2014, the helicopter was ordered from KGCD for bucket support during the IA stage of the Cliff Fire.  The A/C was able to successfully complete one full fuel cycle of bucket support on the incident and was ordered for a fuel and return.  Upon returning to KGCD and while hot-refueling, the A/C experienced a number 1 generator failure.  The pilots and crew noted the issue and shut the helicopter down.  As a result, the A/C was unavailable due to the maintenance deficiency and unable to fulfill the mission request.

After an air attack mission to the XXX Fire, we returned to Boise and landed uneventfully. While taxiing to parking, the right main tire of the landing gear went flat. The pilot tried to steer the plane off the taxiway so as not to block it, however, the airplane could not be maneuvered. Ground control was notified of the disabled aircraft. After conferring with the mechanics and pilot, it was determined that the airplane could not be towed off the taxiway without doing damage to the aircraft. Thus the taxiway was closed via NOTAM. Airport Ops informed us we had to remain with the aircraft while we waited for maintenance to come. The mechanic had to fly in from Twin Falls, so by the time the tire was changed and the aircraft taxied to parking, it was almost 0100, at which time the pilot was off duty 2 hours past duty day.

Helicopter completed 1 fuel cycle dropping PSD balls on burn, and returned to helibase for more balls and fuel. Some of the PSD balls that were loaded were a little discolored, but the potassium promagenate looked and sounded good. Helicopter went back up and dropped more PSD balls, but there was no reaction occuring with the potassium promagenate and glycol. Helicopter returned to helibase and conducted a bench test with the balls. PLDO noticed some of the balls were brittle and were cracking when the needle would inject the glycol. The potassium promagenate was leaking out of the ball before the glycol could react. It was determined the balls were bad. PLDO did bench test with newer box of balls and everything reacted correctly.

On July 13th, 2019 GBCC called right around 2000 to advise that they had a VLAT headed for an RON in Pocatello that they wanted to jettison in Northern Utah. They were originally headed to the 123 fire, but due to the lack of a Lead plane, ended up needing to jettison a load of retardant. Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}1 relayed the lat/long for the South Ridge Promontory Point jettison site to the pilot via radio on the National Flight Follow NFF frequency. The lat/long given was 40 16.9833 x 112 28.4000, which was obtained via a paper sign that hangs behind the aircraft desk. Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}1 went off shift, and briefed Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}2. At 2052, as the T-XYZ appeared over the Great Salt Lake in AFF, he came up on NFF and said that he had passed the jettison point, mentioned Tooele Army Depot, and Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}2 confirmed the coordinates we had with him. He confirmed the coordinates, said that it was behind him and he needed to do a 180 to get there and asked if that is what we’d like him to do. We looked at AFF, and grabbed a GPS point from the program, which was at 41 17.1546 x 112 33.304, was ½ mile directly west of Promontory Point. As he was flying at 357 knots, and the position data was at least 2 minutes old, were unsure of his actual position but knew it would be north of there. We instructed him to turn around and fly back to the confirmed coordinates to jettison the load. He agreed. At around 2110, Aircraft Dispatcher {{{#}}}2 – told me that she thought the two jettison sites signs were mixed up, and that T-XYZ was actually headed to a jettison site called Rock Creek. She showed me AFF which put T-XYZ near the Tooele Army Depot, and showed me a map in CAD of the plotted coordinates of what was at 40 16.9833 x 112 28.4000. It was a chunk of BLM land east of the toe of the slope of the Onaqui Mountains, south of Highway 199, and West of the Tooele Army Depot. After looking at the spot, I was fairly certain that was not a jettison spot as I thought all three of ours were on Promontory Point, however I did not think we had enough time to get the pilot back up to the correct area to jettison before pumpkin time which was in about 12 or 13 minutes. I figured it was safer to have him jettison in the light in an inappropriate area, so that he could still see and avoid things that needed to be avoided, than to have him jettison in the dark and potentially endanger the lives of all pilots on board the aircraft, and possibly people on the ground. After he had moved away from the coordinates, the pilot confirmed that he had dropped his retardant at the given coordinates. We confirmed with the tanker base that the pilot had dropped 9,395 gallons of retardant from an altitude of 500 ft AGL.

Helicopter left Airport at 1453. Upon lifting their second bucket the flight engineer heard a bang noise. He noticed that the {{{#}}}1 engine cowling had popped open. He advised the pilot. The pilot contacted air attack. The pilot then landed the aircraft at the nearest available landing spot. The pilot shut down due to the fact that the engineer could not close the cowling with the helicopter running. The engineer was able to close the cowling and noticed minimal damage. The pilots as well as the engineer felt it would be safe to fly back to the airport at a lower air speed. The pilot then re-spooled and took off en route to Airport. After landing the damage was assessed and the mechanic fixed the butterfly cowling that caused the cowling to come open as well as the hinges that were damaged.

During the first start of the day the oil pressure on the {{#}}1 engine increased beyond normal limits, engine was shut down to determine the problem. Mechanic determined that a transducer replaced the evening before during the phase inspection for the fuel side of the engine was placed on the oil side, which created the high pressure reading. The transducers were placed in the correct locations, the engine ran-up and all pressures were within normal limits. R2 AMI was advised of the situation, maintenance logs faxed and aircraft returned to contract availability status by R2 Maintenance Inspector.

Upon taxiing into pit at Boise, mechanic heard a inwheezingin sound coming from outboard PRT of #1 reciprocating engine. Compression check revealed 10 psi. on cylinder #13. Cylinder was changed. Engine test run & leak checked by mechanic. Aircraft returned to contract availability via telephone call to Gill Elmy, @ 0900 on 8/11/03.

On IA on the Helena Forest the pilot on this 5th bucket drop struck a snag after his drop. The bucket was on a 100’ long line and the previous drops there were no issues. The manager witnessed the strike and told the helicopter to land and inspect the bucket and shut down until notifications were made. There was no damage to the bucket and it was in good working order.

During morning maintenance checks, the fuel filter and engine oil filter were cleaned.  The helicoil was partially extracted.During the first fuel cycle, the PIC reported a chip light and landed in an open field close to the fire.  The plug was cleaned and checked by the A&P.  After a sucessful run up, the helicopter resumed operations at 1300.  At 1308, the PIC reported a second chip light and the aircraft landed in the same field close to the fire.

While taxiing to tie-down, pilot attempted to pass between a parked aircraft and the security fence. Pilot did not notice the gate opening and was watching the opposite wing clearance. Right wing contacted the open gate doing damage to the wing tip and leading edge.

On the evening of 06/30/17, at around 2000, during his post flight inspection, our pilot noticed a small amount of oil under the belly of the aircraft. Upon closer inspection he saw that the oil was coming from one of the hydraulic servos. The mechanic diagnosed the problem as a cyclic servo leaking beyond the acceptable rate. Another cyclic servo was ordered and installed on 07/01/17. During the post test flight the mechanic diagnosed a leaking hydraulic accumulator, and replaced the ``o`` ring fixing the problem.
