A final maintenance test flight was performed, and the aircraft was found to be airworthy. The log entries were sent to the region 3 maintenance inspector who accepted the maintenance and returned the aircraft to contract availability.

I have a concern with what are considered helitack qualified personnel.  I was disturbed by what I observed of another mission while working on the Colter Fire as helitack.My mission was to unload 2 pax plus gear and wait on the helispot to unload a second load of internal cargo.  Comming into the helispot my pilot was advised of winds from the opposite direction than they were actually blowing.  This resulted in landing with a tail wind under full power on an in-ground helispot.  We were 200 lbs below our allowable for an in-ground landing.  While waiting for the next load I checked the backhaul loads that were made up.  I found problems with several loads.  They were located too close to the camping area; the weights were unknown; there was a swivel with a broken gate; a net with only one ring attached to plastic sheeting; and loose items around the loads.  I corrected the problems and secured the loose items.  There was another helicopter providing the fire with blivets and taking the backhaul out.I had my helicopter hold on the ground while I advised the Division Sup. of the load problems, what had been fixed, and the close proximity of the loads to the camp area.  I also talked to the other pilot about the loads before I left the helispot.I was told that there were supposed to be helitack qualified personnel on this fire.  I'm not sure where they were or why the loads were not secured.  I don't know if the loads were manifested.I am concerned that we are putting people through 217 then red carding them as helitack qualified personnel before they have sufficient experience to work on their own, in that capacity, safely, as the job requires.Reviewed and forwarded to BoiseJoe Bates AOBD Bitterroot Complex 805-391-6065

Upon take off, pilot noticed a reduction of torque from the {{#}}2 engine and aborted take off. He returned to the base and upon inspection , the mechanics found several cylinders with pinged spark plugs. They determined that the engine needed to be removed and replaced. The Regional Aviation Maintenance Inspector was notified on this situation.

At approximately 1444 on 7/31/95 the incident commander on the Pilot Fire (X-051) called Elko Interagency Dispatch Center and reported to the aircraft desk that five jets flew directly over their fire at an elevation of 1000 feet AGL and below.  We had a TFR issued to us for this area notam #5/3745.  This was a sensitive area as it was in a MOA and on the edge of a restricted area so we made ample notification both by phone and fax to both the FAA and the military unit responsible for the scheduling of the air space.  I called the Hill Command Post and spoke with the supervisor who said that they had some Air Force Reserve jets flying in the area they were briefed on the TFR in effect for the fire.  He said he would make an investigation and submit a report to the BLM State Aviation Manager.  It was fortunate that the two helicopters doing crew shuttles and bucket work on this fire were both on the ground getting ready to take off at the time of the intrusion.  The jets were flying below some of the crews working the ridges around the fire.  This type of incident has serious potential and is an on going problem with the military.

During preflight inspection of aircraft, problem with electrical system occurred when battery switch was turned on. Igniters came on without igniter switch being turned on. Problem with relay suspected.

During the return flight from a retardant on the Ruiz fire, The AKI call the base to inform us they were returning with an engine that had been shut down due to a problem. They requested the base to notify the airport crash rescue and have them on standby when they landed. The land was completed without incident and the aircraft mechanics met the crew and began trouble shooting. They were removed from service due to a mechanical failure for the remainder of the day.
Upon reading USFS Safecom Ref # 99-358, it should be noted that the crew of Tanker 160 was not involved with observing or notifying the crew of Tanker 64 of any discrepancies on the aircraft.

During pre-flight crew observed Tail Rotor cable #3 sections missing plastic coating. Tail Rotor cable R&R. Rig pins H,Q,& R installed @ Tail Rotor Control quadrants to facilitate removal of cable. Aircraft returned to contractual availability on 13 sept 05 via R-5 Maint, Inspector (G. Burney). TOTAL NON-AVAILABILITY: 6 Hours

Verbatim narrative from the reporting individual follows: ************************************************************************************************************************************************************************** “All narrative from pilot`s statement. I was in a flight of three Fire Boss [aircraft] which had been scooping a section of the Columbia River for one fuel cycle {13+ scoops each}. After returning from a fuel stop, I commenced scooping ops in the same section with the same runs. At the end of my 5th scooping run, it was suspected that I may have made contact with something under the water. I fell out of the circuit and called the Air Attack to advise that I had an issue and would return to Dallesport [airport, KDLS]. Upon calling our [director or maintenance] DOM, I headed to Deer Park [airport, KDEW] for the inspection.”
On 8/17 @ 1300 during a post flight inspection the mechanic noticed some wear in the shear bearing of one of the main rotors. Aircraft made unavailable by manager and mechanic.

Mechanic cleaned torque control unit, found only a small amount of soot, reassembled and conducted test flight. No problem encountered during test flight. Helicopter brought back in service and wound up for a mission with two passengers. Torque split of 20 % registers before any pitch is pulled. Mission is aborted and mechanic gets on for another test flight -- also searches for air leak -- finds no obvious leaks. Aircraft shut down, made unavailable. New torque control unit sent for. Note: Previous Safecoms filed 6/22, 6/23 for same problem. Up to this last incident the vendor's position has been that inisolatedin torque splits of 20% or better are not a grounding condition, poor communication between pilot, mechanic and manager (myself) contributed to some confusion initially over whether problem was a mechanical fault or pilot error (i.e. backing off on #2 throttle accidentally). Pilot error eventually proved not to be the case.

1625 Received call from NXXX inbound to helibase at Noatak - No bubble window; window separated from aircraft in flight; find mechanic so he can check out aircraft.1635 NXXX on Noatak.  Shutdown - Mechanic inspected tail rotor, stabilizer, frame, etc.  No apparent damage to aircraft. Bubble window and seal evidently were pushed away by rotor wash.  Incident Commander stated he saw window seal beginning to separate from upper forward facing corner of door and thought about grabbing it but opted to get pilot's attention first.  Tapped pilot on the shoulder and pointed to window.  Pilot's first thought was that there was another aircraft in the area then saw window quickly separate from door with a bang after it vibrated and shuttered for a moment.  Pilot stated he thought they were still accelerating a bit but had pulled level prior to window separating.  He banked for turn after separation of window but upon noticing glittering pieces (like inchaff falling from skyin) he pulled out of the area to avoid contact with any debris.  Made call to helibase and returned immediately.

Air Attack observed and monitored an unauthorized fixed wing as it entered the XXX TFR executed two circles over Division Papa and departed to the east . The aircraft was identified as white with red markings, including distinctive red circles on the wings, single engine, high wing configuration. Possibly a Cessna. Air Attack was the only Agency aircraft over the fire at the time of the incident. Helibase and dispatch were notified.

ON SEPTEMBER 15 AT APPROXIMATELY 1500 T-xx HAD TO JETTISON HIS LOAD AND RETURN TO SBD WITH A MECHANICAL PROBLEM. AT 1517 T-xx WAS DECLARED OUT OF SERVICE. Pilot ADVISED THE AIRTANKER BASE MANAGER  THAT THE NUMBER 2 PROP GOVERNER WAS STUCK AT 2200 RPM''S.

During routine water dropping on an initial attack fire the pilot noticed an abnormal vertical vibration after filling the Simplex Fire Attack fixed tank. After returning to base the pilot called Simplex to see if there had been any similar problems associated with this fixed tank. Finding that there had been similar issues with other aircraft using this Simplex Tank, corrective actions were taken.

T-XXX HAD JUST LOADED WITH RETARDANT FOR DISPATCH TO LOCAL IA AND WAS PREPARING TO START THE ENGINES. CAPTAIN STOPPED AND REQUESTED TIME FOR UNSCHEDULED MAINTENANCE. A/C WAS ABLE TO START AND TAXI OUT OF PIT AND INTO MAINTENANCE AREA. INSPECTION BY VENDOR MECHANIC FOUND SLOW PROP SYNCH BOX.

Shortly after take off, the helibase was over flown by a Drone and clear the area when the operator was finished with the photo mission and head for the Cheoah Boat ramp.  USFS LEO was called and tried to make contact with the operator but could not locate in the area.  USFS LEO will continue to try and locate for the next few hours @ 1630

On Sunday, September 16, 2012 a type II helicopter was performing sling missions for the Horsethief Canyon Fire and was perceived to fly over a structure with an external long line cargo load. It was reported by a resource not attached to the helibase. The pilot was a relief pilot and had not yet performed missions for the incident. The helibase was located in close proximity to the fire and to the town of Jackson, WY. Retardant operations for the heavy helicopters were co-located with the helibase as well and this all combined to make for a “bottle-neck” area for the helicopters to approach the fire. The pilot was given several sling load missions, and at the same time the helibase launched three other helicopters for recons and water drops. In an attempt to stay out of the congestion, and not being fully aware of the designated pattern, the pilot flew near some structures at the south end of the helibase. The pilot stated and manager and trainee concur that the structures were noted and that the flight path was not directly over them.

A helicopter on a ferry flight to an incident experienced an unpredicted spring squall in northern Nevada. With blowing rain and snow, visability quickly became very limited. Known hazards in the area {terrain and power lines} necessitated an immediate unscheduled landing of the aircraft.

At approximately 1130, while doing water drops on the Crow Peak fire, pilots noticed they started losing utility hydraulic pressure. They executed an immediate precautionary landing in an open field near a road. Air attack and helibase were notified, as were the mechanics. The mechanics drove to the helicopter that was approximately 5 miles from the airport. After inspecting the aircraft, mechanics found an O-ring protruding from the utility filter housing. AMI was contacted.

Helicopter was providing bucket support to an initial attack. They flew two full fuel cycles and upon landing had a chip light come on. The helicopter safely landed and the mechanic checked the chip plug where metal particles were found. They then pulled the oil monitor and found particles on the wafers. The helicopter was then grounded and went unavailable.
Helitanker arrived at the designated dip site, attempted to fill the tank with water, however the snorkel pump was inoperable. The Helitanker than returned to the Banning Helibase.

ON START UP APP RUNNING BUT NOT STARTING ENGINES. APP WAS REPLACED IN THE NIGHT AND STARTED DURING THE NIGHT. IN THE MORNING OF 9/29/06 APP WOULD NOT START. FUEL CONTROL WAS CLEANED AFTER BEING FOUND CLOGGED AND STARTED AT NIGHT. ON THE MORNING OF 9/30/06 APP WOULD NOT START. FUEL CONTROL WAS REPLACED DURING THE DAY AND RAN ONCE AGAIN IN THE NIGHT. 10/1/06 MORNING ALL PARTS FUNCTIONING PROPERLY. 4TH APP CHANGE SINCE JULY 5TH 2006.

IC requested helicopter to come on at 6:00 AM 8/3.  Pilot did not get full ten hours of off duty time.  Helicopter shut down at 2100 on 8/2 came on duty at 0600 hrs on 8/3 which is only 9 hrs. of off duty time.  Pilot is mandatory 10 hrs. of rest.

On the morning of 6/30 helicopter NXXXX was enroute for a routine reconnaissance of Saguaro NP. During recon a crewmember spotted smoke in the Devils Bathtub area. While sizing up the smoke it was realized by the pilot and crew that onboard communications and FM transmissions had been compromised. At this point the pilot diagnosed the issue as a tripped breaker in the avionics. After resetting the breaker and reestablishing communications the breaker popped a second time. Due to the simplicity of the airspace at the time the pilot chose not to reset the breaker a second time, and promptly returned to helibase to further diagnose the problem. Flight time from the smoke back to helibase was less than four minutes. Upon landing the HMBG{t} quickly made a phone call to Tucson dispatch to explain the brief period of lost communications. During this period of time the pilot and manager understood that the ship was still positive on AFF.

On 8/31/2018 at approximately 1700 helicopter was dispatched to two new starts in the Uncompahgre Forest south of Grand Junction Colorado. Weather for the afternoon was high temps in the upper 80s and scattered thunderstorms. After initial size-up the plan was to land and insert 4 Helitack to take action on both single tree fires. An unimproved landing zone was selected by the pilot and manager. As the ship descended the pilot leaned out the bubble to determine if the slope was too great for landing. At about 5 feet above the tree level the pilot requested rear right crewmember to open the door and check for rotor clearance. After checking and clearing the main rotor he looked back to check the tail. The tail rotor was already in contact with the upper 1/3 branches of a large juniper tree. Crewmember immediately reported ``your tail is in the branches`` at which time the pilot aborted the landing and gained altitude to access for vibrations and airworthiness. The ship departed the location for an emergency landing site about 2 miles away. The ship landed safely and shut down, upon inspection both tail rotor blades had received damage to the outer area {side} of the blades and not to the leading edge but the damages were beyond tolerance and the ship was out of service. The tail rotor blades and hub were replaced the next day. After a maintenance flight and approval from the Aviation Maintenance Inspector the ship was returned to service.

While refueling, mechanic noticed that a RPM Govenor (Torque control unit)was off it's norm.  Aircraft called us @ 1533.  Pilot & mechanic requested the removal of aircraft to Kalispell in order to keep dust out of the engine while maintenance is being performed.  Departed @ 1634.

At 1345 local while working the Arlene fire in southern AZ, we received a low hydraulic pressure annunciator followed by a master caution warning. As my crew and I went through the emergency procedures checklist the annunciator extinguished and re-illuminated 2-3 times, eventually coming on steady after a few minutes. A relief aircraft was ordered and we began preparing to return to Libby ATB. The return flight and landing was uneventful with the landing gear extending normally. Upon exiting the aircraft I noticed hydraulic fluid dripping from the left flap. Further inspection showed hydraulic fluid under the left wing and inside the left wheel well. After removing the servicing cover I noted the hydraulic fluid level was below the add mark with approximately ½ inch of fluid remaining.

We departed from Missoula for a mission on the Wood Lake Fire.  After flying a fuel cycle we went to an established helibase in Augusta to get fuel from a sister helicopter from the same helicopter company.  This helicopter is a T3, the fuel truck used to fill the helicopter is for a T2.  The re-fueling hose for the T2 is larger than the one used for the T3.  The company has an adapter that slides over the nozzle, which they used in this case.  The individual fueling the helicopter was carded for T2's but not T3's.  After fueling and while pulling the nozzle out of the fueling port, the adapter slid off and fell into the helicopters fuel tank.  It was noticed and reported immediately to the manager.  The helicopter was non-operational and required the mechanic to drive from Missoula to fix the problem.

Helicopter-XXX was providing water delivery support to the fire with a bucket and 150` longline. The fire was staffed with three firefighters & the IC was directing the helicopter bucket drops. 6 Helitack personnel were staffing the Helispot, approximately 4 miles Southwest of the fire, in support of the water delivery mission. The helicopter had established a dipsite approximately 2 miles Southwest of the fire in the New River and had used this dipsite during the previous fuel cycle, delivering 6 bucket drops to the fire. At 1810 hours, Air Attack notified the HMGB on Air to Ground that the helicopter`s bucket struck a snag & the helicopter would be flying back to the helispot to assess the damage. The helicopter had already completed 6 drops from this dipsite during the current fuel cycle. Upon arrival at the helispot, the HMGB assessed the damage to the bucket, conferred with the pilot and both agreed that the damage could not be fixed at the helispot. The HMGB also inspected the longline, belly hook & helicopter & found no damage. The pilot stated that the helicopter was operating fine & the helicopter & crew returned to base. Air Attack was notified & due to the time of day & decreased fire activity, the helicopter & crew were released back to their Helibase. Upon arrival at base, the mechanic determined that the bucket would have to be sent in for repair.

On 05/13/2006 at 0830 an Air Tanker was ordered to a fire. 08:30 Air Flight crew was notified and Mix Master was notified and in route. 09:00 loading operations were in progress when the ATBM (trainee) contacted the ATBM on site and informed him that there was a problem with the retardant loading operation. While loading the aircraft the Mix Master noted a problem with the refractor readings on the specific gravity of the retardant mix being loaded onto the Air Tanker. After several attempts by the ATBM (T), ATBM and the Mix Master determine the retardant specific gravity. It became apparent that the load of retardant was not mixed with water and was being loaded with HVR concentrate retardant. Loading procedures were terminated at approximately 22096.22 lbs of retardant (2400gls). Air Tanker was spooled up and waiting for confirmation on launch. ATBM discussed the situation with the Air Tanker Pilot and informed him that the load was straight HVR concentrate. After confirming with the Forest Liaison Officer, ATBM (T), and Mix Master the ATBM determined that the Air Tanker return to the pit, shut down and off load the HVR concentrate. The ATBM then initiated a SAFE COM and began notifying the proper personnel. Personnel contacted: Forest Aviation Officer, Vender COR, Vender Structural Engineer, National Forest Aviation Liaison, and Aircraft Maintenance Specialist for Region, Region Safety Officer and Retardant Specialist. Safety briefings were conducted on base and documented.
No audio from Radio 5-Guard 2-CDF AG/1. Cycled radio on/off but no audio for the duration of the incident. See attached narrative on TDFM-136B Failure Report.

The pilot intended to taxi the aircraft to a hangar due to expected weather. We had just parked at the tanker base for a few minutes before deciding the hangar was necessary. The plastic cone was placed in front of the propeller by ramp personnel and was not noticed. The propeller struck the cone.

During return flight back to Rhinelander Airport from prescibed fire support,  engine chip light indicator light came on and stayed on.  The chip light came on three miles from the Rhinelander Airport.  Pilot and Helicopter Manager deteremined that it would be safer to land at the airport than try and find an immediate landing spot.  This was due to the heavily wooded and marshy landscape of the surrounding area, time of day, and the close proimity of the airport. N2HX landed the Rhinelander Airport without incident and was shut down.  The aircraft mechanic immediately upon shut down inspected the engine chip detector plugs and found an significant amount of small metal shaving on both plugs.

During a flight from FBK to BTT one of the 2 FM radios {Technosonic TDFM-136A}showed an error message. The problem could not be resolved.The flight crew was able to maintain safe operations with one FM radio.  AMD technical services was notified.  BLM HOS 7/17/10
Primary Inverter Inop on start up. No Go item.

After landing with a long taxi to the loading pit, with a strong 90 degree left cross winds on a 100 degree day, the right brake over heated and became in-operable. The aircraft was unable to taxi out of the pit. The brake fluid became over heated in the brake caliper and the line was vaporized.
While directing fire suppression activities with heli-tanker 42 and ground units at 1000ft agl, a single engine a/c passed underneath us at approx 800ft agl 200ft seperation from the air attack a/c.

While in transition from the Airport to the fire the snorkel for the Isolair fixed tank impacted the right underside of the tank. The snorkel appeared to be ''''wagging'''' much more than witnessed the previous two days flown missions. The crew stated the snorkel had been removed, and the hydraulic lines had been retaped to the hose portion of the snorkel the evening before. The new position the lines occupy caused the snorkel to react aerodynamically differently. The temperature as well was much warmer and they believe the snorkel hose was made much more pliable {less rigid}.

Dispatched from MSO to this targetInitial check in with air attack 91N who was in the process/transition of inhanding offin mission to inBoulderin air attack.  Objective re: working head of fire discussed by myself with A/A 91N with Boulder A/A monitoring, conversation on air to air victor frequency.This objective unachievable.  A/A 91N leaving for Helena re: fuel.  Discussed with both A/A secondary objective re: structure protection.  BD 22 descends into target area to determine feasibility of action.BD 22 team (Brunsguard/Gayowski)held tankers 09 and 46 off to west while recce done at lower elevation.  No clear exits found re: terrain and smoke conditions.  BD 22 exits up draw-draw inmarginalin for BD and unsuitable for Loaded tanker or tanker with mechanical problem.BD 22 - advises Boulder air attack and tankers 09 and 46 that the mission is to be aborted due to unsafe conditions.Boulder air attack contacts tankers 09 and 46 directly and asks them to go in and to attempt to drop.  exit described was to infollowin the highway.  Both 09 and 46 declined request. Lead 11 arrived overhead and supports/reaffirms BD22 decision to abort mission.  Tankers and BD 22 sent to Helena to hold.

While conducting ATGS operations on the Sawmill Incident, a light helicopter entered the TFR unannounced. Unable to contact the helicopter on the assigned VHF_AM Frequency of 122.425, I contacted East Idaho Dispatch Center and asked if they knew of a local helicopter that might be in the area, they responded that it was probably helicopter xxx and it should be on VHF-AM 136.225. I contacted the helicopter on 136.225 and asked why they didn't contact me on the assigned 122.425 frequency prior to entering the TFR. The pilot responded that East Idaho Dispatch Center had told him the fire frequency was 136.225 for the Sawmill fire, which was incorrect, and had cleared him to enter the fire area. I contacted EID and informed them they had given the helicopter the wrong frequency and asked them why they had cleared the aircraft to enter into the TFR. Their response was that they were told that there were no aircraft on the incident. I asked who told them that. After pausing, their response was ''you never notified us that you were going to fly'', I responded that my instructions were to flight follow with the Pocatello Helibase and also to keep the Air Tanker Base appraised of my status which I had complied with.  A review of the radio log at Pocatello ATB confirmed that EID was notified at 0834 that I had launched and was en-route to the Sawmill Incident.

A Type I IMT was ordered for the Kinishba Fire on the Ft. Apache Indian Reservation. An ATGS on the team arrived at the Show Low Aiport near the fire with instructions to meet up with an ATGS aircraft.  This occurred.  The ATGS was given orders to launch on a mission.  The pilot of the aircraft infromed the ATGS that he had been ordered by his company to not let this particular ATGS fly in the aircraft.  Due to the need for aerial supervision over the incident, a leadplane and leadplane pilot, based at the same airport, was used for the ATGS assignement.  Later that afternoon the company agreed to fly the ATGS in their aircraft.

Upon attempting to land after conducting night aerial ignitions the aircraft collided with a tree, tilted and fell about 15' to the ground. The aircraft incurred broken props, broken arm locking tabs, and a broken landing leg. The Ignis housing was cracked around the 3D printed plastic main body. The pilot stated that he had lost perspective of the aircraft position and the pad. He also said that he could not see the tree line as it blended in with the darkness. There was very little natural illumination and we were using truck headlights to light up the pad.

Heli Tanker XXX was to do water drops in support of the Panhead fire. The first time into the dip site, as HT XXXZ was taking on water the aircraft``s tail drifted to the right and the tail rotor clipped the top of a small new growth pine tree. HT XXX then released the water and hovered the aircraft to feel for vibrations. The tail rotor looked unaffected and the track was good and could not feel or hear anything wrong. There was no landing area nearby, so HT XXX flew back to the TLH Helibase, a distance of 17 miles. At the time of the strike, HT XXX was within HIGE and HOGE limitations.

While doing a recon of Fire number 202, the Master Caution light came on indicating right fuel boost pump malfunction.  In flight troubleshooting revealed correct pressure but despite corrective efforts caution light remained illuminated.  After that we elected to make a precautionary landing at the nearest airport.

While returning from a water drop, the cargo hook manual release cable housing apparently failed at the hook.  The twisting action of the cable (50') combined with the angle of the hook allowed the cable to trip the hook release (manually) and drop the bucket with line (from hook). Upon landing, inspection revealed a broken fitting at the hook insert and further hook operations were suspended for the day. The bucket sustained three broken inarmsin.  There was no further apparent damage to bucket or cable.Indicated airborne wind speeds differed from ground speeds by 30-40 knots at the time of the incident. The bucket assembly landed some 300-400 yards east of the fold-a-tanks at the dip site.  The assembly fell from approximately 150-200 feet landing in an area with no equipment or personnel.

H-XXXX was on short final to H-2 with a slingload of meals. Winds were S/SW 7-10 MPH with gusts to 15. Pilot stated he had just raised the protective cover on release switch when he encountered a severe updraft. In compensation with collective, pilot inadvertently hit the release switch causing the load to fall approximately 20-30 feet to the helispot. The pilot knew what had happened immediately and notified the helibase manager upon returning to the helibase. There were no ground personnel in the vicinity of the dropped load. Damage to the load consisted of several broken cubies and a container of salad dressing.

During a 50 hour inspection the FBO mechanics noticed one bolt missing and one bolt loose on the rear mount of the front turbo charger. The bolts were replaced with bolts that had holes for safety wired and both were safety wired in place.

While performing Ramp operations on retardant loading pit #1 xxxxx Incident A white Ford Explorer identified as the Airport manager entered the ramp operations area without contacting airbase personnel which constitutes a safety violation. The vehicle drove east to west then west to east and appeared to be spraying weeds in the cracks of the concrete. The ramp area is clearly marked with a large red painted border with “restricted area” stenciled in large letters After the props stopped turning the vehicle departed the ramp operations area. A Ramp manager, I normally would be able to confront intruder during ramp operations, however I was committed to parking the Air Attack in front of the operations building. The two parking tenders where committed to parking the two other tankers and could not leave the aircraft unattended.
Pulling out of dip site and just getting above tree line when a EMS HELO overflew our helicopter by 300 feet.
At 1222 the Ridge Helibase had a TFR infraction from a C-130 military aircraft. The infraction was reported by air attack. The TFR was set for Surface to 12500 at a 5 mile radius.

Upon landing while taxiing back to FBO, the left engine lost power. Pilot restarted the engine and we went to parking. To check if the battery was failing, he attempted to restart. It was not happening. I asked if the aircraft was airworthy and the pilot said before we launch he will have the battery checked for a minor problem like corrosion, etc that could be cleaned. Mechanic looked at the output and determined it required replacement.

At approx. 1430 hours while conducting sling cargo missions to H-1 on the Fire, the winds at the ASOS, 27 NM to the north was reporting winds from the southeast approx. 26G36. The pilot approached the cargo area at H-1 and deposited the load onto the cargo area, after the load was on the ground there was gusty wind conditions that caused the pilot to re-grip the cyclic, while re-gripping the cyclic the pilot inadvertently allowed his small finger on his right hand to contact the electric belly hook release. The line departed the aircraft and fell onto the top of the load. There were no personnel near the load or in danger of being struck by the falling line. The pilot contacted the personnel at H-1 and advised he would land and they could look at the nine-pin attachment at the hook and determine if it looked like there was any damage. It was determined there was no damage, the pig-tail and line were reattached to the belly hook, then the {{#}}1,2,3 tests were completed with the hook operating as required. the pilot then took off and returned to the Helibase to inspect the pig-tail and continue operations. Determination was made that a casual factor in the incident was the absence of a guard over the electric belly release on the cyclic. Some aircraft have it and some don`t.

On August 16, on take-off roll to the One Eye fire, from Grand Junction, Lead 2-3 ordered the FAA tower to abort my take-off. I heard the call to the tower, on the FAA VHF frequency, possibly to get around the insterile cockpitin procedures, and disregarded it. I did not believe there was proper authority from the lead plane, I had proper dispatch from Western Slope Dispatch, Lead 7-2 was low on fuel but waiting for me, and I was already approximately 75 knots into the takeoff roll. I momentarily hesitated to abort to consider my options. Since I was under the control of the FAA at the time, and I determined that I could SAFELY abort the takeoff, I chose to abort. The takeoff was safely aborted, not for any traffic problem or mechanical problem with the aircraft. It happened the Lead 2-3 thought I was being dispatched to a fire she had been on and had left. I was in fact going to a different fire. This raises some serious safety questions. Does the lead plane have the authority to override a dispatch order? Does the lead plane have the authority to override proper orders and instructions from FAA at an FAA controlled airport? Have I relinquished my authority as pilot in command on my aircraft to the lead plane pilot? What happened to the sterile cockpit procedure? Even if I had been going to the fire that lead 2-3 was on, I feel strongly that it would have been much safer for me to continue the takeoff, get proper cancellation orders and return for landing. This precludes the necessity of making snap decisions based on the decisions made by others than the pilot in command at a critical time in the operation of the aircraft. It should be understood that this is not a personal attack on Lead 2-3. This situation may have arisen with other lead plane pilots. I think that it is imperative that this situation be resolved in the interest of flight safety, and clarification of chain of command and authority.

Helicopter was tasked with flying three FBAN personnel on a reconnaissance mission from Ukiah Helibase to the August Complex West Incident to analyze the fires' behavior and gather information needed to plan future suppression efforts and update maps. Aircraft was tasked with this mission immediately after leaving Eel River Helibase, and landing at Ukiah Helibase, where the pilot received a briefing from the Helibase Manager, a map, and an IAP. Multiple frequencies in the Air Ops Summary (ICS 220) were incorrect, so an updated list of the correct TX and RX frequencies for those channels was given to the pilot before departing Ukiah Helibase and the pilot was advised the frequencies were correct on the Incident Radio Communications Plan (ICS 205) were correct. Shortly after departing Ukiah Helibase, West HELCO attempted to cancel the aircraft due to poor visibility, but could not establish communications with them. After failing to reach the helicopter on the radio, West HELCO contacted Ukiah Helibase Box and asked that they try to contact the helicopter and relay that they had been canceled due to poor visibility. Ukiah Helibase Box was unable to establish communications with them either. They were finally reached via cell phone with West HELCO's instruction to return to base, and the information that there was a failure to establish communications via radio was relayed. The helicopter returned to Ukiah Helibase and began to troubleshoot the communications failure.

We were on a detection flight and received a call from XXX Dispatch to proceed to a smoke report in the north Bridger Mountains. It was described to us as being above the old Morgan Cemetery, a place known to both myself and the observer. This info indicated that the smoke had been called in by an observer on the ground. We were also given a Lat/Long, which was reported to have come from a civilian aircraft. We proceeded to the location and quickly spotted the smoke, flew to it and began to orbit at approximately 1000 ft agl for a size-up. After a few orbits around the fire, we suddenly saw a glider at our altitude also orbiting the fire at very close range to our aircraft. I broke off to avoid the risk of a mid-air collision, flew some distance away and called XXXX tower to ask if they were in contact with the glider. They stated that they had been and in fact the glider was the entity that had called in the Lat/Long coordinates but they were no longer in radio comm with the glider at that time. With no way to contact the glider we departed the incident. After landing, I determined who was flying the glider and called that individual to talk about the dangerous situation that had developed. He stated that after calling in the smoke and flying away, he had returned to it to check it out. I thanked him for calling in the smoke with a Lat/Long position but suggested that in the future he should then remain clear as some agency aircraft were probably going to show up in short order.

On 11/8/2008, around 1440, we were dispatched to the xxxxx fire {ia}. after first fuel cycle, about 1615, the helicopter went back to the fueling site to hot fuel and retun to the fire. when the ship landed it was dicovered that the ''deadman'' switch on the fuel tender was not working and could not pump fuel to the aircraft. the aircraft shut-down meaning it had a 30 minute cool down period before startup. the plan was to have the fly crew picked up on the line by 1640 so we could return to home base before cutoff. with the ship being down the crew was flown off the fire in another aircraft. When I arrived at the fueling point the pilot informed me that they were still trying to fix the fuel tender. the solution was to remove and bypass the switch. shortly after 1700 we were able to fuel to the aircraft. this resulted in us leaving the fire later then expected and landed at home base after cutoff.

On the previous day while running up the helicopter to do bucket work, theengine popped four times.  The pilot evaluated the situation and determinedit was safe to continue with the mission.  The problem was thought to be afaulty bleeder valve.  This valve was replaced that evening.  On the followingday,during a crew shuttle the pilot noticed a split in the I TT and the N-1gas producer.  Two power checks were performed and were within limits.  The decision was made to ground the aircraft.  Further inspection from the mechanic showed the new bleeder valve to be in-operative.
A light airplane flew northwest to southeast over the Gramm Helibase.

While on a forest recon flight the AOBS entered the TFR (6/6283) over the Waldo Mtn. fire.  The IC contacted the AOBS by district frequency and asked if they were the aircraft circling the fire.  The AOBS never requested permission to enter the TFR from Dispatch or the IC.  There were no other aircraft in the TFR at that time.

Helicopter left Hello HB in the AM for bucket work on the fire. Helicopter XXX returned to HB for  fuel and return to the fire, when the pilots pulled up on the collective they noticed that they were not getting a torque reading for the {#}1 engine. It was discovered that a torque sensor had broken and could only be MEL`d if no spare part was present and/or no mechanic was available to replace it. 1 spare part and 5 mechanics were present, so an hour and a half later the fire received several thousand gallons of retardant.

Tanker departed GCD with instructions from the Ramp Manager to hold at his discretion with active lighting cell west of airport.  The PIC studied his radar and decided to depart with an immediate turn to the north.  Airbase operations were then shut down through the dispatch center until the storm passed. Twenty minutes later on way back from incident 089 dispatch informed the Tanker of storm near airport: pilot circled several times and observed VFR conditions and proceeded to land without incident. The SEMG visited with visiting a/c SEMG and received follow-up phone call from pilot.

After refueling in Ely Nevada, XXX was enroute back to Battle Mountain Nevada.  Two minutes outside of Battle Mountain the pilot and I noticed the aroma of fuel.  Upon landing in Battle Mountain, we were in the process of parking the aircraft and noticed a fuel leak on the right side engine.  The pilot shut down the aircraft and made his inspections.  The problem appeared to be a broken fuel line.  The pilot then made calls to his company and mechanics.  I notified Battle Mountain Dispatch, WGBCC and Boise Smokejumpers Duty Officer.  Returned to service 7/1/03.  All repairs done at 0800.

During a Recon flight over mulitple fires in Zion National Park, while inflight around 1720 helicopter inpacted a small black bird on the co-pilot front window. The bird caused no damage other then a smear mark on the window. Pilot returned to helibase for shut down. Pilot and mechanic inspected the aircraft no damage was found.

Upon coming in to land at the airport the convex cargo mirror came off approximately 10-15 feet above the ground. The mirror bounced off the ground and rolled forward onto the asphalt under the rotor wash. After the helicopter landed and shut down, a further inspection of the mirror bracket arm revealed that the attachment point had snapped off where the mirror was mounted. A discussion with the mechanic determined that the mirror and bracket arm were likely the originals from the helicopter`s manufacture dated 2001. The articulating arm was subjected to the normal vibrations of the aircraft, which over time may have weakened the connection point.

On April 13, 2010, helicopter was hired by NICC for the Walker fire on the Coronado NF. Flight plan was received and faxed to the affected dispatch offices. Upon getting word from NICC of actual departure from airport at 0715 on 4/14, SWCC noticed AFF was not active for the helicopter. SWCC instructed Albuquerque and Silver City Dispatch Centers to attempt to contact the helicopter on both NFF {168.150} and Air Guard {168.625} to confirm positive contact. These attempts were not successful. Silver City Dispatch Center transmitted to the helicopter that AFF was not active and positive contact via radio needed to be established. The helicopter was scheduled for a fuel stop in Safford, AZ before proceeding to the helibase in Tucson, AZ. AFF became active approximately 1 hour after takeoff and approximately 30 minutes prior to landing at Safford, AZ. Tucson Dispatch was briefed on the situation and instructed to brief the assigned helicopter manager on the situation. SWCC confirmed with Tucson Dispatch that positive radio contact was not established during the flight from Safford to Tucson either. Once on the ground at Tucson helibase, Tucson communicated with the pilot that no further flights would be conducted until positive radio contact could be established.

This was the first mission after audio panel{s} were replaced in aircraft. Experienced problems with radio operations when both audio panels transmit selectors were not in the same transmit position while using the AM radios. After identifying the issue and a work around, continued to the incident. On scene was unable to receive on the primary AM radio in either pilot or air attack audio panels. FM communications was ops normal. Departed incident and recovered at departure airport.

While flying Air Attack over the fire we had an electrical system failure. We lost all radios and gps units. We left the fire unable to communicate with the ground resources, air resources and dispatch. While in route back to the tanker base the pilot was able to restore power by switching off the air conditioner and resetting both alternators.

After doing bucket work the pilot landed to reconfigure the helicopter for crew shuttles. When the pilot spooled down the ``Restart Fault`` light came on. The pilot informed the crew and canceled the flight. As the pilot shut down the ``Fadec Degraded`` light also came on. The pilot checked the fault code via the FADEC MX button, which indicated a problem with ``Potentiometer Metering ``. This is the second time the aircraft had that problem.

While doing bucket work on the west fk fire, the TDFM-136 radio locked up and wouldnt transmit or receive. Pilot notified air attack on the AM radio and returned to helibase. Pilot and mechanic trouble shot and recycled the radio numerous times. And could not duplicate.

At approximately 1830 local, after takeoff from french valley {f70}, Ca, right engine indications showed 0 itt, increasing fuel flow, and lowering torque values. When power was reduced, the engine failed due to a massive fuel leak. AN emergency was declared with march gca, emergency engine shut-down procedures were completed, and an uneventful single-engine landing was accomplished at french valley.
On take off from MSO, Chip Light came on. Tanker aborted load at the designated east area and landed at MSO.

On 06-07-2003 when I was flight following with H-332, I could hear the ship's radio when they lifted off the ground in Kingman. Then on first check on status at 15 minutes they could not hear me and went to E-241 to have them relay there lat and long. and to have them E-241 relay. I could hear the ship and the engine, but the ship could not hear me when I tried to get back to the ship E-421 could hear me. For the rest of that mission the radio on the ship would break squelch but I could not hear any voice. I called the SEAT base in Kingman to have them check out the radio when they land for fuel. When the ship was returning to Kingman for fuel I heard H-332 and the ship copied me. Then there was radio problems again at the next 15 min. check in on return for fuel. Over the course of the day there was no radio bleed over from the law enforcement side that I heard. And if they where using the Mt. Lemon repeater they did not tell me or did not hear, and I stayed on the Kingman simplex on Hayden peak.

After returning to Elko from the Sadler Fire the mechanic at the vendor'sdiscovered hairline cracks in the flanges connecting the tailboom to the fuselage.  Helicopter NXXXX was taken out of service, the district Aviation Manager, OAS, and Bell Helicopters were contacted.  The flanges were replaced and the helicopter repaired, inspected and returned to service on 13 August.
on landing rollout on rwy 16, struck 2 small birds. One on windscreen, one outboard of {{{{#}}}}4 engine ldg edge

Pilot of Tanker noticed operational issue with number 2 engine enroute to Air Tanker Base from the Fire. Upon return to Tanker Base, mechanic detected a crack in the PRT hood cover. Maintenanace Inspector was notifed.
#1 recip hydraulic pressure transmitter failed leading to a complete hydraulic ststem failure. Emergency landing was made at Moody AFB. Repairs were made with aircraft available with in 15 minutes.

While preparing to make a drop on the SW flank of the fire, T458 lined up for his drop. When he asked me if he was on the right line, I informed that he was not on the right line and to hold his drop. 458 did as requested, then proceeded to go around. At this time he was heading into rising terrain and had to drop a portion of his load in order to make the go around. After the go around he made the correct drop with the remainder of his load and was sent back to PIH for a load and return. There were no further incidents for the remainder of the incident. - RA Stilliha ATGS-Discussed and reviewed with pilot. He had nothing to add. -B Hazen SEMG-

Upon starting aircraft for initial attack, pilot reported to HMGB that torque gauge was not operational {reading zero}. Pilot and HMGB agreed to shut down aircraft. Pilot and vendor personnel began trouble shooting issue. HMGB notified R1 maintenance inspector.

While on a fire reconnaissance mission on 27 July 2010, the reconnaissance aircraft encountered hail in flight: resulting in a series of small dents to the leading edge of the wings and horizontal stabilizer.  There were several areas of falling precipitation in the area, and a route was selected to avoid obvious areas of heavier rain.  Despite flying through an area of relatively light precipitation, sufficient hail was present to damage the skin of the airplane.  The encounter was brief, and with clear air ahead, the decision was made to proceed on course.  No damage was detected in flight, and the mission proceeded normally.  Upon landing, the damage was noticed and the vendor owner and company mechanic were notified.  On the morning of the 28th July 2010, the vendor owner notified the pilot of the manufacturer specifications for surface damage, and inspection revealed that some of the dents exceeded those specifications.  Once this determination was made, the airplane was taken out of service and dispatch, the Unit Aviation Officer, and the Regional Aviation Maintenance Program manager were notified.

HT XXX mission to Div F for water drops. Manager requested power check prior to departing helibase since it was due. Pilots performed powerchcek, then was conducting flight control check when they noticed they did not have full controls, only forward/aft, no lateral. Pilots, shut down. mechanics checked system. Second start-up the problem still persisted. Pilots then shut down and aircraft down due to mechanical at 1400 due to lost of flight control servo. Manager called AMI at 1415 to inform him aircraft was out of service: COR called. Vendor sent for new part and replaced by 2130. 8/27: Mechanic informed Manager of servo control replacement: they had been put back in service by vendor maintenance. Pilots performed check on the ground and then performed short 0.2 hr test flight in which all controls found to be functioning properly. Copies of maintenance log forms were emailed to AMI: manager called AMI and aircraft put back to availability at 0930 by AMI. Helibase manager and COR informed of aircraft availability.
T-XX captain informed base manager they needed a one hour maintenance break to check a fuel leak on {{#}}2 engine.

At 1046MST, Airtanker stopped in load pit #1 at PRC Airtanker base, for reload to Pack Rat Fire, 0304.  Airtanker had just returned from a day off yesterday, when mechanic changed out oil cooler on #1 engine.  Mechanic was concerned about a very minor oil leak.  Replacement oil cooler was not functioning properly, the way Pilot felt it should, so after consultation with mechanic, Pilot took Tanker out of service and mechanic swapped out oil cooler for the one replaced yesterday.  At 1222, pilot advised they were ready to return to service.  We contacted R-5 Maintainence Inspector who requested copy of log book entry.  Back in service 1240 MST.
The tanker base telephoned an off time to dispatch of 1530 with an ETA to fire of 1555 hrs. Pilot did not check in and flight follow with dispatch center.

On 7/31, an HMGB while reflecting on his assignment, that was nearing an end, realized that he had not seen a first time fire assignment pilot wearing a PFD on two bucket missions. This, despite the fact that the helicopter was dipping from a canal and the very edge of a lake. The IHOG requires wearing a PFD on all bucket missions. The HMGB became mission oriented {IA and suppression} and the requirement for the PFD. Lesson learned: step back and think about all requirements before proceeding.

While flying an air attack mission on the Big Elk Fire, the pilot noticedthat the aircraft was suddenly making an unusual noise.  After looking at thenose wheel mirror, he determined that the nose wheel door had partially opened.  He cycled the landing gear to see if the gear door would close.  It didn't.  We then called Hermit Helibase to ask someone to stand out in the open as we flew overhead, in order to ascertain that the doors were actually stuck in a partially open position.  The person confirmed that the doors were part way open.     The pilot determined it was not an emergency and would not affect the aircraft's aerodynamics.  He reduced the airspeed and we completed the mission.  On landing at Jeffco Airport, further inspection by the pilot revealed a gear door hook was partially broken.  After talking to a company maintenance person, it was determined that the problem would not cause an unsafe flying condition and that the part would be replaced when the aircraft returns to it's maintenance base on July 28, 2002.     After talking by phone with Company on July 31, 2002, they report that the replacement part has been installed in Nxxxx, and the problem has been repaired.

During a longline operation the low oil pressure warning light came on.  The pilot returned the aircraft to Fremont County Airport, Canon City, Colorado.  The mechanic drained the oil and cleaned the oil filter and then replaced it with new oil.  After, this procedure was finished the oil pressure returned to normal and the low oil pressure light went out.
Half of the plastic strobe cover on the vertical fin was misssing.

At approximately 0830 Division Alpha notified field operations of a drone intrusion over the fire area all aircraft operations were suspended for 1 hour after the drone was last seen. All drone intrusion protocols were followed and the air operations were resumed at 0930. The local dispatch, IC {T}, helibase manager, and local law enforcement were contacted. There was no contact made with the operator of the drone.

On July 25, at approximately 1100 hours, at the Idaho City Helibase in Idaho City, the helicopter took off from helibase on a bucket mission assignment and returned shortly thereafter reporting a mechanical issue. Per the mechanic, ``Pilot stated to me the roll channel on the AFCS had a force feedback or hold with the beeper trim setting in the off position. Normal operation of the beeper trim off would be no force or hold in any of the channels. System should have free movement.

Approaching SBD for a load and return to the XXXXX Fire, TXXX had a bird strike on the underside of the right wing with damage to the outer flap tab hinge fairing. There was no damage to the actual mechanism.

While on an aerial recon, the helicopter was sent to investigate a fire, it was determined the helicopter would need fuel prior to an initial attack operation as the helicopter was dispatched approximately some 60 - 70 miles distance.  The helicopter landed at the Roswell, NM airport refueled and attempted to start, upon start-up the helicopter engine would not ignite.  An A&P mechanic at the airport determined the ignitor box was inoperable.  The helicopter was unavailable at 1500 hrs.  The company was notified and a mechanic was sent out to replace the ignitor box and rotor brake cylinder.  The aircraft was put back in service @ 1130 hrs on the following day 4-6-00.OAS maintenance was notified and were faxed logbook entries.

On 7/12/01 at1745 jumpship XXXZ was dispatched to the  Ferry Canyon incident on Prineville BLM. I was the check spotter for  the mission. We were informed from Central Oregon disp. that SEAT XXX  was on scene and T-XX ,and HELO-XXX were assigned.  The Air to Air and  Air to Ground we were given was the primary freq. for that geographic area  ( A to A -132.375 & A to G -169.150). When we came up on those freq.s   they both had heavy radio traffic from the Bald Peter fire on Warm Springs  BIA (approx. 35 air miles away. Both the Bald Peter fire and the Ferry  Canyon fire were large extended attack incidents with multiple arial  rescources assigned. The overlap of radio traffic on these incidents   made communications between arial rescources and with ground personel  extremely difficult compromising both the safety and effectiveness of  our mission and that of the other resources assigned to both incidents.

Tanker XXX, a SEAT assigned to the Aerial Task Force, was struck by lightning during suppression operations while assigned to the Rattlesnake Fire located 20 NM east of Mesquite, NV. The damage was discovered at the end of the day while the plane was being maintained. The exact time of the incident is unknown and the pilot could not recall the event or even flying near thunderstorms. However, there were isolated storms in the vicinity of the fire and flight path to the reload base in St. George, UT. The strike was apparently isolated to 2 zeus fittings on the front left engine compartment cover. The fittings (about 10'''' apart) were charred black, but no other damage inside/outside the engine compartment was visible.

While pulling water from xxx reservoir, the pilot of Nxxx noticed a small drone out side his window. about 100-200 feet away and at the same elevation. Helco was up at that time. 2CK notified Helco, Helco sent 2CK and our other 2 helicopters working back to helibase. Helco checked in with our divisions and he also returned to helibase. AOBD and Helibase was notified. Law enforcement was sent to the area but could not find the operator. air operations were shut down for the rest of the evening.

During refueling NXXXX at a gravel pit near North Fork Resevoir on a Mt. Hood National Forest Wildfire. After 1.7 hr of Bucket Work at an elevation of 3100' to 4000'.  XXXXX XXXXX and XXXXXXX XXXXXXXX smelled a strong battery acid odor or fumes. We ask the pilot and he said it was coming from the little bit of smoke from the exhaust area. We said ok, and got back in the helicopter NXXXX and proceeded back to Warm Springs Agency. Upon landing at WSA the pilot was disconnecting the battery and found the battery cables were hot and the smell of sulfur was still there. Waited 30 to 40 minutes to unhook the battery cables. Problem turned out to be a voltage regulator that was allowing the unit to overcharge the battery. The overcharging was creating the odor.

Dispatched to South Pine Fire #1676, WA DNR @ 16:12 from KOMK,  with report of multiple structures immediately threatened. IA aviation resources initially assigned were ATGS, two AT-802 Fire Bosses, and a T2 Restricted Use helicopter. Upon arrival on scene, H-XXX was on ground at helispot , and preparing for bucket work. Contacted IC on A/G and confirmed aircraft tactical objectives to support ground resources engaging the fire. Cleared H-XXX to lift and work left flank from a dip site located adjacent and west of left flank. Cleared in the FB XXX and XXX to maneuver and drop on right flank . Directed Fire Bosses to go to a scoop site approx 10 miles to north of the fire. Cleared in FB XXX and XXX upon return to tag and extend from previous drop. As we (ATGS) were orbiting around heel of fire , ATGS saw 3 para gliders fly through FTA over the fire approx. 500-1000' below us on the right flank/east side of fire. We notified all A/C on scene of intrusion, and then observed the para gliders depart to the east and fly out over the main valley outside of the FTA. FB XXX and XXX were ordered to scoop and return after the drop. Upon their return, ATGS cleared them in to tag and extend on last drop on right flank. As ATGS plane was orbiting  right flank from north to south, pilot and ATGS saw one para glider fly over the top of our plane within 500'. We were at 5,000 MSL. Pilot looked to his left and saw the other two para gliders  below and left within 1,000' feet of our position . We flew straight south to avoid para gliders, then climbed to 7,000 MSL and orbited outside of the FTA. No TFR had been requested by ATGS prior to intrusion as we were only 30 minutes into the mission.

On final approch to the drop, pilot inadvertently hit the cargo release button. This was mostly due to the pilot's attention being focused on hitting the mark. The pilot did not feel his hand riding up onto the release button located on the cyclic.

While delivering cargo on a longline, pilot hit wrong switch and  causing the longline to come off.  Pilot described no other problems.  Weather was clear.  no obstacles.  No injuries occured.  No damage to  aircraft.  No damage to longline.

Shortly after departing heli-base for a water dropping mission, the Transmission chip light illuminated. As soon as the light illuminated the helicopter returned for landing without issue. After maintenance personal reviewed the records and consulted Manufacture recommendations. The company found two more such events were permissible based on the criteria.

Original Text:In flight mechanical issue. Pilot was working on the burnt canyon fire helping ground crews with water drops. Pilot notice that the DC Generator warning light was illuminated and the Voltage meter was reading 110. Normal readings are 120. Pilot informed manager of issue and landed aircraft as soon as practical. DC generator was not generating power to charge batteries. Mechanic found that the brushes in the generator had failed.

After receiving seven sling loads at Little Panarama helispot the 407 landed to have its longline removed and to transport the three helitack members back to the helibase. The LZ was on a slight slope where the nose would be pointing down hill at a slight angle. inJasonin, an experienced and qualified helitack crewmwber, was marshalling the 407 while myself and another crewmember were closing the trail to hikers. Looking over my shoulder to see how the landing was going I noticed the tail rotor very close to a small sage brush. I then looked back at the crewmember marshalling the 407 to see if he saw the brush. He did and was giving the pilot proper hand signals to move his tail rotor to the left. I then looked back to the 407 and its instingerin was just touching the sage brush for just a few seconds as the 407's skids settled. After returning to the helibase the tail rotor was inspected by the pilot and myself and there were no signs of a strike. The AV Safety Compliance Spec. was notified and the 407 is still in service.

A load of nets {approx. 125lbs} fell off the remote hook about two minutes into flight. The load of nets left the cargo area still attached, two minutes later the pilot was notified that his load fell. The load fell into a grass field and no damages or injuries occured.

Helicopter lifted off Willits Helibase for a water dropping mission on the West-Zone of the August Complex on the Mendocino NF. About 20 minutes after departure from Helibase the mechanic noticed numerous oil spots of what appeared to be helicopter engine or transmission oil on the side of the fuel truck, and mechanics pod. Mechanic requested that Helibase call helicopter back from the fire to investigate the oil source. While helicopter was returning the pilot noticed oil pressure on the number 1 engine fluctuating, still within operating limits but fluctuating. Additionally, about five minutes from Helibase the pilot saw the fuel valve warning light illuminate on engine number 1. Helicopter made a safe and uneventful landing at Helibase and the mechanic had the pilot shut down. 
The Mechanic investigated the oil leak and found that the oil cap was missing. After a run-up was performed the day prior due to seven days of inactivity the mechanic topped off the engine oil but did not replace the cap after topping off. This allowed engine oil to splash out into the engine compartment during the flight, and oil pressure to fluctuate.

Incident started at 11:27, at 11:36 A/A was ordered. Due to forest procedure, Dispatch named the fire XXX based on reported location. A/A responded at 11:53. Jumpers were ordered at 12:27 and responded at 12:42. SEAT was ordered at 12:39 and responded 13:05. Jump ship dropped 2 jumpers at 13:06. At 13:14, the first engine on scene claimed IC and changed the name of the incident to XXX.

During a government requested hot refuel at the helibase, pilot needed to use restroom. Going off of what was understood in FAA part 135 standards and previous contract standards mechanic was placed at controls of aircraft while pilot went to restroom. Regional aviation employee observed this and notified manager that this does not meet contract standards. Regional employee requested a safecom be submitted to `pass the word` to other modules on what may be a common practice.

H-xxx was dipping out of a dipsite that they and another Kmax had been using for the past two days on the East Canyon Fire. Half way through H-xxx second cycle of  bucket work, the pilot was burping water from his bucket to get a positive rate of climb out of the dip. H-xxx then had a wind switch and started to settle and started to burp more water from his bucket but his rate of decent continued. At that point H-xxx released all his water to avoid damage to his bucket and longline. The pilot noticed where he dropped his water that it was possible the water and/or his bucket may have damaged a fence. 
H-xxx immediately notified Air-Attack of what happened and finished his cycle dropping water. After tapping the fence H-xxx moved further back in the dipsite and took a little less water.

At the time this happened the ground crew was talking on the radio about a huge wind switch. At Cortez airport the winds were at 8kts gusting to 26kts reported by CEZ ASOS.

A ground crew was sent out to the dip site and did not find any damage to the fence but did find a screw that was protruding from a fence post that the bucket had scraped on. The bucket did have a light scratch, but no significant damage was done.  Pictures attached.

On 7/18 at 1430, Helicopter XXX  and crew were assigned to initial attack the Powerline fire near Baker City, OR. At approximately 1520, the pilot noticed a transmission chip light and dispatch was notified that the aircraft would land for precautionary measures 12 miles south of Unity, OR. Three chip plugs were inspected and hair sized sliver particle were found on the lower chip plug. The chip was cleaned, reinstalled, and ground tested. At 1745 the aircraft lifted and returned to base. The maintenance inspector was notified and determined that no further action was necessary. Kudos to our pilot for making the decision to land and troubleshoot the problem.

Due to the extreme fire potential, and the shortage of resources, Fire Management for the Kaibab National Forest signed up some SEATS to be utilized on the Coconino and Kaibab National Forest.  The SEAT involved in this incident had just moved to the Kanab Airport from Flagstaff the day before.  Williams Dispatch had difficulties talking to him on 7/4/02 as did Air Attack 14S, but we were able to accomplish our flight following into Kanab without incident.  We had Observer II spend some time with the pilot, in getting familiar with our radio system, and explaining to him how things operated.  At the end of the day, it was thought that the pilot of T-426 did have a clear understanding of the radio system and how he was too talk to Williams Dispatch.  On 7/5 T-426 went into service at KNB loud and clear.  At approximately 1130, Kane IC requested two SEATS.  The SEAT manager for T-426 was notified, they were at lunch, but back in route to KNB.  Williams Dispatch requested the second SEAT from the Arizona Strip out of SGU.  A few minutes later Kane IC, stated to advise him prior to SEATS taking off as he may only need one.  The AZ Strip was on the phone, waiting to determine if we needed them, when Williams Dispatch received a call from an employee at KNB, wondering if T-426 was talking to us.  Kane air attack was notified that T-426 had taken off KNB but we had no ETD or ETA, and Kane air attack stated to Williams Dispatch that he had just made contact with T-426 and he was one minute out.  T-426 dropped his load on the Kane fire and returned to KNB with no radio contact to Williams Dispatch.

Txx was cleared to loading pit and parked while other aircraft being loaded in second pit. Txx had been sitting in pit one waiting to be loaded. the base loading crew went to pit one to commence loading. after hooking up to the aircraft the loading crew noticed leaking coming from the doors and shut-down. the loading manifold on board the aircraft was not opened by the flight crew prior to loading. this was a different loading crew from the previous day. there was missing communication between the crews the lead to this mishap. the loading manifold was damaged and will need to be replaced.

While preparing to leave Redmond for Prineville for ATGS mission, left engine turned over, then quit.  On subsequent attempt, starter spun, but did not turn engine.  It was determined that pin in starter had sheared.

At 1615 Dispatch recieved a smoke report in the Voltaire Canyon area 7nm from Minden Tanker Base. Air Attack, Helicopter XXX and Tanker XX responded as a part of the initial dispatch. At 1634 I advised Air Attack that North Op's had 2 S-2 Air Tankers available. He advised they could handle with the air resources already on scene. At 1717 I recieved a radio call from H-YYY stating he was inoff Minden and enroutein. I confirmed the call sign was H-YYY not H-XXX which was already assigned to the fire and that he was enroute to the fire. He confirmed the call sign, when I asked if he had a crew on board I recieved no response. At 1718 I tried to contact air attack regarding H-YYY responding. At 1723 Air attack advised they had contact with H-YYY, I asked if he could find out if there was a crew on board and stated dispatch did not know they had been requested. Air Attack advised H-YYY only had the pilot on board and would be used for bucket work only.At 1900 I spoke with the ATGS on the phone. He stated he was not aware of H-YYY being ordered. I asked our Floor Supervisor to track down who had requested the ship, and when had it become available as it had been listed on a 2-hour call back for the day. She contacted the State Duty Officer who stated that the pilot for H-YYY had called him and asked if the fire could use the second helocopter, the duty officer advised that they could. There was no communication with dispatch, air attack or the IC regarding this decision.

NXXXX completed one fuel cycle of water drops and returned to the helibase. When aircraft landed, white smoke was coming out of the engine cowlings.  The mechanic told the pilot to shut down immediately.  Upon inspection, the #1 bearing carbon seal was leaking, blowing oil out the bleed band.  Pilot reported no indications of a proplem while flying bucket mission.  A power check was completed one hour prior to oil leak, and everything was normal except the engine was running cooler than normal.

At approximately 1400 on Sunday afternoon I received a report of a guy preparing to launch a drone near Lucia CA off of HW1. I immediately called air attach and informed him that there was a report of a drone preparing to launch near Lucia about 15 miles to the SE of his location and asked him to confirm that it was indeed outside of the fire TFR. The air attack confirmed that the location was 5 miles outside of the TFR. Meanwhile the TFLD that reported the drone turned around and went back to the drone location to talk to the pilot. By the time the TFLD reached the drone location the operator had packed up and left the area. Presumably because he saw the agency vehicle slow down and turn around. I then informed the incident air attack that the drone operator had left the are and was nowhere to be found. About 45 minutes later I received another call about a second drone sighting. This time it was flying inside of the TFR {and in a Condor sanctuary no fly zone} and a quarter mile from where our helicopters were dipping from about an hour before the sighting. I again reported the sighting to airattack who was working with several aircraft up drainage {2.5 miles N @ 4,000 ground elevation} from the drone location {sea level}. I instructed the STLD who reported the drone to solicit the help of the park rangers and confront the drone operator. They were successful in convincing the pilot to land the drone and to stop flying the drone near the fire TFR. Although I asked the STLD to collect any information about the drone and the pilot that he could he was unsuccessful as the pilot made a speedy getaway during a very high road traffic area and time. We immediately made contact with airattack and informed him that the drone had landed and was no longer a factor. An AAR was done the following day using the NWCG UAS Reporting Protocol matrix. Everything was done in the proper sequence and in a timely matter. We used that opportunity as a learning moment for everyone on the decision and stressed the importance to immediately report any drone airings up the chain of command and to the controlling airattack or aircraft.

T-XX was dispatched from the Twin Falls Air Center (TFAC) to the Colby Fire (CA-LNF-0033801)at 0910 hours, on 11 August 2007. The aircraft had been parked in Pit #1 at TFAC overnight. The dispatch was announced over the PA as a 'Fire Call.' The pilots were in Operations awaiting copies of the fire dispatch. The retardant contractor began loading the aircraft with Phos Chek LC95A without the Air Tanker Base Manager comfirmation to load, or pilot/co-pilot at the aircraft. The pilots arrived at the aircraft after approximately 2,200 gallons of retardant had been loaded. The pilots had not wanted the aircraft loaded for the flight; however, the retardant contractor stated the aircraft could be downloaded. The pilot said to complete the load to a total of 2,447 gallons.

Following air tactical missions, the aircraft landed in Miles City for fuel and a break. During routine maintanance checks, the pilot put 6 quarts of oilin the right engine. The aircraft had just completed a 4 hour flight. Oil pressure and temps remained in the green during the flight. Prior to this flight the engine had been using less than 1 quart per hour of flight.Pilot decided to not continue with the next air tactical mission and flew the aircraft back to Corporate Air in Billings.

Pilot stated that he had an Engine/Airframe/Oil Filter Chip Light while on a Initial Attack mission. Pilot landed the aircraft and checked the chip plug and found very light fuzz on the plug. Pilot is an A/P mechanic.

NXXX (P-1) responded to a fire on the Apache-Sitgreaves N. FS., 9N,27E,S27 at approximately 1315, an ATGS was also ordered from Winslow.  P-1 arrived on scene from White River with two helicopters and three seats, one from White River and two from Springerville.  Upon arrival P-1 (the pilot of P-1 began directing the helicopters and telling the seats where to drop and whether to split the load).  He continued this for two seats when a qualified ATGS arrived on scene.  The observer in the aircraft is not a qualified ATGS.

Pilot: Incident 206 west of Juntura, OR. Approximately 1620 PST. Just as I was setting up to drop my last bucket on the fire before returning to Burns for fuel I experienced a complete hydraulic failure. I immediately dumped the water that was in my bucket and isolated the hydraulics. I notified Air Attack that I had had a hydraulic failure and that I was going to find a place to land. Air Attack acknowledged my transmission and said that he was going to drop down to a lower altitude and follow me to my landing spot. I turned into the wind and started flying towards the valley that had farm fields. When my bucket was close to the ground, I released it from the belly. After releasing the bucket, I continued my approach to the field and landed without incident.I then gave Air Attack my lat and long and told him to contact my manager, and my fuel/service truck to give them an update. Air Attack told me that he would relay all information to dispatch. While waiting for my manager and service truck to show up the Burns Aviation Manager, showed up to check on me. I informed him that I was okay and enlisted his help to retrieve my bucket. My manager and fuel/service truck showed up about an hour after I had landed. Maintenance was notified and parts should be here in the morning. Manager: All Federal and State contacts were made to the appropriate parties including the Contractor`s home base. Ship was about to go fuel so had been flying for 1.8 hrs before incident. Due to the quick response of the pilot no injuries or damage resulted from this incident. The contractor should be commended for including in their preseason training actual hydraulic failure training in a controlled environment. The pilot responding quickly and decisively to the failure.

Crewmember removed the pilot's door for a longline mission and placed it painted-side up, approximately 70 feet from the pad-on the downwind side due to the layout of the helibase.  Upon departure, the rotor wash flipped the door over, now painted-side down, resulting in several scratches in the paint.

Helicopter assigned to the Honeymoon fire was requested to perform water drops. The bucket/hook checks were performed and then the bucket was hooked up by HECM and HMGB. Bucket control head put into keeperless hook and then hook was locked into place, a tug was made on the control head. Pilot departed helispot enroute to fire {approx. 300```` away from helispot and approximately 30 feet in the air when bucket detached and fell to the ground}It actually fell into a shallow pond. Helicopter returned to spot as the bucket was retrieved. Hook was looked over but seemed to be in good working order. Bucket was inspected and checked - no damage was found - then re-attached to keeperless hook. A very decisive tug was made on the control head to ensure it was locked in. Pilot performed a test flight and resumed bucket operations with no issues.

Intermittent issue to bring flaps up for three days prior to this event. No issues to bring them down but after drop flaps would stay indicated at half on way up while lever in up position. Pilot had to wiggle the lever and eventually they would come up. Base Mech. was working on the issue. Cleaning canon plug and changed  transmitter. 

Left brake was changed as well in this period of time.

Later, While coming back to land on an empty tank with gear down and locked, pilot smelled a heat/rubbery smell and saw light smoke appearing from the vents and main cabin.

Landed and shut down the aircraft. Pilot noted left hydraulic gauge indicated 1700psi (Normal Ops is 1500psi)

Pilot ferried Tanker to MCC the next day with gear down and locked.

Shortly after taking off from (GJT)Grand Junction, CO the pilot asked the personnel in the back if they had opened a window and the response was the windows were already opened. We then proceded to the next fuel stop. After landing it was immediately noticed that there was grease all over the tail boom, rotors, and body of the ship. We were at Classic helicopters service center in Page, AZ and we were having a 50 hour done so the mechanic said he would check it out. Upon returning from lunch I was notified that one of the excluder seals had gone bad and lost some of its grease. The mechanic had said we could still fly and it would need to be replaced shortly, after contacting the region nine maintenence inspector it was determined the ship was unavailable until the seals were replaced. It was not determined if the pilots question about the windows being opened could have been the seal going or not. After the initial question no abnormalities were experienced.
Thermal overheat of the primary longitudinal trim motor.

After initial attack/bucket support at the fire Helibase, we were loading the aircraft to return to our helibase at the airport. After loading cargo/bucket, a crewmember noticed that the bottom of the left cargo door was not connected to the aircraft {it could be pulled away from the body}. After further inspection and looking at the right cargo door, it was determined that the bottom guide rail {made of rolled sheet metal} was missing the forward 8-9 inches of the inside lip, allowing the door bottom to be loose when the door was fully open. Pilot determined that when the door was fully closed it was secure and not loose, but said he would not allow door open operations {rappel operations}. The manager concurred, as well as 2 other qualified managers onboard, and we loaded up, the pilot closed the doors himself, and we returned home, where after consulting the mechanic when he arrived, the pilot grounded the aircraft until the situation was remedied.

On the 2nd load of the morning, with the 2nd stick of rappellers, the engine fuel pump caution light came on.  The indicator light came on while the rappellers were on the skids, ready to exit the aircraft.
