The pilot notified the spotter after the rappellers were on the ground and off the ropes, due to the fact that there was no fluctuation in fuel pressure.  The spotter disconnected ropes, closed doors and returned to the helipad.  Helicopter was then shutdown for inspection.

NXXXXX was dispatched to the Canyon Fire for Initial Attack.  While in transit pilot noticed a split needle discrepancy for rotor and turbine rpms.  Needles came back in balance but we decided to return to Bridgeport.  Mechanic found a dirty cannon plug on the tach. generator.  Contractors ran up aircraft and took maintenance flight.  Spoke with maintenance inspector and aircraft was brought back in service.

Pilot went to refuel at Cascade airport without manager on board and with bucket still attached.  Over flew highway 55 and landed with out a marshler.  Pilot hot refueled with the vendor.The pilot was asked; about fuel situation by the manager at the dip site and replyed that he had 4-5 turns left.  He was informed to hold up on the refueling until the manager checked with the IC to see if they would be released.  While talking to the IC about release, the pilot monitored the conversation.  The pilot informed the IC that he was going for fuel and would return and was told by the IC, inThanks but you are being released.in  The manager tried to contact the A/C on air to ground with no response.  When he returned from refueling, the manager directed the pilot to land and shut down.  The Manager discussed the ship flying off for refueling without a manager on board, flying accross highway 55 with an external load and was asked if he had hot refueled, as it was realized that it was a very short turn around.  Pilot stated that it was a hot refuel and that it was in their ops plan.  Further research revealed that hot refueling was only for EMS operations and stated that the doors on the fuel side will remain closed.  The door was removed and was in the back seat.  The manager explained the need for the manager to be on board when the A/C left the fire when there was no helitack  on the other end, procedures for overflying roads and populated areas with external loads and what the hot refueling procedures were.  There was no flight following from the time that the aircraft left the fire until he was 3 miles out on the return flight from refueling. /s/ Helicopter Manager

A non-essential person was flown on a recon flight against the helicopter manager's objections.  Team air ops discussed the situation with the person who took the non essential person on the recon.  Items covered included 12 aviation watchouts, risk assessment, unneccessary exposure.
While slinging a blivit with 2 attached 5 gallon cubitaners, a cubitaner fell to the ground.

A type two helicopter with 100’ LL was requested for bucket work and departed the Helibase for the fire at 14:40. It took approximately 25 to 30 minutes of flight time for the pilot to arrive at the division and dip-site that was being worked on. 

The helicopters altitude was above 9500 MSL and wind appeared to be relatively strong 10+ MPH. As the pilot filled the first bucket, the aircraft climbed normally.  The Pilot was in contact with the A/G to pre-treat an area prior to a burn operation.  As the aircraft climbed the Pilot saw the strobe for the intended drop zone.  As the aircraft turned downwind, the airspeed deteriorated so the pilot aborted the drop by flying forward to gain airspeed.  As the airspeed increased the altitude decreased where the bucket caught a tree limb prior to completing the pullout.  The Pilot did not notice the bucket contact the trees as the bucket was aligned between the tree line along a road.  The pilot turned out and picked up the strobe to complete the drop

During the pre-use inspection of the fuel truck it was noticed that the fuel bonding cable consisted of a 50''retractable measuring tape with a bonding plug and a clamp attachd to it. A continuity test was conducted resulting in negative continuity. The measuring tape had electrical tape wrap around a section. Removal of the electrical tape discovered that the measuring tape was broken. The measuring tape had no continuity due to the painted surface of the tape being overlaped together with electrical tape. The contractor had a back-up cable that sufficed.

While on the gardner fire T-495 had to make an emergency landing due to a fuel system problem, T-495 was in a hold pattern on the fire when he noticed a fuel problem and was forced to land on a near by road. no injuries or damage to pilot or ship.A U.S.F.S. INVESTIGATION TEAM HAS BEEN ASSIGNED, REPORT TO FOLLOW

Air tanker XXX took off from S80 @ 1830 made a drop on the Warm Springs fire then went to McCall for fuel and another load of retardant for the Warm Springs Fire. Upon returning to Warm Springs fire; unforeseen circumstance, structures being threatened and weather (head wind), T-XXX was unable to meet the Legal S.E. FLY time of 2107 PDT when returning to Grangeville. T-XXX landed at 2114 PDT, 7 minutes after Legal S.E. Fly. Communications with the T-XXX were kept at all times and the mission was accomplished safely.

On the afternoon of July 5, the HMGB of a Type 1 heli-tanker advised his pilot of a weather service warning for severe thunderstorms with quarter-sized hail and to “baton things down.” The company rep, the ASGS, and the HMGB got into a discussion about whether flying to avoid the storm would be revenue or non-revenue. This occurred at the box on the helibase, about ¼ mile from the helicopter pad. The ASGS said that nobody was ordering the helicopters to move, so if the company decided there was an eminent threat, it was there decision to do so and the flight would be non-revenue. After the discussion, the HMGB drove down to the pad. When the HMGB got to the pad, he said the helicopter spooled up and was lifting off before he got out of the truck. The HMGB reported afterward that he did not know if the aircraft had communication with anyone, as the wind of the coming storm along with radio chatter prevented him for knowing for sure. The HMGB was also unsure of how many souls were on board at that time {1830}. After the incident, neither the personnel at the helibase {HMGB, ASGS, or others}, or dispatch knew SOB/FOB for the ship. At 1720, the incident HB got a call from the Helitanker: “Off HB to Torrington: will contact Casper.” The aircraft desk noticed a Type 1 helicopter go positive AFF at 1724. At first, the desk thought it was a local fire mission. By 1730, the two dispatchers were discussing the craft and its mission. They knew of nothing it could be doing that would take it to the east. Contact on National FF was attempted, and a message was left with the AOBD on the incident. Great Plains Dispatch was asked to contact the ship for mission, fuel, souls. They couldn`t reach them. About 1757, the ship went red on AFF. We again called Great Plains Dispatch Aircraft Desk. The ASGS was notified dispatch that had no contact with the ship and they had gone red on AFF. He said they were moving to avoid the storms. Meanwhile, dispatch called the Casper tower. The tower had not heard from the craft and informed Torrington was an unmanned strip. Dispatch called sheriff`s office and asked them to send an officer toward the airport. At 1802, AOBD called and said the helicopter was moving to avoid storms and was calling Air Support to see the status of the ship. At 1811, the GACC called to inquire on HT status. During that call, AOBD called back and informed all that the manager had contact with the pilot and everyone was alright. The airport tower, county law enforcement, the GACC, and the neighboring dispatch center involved were all notified of the situation. Per AOBD, an AAR will be scheduled to learn from this incident and avoid future communications issues.

We were returning from dropping jumpers in NV and preparing to land at TWF. Everything was normal with the landing until the front landing gear contacted the tarmac, then we felt some severe vibration and we figured we blew a tire on landing. Upon inspection we confirmed the right front tire was flat.

While dropping water on the fire the pilots reported that the oil cooler light came on while main gear box temps increased 10 degrees Celsius. The pilots immediately left the fire and returned to the helibase, at which time the light extinguished and the main gear box temperatures returned to normal.

NXXX was dropping water on White Knoll fire. Pilot was over drop site, talking with air attack, then hit wrong button, dropping long line and bucket. No ground personnel in area. No damage to aircraft. Bucket was burnt up by fire. Cause was pilot error.

At about 1030 Helitanker was sent to the dip site to get a few loads of clean water, and drop on the fire to rinse out the tank and snorkel system after dipping from a pumpkin which contained diluted foam. After taking on some water the tank hydraulic system doors failed and released the water back into the lake. After returning to helibase the flight crew determined the Ag Air pump which controls the tank and snorkel system sheered a shaft pin causing the tank system to fail.
During takeoff from Rock Eagle Helibase an engine chip light came on. Helicopter was only about 3 feet off the ground. We immediately set helicopter back on pad, with no problems.

While doing water dropping mission, Isolair tank doors quit working. Pilot was able to cycle once and then nothing would work, returned to Helibase. Mechanic working on aircraft tank and couldn't get it to work. Isolair company thought hydraulic pump was not functioning. Tank removed from aircraft and was back to work with Bambi bucket. New pump being sent by Isolair.

On July 1, at approximately 2000 while on approach for Designated base, the aircraft struck a bird. The impact occurred on the front center{nose}of the helicopter and the bird departed up and to the pilot side {left} of the windscreen. Damage to the nose cone includes 2 cracks thru the skin of the nose cone, each approximately 7 inches in length, one vertical on the left side of the impact area, and one horizontal crack across the bottom of the impact area, viewed from the perspective of one looking at the nose cone from the front of the aircraft. No other damage other than these cracks was noted. The bird species unknown, but did not seem to be particularly large for the split second it was observed before impact.

April 25,2016 the Eastern Area IMT2 assumed command of the 16 Mile fire at 1900 hours local time. Previous IMT3 had established a TFR for this incident.On April 26, 2016 on an orientation flight {ATGS and Line Operations}of the 16 Mile Fire: pilot for helicopter 1FS was alerted by TCAS of another aircraft in the vicinity. The unidentified aircraft was quickly located by the pilot and ATGS/HLCO and See and Avoid procedures were implemented. Pilot made contact with second aircraft on local unicom frequency to advise them of the TFR and that they were inside the TFR. The second aircraft departed the TFR airspace without further incident. As the Air Ops for the incident, I went to the tfr.faa.gov site to get TFR information and noticed there was no AM frequency listed for non-firefighting aircraft to use to contact firefighting aircraft for permission to enter the TFR.

While over the incident, T-XX noticed the hydraulic pressure began to drop. The lead plane was notified and T-XX had enough hydraulic pressure to make the drop. While going to SBD T-XX began lowering the landing gear which caused a complete loss of hydraulic pressure. T-XX had the tower call for an engine to respond and followed their emergency procedures for hydraulic failure. Pilots were able to land and stop the aircraft on the runway using the emergency air pressure braking system. Without hydraulic pressure, T-XX was unable to taxi off the runway. Approximately 5 hours later, T-XX was towed off the runway after a tow bar was modified.

Subject:  SAFECOM - Canadian Bird Dog#52,           Left Engine Failure.At approximately 1100 hours MDT Canadian Bird Dog#52, a Turbo Commander, departed Miles City, Montana for Helena, MT.  After reaching cruising altitude of 12,500 feet westbound, and 25 minutes out of Miles City, the left engine suddenly lost power and went to auto feather.  There were no prior indications (instrumentation) that there was a problem developing.  After a cool down period of approximately 2 minutes, and attempt to restart the engine was made but immediately aborted due to no indication of oil pressure.The aircraft was under FS flight following with Lewistown as Billings could not be raised.  Flight following and position reports were also conveyed to Helena on FS nets.The aircraft had no difficulty maintaining altitude and was operating in CAVU conditions.  The flight crew made a judgement call to continue on to Missoula where they had maintenance support even though it was somewhat further than Helena where the logistics of repair would be difficult.  This decision was based on what the flight crew believed to be inpracticablein given the circumstances of clear air, no problems in maintaining altitude, other available landing places along the route, and the availability of maintenance support in Missoula.Bird Dog #52 continued west at 12,500 feet MSL with no further difficulties, other than reduced airspeed, and maintained visuals on airports and landing area's they could reach if problems developed with the right engine.Landing was affected in Missoula at near 1200 hours where they taxied to Northstar Aviation and met with their maintenance team.  The cowling was removed, screens pulled showing a lot of evidence of metal particle, i.e., steel and brass.  The engine had failed and required an engine change.USDA Forest Service LiaisonCanadian Airtanker Deployment

The pilot, while on the drop feels like this was a potential near miss. As he was going into a drop, a single engine airplane, a SEAT, appeared directly in front of us about 500` higher. We we`re at 6000` MSL and had clearance to 7500` MSL. The SEAT was well into our cleared airspace. We had no communication with this aircraft and we were not advised of its location by air attack prior to visual contact. I don`t believe air attack had a visual on this airplane. We had been holding at the dip for all tanker activity previous to this incident. This aircraft created a hazard and distraction for our line up on the drop.

Helicopter was supporting the Lonesome Complex, Middle fork fire with bucket drops.  At 1505hrs A/C departed 64S per request by air attack for bucket work.  A/C completed his 1st fuel cycle and RTB for fuel to load and return.  A/C departed at 1715 for his 2nd fuel cycle.  No blade check was performed between cycles.  A/C returned to 64S at 1800hrs due to failing visibility conditions over fire.  Mechanic was performing post flight maintenance when he discovered a crack approximately 12 inches long in one of the left pair of blades running width wise not length wise to the blade.  A/C was put into unavailability status and R-6 Maintenance Inspector and Helibase Manager were notified.  A/C had not flown previous 2 days and flew 7.6hrs on 9/7/08 on above incident.

Jump XX was responding to the Cotton Wood fire,Upon arrival we spoke with Helicopter XX1 (already on scene).  XX1 indicated winds on the ground were15-20 mph. very gusty and turbulent.  Jump XX elected to stay at altitudeand direct the air show. Aproximatly 1 minute later tanker 183 arrived on scene. We had repeatedly tried to get TXX2 on victor with no success.  Wethen called 429 dispatch (Shoshone BLM) to have them attempt contact and bring TXX2 up on victor.He responded and we continued air operations for the next 2+ hours.

Helicopter was doing bucket work with a 120 ft longline on the fire. After several failed attempts of dropping the water on target I suggested to the pilot to try a different approach and be higher and faster. After doing a dry run for the drop the pilot set up for a live drop. After hitting the target, his bucket struck a tree and boulder at the top of the ridge.

At approximately 1345 aircraft departed the North Fork Fire for a retardant dropping mission on the French Fire. After about 1.5 hours into the fuel cycle the pilots noticed the engine oil pressure in the {#}1 engine dropped. According to the pilots, this is what took place: ``As we were descending for our 5th drop of retardant we noticed our number 1 engine oil pressure drop to the bottom of the precautionary range {40 psi}. This immediately grabbed our attention and we continued with the drop as we had power out, were lined up, and needed to shed the weight anyway if we have a legitimate engine oil system failure. We made our run-out downhill and loaded the engine to see if an increased power requirement would bring the pressure back up to the normal range. It did not but rather stayed in the precautionary range so we notified air attack we were returning to the helibase with an engine oil pressure in the precautionary range as we came off the drop. We emphasized that we weren’t in a dire situation and he kindly asked us to notify him when we make it safely back. Enroute to the helibase the oil pressure continued to decay and we shut down the {#}1 engine at the top of the ridge above helibase,{approximately 2 miles out} as the oil pressure started to drop below the precautionary range. Right after we cleared the tank for landing, we contacted air-attack and told him landing assured and made an uneventful, single-engine landing at approximately 1548. Subsequent inspection determined the number 1 engine oil pressure relief valve failed thus causing the decay in pressure. One of the final steps in in the Before Landing Checks is disarming the tank which causes the doors to open and any residual water or retardant to come out. This is {and was in this instance} done over an unpopulated area. Approximately 20 gal of residual retardant came out due to not having had the opportunity for a rinse load as the final turn of the cycle”.

The Helicopter was supporting burn out operations on the Colockum Tarps Fire with a 150 foot long line and 240 gal bambi bucket. The pilot positioned for a drop and the bucket would not release. He pulled out and came back around to try again. The bucket failed to open a second time so the pilot was going to return to the helibase to determine the cause of the malfunction. It is 13 miles back to the base so he wanted to set the bucket down and tip it over. He was flying down the valley looking for some flat terrain to set the bucket down. He got distracted while looking for a suitable spot and impacted the top of a tall tree doing substanstial damage to the bucket. He called the helibase immediately to report the incident and returned to base.
During morning pre-flight inspections the mechanic observed a small deficiency on the bottom tip of a main mast blade. Upon further inspection a small blade delamination was detected.

A type two helicopter was over the Xxxxx fire with a full bucket of water waiting to be cleared in by air attack to begin working. To control air traffic all medium helicopters were assigned to the south end of the fire while all heavy helicopters were assigned to the north end of the fire. Air attack directed the type two helicopter to the middle of the fire to work directly with a hand crew. The fire behavior started picking up and the Air to Ground frequency became overloaded. The pilot was unable to make contact with the hand crew. Air attack then directed the helicopter to the north end of the fire where the heavies were working. The pilot was not familiar with this area of the fire. In route to the north end of the fire the pilot felt confused and was having trouble understanding what the air attacks intensions were. The pilot requested to work in the rotation with the heavies and was denied by air attack. At this time a type one helicopter with a hundred foot long line and bucket flew directley over the top of the type two helicopter. Both pilots agreed it was to close for comfort. After flying around for over fifty minutes with the same bucket of water the pilot decided to return to base and tie in with the Helibase Manager to inform him of the confusion that is happening with the air space around the Xxxxxx fire.

After departing the Durango Air Tanker base, en-route to the Papoose Fire on the West Fork Complex, Air Attack platform xxx was not able to establish proper cabin pressure. Because air attack operations over the Papoose Fire required 14,000 to 15,000 MSL, cabin pressurization was required. The plane returned to Durango and landed without incident.

Upon takeoff for a water delivery mission{third cycle of the day}, the PIC noticed hydraulic fluid leaking from aircraft onto the helipad. The aircraft was immediately set back down. The leak turned out to be the yaw number 1 transfer tube. The leak was fixed and another leak was found during the leak check, which was in the pitch tube.

Pilot lifted for a long line cargo mission from the helibase. After lifting about 100 feet off the ground pilot noticed he had a transmission chip light indicator and proceeded to land back at his pad without incident. Pilot shut down and mechanic pulled out the transmission chip plug and noticed some larger than normal metal pieces. After talking with the company the decision was made to pull the transmission, have it sent into a certified shop, have it inspected and any worn parts replaced

WHILE FLYING AIR DETECTION, FOR BOTH THE OZARK AND OUACHITA N.F.THE CESSNA 182 ENCOUNTERED A TWIN ENGINE AIRCRAFT APPROACHING AT THE 2:30 POSITION. THE AIR OBSERVER NOTICED THE TWIN WHEN IT MADE A HARD LEFT BANK AND CLIMB.THE AIRCRAFT WERE WITHIN 1500-2000FT. OF EACH OTHER WHEN THIS ACTION TOOK PLACE. THE OBSERVER NOTIFIED THE PILOT OF THIS ACTION, FOR HAD NEVER SEEN THE APPROACHING AIRCRAFT. THE TWIN WAS NEVER IDENTIFIED, AND THE 182 CONTINUED WITH THE DETECTION FLIGHT.BOTH AIRCRAFT WERE FLYING AT 4500FT. THE TWIN WAS FLYING EAST-WEST, AND THE 182 SOUTH-NORTH.

Our helicopter unit was dispatched to a wildland fire. En route to the fire the hinged doorpost panel on the left side failed to latch after unloading cargo. Upper portion of the panel would not latch due to miss alignment of the door pin. Door was removed from aircraft and the mission continued.
As Air Tanker XX performed start-up on the Redmond Air Tanker Ramp to respond to Buckhorn Incident the right jet engine would not start.

On September 21st and 22nd, the Gill Helibase experienced radio traffic bleed-over on 168.350 the assigned DECK frequency.  It was suspected that the bleed-over was due to a unit using DECK as its personal frequency without authorization.  The Helibase manager trainee attempted without success on multiple occasions to contact the transmitting unit when their traffic was heard.  This issue first occurred on September 21st and was communicated to the entire Gill Helibase at briefing on the 22nd.

The relief mechanic was performing a post shut-down inspection of the main rotor system. during this inspection, the mechanic noted play in both red and white stabilizer bar damper links. while the amount of play noted was consistent with normal wear of the rod end bearings and would not typically cause alarm, the mechanic remembered that the primary mechanic had stated at the last relief that he planned to replace the links, so the mechanic inspected the links more closely. it was at this more detailed inspection that the mechanic noted that the play was actually caused by premature wear of the rivets which secure the rod ends to the link tubes. at this time the mechanic made the decision to ground the aircraft based upon the fact that the rivets had worn to an unaccepable level in just over 30 hours. while waiting for the replacement parts to arrive with the fuel truck and maintenance trailer, the mechanic performed a detailed in spection of the subject parts and noted that the links were assembled with incorrect hardware and no structural adhesive, as directed in the bell helicopter standard practices manual {bht-all-spm}. the rivets installed were a 2024 alloy with a dd temper. this rivet has a shear loading capacity of 41000 psi. the required rivet is made from monel and has a shear strength of 49000 psi. it is noted that the identifying marks on a dd rivet are two raised dashes while the monel is identified by two raised dots. the parts had been purchased from XXXXXX XXXX, inc.

On Tuesday while working the Snow Fire on the San Bernardino National Forest T-xx came in to the San Bernardino Airtanker Base to get a load of retardant. On his roll T-xx asked me to go outside and look at his gear while he flew over the base and see if the right landing gear was still down. When he flew over we discovered the right landing gear was still down. I told T-xx that his gear was still down. I asked if he would like me to inform Aircraft Rescue, and he advised me that he was going to head to Chico and have his mechanics look at the situation. I advised South Ops, FICC and R-5 RASM of the situation. On the way to Chico T-xx Jettisoned his load at the San Bernardino Jettison Area. At 1850 I called CIC and got word that T-xx landed without incident at CIC at 1842. I contacted R-5 RASM and made sure that he had gotten the news.

During set up for the OGE hover prior to rappel operations the front seat ride along passenger noticed a master caution light come on. The pilot noticed it but the light immediately turned back off after a few seconds. Nothing was said during the rappel sequence about the master caution light going on before rappel operations. We completed rappel sequence and cargo let down operations and had an AAR on the events that unfolded. We talked about the intermittent “caution panel” caution light that is accompanied by the Master Caution light on the front dash. This light cannot be extinguished while illuminated because it means that the Caution Panel is INOP. The helicopter mechanic believes the light comes on due to a faulty relay. This led to a discussion that the Intermittent Caution Panel could cause a concern while in rappel operations. If the sequence was different and the light happened to come on during rappel operations it becomes an expedite and could mask other possible issues if the pilot is concentrating on flying the helicopter

On 14 July, 2000, Helicopter Nxxxx, a Bell 407 Helicopter, departed Boise Airport (BOI), Boise, Idaho enroute back to station at Garden Valley, Idaho, a trip of approximately 40 miles / 15 minutes.  A precautionary landing was initiated when the aircraft cabin and the fire crew in the rear of the aircraft were exposed to a strong burning odor and fumes from an overheated fan blower motor.The aircraft was held on the pad at BOI for an extended period to allow for air tanker traffic on several large fires nearby.  The pilot turned on the fan blower to provide air circulation for the rear flight crew.  Prior to departure, the pilot shut off the ICS system to the rear of the aircraft.  BOI Tower and Approach were both very busy with the Air Tanker Traffic and the pilot wanted to keep a 'sterile cockpit' in his departure from the airport.  Approximately 4 minutes into the flight, the Fan Blower Motor for the Overhead Airduct Vent System overheated and seized, popping a circut breaker.  Heat generated by the fan blower motor generated a strong smell and fumes in the rear of the aircraft.  With the ICS system off, an inability of the rear flight crew to communicate with the pilot caused some excitement.  When the pilot turned on the ICS system, he was informed of the fumes and smoke in the rear of the aircraft.  The pilot initiated a precautionary landing in a hay pasture near an active sprinkler irrigation system.The helicopter manager exited the aircraft and checked the rear cargo compartment for signs of a fire and heat externally and then internally.  He located a spot inside the baggage compartment on the upper bulkhead and the pilot identified the probable source as the fan motor.The aircraft was shut down and the pilot removed an access panel in the tail cargo compartment and verified the source of the heat as the fan motor.The helicopter manager notified dispatch and contacted R-4 RASM and explained the situation.  The flight crew waited for their helitender and chase vehicles while the Helicopter made a maintenance ferry flight to Garden Valley.  The motor was removed, the circut breaker was zip tied off to prevent engaging and an entry was made in the log book.  That evening the aircraft was released as fit for duty.  A replacement motor is on order.The pilots had been having difficulty with the fan blower unit before, but misdiagnosed it as a problem with the climate control system.  A 100 hour inspection and maintenance interval was coming up where the system was going to be thoroughly inspected and checked.

Aircraft start aborted. Inspected shimming of engine fuel nozzle per Rolls-Royce manufacturer. One thin shim was removed. On ground run up, verified start within limits and no other discrepencies noted. Aircraft returned to service per Regional Maintenance Inspector.

Due to multiple types and numbers of aircraft, the ATGS on 07/07/01 at 1720 requested a second air to air AM victor Freq. to use for Rotor wing A/C, the order was placed and the freq. was received at 1800 and relayed to the ATGS. At the end of his shift the ATGS requested an additional AM freq. to be used for fixed wing a/c and an air to ground FM frequency for 07/08/01 at 0600, to free up the initial attack frequencies.  The order was placed from GJC to RMC at 2110.  Upon arriving at work the next morning I received the frequencies assigned from RMC. After checking the frequencies assigned, I noticed that the air to ground FM freq. was already assigned and being used in vicinity of the Deer Creek fire.

Statement by Pilot, XXXXXXXXX.As I was on the water drop my bucket failed to open with the collective switch (button) so I tried the cyclic (button) and squeezed my whole hand and I bumped the pinky button that released my belly hook (pilot XXXXXXXXXXXX, 1015).Statement by HCWN, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXX.1002 didn’t notice but someone over the radio says spanky one of those days. I look up and notice that no line and bucket attached. Approached him, he informed me what his narrative says above. HEB1, XXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXXX34KA dropping long line and bucket. Crews on ground were well clear of drop area.
When pilot started Helicopter all electrical power was lost. Mechanic checked electrical systems and determined the battery was bad.

We had IA`ed a fire a few miles from our base. After bucketing for about 45 minutes I inadvertently pushed the belly release button while intending to push the longline release button. The nearly full bucket and longline impacted the ground on the interior of the fire and well away from personnel. I contacted ground personnel by radio then returned to base. There was no damage to the helicopter or injury to any person. The bucket was destroyed. The longline sheath was damaged and will need to be inspected thoroughly. I didn`t feel stressed or rushed. There was another medium in the circuit and air attack was well above. The tankers had come and gone. The fire was contained. There were no physiological or external factors that I can pinpoint as relevant. Wholly an error on my part.

Minutes after launching on an initial retardant run for the congested  Fire, the pilot experienced radio communication promblems. Unable to resolve this issue in flight, the pilot, per policy, returned to base, jettisoned the load, and landed. The radio cord from panel to helmet was replaced, and the SEAT rejoined the rotation.

XX Helicopter lifted from the XX Helibase and attempted to contact XX Dispatch on National Flight Following repeatedly.  XX Dispatch did not reply to XX Helicopter.  XX Helicopter switched to a forest frequency and made contact with XX Dispatch, at that time it was determined that National Flight Following is not being received into the dispatch center and the dispatch center is not able to transmit on National Flight Following.

Aircraft was landing at the helibase when a box containing a spare rotor blade was blown by rotor wash from the top of the company fuel truck.  The blade was damaged to the point of not being serviceable as a spare for the helicopter.  The combined total weight of the blade and the box is about 600 lbs.  Had anyone been in the area when the box fell, they could've been seriously injured or killed.  The box had been untied by one of the contractor's employees in preparation for placement of the blade on the helicopter. The pilot held a safety meeting with the crew and clarified duties of each.  The meeting was mandated by the company home office.

During bucket operations on the XXX fire the long line became wrapped over the rear right skid of the helicopter. Hotshots Perspective: Hotshots were working helo in division alpha doing bucket drops. Helo returned from dip to hotshots and made a drop. After the drop hotshots returned to work and did not see anything wrong during the drop. They noted that the pilot had been doing good work, but the winds were a little squirrely with an upslope component. The also stated that Helo was droping 50 to 100 feet above canopy. After drop helo returned to alpha dip. Div-A perspective: Div-A was at a cabin adjacent to alpha dip with an engine. Helo was going back and forth between alpha dip and dropping water in XXX canyon. There was a middle ridge in between the dip and where the drops were taking place. Distance from dip to middle ridge was described as around mile. Div-A noted that he saw the helo near the middle ridge and the bucket appeared to be flying erratically but was pretty far away and he was looking through some canopy when he made the observation. The Helo then arrived at the dip and the bucket started to come down through canopy. As the bucket came down an Engine crewmember alerted division that the long line was over the skid. Div-A contacted helo and alerted pilot as bucket was entering water. Pilot asked if it was over the front or back and was told back. Pilot then lifted and appeared to be releasing water as he lifted. Pilot then returned to Helitack to get fixed. Engine Perspective: Engine was at alpha dip with Div- A, Engine noticed Helo flying to dip making S-turns on the approach. As helo came to the dip and started to lower bucket towards water they saw the long line was over the skid and notified division. Pilot Comment - I was supporting XXX Hot Shots with a 240gal bambi bucket on the XXX Fire 06/26/2019 at approximately 1200 local time. At drop {{{#}}}11 my ground contact asked for a trail drop about 400 feet higher on the ridge above the previous drops. I made the drop and climbed over the ridge and started my descent to the dip site. The dip site was relatively close and at a lower altitude. I flew some S-turns to slow my forward progress to allow more time to descend. I filled the bambi bucket at the dip site and as I picked the bucket up the helicopter gently rolled a little to the right. I lowered the bucket back into the pond and slowly picked it up again and the same gentle roll repeated. I released the water because I suspected the long line was hung up somewhere on the helicopter’s landing gear. The dip site manager confirmed my suspicion. I released the water and flew back to Heli-Spot 3. Upon landing it was discovered the long line was over the portion of the skid tube behind the aft cross tube. My helitack crew fixed the problem and I returned to supporting the hot shots. The thunderstorms that air attack briefed us on were starting to form and winds were moderate but manageable. During my S-Turn descent my air speed was between 30-40kts to minimize forward progress to allow more time to descend to the dip site. My turns where never more then 20 degrees each direction and control movements during the drops where never excessive. Manager comments – Helicopter launched from helibase at 10:40am for bucket work. Helicopter was configured for bucket operations at H-3. Longline and bucket configuration was correctly completed and all checks were made without incident. Helitack personnel were at H-3 when Div informed Helicopter XXX of longline issue. As soon as Div reported the issue the pilot released the water and flew to the helispot. The helicopter was landing at the helispot when we took some photos of the longline over the skid. The manager spoke with the pilot while HECM’s fixed the longline as well as inspected it for any damage. No damage was identified on the longline, bucket or aircraft. The pilot and manager discussed any concerns with the weather, dip site and bucket operations overall. Pilot stated everything was going well but the winds were “squirrely” do to outflow winds from a system building nearby. He and I felt comfortable returning back to bucket operations to finish the 20 minutes left on the fuel cycle, which was completed without incident. When we returned to helibase we called an AMI about any concerns he may have. AMI had no concerns. We re-inspected the longline and bucket, everything looked as it should and was in good working order. XXX had completed 11 drops without incident prior to longline over skid incident. Air Attack had reported feeling outflow winds shortly before the incident with the longline. The distance between the dipsite and dropping area was approximately 1 mile with a ridge line between the two.

At aprox 1254 March 14, 2010 the helicopter was spooling up at the Airport. In aircraft were Pilot, FIRB, and PLDO. HMGB was aprox 50 feet in front of aircraft as crash rescue/fire protection. Aircraft was configured for aerial ignition mission on NF. Pilot and HMGB established good communication on air to ground frequency as a routine and did so as aircraft spooled up. Left front door of aircraft was off at FIRB’s request with Pilot’s approval. Aircraft was at flight idle. After comm check HMGB heard FIRB seconds later, on air to ground say, “could you hold on to this” as FIRB was digging in his left front pocket. HMGB then made it two steps toward aircraft to take object from FIRB then heard a sharp noise followed by several other noises aprox twenty feet to left side of aircraft. HMGB then hand signaled pilot to shut aircraft down. Pilot did not fully understand so HMGB approached pilot door to tell him to shut down. Dispatch was notified there was a situation and aircraft would be unable to perform aerial ignition for RX burn. Pilot, FIRB, PLDO, and HMGB discussed what had just happened. A pocket knife was under-hand tossed by FIRB from aircraft toward HMGB, which made contact with one main rotor blade. FIRB had attempted to toss the knife in the grass just off the asphalt in front of aircraft to avoid anything falling from aircraft during flight. Upon contact with the rotor, the knife burst into pieces landing off to the left side of the aircraft. Pilot inspected blades finding place of impact. HMGB called and notified Regional maintenance inspector at 1305. Pilot contacted Helicopter’s mechanic at same time. HMGB notified COR/AFMO of situation at 1328, and FMO 1444. Helicopter mechanic arrived at aprox 1530 and performed inspection of blades and aircraft. Inspection revealed two small gashes aprox 9 inches from tip of one blade and aprox 2 millimeters deep on the leading edge. Also found were several small paint chips on underside of blade which did not enter “honey comb” of blade. Mechanic then spoke with Regional Maintenance Inspector and Helicopter operator’s Chief of Maintenance for directions. Aircraft will remain at airport for the night to allow mechanic time to obtain proper equipment for a possible repair.

Drone incursion over fire area while rotor wing operations in progress. Resources notified and air ops shut down. Local law enforcement notified. Drone was seen leaving fire area into adjacent subdivision. Resumed air operation after 30 minutes. Drone operator not found.
Lower rudder hinge cover departed A/C. This part is not a required structural item.

HELICOPTER XXX, AN S-64 SKYCRANE WITH INTERNAL TANK ANDSNORKLE, WAS DOING WATER DROPS ON THE BOULDER FIRE ON 7/27/02.  UPONSHUTDOWN ON LAST SORTIE OF THE DAY, THE PILOT AND MAINTENANCE CREW CAMEOVER AND REPORTED A NEED TO REPLACE A DELAMINATING ROTOR BLADE.  THEREHAD BEEN NO STRIKE OR ACCIDENT REPORTED PRIOR.       AN INSPECTION OF THE BLADE REVEALED A 2inX4in PEEL BACK ON THE BOTTOMOF ONE ROTOR BLADE ABOUT ONE THIRD OF THE WAY DOWN FROM THE TIP. THE PEELTURNS OUTWARD AND LOOKS LIKE A inTEAR TO THE SHEETMETALin.  THE SPAR UNDERIT IS VISIBLE AND APPEARS UNDAMAGED.  THE BIMS READS WHITE, INDICATINGNO LOSS OF PRESSURE.  THE CREW REPORTED IT AS SOON AS IT WAS DISCOVERED,ABOUT 2030 HOURS.
AFTER FUELING, ABOUT 10 MINUTES INTO THE FLIGHT...MASTER CAUTION LIGHT CAME ON

While on a ferry flight from 5 mile airstrip after demobilizing the 757 fire. had a MASTER CAUTION and PANEL CAUTION light illuminate. The pilot had just turned on the guage lights switch when this happened. We identified an open gravel pit along the alaska pipeline that was flat. identified no hazards {lines, towers, cranes} and performed a precautionary landing. The pilot turned off and on the guage light switch and noticed a dimming and realized a bad contact in the switch. Reset panel caution. Reset Master caution. No further illumination of either Master or Panel Caution. Resumed flight, with no further incident.

ATGS: Assigned A/G Frequency 159.3450 had a tone of 192.80 on both RX and TX. When we arrived over the fire, we were calling the IC on A/G and he could hear our transmit but we could not hear his reply. I reprogramed the radio and removed the tone in RX and communication problem was solved.

NXXXX was flying air attack on the Burnt River Complex, over incident 154, call dispatch with a report that they lost an engine and were going to try to fly back to Baker on a single engine. At the time of engine failure, they were 22 miles out of Baker. Maintained Contact with NXXXX throughout the flight to Baker. They were able maintain altitude and land safely @ Baker without incident.Contacted Forest Aviation Officer and vendor. Also requested emergency response at the Baker Airport.

Aircraft had performed multiple crew shuttles as well as a cycle of bucket work on two fires that were in close proximity to each other. Aircraft set down for fuel at local IA helibase and was shut down preparing to shuttle additional FFTR’s into Fire. Helitack personnel opened right rear door to load gear and door dropped due to only being attached by the lower door pin. Upper door pin was missing. Helitack caught door preventing it from being damaged. How the pin became dislodged or when is unknown. Cause of the pin to become missing is also unknown, but previous inspections have revealed one of two ball bearings missing that could potentially allow for the pin to back its way out of the door hinge.

Ordered an infra Red flight of our slash burns for 5/19/97. Was told by the vendor that their radio was not operating and so their helicopter had not been carded as yet. They arranged to use a Bell BIII to complete the flight using a Westcam infra red camera. When I arrived at the vendor's the camera installation was nearly complete and the pilot was waiting for the weights and balance calculations. The Westcam camera is a nose mount weighing 80 lbs. It was determined that you could operate as long as no one was in the left front seat and a 30 gallon fuel reserve was maintained. Mission went foreword with out incident however I have real concerns about the IR mounting system which is a temporary mount: 1) It obviously makes a significant change in aircraft CG and reduces the amount of useable fuel (this mission was flown by a light-weight pilot and I'm not aware of any lighter pilots, a heavier pilot may not have been able to complete this mission). 2) The ground clearance of the camera is approximately 4 inches. This is ok if your operating from a cement pad as this mission was but would be unworkable on most fires or other field operations. 3) No agency personnel were on this flight but on some IR missions it may be desirable. I think this system needs to be looked at before someone decides to do so.

T-XX was flying a mission on the Plateau Fire {H86L} UT-FIF. At approximately 1932 hours on 22 July 2014, T-XX called in an emergency for a landing at CDC. Lead ATBM received the radio message on ramp frequency, told T-XX that they were on ramp and asked them if they needed us to call 911. The response was no for a 911 call. At 1935 hours, ATBM noticed the right engine prop was not turning on landing and confirmed this on the taxi. T-XX parked at the FBO. LATBM then contacted R4 AV Maintenance Program Manager, ATBM left a message with Grangeville Aircraft Administration Base, and then acting UAM UT-FIF was notified. Color Country UAM & Cedar City Air Center Manager was present during the incident. T-XX was returning from delivering 2nd load of retardant from Cedar city when this occurred. The tanker was at the outermarker of the ILS Approach when the pilot felt the aircraft yaw and saw the Tachometer gauges split. They then went into their normal emergency procedures consistent with training shutting down {{#}}2 recip, started jets, and landed at CDC with no issues. Contractor maintenance staff at the base began troubleshooting the engine.

At approximately 1745 Helicopter Helicopter1 entered a dipsite on the Rogue River after Helicopter2 had departed. The lighting was flat, and as Helicopter1’s FAST bucket entered the water, it rolled over into itself and the wires became tangled with the power head. The pilot re-positioned the bucket on a gravel bar adjacent to the dipsite to see if the problem could correct itself. The re-positioning caused one of the tangled wires to push the retaining band and gasket off, which holds the bucket material around the gate valve. The pilot notified Air Attack of the issue and was directed back to base along with the other helicopter as sunset was approaching. There was minor damage to the bucket consisting of two cables that had become kinked, and the missing band and gasket. No other damage was found.

On initial contract and mission briefing, Dec 31, 2006, pilot for 5878M when asked about a/c maintenance schedule informeds the ATGS that maintenance specifically the next 100 hr would not be an issue, alot of time left. On Jan 3, 2006 the pilot informed the ATGS he had been mistaken there was only 7 hours left before the 100 hr. ATGS explained that at the current use rate that would be about 2 days out, and to, if possible, make arrangements for an overnite mtc in order to reduce unavailability. At approximately 2000, Jan 3, the pilot informed ATGS that they had in fact overflown the 100hr and he would need to fly the aircraft back to Amarillo,TX and would not be back until Friday Jan 6. ATGS informed the pilot neither of these things was acceptable and that he was recommending the A/C be released and replaced with another A/C. Hot Springs Dispatch was informed and ICP concurred and the N5878M was released.
On returning to Fox ATB from the Piru Fire, the pilot reported he had a broken flap follower.  Landed without incident.  South Zone Avn advised.

While engaged in an air attack mission, pilot noted a discharge light from the voltage meter and subsequently observed fluctuations in the alternator output. As the shift was almost over and aerial supervision was not required, the aircraft was returned to the airport.

A chip light came on during the return from bucket drops to helibase. The pilot continued flying to the helibase with no major decreases to the helicopter performance as the left fuel pump and auxiliary fuel pumps were still functioning properly. Upon landing, the mechanic diagnosed the problem as not enough power flowing through the right fuel boost pump. After inspection it was determined that the fuel boost pump was no longer working correctly and needed to be replaced. A replacement fuel boost pump was ordered and arrangements were made by the vendor to deliver the pump to the Burley airport the following day.

Low Voltage light was on after take off. Pilot was going through the steps to reset voltage with no success. The AOBS-T offered to go back to Alturas airport and was advised by the pilot it was fine. We proceeded with the recon flight and all went well till the last 15 min of the flight when the radios tied to the AOBS and AOBS-T stopped working.

116 was enroute back from the fire to the helibase for water and noticed a 206-L3 flying 300-400' AGL just south of the helibase.  No evasive maneuvers were needed.  Helibase personnel recognized the L3 as a Globe medivac ship.

Noticed oil leak on transmission line. Shutdown & repaired. During restart No. 1 engine throttle cable binding was noted. No. 1 throttle cable re-rigged. Operational check normal. Mike Brady notified. Placed back to availability 1850.

Arriving back to the Stead Airtanker base the crew selected gear down. There was no light indication for the right gear. The crew departed the airport traffic area to run checklists and trouble shoot the problem. The crew found that the bulb on the right gear indicator was burned out. Crew made a normal landing.

While washing the underside of the wing the co-pilot discovered a 12 inch crack in the underside of the wing.  This crack extended aft of the inboard center wing inspection panel and was approximately 6 to 8 inches from the fuselage.  Upon inspection of the opposite wing small cracks were found running aft of two inspection panels (inboard and outboard).  These inspection panels are in the center/underside of the wing, between the nacelle and the fuselage.The Captain acertainied that this was a stress or weight bearing section of the wing and took the aircraft out of service, pending full inspection and evaluation of the cracked areas.  Other P2V aircraft at GJT were asked to wash and visually inspect the same area of the wing.Region 2 Safety and RAO were notified - They contacted the Boise Office.The Captain contacted Neptune Inc.

Sometime during the last water dropping mission of the day, the window on the cargo door became separated from the door and was lost. This occurrance was discovered when the helicopter landed at the helibase. Since the window was not found, the actual cause of the window loss is unknown.

I hope that this Safecom gets wide distribution to all aircraft ground support personnel (fixed wing and rotor). There are some very valuable lessons learned within this Safecom.I was on standby in Grand Junction acting as ATP (Air Tactical Pilot.) It was the end of the standby shift and we had just finished plugging the aircraft with intake plugs, pitot covers and prop stops. I was inside the cabin when ramp manager approached with a dispatch to a fire. The mechanic that is always with the aircraft, standing outside, said that he would unplug the aircraft while I stayed inside the plane. I watched him as he traveled around the airplane grabbing the plugs and other equipment. I watched as he placed the bag of items unplugged into the plane. The cockpit checklist was complete up to engine start and started the right engine. The ATS (Air Tactical Supervisor) yelled stop engine, which I did. At the same time I noticed the ramp manager giving the stop engine sign. There was still and engine plug in the intake of the engine. There was no damage caused, as there were only one or two revolutions of the prop before the cut sign was given (no engine light off). A complete walk around was performed and a restart was done after another complete checklist was completed. Engine was started with no mishap.As embarrassing as this is for me, there are several lessons learned here that I would like to comment on.1.	As pilot in command I should have been the person to remove all the plugs from the aircraft. The PIC is responsible for the pre-flight of the aircraft. It would have only taken me but a few seconds to perform the task and ensure of a proper preflight. This is a classic example of “complacency.”2.	The use of ramp managers and other personnel such as them are invaluable to the safety of the aircraft and the crews in and around them.3.	This situation shouts CRM. In the many years of aerial fire fighting, I have had several ground personnel come up to me and point out things on the aircraft that they had a question about. 90% of the time it was something if importance. The ATS was watching the ramp manager as I was looking at the flight panel. Using the two-crew members in the ASM role caught the engine stop signal way before I would have if it had been a single pilot operation.Job well done on the part of Ramp Manager, because of his actions, we didn’t cause any damage to the aircraft and were able to continue with the mission.

Helicopter XXX responded to a call for initial attack resources to the Travertine fire in Death Valley National Park. The Type 2 ship dropped of its helitack crew on the fire and intiated bucket drops on the fire. The fuel truck for XXX was routed to the fire by an initial route through Trona, CA. It was then turned around and rerouted to the scene via a longer route. XXX ceased initial attack operation due to low fuel and landed near the NW flank of the fire. After an extended down time and encroachement into the vicinity by the head of the fire, the pilot was forced to relocate the ship. Due to low fuel the ship was not able to fly less than 2 miles to the nearby Furnace Creek Airport. It landed in a small parking lot of the Furnace Creek Inn adjacent to Hwy 190. Fortunately the Inn was closed for the season and no vehicles were present in the lot. The low fuel condition of the aircraft forced the pilot to land in a compromised landing zone that was not designated for this purpose. The Furnace Creek Airport is in close proximity to the Furnace Creek Inn. The XXX fuel truck arrived at the end of the operational period rendering XXX inoperable for most of the operational period on the fire. Additional acres were lost to the fire as a result. HWY 190 was closed as the fire burned westward on the north side of the highway. The fire was contained by NPS/BLM engine crews along the road.

7/17/2014 Two TFR’s were in place over their respective fires. The fires rapidly grew the night of 7/17-18 growing 20 miles beyond the boundaries of the TFRs. Four fires effectively merged into one which became a complex fire. 7/18/2014 In the morning, Air Attack noticed that a private company had taken independent action outside the TFRs on the fires southern perimeter with ground forces {crew, dozer,etc}. They had two helicopters supporting the private independent action outside the TFR. The helicopters did not have communications with fire team ATGS. The ATGS contacted Air Attack and it was decided that the ATGS would attempt contact with the private helicopters while Air Attack continued duties elsewhere on the now very large incident. The ATGS contacted them at the local airport and made arrangement for the forces to continue, as not being a factor to government supervised aircraft, as long as they were in communication on ATGS assigned Air to Air and Air to Ground Frequencies. Later that day at 1830, another TFR was put into place that covered the current fire and expected growth. The new TFR extended over the area the private crews were working. The private ships continued operation while the ATGS’s kept other incident aircraft separated from them. 7/19/2014 Private fire forces continued to take action as the day before, but now the TFR was in place that covered their operations where two private helicopters were working. Fire forces engaged the fire, specifically trying to protect a structure. The complex fire forces on the ground tried contacting the helicopters. The ATGS tried also. Neither helicopter communicated with the ATGS to ask permission to enter the TFR, nor did they communicate when asked to do so. All complex fire aviation forces were withdrawn from the area. Ground forces did not feel safe without agency air support so they also disengaged. The manager of the private company was contacted later in the day by the complex IC who explained the gravity of TFR violation and the effect of their forces on the planned action of the complex forces. The manager said his forces would comply with the communications, but would continue to take independent action with all his forces. 7/20/2014 Private forces continued action. The private company requested a change in the TFR so they could dry cherry orchards with predicted rain on 7/22 and fight fire. Private aircraft did comply with radio communications. Complex aviation assets were separated from their forces. 7/21/2014 Private forces continued action. Private aircraft did comply with radio communications. Complex aviation assets were separated from their forces. The fire behavior was such by then that a change in the TFR was justified. The TFR was changed effective about 1800 and to continue daily. This TFR excluded the orchards and the independent fire action area.

Severe west northwest winds repositioned the parked unmanned aircraft. The aircraft was parked positioned facing south in the center of the pad. H-XXX came to rest with the nose facing west and the tail boom impacting the fuel trailer. The fuel trailer was parked outside the rotor area at the south east portion of the helipad. The helicopter blown by severe winds was moved 8 feet from its original parked position and impacted the fuel trailer at the south east part of the pad. The helicopter sustained damage to the horizontal stabilizer and bent the tail boom. The fuel truck incurred damage to the basket storage mounts, however the fuel cell was not ruptured. There was safe parking clearance for both pieces of equipment involved. The helicopter had been observed at 20:45 by the contractors to be OK when they left for dinner. Between 21:45 and 22:00 the moved aircraft was noticed by the employees and was reported to the Helitack at 22:30.

MAFFS Tail #8MAFFS Unit #8MAFFS 8 was on a actual fire drop at the Rattle Complex in Southern Utah.  Just after the drop was started the aft V band on the right retardant discharge tube ruptured and filled the aircraft with retardant.  After allowing as much retardant as possible to drain, the ramp and door were closed and an uneventful return and landing were accomplished.  The two loadmasters (LM) were completely covered with retardant and consulted with a Flight Surgeon on Hill AFB and were released for duty.  During the event, communications were lost between the LM's and front end crew.

Crew was alerted for a MAFFS mission to the Million Fire from Colorado Springs at 1500 local(mdt), after sitting on standby for the previous 3 days without flying.  This was the first fire mission for this crew, this season.  It was discovered in the pits, prior to launch, that the MAFFS unit dispensing tubes would not relock in the exended position once brought into the aircraft.  So the pilot decided to leave the tubes out and locked and fly to the fire unpressurized.  On the previous flight (deployment from Charlotte, NC to Co. Springs)an equipment malfunction code affecting the radar was discovered by the crew, which resolved itself well prior to reaching Co. Springs and showed no further indication of degradation.  Just prior to take off on the incident flight, the crew again had the equipment malfunctions code, and took off expecting to code to clear.  After takeoff the pilot climbed to 10,000 msg and visually cleared terrain crossing the first ridge southwest of Co. Springs and on across the valley that provided terrain clearance.  During this time the navigator was having increasing difficulty using the radar for terrain clearance.  The visibility was deteriorating but still well above VFR.  As the crew worked to clear the radar problem and plot position using GPS, the pilot was skirting high terrain on the left with lower terrain on the right.  The pilot attempted to cut across the end of a ridge extending from the terrain on the left to the valley on the right.  As the aircraft passed the extension of the ridge on the right he realized that he may be able to cross the saddle and went to maximum power and flaps 50%.  The flight engineer closed the engine bleed valves for maximum power.  After a few seconds the crew realized for sure they would not clear the saddle on the right and the pilot turned left up the canyon towards the last remaining option, a shallow saddle between two peeks.  The pilot directed emergency drop of the retardant load and flaps to 60%.  The copilot and loadmasters accomplished the drop and the copilot positioned the flaps to 60%.  As the load went out, the aircraft climbed over the saddle and out over low terrain.  The crew returned to Co.Springs, uneventfully, and shut down for the day.

Upon lift off / departure from RDD pilot and ATGS immediately noticed very hot air blowing from the air vents and aircraft had a haze in the cabin. Pilot made a quick check of aircraft vents to no effect. Pilot immediately called tower and asked for priority landing at RDD and returned the aircraft to RDD. The whole flight lasted less than 5 minutes.

Mission: The Aircraft was performing sling missions on the Miller Incident delivering miscellaneous sling loads, including 72 gal. blivits, lunches, 5 gal water containers {QBs}, and back pack pumps to three different sights. Distances form Trinity Center to sling sights 16.6 miles Elevation of Miller 5650 feet Elevation of Trinity Center 2500 feet Max temps for the day 70-72 Mission Brake down: @ 1330 Aircraft is configured for long line missions. Long line is hooked up to belly. Long line is connected with a clevis to a second clevis connected to the remote with two zip ties through the keeper pins of both clevises. One helicopter crew member performed as a second observed. After completing hook up a 3rd crew member performs a check with the pilot. @ 1400 Aircraft departs Trinity Center enroute to Sling Sight 3 with 1285 lbs, Aircraft delivers load. @ 1433 Aircraft returns to Trinity Center picks up 2nd load 1555 lbs and delivers to Sling Sight 1, @ 1457 Aircraft returns to Trinity Center to pick up 3rd load, helicopter crew members observed electrical connection was disconnected crew members reconnect tape and connects 3rd load of 1345 lbs. @ 1506 Aircraft arrives at Sling Sight 1 with load, attempts to disconnect but is unable to. Helicopter crew member disconnects load manually and checks connections nothing seems to be out of place, Aircraft returns to Trinity Center. @ 1523 Aircraft was observed from Trinity Center Helibase. Long line is observed to be flying with an unusual flight attitude. The pilot identified that the remote was missing and landed pad 1 at Trinity center. Upon further inspection, the remote hook had been detached from long line. The eye of the long line is undamaged: the electrical cord with connection had been ripped off. @ 1600 Vender made arrangements for a new remote to be delivered to Weaverville. @ 1630 Venders mechanic inspects long line and repairs electrical connections. @ 1700 Phone call was made to Aviation Maintenance Inspector. A conversation about the long line and its ability to return to service was held. Long line was determined to be useable after proper documentation was completed. @ 1745 An After Action Review was performed with all Helibase personal. @ 1935 Aircraft returns to Home base and shuts down for the day.

At about 1730 hours, July 14, 2003, Coronado Initial Attack Dispatch called me to see if I was available to fly to the San Carlos Apache Indian Reservation to work on an initial attack fire, the Popcorn Incident.  I replied that I was, and acquired all the necessary information, including resource order numbers, frequencies, air and ground contacts, etc.  My pilot and I departed Tucson International Airport (TIA) at 1816, under partly cloudy, but threatening skies.  Airport weather indicated moderate to severe thunderstorms to the northeast and southeast of the airport. As we cleared the terrain to the north of Tucson, we began to receive radio traffic from the SCA aerial observer, P3, who was flying over the fire, and I called San Carlos Dispatch to let them know I was inbound to the Popcorn Fire, and approximate ete to the fire.  San Carlos Dispatch told me that P3 was over the fire and that he seemed to be having trouble transmitting over the assigned VHF frequency, 127.975. Between 1824 and 1857 hours, as we approached the fire area, P3 was attempting to talk to heavy air tanker, T55, SEATS 411 and 459, both flying out of the SEAT Base at Whiteriver, and me, on VHF 127.975.  As I got closer, it became apparent that the pilot who was flying P3 was in communication with T55, who was on scene, and that from the target description being given to T55, the P3 pilot intended to drop T55`s retardant load on the fire.  At 1850, T55 did drop his load on the fire.  When I got to within 12 nautical miles to the south of the fire, I called P3 on the victor frequency to seek permission to proceed to the fire.  As he had his hands full, he told me to stay where I was until he told me otherwise.  We went into an orbit around the east side of San Carlos Reservoir, and I noted that the air was extremely filled with smoke at that point.  We were orbiting at 9,500' and as we listened to the radio traffic, the overload on the observer was apparent.  At about that time, first he mentioned that two unidentified helicopters had gone through his airspace from the direction of Whiteriver, and a little later, he said that a news media helicopter had entered the airspace unannounced and without permission.By then, the two SEATS who had been working the fire were back in the airspace, and it didn't seem that either the pilot or observer of P3 had a firm grasp on the situation.  At this point, my pilot, whom I was flying with for the first time on 07/14/03, told me he felt very uncomfortable entering or proceeding into the airspace under the present escalating circumstances, so I called P3 and then San Carlos Dispatch and told them I thought they had an unsafe situation on their hands and that we were returning to Tucson.  They told me that was my option, so at 1857 hours, we returned to Tucson, where we landed at 1922.

While returning to Waldo HLB, Master Caution Light for the generator came on. Pilot reset generator caution light twice and light went off. The Master Caution light did not go off however,pilot tried to reset Master Caution light numerous times, but light did not go off.Pilot landed at helibase safely and without incident.Pilot notified Helibase and helicopter manager of problem.Helicopter Manager made notifications to regional aircraft safety inspector.

Pilot was picking up a load of water with a bambi bucket on the belly hook and as he started out of the dip site he felt a locking up of the the control systems followed by a surge accompanied by a grinding noise in the area of the transmission. This was followed by a complete loss of hydraulic control. An emergency procedure for hydraulic failure was implemented. The pilot was approximately 4 miles from the Bremerton Airport at the time. The pilot jettisoned the water and on short final jettisoned the bucket and accomplished a running landing. The pilot landed the aircraft with no damage to the bucket or the aircraft.An inspection at the airport by the lead mechanic found that an aluminum hydraulic line coming out of the filter had completely broken apart, resulting in a complete loss of hydraulic fluid. The break occurred under  the ferrel fitting and the two ends totally separated.Pilot performed a perfect emergency (by the book) hydraulic failure landing.

While on landing at PGD, tanker #xxx had a tire go flat on the left main landing gear.  Captain XXXX was able to clear the runway and move the tanker onto a taxi-way, where the air tanker now sits.  H&P mechanics are enroute to PGD to fix the tire.  Tanker #xxx is not available at 1349 until further notice.                        6/4/01, 1545 hrs.

Replaced retardant tank control box by crew chief prior to duty day. Unit was tested and signed off as operational prior to start of day. After retardant was loaded onboard the aircraft, taxi and run-up were completed. Tank system was then turned on and armed for take-off and taxi to active was begun. At that time the distinct sound of a door opening was heard, and visual check confirmed there was retardant on the taxiway. Control panel was visually checked again for proper settings with no errors noted. Taxi and take-off were completed with no additional problems until some distance down the runway when other doors of retardant were opened without command. System was shut off at or just after rotation. Over the jettison area the system was rearmed, at which time the last door opened without selection or normal operation by crew. Normal landing was made.

Our helicopter was requested to conduct a cargo let down for a medivac mission.  We arrived at the designated lat/long and attempted to establish communication with the ground contact.  (Strike Team Leader)  After several attempts the EMT on site responded.  We told him to alert the STL that we were trying to establish communication with him.  When I established contact I informed him to inclear all personnel of the cargo area until the mission is completein.  I then repeated myself.  Once all personnel were clear of the area I conducted the let down.  Once the cargo was on the ground I started to de-rig the let down line.  I looked out the door to maintain a tight line and check the rotars when I saw the individual attempting to unhook the cargo - I told him to clear the area but it was too late.  The let down line was free of the cargo with nothing to weight it down.  I instructed the pilot to lift up as I cut the line free from the helicopter.

Departing from BJC after checking in with Pueblo Dispatch it was relayed that the AFF was non-operable. In addition it was discovered that the COM 5 FM radio was not functioning properly. It was decided by the ATGS to continue the mission with just the one FM radio. Lead XX was over the fire as well and could monitor frequencies and alert the ATGS of missed calls due to the failure of the 2nd FM.

At approximately 1400 hours, a jumper aircraft, Jumper 51, transitioned through the Rattle Complex TFR at 10,000' AMSL, east to west.  I contactedthe aircraft on Guard but he identified himself only as injumper ship.in  After contacting Moab Dispatch we learned the aircraft identifier, departure, and destination.

After completing crew shuttle, the pilot noticed the generator fail light was on. Mechanic took a quick look and they decided to fly the ship back to Cortez Airport (six minutes). At the airport mechanic troubleshot the generator system. No faults were found and pilot performed startup generator re-set and helicopter then operated normally. Called equipment specialist and he ok'd putting ship back in service. There were no problems the next day.

During a spot maintenance and safety inspection of Nxxxx by the Regional Aviation Maintenance Inspector (AMI) and Regional Aviation Safety Manager (RASM) it was noted that there was 'duct tape' on the radome of the aircraft.  When the Pilot-in-Command (PIC) was asked about the nature of this non-approved repair he stated that the duct tape was covering the damage of a bird strike.  When asked if the bird strike damage was written in the aircraft maintenance log, the PIC stated that there was no write up but that the FAA had approved the repair.  When asked if the FAA had put this in writing the PIC indicated that they had but he did not have this document on board the aircraft. I informed the PIC that this was an unapproved repair and that the structual integrity of the radome is compromised.  He had nothing else to say and asked us to leave so they could get under way.  I notified  the regional coordination center that the aircraft should not be requested until this issue is resolved.  I also notified the AMI and Contracting Officer of the Host Region and left messages and I attempted to contact the affected FSDO FAA office with no results.

Upon returning from incident 167 the previous evening the Hatfield gate on T-XXX gate would not shut all the way. After a short delay the pilot was able to get the gate to close, and a load was pumped onto the aircraft. Due to time of day T-XXX sat loaded overnight. On the morning of the 25th pilot informed SEMG that the circuit breaker to the dump gate had popped, and per the company mechanic the pilot had reset it as well as checked for loose connections. SEMG informed a Tech Rep of the issue and was advised to watch the situation and if there were any other problems or issues to call. T-XXX was dispatched to Incident 167 and after a successful 2 drops again had problems with the gate not closing all the way, only this time the circuit breaker did not pop. T-XXX was taken out of service.

Original Text:Official Sunset 2008 Civil Twilight 2038 2008 I contacted the manager for H-9EH at the Craig airport (since he had just returned from the Pagoda fire) to see if he had talked to H-185 to see when he was going to return to Craig since Civil Twilight was fast approaching and I also asked him to remain at the Craig Airport in order to give the pilot and fuel truck driver for H-185 a ride to their motel. The manager for H-9EH indicated that as far as he knew H-185 was going to remain the fire over night. This did not sound right, so I contacted Pagoda helibase. 2010 I called Pagoda helibase on the dispatch radio. The helibase indicated that H-185 had departed 7 minutes ago headed for the Craig airport. I then tried to contact H-185 on National Flight Following and then on the local freq''s with no results. 2029 I once again contacted the manager for H-9EH at the Craig airport to se if H-185 had returned to Craig. He indicated that the pilot and fuel truck driver were in the back of his vehicle and the helicopter had landed 10 minutes ago.

While performing large fire support on the Incident, an oil leak was discovered. Oil was dripping out of the valve and pooling in the carriage. 7/2/04 This narrative is an ammendment to the SAFECOM filed for this helicopter on 6/30/2004 (submitted by Helicopter Manager). Narrative: While performing a longline hookup I noticed a couple of puffs of white smoke come out of the left side cowl. I immediately had the pilot land and shut down the A/C. Upon inspection a leak was discovered on the breather tube flange that returns excess oil to the exhaust to be burned off. After discussion with the pilot it was determined that the helicopter needed to be repaired and that it would become un-available. I discussed the problem with my HELB(t) and we decided one of us needed to return to helibase to begin working on getting the helicopter repaired. The HELB(t) flew to helibase with the A/C. While I had confidence in the judgement of the pilot that the leak did not jeopardize the safety of the flight, I should have not asked the HELB(t) to fly down with the ship. This was a MAJOR oversight on my part. Policy dictates that when a problem is discovered that the A/C becomes unavailable @ that point. Once unavailable NO government personnel should be transported until the A/C is returned to service by an appropriate maintenance inspector.

At 1600 helicopter 205WW was dispatched to Incident  564 near Tonasket, Wa. We received all of the info for the fire including lat & long. I gave the pilot the lat & long and he went to put it into the GPS and the GPS did not work. So the pilot and mechanic took a look at it and the lithium battery was dead. They were going to take out the battery but Trimble said it would ruin the GPS. Later that day there was a mission to pull 19 people off H-55 and the pilot has been on this Complex for 2 months and has flown to 55 many times. In the contract it is required have a GPS. So I put them unavailable even though he has flown the fire many times and doesn’t need a GPS to get there for the ferry mission. It would be very easy to send Lon to 55 but I have read too many safecoms that start out small but end up in a bad situation. Corrective Action:GPS will be here next morning and will be up and running by 1000.

While lifting up off the helibase, for a rappel check ride, the cargo hook came opened. The load didn’t come off the ground, but as the helicopter lifted, the Velcro breakaway strap separated and fell to the ground. I informed the pilot and he confirmed what happened. We landed and did a hook check again, and continued on with the mission with no other problems encountered. We did a hook check earlier for the first longline mission of the day and encountered no problems with the mission. And we did 5 mockups with cargo, prior and the load was attached.

While in flight this N 1 gauge failed and engine out caution light illuminated. A normal landing was accomplished, upon shut down the gauge started working again. This aircraft was de-rigged and returned to Naples Airport. Upon landing at Naples Airport, the N 1 gauge failed and engine out caution light illuminated again.

Post flight inspection revealed a hair-line crack at the main rotor blade tip.  Removed and replace m.r.b.  Test/maintenance flight proved aircraft airworthy.  M.I. (R-5) approved aircraft return to contract availability.  A/C non-available for one hour. (Flight maintenance log faxed to R-5 M.I.)

During departure with 2 nets weighing 1600lbs, NXXX did not gain enough altitude to clear the canopy north of the Helibase. Load calc at 7000 @ 25 was 1825lbs. Manager told pilot to return to cargo and place loads on deck, pilot did so. NXXXX than took different loads weighing less with no problem. Upon completion of mission the pilot realized he turned the pitch control setting (dial) 30 degrees in the wrong direction. He set it at -30 instead of +30. This caused the ship to show itself redlining while it still had enough power for the load.

Helicopter NXXXXX (H-52) was assigned to the Big Wash fire on 6-6-02 (Cedar City BLM). H-52 was reconing division W with Operations and the Safety Officer. Air attack 69 November was on station along with helicopter Hotel Tango and Hotel Quebec (who where doing bucket work for division W). H-52 was orbiting Division W at 9000' MSL and coordinating with division (on air to ground). The elevation of the fire being around 8400'. While watching helicopter Hotel Tango returning from a drop, an unidentified fixed wing underflew H-52 going southbound (Later identified as Lead 44). Neither H-52 or helicopter Hotel Tango had heard that Lead 44 was in the area. When H-52 inquired to air attack about other fixed wing in the area, Air Attack responded in Lead 44in.

While performing a reconnaissance/GPS mapping flight for a fast moving DNR fire, helicopter pilot noticed an airplane making a low pass in front of the helicopter. Pilot responded by making a sharp right turn, discontinuing the mission and returned to the helispot. Radio contact was made with the lead plane assigned to the fire and it was determined that the lead plane made the low pass. The leadplane pilot acknowledged that he did not warn the helicopter of the intended low pass and apologized.
