Leadplane pilot indicated his TCAS alerted him to the presence of the helicopter causing him to take evasive manouvers. Helicopter pilot did not feel there had been a danger of collision, but his comfort level was exceeded. He later stated that in his opinion in view of intense air activity, the need for the recon/GPS mapping mission was questionable and that those missions should have been carried out by ground personnel or at a later time. At the time of the incident, Air Attack was away for refueling and 5 air tankers, 2 leadplanes, a SEAT, a PBY and 2 helicopters were assigned to the fire.

Landed at the airport and taxied to the FBO. Pilot requested the plane to be refueled, during the refueling process the right-wing fuel cap would not come off of the tank. The relief pilot for the company was on scene and is an A&P certified mechanic, assessed the problem, finally got the fuel cap removed. The problem was the sealing gasket on the tank had turned and was over the vent tube which pushed it up at an angle that didn’t allow the twist lock the ability to twist to let the cap come off.

Helibase Mgmt Comments: While working on the incident it was determined that multiple helibases would work better, one for each type of helicopter. There were new areas designated for the two new helibases. I was sent to help develop Blue helibase with several folks. We left the main helibase, Milan, with the impression that we were to get the helibase operational and then we would call back and have the ships sent over. The people running Milan Helibase were under the impression that they would send the ships out to do bucket work and after there fuel cycle would land at Blue Helibase. Before Blue helibase was operational helicopters started coming over to land. This came as a bit of a surprise to us working to get Blue Helibase ready since we did not know they were coming. The pad makers were laid out, but not all of the brush had been taken out of the safety circles. This was one of several things that were not ready when the helicopters started coming. Helicopter xxxx was one of the ships coming into land. The pilot was told to land on pad one and that a marsheller was heading out there. The marsheller got out there about the same time that xxxx was trying to set down his bucket. The marsheller moved out of the way and did not marshel the helicopter down. After the marsheller got out of the way and turned around he notice that the tail of xxxx was close to a bush near the edge of the safety circle. The pilot at this point was looking down as he was landing the ship. So the marsheller was not able to notify the pilot with hand signals. This was when the helicopter was almost down. After the pilot had shut down and got out he notice his tail was just above a juniper bush. At this point the bush was cut out. The helicopter''s mechanic looked at the tail rotor and told the Helicopter Manager that no damage had been done. At about 1330 after flying .8 of an hour it was realized, between the Mechanic and Helicopter Manager, that there had been a green smudge on the tail rotor. At this point the Helibase called Air Attack and had xxxx return to base and shut down. There are several lesson that have been learned. 1. The importance of positive communications 2. Clean all obstructions out of safety circles 3. If Parking Tenders are not giving hand signals they need to be able to communicate via radio with the pilots. Pilot Comments: After helibase radioed that they were ready for me to land, I made my approach into the wind to pad #1. Marshaller was in place. I set water bucket down between the marshaller and the pad marker.I decended down to a 10 ft. hover and looked ahead at the marshaller, he was not marshalling,only standing and watching. He gave no indication of any hazard. I looked down and continued to land. After shutdown, I exited the helicopter and saw a juniper bush under the tail roter. In addition to other contributing factors, such as the helibase not ready to recieve landing helicopters, and the marshaller not giving any hand signals. The landing saftey circle was clearly not adequate for this helicopter. At a minimum the approach and departure path should have been cleared of brush in accordance to the IHOG chapter 8. The 90ft saftey circle is not large enough.If the pad marker is in the middle of the saftey circle and a helicopter lands with the nose on the pad, the tail roter will be outside the saftey circle. I recommend that the IHOG be changed to provide an adequate safey circle. Also, after discussion with helibase manager, I was informed that they were told by the regional helicopter operations specialist, in region 3, that a marshaller was not required, and a parking tender was to be used.

At 1548 on 08/19/2010 while working the Aircraft Desk on the Forest Dispatch office, I received a call from Medford Interagency Dispatch that there is a helicopter enroute to a fire on the Willamette NF.  The helicopter will be flying close to our boundary so they wanted to give us a heads up.  I followed the helicopter on National Flight Following and when the helicopter got close to our forest boundary I advised the Air Attack of the presence of the helicopter.  As the helicopter came farther onto the forest, I called the other dispatch to see if they had contact with the helitanker and was told yes they were talking to the helitanker on National Flight Following. {I could not hear them talking}.  Air Attack was unable to raise the helitanker on either air to air or on National Flight following.  We tried calling the helicopter multiple times also.  While keeping a vigilant look at AFF because of all the aircraft we had in the air at the time, I saw that the helicopter was flying right toward our fire.  I immediately contacted Air Attack on the radio to make sure he had a visual on the helicopter and air attack said he did but still could not raise the Helicopter on Air to Air or NFF. The helicopter flew through our fire and continued flying to the north and then was no longer a safety issue to our aircraft. During this time I was also on the phone with the other dispatch trying to get them to contact the helicopter.  Again, I was told that the aircraft dispatcher had contact with the helicopter.  I informed them that the helicopter was flying right through the Temporary Flight Restriction and was told they would contact the pilot again on the radio.  We did not hear back from the other dispatch.  I told the primary Air Attack about what had happened and he said he would have the Unit Aviation Officer {UAO} contact me.  I told the UAO what had happened and was asked to file a Safecom.

Approximately 10 minutes into retardant dropping mission ----- experienced a chip light on the #2 engine. Informed Air Attack he was returning to base. Upon landing the Asst. Crew Chief removed the chip plug and removed the infuzzin. 239CH returned to the fire.

After taking off from the Air Attack base at 1130 for the Dinely Fire on Tulare Unit, Cal Fire, I was programming in the incident frequencies and the AM 3 radio shut off and would not come back on. I took the pilots AM 1 once we were clear of tower traffic with Fresno and used that as 122.925 for briefing victor. I typically use AM 3 for tactical rotor traffic, so I used AM 2 for that function. I would have typically not continued to the incident without all of the radios working, but there was an immediate structure threat reported so we continued to the incident. We were relieved by AA-XXX at 1230 and returned to FAAB. We went U/A upon landing at FAT.

While en route to the Silverado Fire the aircraft indicated a flap fault on the master warning system. After following the QRH it was determined that the flaps were in a position other than indicated on the flap position indicator. The crew determined that the mission should be aborted due to the abnormality and the continued risk of the flaps becoming inoperative. The retardant load was jettisoned in the jettison area at the nearest tanker base and the aircraft landed uneventfully.

After previous issues related to long-line operations on the XXX Fire during the previous shift, the pilot, manager, and Supt. had a discussion regarding continued long-line operations. It was decided that the pilot would take part in the first long-line operations for the day. At 1400 helicopter  departed Helibase for the cargo area to retrieve a load of approximately 1500 pounds using a 150 foot long line to deliver this load to the fire. After making his initial orbit and attaining positive communication with resources on the ground the helicopter made its inbound approach. Helicopter made a sustained hover over the cargo area at a consistent elevation for over 3-4 minutes. It did not appear from the perspective of the manager or those involved in the cargo operation that was making significant progress on delivering the cargo hook to the cargo area.
At 1245 T-XX requested a 1 hour maintenance break for a battery issue.

While doing bucket work on the Sand Hill Fire, I observed an unannounced and unknown helicopter in the vicinity of the dip site.  N8145Y had picked up a bucket and was enroute to the fire when a helicopter that appeared to be a white Bell 206, flew by between the dip site and the fire.  8145Y was more than 1/2 mile from the intruder and never had visual or radio contact.I only had visual contact with the intruder A/C for a couple of seconds and couldn't get even a partial tail number.There was no TFR on the Sand Hill Fire or the Deadline Complex when this happened.

While post flighting TXX, the pilot found evidence of a wire strike. There were scrapes to the nose cone and nicks on two prop blades and one oneach engine. He was unaware of  the time that the strike occurred, but it occurred on the Dam Fire CA-CNF-000067. He made two drops, both onthe same target. There are wires running perpendicular to the drop and passing over the target. On both drops the pilot was over the middle of the span and thought he saw both poles and wires. The drops were madedirectly into the wind, 40K on the awos. On the climb out the aircraft performed normally.

Left cylinder head temp gauge reading high and at times pegged above allowable operating range. All other engine instruments were operating normally. When the gauge failed to return to the normal operating range, the ATGS terminated the mission and returned to the local airport. Maintenance personnel arrived. A wiring problem was corrected: The airplane was test flown by maintenance and the problem checked out satisfactory. The Regional  Maintenance Inspector was notified of the discrepancy and repairs. A Pilot`s Discrepancy Report with corrective actions were entered in the aircraft logbook and returned to availability per the Regional Maintenance Inspector.

Approximate 35 minutes into flight to check misc incidents. Noticed fuel leaking out of right inboard fuel cap. Immediately returned to Airport. On the ground the pilot checked fuel cap and we had the aircraft topped off with fuel. Taxied aircraft on ramp and found that cap was still leaking fuel. Placed aircraft out of service. Notified dispach and local FAO.

While working a Deaton Cole fire in west Texas with load and returns, an airtanker was not contacting dispatch when returning to and launching out of Midland Airtanker base. Midland Dispatch tried to contact the airtanker on local Aircraft frequency, National Flight Folllowing, and Air Guard and there was no reply from the airtanker. This airtanker did received the local frequencies the day before from the Midland Airtanker base manager.

inThis airplane is shaking real bad and I don't know why!in  That is the first thing Lead heard after the tanker dropped his first two doors on the fire.The time was about 1700 on 8/7/01.  It was the tanker's second trip to the fire.  Lead arrived at the fire just as the tanker completed his first drop.  The decision to load and return was made and when the tanker returned, Lead conducted the normal brief and provided a show-me run on that same spot fire a helicopter had been working on.  Getting to the drop site required a significant descent which put Lead way down in the valley, so it took a long time to climb out.  The tanker asked where Lead was and at the same time announced he was on a base to the drop.  The tanker continued with the run and Lead could see him on the base leg turning final.  Lead watched the two door drop.  Not long after the tanker was on the exit he made the radio call, inThis airplane is shaking real bad and I don't know why!in  Lead immediately told the tanker to punch off the remainder of the load which he did.  The tanker captain said it felt like the airplane was in a stall.  Not long after that, the captain announced he found the problem to be the life boat access door on top of the left wing between the left engine and fuselage had come open.  At the end of the valley on the exit a right turn was required.  Lead informed the tanker to turn right at the end of the valley as briefed earlier.  The captain said he had to go left because the tanker wouldn't turn right.  Lead said, inYou have to turn rightin.  The only way out was right unless enough altitude was gained to clear the ridges that formed the bowl if a left turn was made.  After retracting some flaps, the tanker captain informed Lead that the shaking wasn't as bad and that he could turn right.After having successfully negotiated the exit, Lead informed the tanker that he would follow him to landing.  The initial decision to go to Coeur'd Alene was scrapped after the tanker captain decided that the airplane flew better with no flaps.  Due to construction on the runways at Coeur'd Alene, there wasn't a long enough runway to accomodate a no flap landing.  Lead informed the tanker that his options were Spokane Intl. (GEG) or Fairchild Air Force Base.  The tanker decided GEG. About 40 miles out from Spokane, Lead contacted Spokane Tower and declared an emergency for the tanker.  The tanker made a no flap approach and landing and a one engine reverse landing roll with the opposite engine.  The landing was uneventful.

The pilot of 28M noticed that the main cabin door had play in the door hinge and some of the rivets had started to pull through the sheet metal.  It was brought to the attention of maintenance and the door was removed for inspection.  Maintenance found several rivets that had pulled through the sheet metal that covers the outside of the door and the metal door hinge had ripped several inches on the aft section of the hinge.

I advised the Unit FMO (Montrose BLM) that aerial supervisionresources for the incident (FS jurisdiction) should be requested in view ofongoing and anticipated tactical use of aviation resources (multipleairtanker missions, one helicopter and expected media interest).  At thetime of this discussion, I was unaware of the status of any outstandingresource orders for either a lead plane or air attack.While assigned to an adjacent unit (GJD), I completed a partial fuel cycleover the incident later that afternoon, but was dispatched to anotherincident for initial attack.  The status of aerial supervision assigned tothis incident is unknown.The Unit FMO was engaged in extended aerial observation missions over theincident using a local vendor and a portable handheld radio.The intent of this SAFECOM is to again point out a situation which has beendocumented over the last several years in Western Colorado/Eastern Utahregarding the short term unavailability of adequate resources and equipmentto conduct aerial supervision over an incident.In some situations, fire managers are continuing to 'make do' with regardto the ability to provide aerial supervision in a timely manner.  Thissituation is incompatible with the interagency emphasis on addressingsafety.

The pilot of tanker XX radioed the FS that his left Engine was running rough and that he would be returnning to the tankerbase. The tanker jettisoned the load of retardant and the plane''s landing was uneventful. Upon inspection, the number 6 cyclinder was blown and the engine PRT needed to be replaced.

Arrived fire 1725. Took pilot side door off for IA bucket work. Laid door 200 yards away from what appeared to be secured line on the NW corner of fire. Initially planned to establish lookout on knob nearby and remain at landing site. Helitack crew leader (from another crew) requested XXXX manager and crewmember to tie in with crew and secure line around northern half of fire, leaving landing site unstaffed. At approximately 1953 breakout occurred along NW flank directly across from landing site and location of door and helitack gear. Landing site was burned-over, destroying a flight helmet and damaging the pilot side door. Door was later repaired enough to put H-XXXback to availability for IA the following day.
Hoist pump leaking @ garloc seal. Removed and replaced seal faxed flight maint. log to Gerry Burney Aircraft placed back to contractual AV.Aircraft out of service 1.0 hr.

This was an incident when the aircraft was not running and tied down. The Mechanic was climbing down from the top of the Boing Vertol and lost his footing and fell to the ground. He also hit the wheel well on the way down. He was transported to the hosptial via ambulance for possible back and head injurys. There was not a witness to the actual fall but the helicopter manager observed the mechanic walk stiffly and disoriented away and more or less slumped down by the fuel truck and became unresponsive. Helicopter manager and one of the pilots responded to the mechanic and called 911 for help. Several hours later the doctors at the hosptial determined the mechanic did not have a broken back, but did have a mild concussion and was later released. This is a heads UP to be vigilant be aware and remind everyone that things can and do go wrong in the blink of an eye even when the aircraft is sitting on the ground and not running

On 7/13/2005 an Air Tanker returning for a load on the West Omak Lake Fire, requested an additional 100 gallons of retardant equaling 900lbs be pumped on the tanker. The reason given for the additional retardant was to have extra weight to add head pressure to get the aircraft doors to flow evenly. Without even questioning the request the additional retardant was loaded.

After completing a personnel transport mission to the Jordan fire I was returning to the Lone Pine airport and was experiencing moderate turbulence in the lower Cottonwood Canyon area and was staying out of the bottom of the canyon to stay out of the area that would be more turbulent. At that point a gray F-16 passed through the bottom of the canyon, approximately 500 feet to my left and approximately 100 feet below my aircraft at an undetermined speed. Knowing that military fighters normally fly in pairs, I immediately executed an evasive maneuver to the right hoping to remove my aircraft from the path of a possible second aircraft. There were no other aircraft in the area. After landing at Lone Pine Inyo dispatch and Joshua approach were notified.

During bucketing operations on the fire, we were assigned a mission on the right flank: with the assurance from Air Attack that the multiple SEATs would remain over the left flank.  While at the dip, we observed a SEAT flying at our altitude {1600’} directly over our drop zone on the right flank, approximately 1/4 mile or less from our dip site.  I immediately called Air Attack on the Victor and told him the SEAT was not where he was supposed to be.  Air Attack then instructed the SEAT to fly his pattern in the opposite direction so as not to overfly the right flank.  We had previously heard the Air Attack instruct the SEATs to stay on the left flank and not overfly the right, where the helicopter was working.  The sky was clear, and there did not seem to be a need for the SEAT in question to fly over the right flank.  A second SEAT, shortly thereafter, overflew the right flank after being instructed not to, but at 2500’, not at our level.

T-65 Mechanical safecom.While working the Proctor Fire for the CDF, Monte Vista Unit, T-65 developedtrouble with the #1 engine.  The flight crew dropped their load on the fire, feathered the prop, and T-65 returned safely to Ramona.  1800 hr. T-65 out ofservice.  Soon after the flight crew determined an engine change was in order, and flew the aircraft to their home base for repair, non-revenue flight.On the morning of 10-02-99 I was called by Bill Foy stating the aircraft was ready to return to Ramona.  Gerry Burney was informed of the situation, and the repair documentation was sent to him via FAX.  T-65 returned to Ramona, and was put back in service at 1000 hr.

Small charter plane carrying radios to a fire in California, had a schedule of 6 hours and 35 min round trip. The trip took him 8 hours and 28 mins. No weather was reported in the area. The company knew the route and agreed to the F/P made with the route. The pilot also did an extra stop on the way back to BOI unknown to anyone. Making him 45 minutes over due.

Approximately 20 minutes after intrusion of a UH-60 (Blackhawk), another report from ground that a BI-Wing aircraft had passed through the fire area Northwest to Southeast.  We made no visual contact with aircraft.On 6/17, ATGS confirmed that TFR was still in place.Air Ops Notified.
Tanker xx completed drop on White Knoll Fire and returned to Grand Junction. Experienced loss of right main tire during rollout phase of landing on runway 29.

While conducting PSD operations, experienced 2 hang fires within Premo Mark III machine. Specifics: balls were manufactured in 1999, new Prestone Glycol, and qualified PLD Operators. Events: Experienced 2 seperate hang fires with 2 different operators. Both events required water flushing and had melted material within slipper block. The first incident was a stuck ball caused when the injection needle hit seam and a piece of the plastic melted in place. The second incident was similar to the first other than in a different slipper block and it actually jammed the machine making the mannual clearing impossible. No balls were dropped out of the unit and all fires were extinguished before leaving units. Conclusion: It is unsure why these misfires happened. Options are: 1. Operator Error 2. Material Age 3. Cleanliness of machine

Mechanical Problem -- S.E.A.T. was on a fire retardant dropping mission for the Pahcoon Fire. When the pilot landed at the airport he reported a right brake fade. As a precautionary measure the pilot repositioned spacing on brake disks. Thereafter the plane worked properly.

Working Dupuis fire with mixed aircraft ATT-6 asked NXXXX to hold over dip site. Tanker XXX (CL215) was comming down left flank of fire and going to turn base 1/2 mile south of heel. NXXXX left dip site and flew into flight path of T-XXX. Att-6 then had NXXXX return to dip site before T-XXX turned base. There was better than 3/4 mile separation at this time and T-XXX was able to make a safe drop.

During bucket work on the Berryessa Incident, Helicopter 68L released bucketand longline into lake Berryessa. This was not reported by the pilot but by another helicopter that witnessed the incident. Bucket was retrieved thefollowing day with the use of 7 divers.The bucket and connections looked tobe operational without mechanical failure.

Departed Hanksville airport for Air Attack mission on the Bulldog Fire. Upon arriving on the fire the pilot noticed the engine running a little rough. He turned the key for the left magneto and the engine sounded fine but when he turned the key for the right magneto the engine sputtered and sounded very rough. The problem was noticed at 1530. We departed the fire at 1533 and landed at Hanksville with no problem at 1543.

During the backhaul mission the crew attached the load. While the helicopter began to lift, the clevis hook opened leaving the cargo on the ground along with the remote hook. The ground crew and pilot quickly noticed the clevis hook was open. The pilot then lowered the open clevis and the crew reattached the remote hook with the load to the clevis. The pilot continued with the backhaul and returned to helibase with no issues. On return from the sling site mission, we discovered the gate lock on the orange clevis hook was open and failing due to dust and dirt clogging the locking mechanism. This prevented the clevis hook from locking, and allowed the remote hook to come off at the sling site.

After retardant loading operations at the Tanker Base, the load hose was disconnected and moved off the ramp. The parking tender gave the OK to start up and T-XX left pit 2 and began to taxi when the parking tender noticed the cap sitting on the ground. T-XX was contacted and returned to have the cap put back on and return to operations. The Ramp manager and the retardant plant manager both came to speak with the Airtanker Base Manager and agreed to have a briefing with the FS FWPTs and retardant loaders on duties and responsibilities outline in the Air Tanker Base Operations Guide and the established SOPs for the retardant loading crews. All agreed a good lesson learned at a busy tanker base.

My helitack crewmembers were directing water drops with both agency exclusive use helicopters.  NXXXXX, NZZZZZ.  ZZZZ came into the drop kind of low.  There were numerous trees in the 30-50ft range.  As A/C was coming in low the crewmembers were telling him he was low and to pull up.  At that time it appeared that his bucket hit a tree and wrapped around it.  I noticed his long line became taunt and it looked like the helicopter jerked a little bit.  During this time the crewmember that was directing the drops was telling him to pull up.  After the helicopter jerked he then proceeded to pull forward and untangle the bucket and long line.  He did this successfully.  I believe he returned to base to get his bucket looked at.

During support operations of the Bottleneck incident helicopter 4SA was conducting longline operations, providing blivets to crews.  On the third turn, pilot placed remote hook next to the second blivet which was daisy chained to a tuna net filled with bladder bags.  The hitcher was sent in by the radio operator, and accidentally placed the rings of the tuna net on the remote hook (no swivel).  Helicopter 4SA was quickily informed of the situation, and quickly returned to longline spot.  The problem was fixed by placing the swivel to the remote hook, and the operation continued without further incident.

On 4/29/98 at 1545, when helicopter was requested to do water drops,long line did not adapt to water bucket clevis. we had to do some minor changes: Spring clip had to be taken off in order to place the hook from longline onto shackle of water bucket control module, then spring clip was installed back on. This was not a big issue, but in light of the fire season coming on, this may help vendors and agencies in the equipment checking process.

On long and final, the pilot and air attack notice the red, ``gear unsafe`` light illuminated. Hydraulic pressure was good, and after discussion proceeded to drop the landing gear. After selecting the gear down position, all three landing gear operated normally and three green lights indicated that the gear was down and locked. The gear unsafe light went out and the airplane was landed normally. After the landing was complete, and plane was parked, a call to the mechanic was made.
On 6/16/06, Silver City, NM, the aircraft was made unavailable due to a failed vent blower.

H534 was inbound to Mill Creek Helibase after a water dropping missison on the East Fire.  While landing the Pilot landed the helicoptors' snorkel toofar forward under neath the fixed tank.  The fixed tank has a 50 gallon fiberglass extension on it behind the standard 300 gallon steel tank.  The result was a horseshoe size crack on the fiberglass extension. A parking tender was in place at the time, but he was too for back and the skidswere above eye level.  Parking tender informed the manager of the incident.  The helicoptor manager informed the parking tender that he should of been a little bit closer, so he could see the position of the snorkel in regards to the fixed tank.  The tank was repared with no difficulty at all.  The Pilot also stated that he would pay more attention the the position of the snorkel while landing.

While going through engine starting procedures, we were unable to achieve engine rotation on the second engine start. Further investigation revealed a sheared starter shaft. The infrared mission was cancelled and maintenance was scheduled to replace the sheared shaft. Two infrared fire mission resourse orders were not filled that night due to Sabreliner mechanical problems. The next scheduled day time flight had to be delayed two hours for completion and checkout of the starter shaft maintenance. The aircraft was back in service that afternoon but because of the delay was unable to complete the mission due to afternoon thunderstorms and cloud cover.

Upon dispatch pilot was distracted from completing his normal walk around of the aircraft. Upon taxi of the aircraft about 30Ft. The pilot noticed through the rudder pedals there was no movement of the rudder. Pilot instantly realized what had happened. Pilot took appropriate actions to correct the situation. The aircraft responded to the incident and returned without further incident.

On June 6, 2014 H-XXX was re-positioning from a landing dolly to the tarmac to load helitack crew. During the transition from the dolly to the tarmac, H-XXX flew over a shed owned by another company located in a hangar next door. While flying over the shed a loose piece of corrugated metal was picked up by the rotor wash and came close to making contact with the helicopter.

Our best information indicates that the forest used a point-to-point carded fixed-wing aircraft and pilot for fire detection flights unknowingly several times in 1998. Dispatcher and observer apparently did not compare the intended mission with the aircraft and pilot's carding qualifications. A FM packset with headset was used for communications and flight following. There was no intercom capability with the pilot.
Tanker LOST AN ENGINE ENROUTE TO FIRE. ABORTED LOAD AT 1136 HRS.  RETURNING TO Home base FOR FIX.

On the morning of 06/09/12 XXXX Tanker Base received a dispatch for  two tankers to the XX  fire. A preflight walk around was completed by the flight crew.  Prior to engine start up, the tanker base manager noticed a “remove before flight” flag on the right pitot tube. The aircrew was notified, and the co-pilot was able to reach out the window and remove the pitot Tube cover

Flew two 3.9 hour missions on the fire 25 miles South of the Airtanker Base. Approximately 100 Airtanker leads between the 10 SEATs, 2 LATs and 2 Scoopers for the day. Flying back to Base at the end of the second mission ATC advised me to make right traffic for 28R. On downwind, tower instructed me to continue and pointed out traffic on final for 28R. I reported the traffic in sight, and was instructed to turn base behind the traffic, cleared to land 28L. Just as I started the base turn, tower asked me to turn base and I replied that I was in the turn. On short final Tower said check wheels down, then immediately thereafter Tower said go around. I executed the go around procedure and realized I had very nearly landed with the gear up. I completed the landing checklist, made a normal landing and thanked the Tower.

Aborted start on fire dispatch. Pilot attempted to start the aircraft with the battery cart. Initial voltage OK, upon spooling engine pilot noted excessive voltage drop. Not enough battery voltage to continue start. Pilot verified condition - low NG speed. Pilot followed proper procedure and correctly aborted start without any damage to aircraft.

At 1345 ATGS informed me that the FBO at Durango-La Plata Field, filled his assigned aircraft, a turbo prop, with AV Gas.  370 gal capacity with 90 gal. of Av Gas.  FBO is currently siphoning the fuel tank and will refill with jet A per OAS recomendation to the pilot.  The fuel prot was clearly marked NO AVGAS.  Estimated lost time of 4 hours. Pilot will file a safecom also.  The fueling operations with this FBO have been problematic since 1996 and the Bircher incident in 2000 has been no exception to the rule.  Other problems encountered this year and addressed on an on-going basis by the ATBM include: Broken fuel trucks unable to respond- corrected.Inadequate oiling system (nozzels) - corrected.Slow response to Tankers fueling during periods of high activity - corrected.Inadequate training and supervision of inexperienced fuelers. - on going.Horeplay on the FBO's ramp with tugs, golfcarts and tractors - identified.Excessive vehicular speed in Tanker Pit area - corrected.A general heads up situation exists when fueling at Durango and should be a considered a whatch out situation.

While enroute to a dipsite on a new, to us, part of the fire, air-attack commenced with a hand over briefing to the replacement air-attack on the rotor air to air. We were already in an area of somewhat limited visibility, in a canyon and looking for another aircraft. The briefing continued for an extended length of time, limiting our ability to communicate with, and locate, the other aircraft in the area, creating an unsafe flying environment. Soon after, we were close to dropping a bucket of water with ground personnel in the area, who we were in contact with, when air-attack started briefing a safety officer over the air to ground frequency. The briefing continued, without a break, until I cut in and informed them that the frequency was needed for making safe drops. With personnel on the ground under canopy, invisible from the air, I felt the frequency should be clear in case the ground personnel needed to contact me before dropping, for their safety in particular. The drop was not made until the frequency was clear. The air-attack then informed me that the air to ground was the only frequency he could use for his briefings, but he would try not to brief while we were over the drop zone. This seems to be a common problem that shouldn''t occur on an established fire with multiple frequencies.
Pilot did engine run up checks and found magneto on left engine inoperative.

Slack in the 9-pin pigtail on a longline was taped too short.  When flying with an empty Bambi bucket the pigtail was pulled loose from the connection to the ship and the bucket was rendered inoperable.  Pilot landed, retaped the pigtail with more slack and continued the mission with no further incidents.
After a scoop, the pilot noticed the gate ``Pump Inop`` light on. System pressure was good. He used the E-dump system to drop the load on the fire. The gate would not close after the dump.

Initial attack of the Big Chief fire on the Carson City District, BLM. Air attack gave the first SEAT entering the FTA a clearance altitude of 6,500. Air attack was at 7,500. In the mean time before the SEAT pilot reported ``on scene`` air attack changed altitudes to 9,000 for better communications with dispatch. After a few minutes orbiting the fire in a right hand turn at 9,000 the air attack pilot noticed an inbound SEAT at about the same altitude as air attack and approximately 1 1/2 miles out. The air attack pilot`s reaction was to go into a left turn to avoid crossing paths with the SEAT. Air attack contacted the SEAT pilot on the assigned air-to-air victor frequency. The SEAT pilot acknowledged that he received a clearance altitude of 6,500 into the FTA but was staying higher than that because he couldn`t see the fire and thought it might be out beyond the next set of ridges and he would need that altitude for terrain clearance.

While searching for the Benton helispot (I could not locate due to being in new country) we decided to land east of the county equipment yard with 31 minutes of fuel remaining. Later (that day) the pilot indicated that the fuel light came on.Pilot statement:After having been dispatched to a fire in the northern area of our district we were to work an area approx. 5-7 miles west of the Benton BLM helibase.  Not having familiarity of this area I asked the crewmembers where my fuel would be.  One of the crew in the rear of the helicopter pointed to a spot on the horizon as the area of the BLM helibase where my fuel would be.After working the fire I returned to my landing site and informed the XXXXXX. that I needed fuel.  After several minutes, and me once again advising the XXXXXX. that I desperately needed fuel they boarded the helicopter.  I departed the dip site and began a heading toward the area that we had all agreed upon earlier as the BLM helibase.  The XXXXXX pointed to a different location toward downtown Benton.  I re-informed them that we had all discussed the BLM helibase prior to landing to re-configure for the fire and that I was heading for that area.  My fuel truck had not yet arrived at the helibase.The XXXXXXXX advised me that they were quite sure that where we needed to land was at the downtown area of Benton.  I was heading for a spot of trees approx. 4 miles north of Benton.  They  diverted me to the area of downtown Benton stating `they saw the yellow fire trucks at the station`.  I will now note that my VEMD indicated I had 29 minutes of fuel remaining.  This fuel reading is based upon actual fuel flow and is accurate based on this.I now headed for the area that my XXXXXX advised, however I once again pointed north and advised that the BLM base should be north of our location.  They  told me that they were unsure of where the base actually was but they saw fire trucks.  I also now saw the trucks that they had pointed out however saw no landing pad.  I began to orbit the site in downtown Benton and saw that my fuel light began to flicker `on`.  Being somewhat fuel critical and now not having confidence that my XXXXXX knew where we needed to go, I elected to make a safe approach and landing to a dirt road behind the downtown fire station in Benton.  We did land safely and received re-fueling shortly thereafter.  After receiving fuel, I flew to the area north of Benton so as to familiarize myself with the helibase location.

Responding to the Skalkaho Fire from Grangeville, ID while in cruise configuration, mid way.  The #2 recip engine bagan backfiring and running rough.  The engine was secured and the load jettisoned followed with an uneventful landing at Missoula, MT.

On 8/23/2008 the aircraft departed Redding Airport with pilot and ATGS to do a reconnisance of the Iron/Alps Complex. The mission went without any problems and the aircraft returned to and landed at Redding. After parking the aircraft the pilot rotated the left propeller as is normal operational procedure after landing and there was a audiable noise in the spinner while being rotated. The pilot checked the right propeller and rotated it but all was normal. The pilot informed the ATGS that he would have a mechanic check the left propeller. As a result of the check, the mechanic informed the pilot that there was something loose and rattling in the spinner. The ATGS reported the propeller problem to the AOBD on the Iron/Alps Complex and the aircraft was taken out of service at 1330 hours

After flying on the Fire, we landed at the airtanker base. During the post flight inspection I noticed that the main cabin door would not close quite right. After further inspection it was noted that the right side of the main cabin door hinge was torn about six inches causing the aft portion of the door to close prior to the forward portion of the door. Maintenance was notified and concurred that the hinge needed to be replaced prior to flying the aircraft. A new hinge was ordered.

On returning from a recon flight the pilot called on the radio to the Helispot and said that an engine chip light just came on. He then said that all gauges are operating in the norm and ops were normal. About one minute went by and the pilot called back on the radio and said the chip light went out and ops normal. The Aircraft returned and shut down.

After loading 4 passengers gear in the cargo hold, 94M flew to the helispot to unload. It was discovered that a pack had slipped and dislodged the copper safety wire on the window. We noticed that this made the window want to fall in toward the ship. We secured it , flew back to Helena, and our fabulous  mechanic/ pilot simply refasted the sheer wire and all was well once more!

On duty 0800 at Missoula. Arrived at helibase at 0900. Upon doing morning pre-flight inspection Pilot noticed a crack of approx. 2-3 inches in skin of tail rotor blade about 1/3 of the way up from the tip of the blade. Mechanics and pilots further inspected the blade and then consulted with company maintenance staff and concluded the blade needed to be replaced rather than patched. A blade was transported to the incident helibase in Montana and installed by the field mechanics that evening. Aircraft was run up to full operating power on the ground and they tracked and balanced the rotor system. Mechanic signed off the maintenance log and gave a copy to the manager. R1 Maint. Inspector was contacted and he put the aircraft back in contract availability on 9/11/03 at 0915.

I responded as ATGS to a large fire that went for weeks with a team, was now a type 3 organization but still had active areas. Responded to replace the assigned air attacks because they got diverted to a new IA nearby, pulling a lot of aircraft with them. Numerous SEATS, Tankers, and a Lead plus helicopters were on the new fire as I responded from 50 minutes away to the old large fire, which would be my first time on this fire. I listened enroute to the frequencies on my TARO and noticed a lot of radio traffic and easily surmised it was for the new fire, not mine. I confirmed frequencies with dispatch. My fire had a dedicated Air to Air held over from the larger team. By the time I was 12 miles out the relief air attack on the IA had taken the Air to Air from my fire to use as a rotor victor. I was not able to do a blind call on my fire and it took a bit to get ahold of the IA air attack. I had AFF {for flight following}, and reached the Ops on my fire on a repeater, plus the helibase. I determined no aircraft were currently up on my fire, though a couple of important missions were pending with the aircraft still left for the older, large fire. The air to ground for my older, large fire had gone over to one of the 3 local IA FM air to grounds when the type 3 team took over. The new fire was supposed to use another local IA A-G.  The IA air to air for the new fire was the only air to air for IA for that zone which was correctly being used, but for tanker ops when things got really busy and that`s when they took my air to air for their rotor.

As the helicopter was going into the dip, pilot started to feel a "shuffle". Pilot notified ATGS and returned to helibase. At 80 knots the shuffle was non-existent and pilot suspected it was a bad damper. After shutdown at Helibase, it was discovered that the main rotor damper needed replacement.

Helicopter XXX was doing GPS mapping mission, observed a small fixed wing within TFR. Helicopter pilot contacted plane via unicom advised of TFR. Pilot stated he was unaware of TFR and left area, landed Blanding

Jumper 79 was dispatched to the Emmett incident on the Bitterroot NF.When contact was established with Hamilton Dispatch we were diverted to threenew fires and given a priority.  When we arrived at the first fire (Trout Creek)  with the Lat./Long. we were given it was not the Trout Creek Fire butthe Smoke Creek Fire.  Jumper 15 was already at the Smoke Creek Fire.Enroute to this location we ask Hamilton Dispatch if there were any otheraircraft in the area of the fires we were headed to and the responce was noother aircraft in the area.  We ask Hamilton Dispatch to then verify theLat./Long. for the Trout Creek Fire.  They then called back with a correctedLat./Long. which took us to the Trout Creek Fire.  We dropped two jumperson the Trout Creek Fire then proceeded to the Lake Creek Fire and while orbiting it encountered numerous aircraft (helicopters and an Air Tanker)and none of us talking to each other. We then decided to move away from the area and orbit until this confusion was sorted out. We were not given an Air-to-Air freguency and I do not believe any of the other aircraft were either nor were any of us alerted to the possibility of other aircraft in the area.  We then called Hamilton Dispatch to ask for a freguency for these aircraft and the Emmett Fire and numerous frequencies were given to us.  We notified Hamilton Dispatch of the need for a Air Attack and they said one was on the way and for us to proceed to Hamilton until the situation improved.As we departed the area we could hear that the Air Attack had arrived and was able to contact most of the aircraft on the fire but could not contact one helicopter at all even on guard.  The Air Attack then called a halt to all air operations until he could make contact with all aircraft.

After take-off, acft could not retract left main gear. Flight manual procedures were followed which directed the crew to lower the gear. A safe gear down and locked indication was displayed. Once a safe indication is indicated no further trouble shooting is allowed in flight. Flight engineer visually checked for safe indications thru inspection windows. Retardant was dumped at the fire site due to its proximity. Acft landed at IWA without incident.

Returning to base on the last flight of the afternoon at 1926 on 6/26/2006 the pilot of T-4xx noticed that the GEN INOP light was flickering on. The pilot informed the manager that the company owner and a mechanic would be at the base before the beginning of operations on the 27th to have the aircraft repaired.

On 6/29/16 I departed Allakaket at 1332. I had a passenger on board. We were going to map the fires of the Alatna complex. We had gone about half way around the first fire when the right engine started to lose oil pressure. When the pressure drop reached 30 psi I shut down the engine and feathered the propeller. We returned to Allakaket at 1348. Oil was leaking from the right engine. The people on the ramp brought materials out to the aircraft and contained the leaking oil.
Helicopter Manager and helicopter met on the fire. Upon arrival at the base, the manager was requested to fly missions prior to inspecting aircraft, fuel service vehicle, and pilot qualifications

Flight conditions were VFR with visibility } 10 miles, but ````````murky````````. Level flight at 3000```` AGL. Mission was recon of fires from the previous day. After approx 20 min. into the mission we were diverted to a new fire assignment. Soon after being diverted, both pilot and I heard a single ````````thump```````` from the rear of the aircraft. Nothing was felt in the aircraft. Engine performance and flight controls remained as they were {no indication of trouble. The pilot remarked it may have been a panel expanding. I thought it may have been a frozen water bottle or briefcase falling to the floor. Since there were no additional noises, changes to flight characteristics, or instrument readings, we continued the mission. When we landed 3 hours after the incident, the pilot noticed a smudge at the very top of the windscreen, hidden behind the co-pilot````s sun visor. He stated that we hit a bird. I said when? since we heard no sounds of an impact in front of us. I went to the rear of the aircraft, looking at the horizontal stabilizer for any signs of impact. Finding none, I inspected the propeller, and found streaks of oil or other liquid on the front and back side of one propeller blade. No damage of any kind was found. We both assumed the bird had hit the widscreen, then the air intake and then the prop.

On 6/21/07 @ approximately 1630, Pilot was doing bucket work on 4-mile Ridge Fire in Superior, MT. Operations were normal. The pilot radioed helibase he was returning to HLB because of a chip light out on the engine. Pilot/Mechanic worked to find cause of failure. A piece of white fuzz was found on the filter. The fuzz was removed and chip light fixed. The helicopter was back in the air by 1700 hrs. Operations were normal the rest of the duty day.

Jumper aircraft dropped 8 jumpers from NCSB on Badger Incident.  The aircraft called at 1847 to say they were in route to Redmond for fuel and asked if we have them on AFF. I stated we did not (I had AFF up but they were not showing). The aircraft said they'd flight follow on local repeater. (We do not have functional national flight follow frequency at our dispatch center.)  I advised the aircraft to call from Redmond via landline once on the ground.  I called Central Oregon dispatch at 1848 to let them know of incoming aircraft but COC had gone out of service.  I called the Redmond Tanker Base - no one there either.  I called Central Washington Dispatch (CWC) to tell them of my concerns regarding aircraft not showing on AFF and no one at COC to receive.  CWC told me the aircraft icon was showing inactive at NCSB.  CWC gave me the tail number, which hadn’t been included on the resource order; for I only knew the call sign of Jumper ___, which CWC had at time of order told me was ___.   I checked - Automated Flight Following which does not have these call signs inputted.   There was no further check-ins received at our dispatch.  At 1914, 25 minutes after last contacted the jump ship, we received a landline call that they planned to lift off from Redmond in 30-45 minutes.  At 1918 we received another landline from the jumper aircraft that they would flight follow with us until they crossed the Columbia River, then flight follow with Wenatchee Dispatch.  At 1946 the jumper aircraft called via landline to say they were in route to Wenatchee and at 1955 the jumper aircraft called our dispatch on local repeater saying they'd made contact with Wenatchee Dispatch.  There was no flight following for this aircraft from 1847 to 1914 due to1) The Aircraft tail designator was not active on AFF (and not able to reflect its call sign)2) The limited range on local repeater3) Our dispatch center has no functioning national flight follow frequency4) It was unknown ahead of time that the jumper aircraft was planning to refuel at Redmond so Central Oregon Dispatch could have been notified before they went out of service.

While taking off from 25 Mile Helibase, rotor 338 hooked bucket cableover the mirror mount. After the second occurrence there was a pilot debriefing where-in we discussed the problem. During take off pilot is coming forward before there is enough tension in the cables allowingthe cable to slip over the mirror mount.To solve the problem the pilot agreed to come straight up before sliding forward over the bucket, keeping tension in the cables.

At 14110 after a shutdown the helicopter was going to reposition closer to the fuel truck. After starting and lifting to about 15 feet the engine lost power then caught and lost power again the helicopter wobbled for a second or two then was put on the ground by the pilot. The pilot said he lost power caught then lost it again. The ship was put down from about two feet in height. XXXXX XXXXX HELB said he heard the tail roter slowing from a position about 300 feet away. Ship placed NA at 1415.

I had a 100 foot line with the bucket. The pond I was going to get the water from was on the west side of the fire and the winds were coming out of the south west about 20 knots. I came into the pond with a head wind. I pick up the water and as I started my climb out the winds shifted and I started to settle and yaw to the right. I raised the collective and pushed left peddle, which in turn I pulled 110.2{%} torque. I released the water and went back to the helispot.

While waiting for the next air attack mission an Air Attack plane was parked on the ramp at the tanker base.  The pilot was sitting by the plane.  The plane was positioned behind a reloading pit but all the way on the other end of the ramp, approximately 200 yards from the pit.  A VLAT (VLAT 1) was in the pit getting fuel and retardant when a second VLAT (VLAT 2) landed and taxied in to wait in line for the reloading pit.  VLAT 2 positioned the plane for a straight in to the reloading pit and squared up 30 yards directly in front of the Air Attack plane.  The Air Attack plane was subject to the jet blast from VLAT 2 for approximately 20 min, blowing dust, sand, and debris onto the plane.  After VLAT 1 cleared the pit, VLAT 2 pulled forward and started his reload and refuel.  About an hour after this event, the air attack platform was given a dispatch.  During the preflight walk around, the pilot discovered gravel in the intake of engine number 1.  The gravel was cleared and the props were rotated by hand to see if there was any more gravel.  None was found and the mission continued.

At 1713 the helicopter at Pad 4 at the Valley Helibase; completing 13 water drops and 1 retardant drop in Div E.  The aircraft refueled and was checked over by the mechanic.  The aircraft was needed back in Div E. and departed the helibase at 1755.  While in flight to Div E, the pilot noticed a reduction in oil pressure in engine #1.  The pilot radioed back to base that he was returning for maintenance issues and was approximately 3-4 minutes out.  The helicopter landed with no complications and the mechanics began to evaluate. The aircraft became unavailable at 1800.

While conducting an Air Attack mission I encounter a rise in N2/NR. I was unable to get the rpm`s down to normal operating range so I opted to land immediately at a near by military training area. Upon landing I ran a few ground checks confirming that the turbine governor had failed completely. A call was made to heli base informing them of our situation and to order another helicopter to fly back to LADD to pick up our mechanic.

Pilot flew into a sling site to retreive backhaul. Qualified helitack (smokejumpers) hooked the load to the cargo hook. The pilot inadvertantly released the longline from the helicopter, causing it to tumble to the ground (pilot was hovering slightly uphill from personnel while hooking, so the line fell uphill) He was unable to land, so he returned to the helispot while the jumpers topped a few trees to allow him to do a hover hook up. He returned to the sling spot, the load was reattached by hover hook up and he began flying back to the helispot. One half way back, the load, longline, and hook all disconnected from the helicopter. After some searching, the load was located, the location GPSed and retreived shortly after. The pilot admitted his error in mistakenly ''''punching off the load'''' the first time while he was looking down through the bubble. He is confident that he did not ''''punch off'''' the load the second time and is unsure why it happened. After locating the load, he picked helitack up at the helispot and we returned to the airport, ending the day.

At 1405 8 August, 2002, T-60 was dispatched to the in Sour Bisquitin fire. Our load was 2550 gallons of retardant and a full load of gas weighing 12,000 pounds. We departed Klamath Falls airort wihich was VFR, but the smoke was heavy in all quadrants. The temperature was in the mid 90's with an attendant high density altitude. Climb peformance was going to be poor as with all heavy piston powered aircraft. Translated, this means the climb rate was going to be marginal at times and fluctuating between zero and three hundred feet per minute for significant stretches of time. The tops of today's smoke layer varied between eitht and ten thousand feet. Obviously, quite a lengthy time is spent flying through this smoke in IFR conditions. When there's no way anyone can tell exactly what the visability is in the smoke, calling the visability acceptable, is a foolish game. Not only that, flying IFR without filing a flight plan, (totally unreasonable) is illegal. When I arrived over the coordinates given me in the dispatch, I was looking into a heavy layer of smoke below me. If the coordinates were a little off, that wasn't the problem. There was a heavy layer of smoke between me and the ground. The drop altitude was below 4000 feet. That was going to require me to descend 4000 feet through the smoke and hope there were no hills or other aircraft in my way. The odds are it could be done, and for that matter, has been done countless times. Where is the plane in front of me coming off his drop?. If I drop, where is the tanker coming in behind me? Sound sily? Think about it. Had I dropped my retardant load, the climb back to altitude would have been faster, but still in IFR conditions. What heading do I take to assure myself of missing the tallest peaks? Can I see them? Maybe. My decision was to stay at altitude(I actually climbed another 1000 feet to have somewhat better visability) and return to Klamath Falls loaded. Any tanker taking the same direct route between Klamath Falls and the fire would have to cope with the same visability problems. As it was, another tanker popped into view so close as to make the passing not much more than luck. The closing speed of two tankers doing 200 knots each is obviously abut 400 knots. Roughly figuring, that's about 700 feet per second closing rate. In the smoke, evasive actin would be moot. My decision was to abort the mission. We are constantly being told not to push a situation or take chances. The reluctance of pilots to follow this advice is evidenced all the time. The reason has as much to do with making money as with the inmachoin can do mentallity. The inSour Bisquitin fire is over 300,000 acres and drops I made days ago are now burried well inside the burn. We are called to drop upon lines where there is no visable ground support nor high priority ground to protect. We pilots are not blind, nor is this something new to behold. We are not building a fireproof wall with the retardant we drop. These few drops made before smoke shuts down the tanker opperation are not critical to the control of a monster fire. I'll gladly argue this point with anyone.

Pilot Narrative: During start sequence, positive fuel noted, rotary switch in ``Air`` position for NTS light/power level check, cleared the right engine area and witnessed white/grey smoke pouring from right engine inlet. Aborted Start. Rotary Switch off. Battery off. At no time was rotary switch in ``start-run-ground`` position, nor did engine turn.

Requested for a new start in the Poudre Canyon area near Fort Collins, CO. On departure, approx. 3 minutes out, the engine chip light detector illuminated. The Pilot informed the passengers and started the return to Monument Helibase. The Manager informed Peublo Dispatch on the situtation while returning to Helibase. The pilot landed with no issues at our designated helipad. The crew departed the helicopter.

Upon landing at BOI T-840, was loaded with retardant but had a leaking door. We off loaded the retardant and gave them a chance to correct the leak with no improvement. The Mechanic came to BOI, began work at approx. 0700 on 8/16. and replaced the doors. Still has a leak, but calibration issues.

started helicopter to leave for the skyline fire when the pilot noticed that the # 1 starter generator light was remaining on after run up. Shut down helicopter so mechanic could inspect the starter. Mechanic determined that part was defective.

I was the ATGS Trainee assigned on Air Attack-XXX. I was operating as the I.A. fire Air Attack. At approximately 14:50 hours I received a 12 mile call from Tanker-YYY. I gave Tanker-YYY an in brief including my altitude, altimeter, entry altitude, aircraft assigned, and hazards. To reduce conflict I advised Tanker-YYY to approach from the west side of the fire that the assigned Air Tankers were entering from the South / East side from San Bernardino Air Tanker Base. Tanker-ZZZ was cleared into the FTA behind Tanker YYY. While Tanker-ZZ was in his drop pattern Tanker-YYY entered the orbit. Tanker-AA entered the orbit behind Tanker-YYY. While Tanker-YYY was on Final for his drop. After Tanker-ZZZ was clear of his drop Tanker-AA advised me that he had to maneuver to avoid Tanker-YYY that had made a right hand 180 degree turn in front of him and that Tanker-YYY was now doing a right hand orbit. I confirm with Tanker-YYY that he was in a left hand orbit at the assigned altitude? As Tanker-YYY stated to me that he was in a left hand orbit I observed him in a right turn. I then reconfirmed that he needed to stay in a left hand orbit.
2 door of retardant was dropped from T12 by accident on the grass area to the south east.
Pilot attempted start of aircraft with main rotor tie down still in place. It was recognized prior to light off of engine by crew followed by immediate shut-down of starter generator.

The relief pilot had found the hydraulic fluid resevoir low and called to the AvCenter line staff to bring  to him some hydraulic fluid. They brought the Skydrol high altitude fuild and the pilot put it in the reservoir. He then put the jug in the baggage compartment where the mechanics found it during the 100 hour  inspection, on 8/1/08. The oil was added on 7/4/2008 and the aircraft has been flown with the Skydrol in the system.

At approximately 1638, T-yyy was pulling off the taxiway onto Ramp E entering apron area. At the same time, a contractors fuel truck, without permission from the Ramp Manager, attempted to cross Ramp E in front of the approaching T-yyy. The pilot of T-yyy saw the fuel truck and came to an abrupt stop. The fuel truck backed up to allow T-yyy to pass.

On 02/16/2005, while conducting an aerial ignition operation with the Premo MKIII, aircraft experience another engine chip light. The pilot cleared the machine and returned to H-22 which was the closet place to land. This was the third chip light on this aircraft. The other occurred on 02/07/05 and 02/12/05. After the engine chip light on 02/12/05 a complete drain and flush with a 30 minute penalty flight were conducted per Regional Maintenance Inspector. After this chip light the chip plugs was pulled by the vendor merchanic and a small piece of metal was found on the chip plug. The merchanic determined that this aircraft engine need to be completed reworked.

While conducting a PSD mission on the X prescribed fire the PSD machine abruptly stopped firing. The operator noticed the machine was not dropping balls. A power loss was noticed on the dispensing part of the machine and the cockpit was notified of a problem. A number 2 circuit had popped. The operator looked and pulled the fuse, the fuse appeared in working condition and was reinserted. The operator then attempted to clear the chutes manually but the machine was locked. Then the operator pushed in the fuse which turned the indicator lights back on briefly but did not turn the crank. The operator pressed the water button as a precaution. There was no smoke or any indication of an ignited PSD balls in the machine. The operator, burn boss and pilot decided to land the helicopter at the nearest landing zone. An attempt was made to get the manual assist dial to turn but there was no success. The ship flew back to helibase and the machine was removed from the aircraft. Outside the helicopter the manual assist was turned with more leverage and freed the machine. The machine was reattached to the helicopter and performed without error. There were no more PSD missions that day. There were no jammed balls in the machine at any point. The problem leads itself to a mechanical seizure. Prior to the incident there was a very thorough briefing conducted at the helibase to include all required documentation. The machine was bench tested prior to the operation. There was excellent Crew Resource Management established with the flight crew to include the contractors. Emergency procedures were followed and the training and trust that were established may have helped prevent a more serious incident.

during shut-down operations, at hopkins field, the pilot noticed the main rotor rpm gauge ``jumping``. upon inspection by the mechanic, it was deemed to be either a bad tach sensor or tach generator and replacement parts were needed. messages were left for two amd maintenance inspectors. R2 maintenance inspector was reached and informed of the issue. the aircraft was placed in unavailability status.

At approximately 1555 we departed Cedar City for a fire east of Price, UT. After takeoff we retracted the gear. The gear would not retract. We cycled the gear several times, it still failed to retract. We jettisoned the load and returned to Cedar City. After landing I visually checked the landing gear and found a bolt line and hard line to emergency air brake system had come loose. After further checking the landing gear systems I found the landing gear hydraulic down line lever had been engaged. This system had not been used all season nor in previous seasons. I asked my co-pilot and mechanics if they had set the lever or worked on the air line. They stated they had not. I have no explanation of how or who engaged the lever or removed the air line fittings.

On the return flight to the water source in turbulent conditions pilots hand slipped on the cyclic control releasing the Bambi Bucket.  Crew retrieved the bucket.  Minor repairs were made to the bucket and returned to service.  The major correctable factor in this incident is the position of the cargo release button which will be relocated by the mechanic on the next 100 hour inspection.

During IA bucket drops, a bird hit windshield of aircraft. Not knowing for sure if there was damage, the pilot landed the aircraft in a nearby field and did a visual inspection. Seeing no damage he returned to duty without further incident.

While flying an air attack mission, we exceeded 8 hours of flight time for the day. Our morning air attack shift was lengthy due to difficulty in arranging for a relief air attack, and our later shift in the afternoon and evening had several helicopters working the fire with areas of compromised visibility due to smoke. While the helicopter pilots operated professionally, I felt obligated to remain on scene as ground crews attempting to hold roads and dozer lines occasionally summoned air support toward areas of diminished visibility. In this situation, my focus became finding safe targets for the helicopters, and providing on-scene flight following. I allowed myself to lose focus on my own mission, however, and it was my pilot who noted with alarm that we had flown nearly 8 hours already. As we made this realization, the helicopters on scene reached the end of their fuel cycle and headed for the helibase. We closed out with the helicopters as we turned toward our home field. No other airports nearby would allow us to land before our flight time expired.

On August 18, 2000, while retrieving a paracargo deployment bag, the static line became wedged between the rear ramp door and the fuselage of the aircraft.  The location was approximately 3 feet aft of the left jump door, under the plane where the fuselage and the rear ramp door meet forming a seam.  Apparently, while pulling in the static line and deployment bag, the static line wedged into the seam and could not be removed.  This was the last cargo drop of the mission.  After conferring with the pilot, the spotter cut the static line, leaving approximately two feet of line at the wedge point.  The trailing two feet of static line and deployment bag continued to stay wedged in the ramp door seam until it was removed on the ground in Afton, WY.The location of the wedged static line and deployment bag never compromised the safe operation of the aircraft during the incident.

Flight was scheduled for 1130 to try to locate a reported smoke in the wilderness. The aircraft arrived at dispatch and picked up the duty officer at approximately 1145. The pilot commented that he had to swap planes because the other plane was blowing blue smoke. The passenger was loaded and briefed, then the plane taxied out and departed the airport. As the plane departed the traffic pattern, the passenger asked how much fuel was on board, to which the pilot responded 3 hours. The passenger checked in with dispatch, indicating pilot plus 1, 3 hours of fuel, and the destination. The passenger stowed the radio frequency card, then noticed that one fuel gauge was near empty and the other was about a quarter tank. After pointing that out to the pilot, the aircraft returned to the airport for fuel.

8/8/02 Long Mesa Fire at Mesa Verde NP, CO. Fire status - contained and being managed by Type 3 organization after transition from Type 2 team. At approximately 1500 on 8/8/02 I was approached by the Type 3 Operations Section Chief requesting that I deploy a three-person helitack crew and begin bucket operations to mop up some inpolitical smokesin within the perimiter of the Long Mesa Fire. As we discussed the mission I became concerned that this mission fell into the category of inis this flight necessary? As this question was being asked to OPS he became very defensive and felt we were refusing a mission. Several attempts were made to clarify our concerns. I attempted to outline a risk analysis for the OPS and determine what the best course of action might be. My concerns were that we were being asked to deploy personnel on spots that OPS stated were no threat to the line and perform bucket work on those same spots. As the conversation continued the OPS Chief stated that if we did not want to do it he would get another crew to take care of it. I tried to explain that it was not just a concern for this crew, but for any personnel placed in a hazardous area only to be mopping up interior inpoliticalin smokes (other hazards: terrain, snags, etc.) We came up with several options for the risk analysis, but these were all rejected by OPS since we questioned his original mission. I was not convinced that this was an overly hazardous mission, I just felt it was a proposed mission that needed further discussion to come up with other options or actions to mitigate hazards.

We were dispatched to the Powerline Fire for recon and bucket work.  At 1145, we heard the IC call dispatch and tell them that there was military aircraft in the area and to make contact with the military to advise them we would be working in the area.While enroute to the Powerline Fire after passing H-27, the crew member sitting in the right rear seat called out an aircraft to our right.  Time: 1150 hours.  Seeing that it was a military jet (F-15) traveling from north to south, pilot decended from 800' to 200'.  The crew members and pilot did not observe any more aircraft.After arriving at the Powerline Fire and doing a recon around the fire, we then headed back to H-27.  At 1204, we observed two more aircraft traveling from south to north at about our altitude of 500'.  As we approached H-27, two more aircraft were observed manuvering and traveling from an east to west direction below 500'.  They made several passes.At 1209, the IC asked Dispatch to follow up with air ops on contacting the military.At 1211, Air One (Air Attack) was advised of jets and NXXXXX in the area.After landing at H-27, we advised the IC we would delay doing water drops about one hour until we no longer saw or heard any aircraft in the area. We began bucket work at 1313.We relayed our concerns to Tallahassee Dispatch and they relayed to FICC our concerns and requested that they try and get some information about the activities that were going on.  We left the Powerline Fire at 1747 to return to Tallahassee.  We never heard back from FICC if they were able to contact the military or not.
At 1400 aircraft unavailable as the # 2 engine was slow to start. The igniter boxes were determined to be weak.

On 8/6/12 our mechanic was doing some cleaning of electrical plugs on the ship and left the left side engine cowling open. Soon after he was done with the cleaning we got a fire call, I informed the pilot we had a fire call he went out to the ship and proceed to start the helicopter. As a crewmember was loading on the left side he notice the cowling was open and brought it to my attention as I come around the left side and was stowing my equipment in the front left seat. I leaned over and told the Pilot and then motion to the mechanic to come over and make sure the cowling was closed properly which he did. We proceeded to the fire with no other incidents.

Helicopter had returned to Green for second long line mission to H-35. Pilot put the hook on the ground let the hitcher come in and hook the load. As the pilot lifted the remote hook off the ground the swivel departed from the remote hook. Pilot let the ground folks know to go in and check the remote hook. .

During the morning aviation briefing at the Ontario Airbase it was discovered that the Air Attack on the Mack Fire on the adjoining Boise NF was using the National Ramp Frequency as the Air-to-Air frequency with multiple aircraft operating on their incident. A call to Boise dispatch verified that the fire had been assigned 123.975 for their fire.  This excessive traffic on the ramp frequency rendered it unusable for out base operations which were just starting up for the day in support of heavy IA and large fire support missions. A call to the NWCC and National Freq Coordinators indicated that the assignment of 123.975 as an Air-to-Air was obviously a mistake. He recommended placing an order for a replacement ramp freq, which we did.

While performing bucket drops on Div Z of the XXXX fire the Pilot was alerted of a chip light.  He immediately notified the Air tactical group supervisor and helibase of the chip light and returned to XXXX HB.

After initial size up of the XXXX Fire the helicopter and crew landed at a dipsite three miles to the south of the fire.  The helicopter was configured with 100 ft long line and bucket.  After the third dip one of the helitack crewmembers saw a small white object hovering to the east of the fire.  After confirming with another crewmember it was determined to be a small drone somewhere near the FTA.  Helitack notified ATGS on Air to Ground frequency immediately, and ATGS relayed info to Dispatch and KXXX airport tower.

While doing an external slingload mission, on approach to x Helispot to pick up the external load with 150` longline: the hook drug through the top of trees adjacent to the helispot. Additionally, the helispot manager felt the hook was also too low while overflying parked vehicles near the helispot. The mission continued without event. This report was received as a phone call to the Helibase Manager in at x Helispot, and then relayed to the submitter, the HMGB.
After lifting off pad, helicopter was hovering approx 50' off the pad establishing radio contact. Ground crew noticed pitot tube cover had not been removed from helicopter.

While enroute to an IA mission from Helibase, about 5 miles out, the Master Caution illuminated with a Hydraulic {#}1 light illuminating on the caution panel. Observed the pressure on Hydraulic {#}1 dropped to zero and yaw channel on SCAS light illuminated. Turned off Hydraulic {#}1 system and disabled yaw channel on SCAS. Turned aircraft around and flew back to base with Hydraulic {#}2 system fully operational. With {#}1 system disabled, hydraulic boost to tailrotor is disabled. Made a slow shallow approach to the helipad and landed without incident. Further investigation by maintainence personnel revealed that one of the hydraulic hoses failed.

During refueling I looked into the cowling at the front of the aircraft. I noticed a broken metal line on the right side of the front engine. After removing the engine cowling the pilot determined it was the fuel primer line. Note: The fuel priming system is normally used only during cold wx ops, so the pilot had not been using the priming system.

WADNR UH-1H xxxxx was dispatched to the Ryegrass Coulee fire in the vicinity of Vantage, WA at 0730, 07/10/2018. xxxxx flew one fuel cycle and then landed at the helibase/ fuel site for a fuel and hold. At approximately 11:00 Air Attack requested xxxxx for bucket work, while lifting to leave the helibase a chip detector and warning light activated. The pilot contacted air attack and informed him the aircraft would be down for maintenance. xxxxx set down at the helibase, contacted agency mechanics and went through the proper procedures to isolate and remedy the issue. After the appropriate steps were taken the agency mechanic cleared xxxxx for incident operations. The aircraft finished up the day and returned to ellensburg base with no further issues.

While conducting water dropping operations on the monument fire, the pilot noticed that the governer for one of his engines had been operating improperly. Upon further inspection it was determined that the number 2 engine governer on the high side had failed. R3 Maintenance inspector was notified immediately and the helicopter has been placed out of service until repairs can be made.

Tanker-XX stopped at pit for refuel and reload of retardant. After refuel, a planned contract load of 2080 gallons of MVP was initiated onto T-XX. Shortly thereafter two S2 tankers stopped in their pits for a hot load. The operater of the micro motion began loading an S2 while simultaneously loading T-XX. The attention of the operator focused on the S2 load for it was going to finish first. When the appropriate amount of retardant was approaching, the operator initiated shut down of the pump, meanwhile T-XXs load was hitting its contract load of 2080 . The operator noticed this and shut down the pump for T-XXs pit and loaded the tanker to 2180 gallons. It was some time later that the tower personnel found the discrepency on the tape after it was sent.

Upon review of maintenance log book the mechanic noticed that a required engine oil change had not been documented in the maintenance log book for the aircraft. The mechanic was unable to contact the previous mechanic who had performed the 100 hr. and oil change. Mechanic decided to change oil due to the unknown status/documentation of last oil change.

Returning from the Burnt Canyon Fire near Terra, Utah, Tanker 139 was directed to land at Hill AFB Airtanker Base.  While making an approach to Runway 32 the Tower reported that there was a displaced threshold 4000 feet from the approach end of the runway.  The displaced threshold was properly marked.  1000 feet and 1500 feet before the displaced threshold were two temporary barricades, the first at 1500 feet from the displaced threshold is made of cinderblocks spaced about 10 feet apart with plastic stantions tied together by a rope and the second barricade 1000 feet from the displaced threshold is a continous line of 6 inch by 6 inch landscaping timbers with road barricades lying on the sides with strobe lights at about 10 foot intervals. Tanker 139 landed about 2000 feet in front of the first barricade, disintegrating one cinderblock and knocking down all the plastic stantions.  The pilot held the nose off the runway and hit the line of landscaping timbers with the 56 inch diameter right main tire.  Several strobe lights and road barricades were destroyed.  Inspection of the aircraft revealed only a minor dent in the lower aft fuselage possabley caused by debris from the cinder block.  The large diameter main wheel did not appear to be damaged.
