The officials at Hill AFB inspected the damage to the runway barricades and to the aircraft. The Wasatch Cache FMO directed that the tanker be held until inspected and released by a Forest Service Inspector.

During normal starting procedures during a response for a fire call , the aircraft showed a battery overtemp caution light.  Aircraft was unloaded and company mechanic at Sheridan, WY. was contacted.  He advised restart due to information that it was the first start of the day and OAT = 100+ degrees.  Aircraft was reloaded and successfully started.  During take off before V 1 the aircraft yawed to the left and the captain corrected to keep the aircraft on the runway.  He aborted the take off and taxied back to the base.  The aircraft was pre-flighted in the morning and Redmond Air Group (Watkins) was notified and flight operations resumed.STATEMENT FROM XXX (PIC):     The cause of the yaw to the left is not known.  After correcting for the yaw, I looked at the gauges and noted a 12-15% drop in torque on the right engine.  The take-off was aborted for that reason.     In subsequent engine runs the torque drop was duplicated by setting the power at the SRL (Single Red Line) limit of 650 degrees at which point the TTL (Torque / Temperature Limiting) system bypasses first to prevent a further over-temp condition      The amount bypassed was evidently enough to cause the 12-15% drop in torque on 07-24-2002.                                         XXX                                          08-06-2002
Upon landing at airport the fueler discovered a missing fuel cap. The aircraft had been fueled at a local FBO prior to the flight.
During flight on 08/04/09, the emergency hydraulic fail light illuminated in flight.  The pilots referred to the emergency check list procedure and landed as soon as possible at Helibase.

Airtanker landed at 1600 MST upon return from retardant dropping on Fires. Pilot reported that he was having problems with his retardant tank system and would like to have his mechanic come out to the airtanker and check out the electrical relays to the tank system. Mechanic checked system out made some adjustments and tightened up some relays and electrcal connections. At approximately 1450, mechanic requested that a load of retardant be placed on board and airtanker sent back to fire. After loading airtanker, pilot said the system still wasn''t working (lights) correctly and declared themselves out of service for the day. Time out of service actually began when airtanker first came into pit at 1600.

Pilot reported leaking nose wheel steering piston, from aircraft preflight inspection.  Believed to be crushed or split O-ring.  Placed airtanker out of service, awaiting arrival of company maintainence personnel.
After reaching cruise alt. we got a chip light on the right engine. We called dispatch and headed to the jetision area. We jetisoned the load, feathered the engine and landed at Ogden.

At 1000 hours on July 9th, 2011, a crew shuttle was completed and the helicopter shut down at Turtle Helibase. We started configuring the helicopter for a longline mission to deliver a 72 gallon blivet {1st load}, and a second load that is daisy chained. At around 1020 hours I attached a 100`longline and remote hook to the aircraft and per-formed the standard 1,2,3 checks to make sure everything was working properly, which it did. I did not remove the door since the contractors typically do this when we configure while the aircraft is shut down. I then went to staff crash rescue. At 1038 when the aircraft started to lift I noticed the Pilot side door open, and over the radio I asked if he would like to set down so I can remove the door. His reply was I`m good with it, if you are.” Knowing that it is pilots’ discretion to leave the door on, I figured it was alright. I made no other radio contact with the pilot regarding the issue. At the same time the HMGB and HMGB {T} saw the door on but open and the HMGB {T} made radio contact with the pilot and told him that he would set down at the Helibase after delivery of the first load and we would remove the door before he brought out the second load.

Helicopter lifted for a recon of the Fire. Just after lifting pilot noticed that the TOT Indicator was reading zero. Pilot then attempted to reset TOT unsuccessfully. We immediately informed helibase, helispot, and AA of the issue and landed safely at helispot
During preflight pilot found a crack in the exhaust cone         near the attachment clamp. The exhaust cone was removed          from service. Aircraft was unavailable.

On 8-10-2018 helicopter Nxxx piloted by xx xx departed xx Helibase located at xx airstrip for its second cycle of the day. At approximately 18:11 the DC Buss circuit breaker tripped causing the loss of the avionics including the FM and Victor radios. After completing one high altitude circle diagnosing the problem and resetting the breaker, the breaker tripped again and Nxxx returned to Helibase. Fearing the AFF and communication radios were lost simultaneously and that emergency response activities were beginning, the pilot utilized the hand held BK radio to establish contact with the Helibase on the deck frequency. Nxxx requested the Helibase to communicate to air attack the issue and that they were returning to Helibase. Upon landing at Helibase the system came back on normally with no sign of faults. Nxxx departed Helibase on a test flight back towards the fire and the breaker immediately tripped again. Nxxx landed at Helibase and went out of service. After hours servicing found that the vibrations encountered during translational lift caused a metal avionics component which is shock mounted to get too close to a circuit breaker on the DC Buss causing the trip. Clearance was increased, insulation was added to the circuit breaker to fix the issue.

The mechanic set a roll of paper towels on the tail boom while cleaning. This consisted of the cardboard roll and three pieces of paper towel. As the aircraft spooled up the roll fell, hitting the tail rotor. The tail rotor was not up to RPM. The mechanic checked the tail rotor before further operation and no defects were found.

On August 5, 97 I called and requested a Baron aircraft with a 9600 radio on board to do a recon flight on the Wabayuma fire near Kingman. I advised the person on the phone that the pilot and aircraft had to be carded for fire recon. The vendor advised me they would call back as soon as possible. Within 15 minutes the vendor called me back and gave me the Baron tail number and advised me who the pilot would be. The vendor then assured me that both the plane and pilot were carded for fire recon. In the flight the pilot was not able to use the 9600 radio. There was no ground to air communication although dispatch was able to accomplish flight following via victor frequency. This situation raised a red flag in dispatch as to the pilot's qualifications and in further checking found that neither the dispatch office nor the flight manager had checked the pilot qualifications. Later the dispatcher checked the OAS internet pilot carding data base and found the pilot was carded.

During the Avila Fire the CAL FIRE S2 began loading at PRAAB after 7 loads from SMX.  The firefighter loading the tanker noticed that a metal extension was left on the loading port of the aircraft.  It was about 6 inches long and appeared to be a extension for loading tankers.   The cap was securely placed on the end of the extension.

At 1902 Helicopter XXX was advised of pumpkin time being 1953 and they had a good copy and understood. At 1917 Helicopter XXX wanted to do one more bucket, then land, pickup their firefighters & de-configure the bucket. At 1929, they advised they would be enroute to final destination after they landed at their fuel truck to refuel. They landed at 1936 to begin refueling. At 1948, they were enroute  with an ETE of 13 minutes. They landed at 2011, 18 minutes after pumpkin time.

We were to relieve Air Attack over the fire. On take off at Tucson the left turbo temp light came on. The pilot adjusted the mixture and it went out but then the right one came on and bounced between 1400 and 1900 degrees. The head temps were good and oil temps were within acceptable levels. We returned to the airport and notified all concerned.
Right auto ignition indicator came on with auto ignition switches in the off position. Contacted OAS Fleet manager and decided to ferry aircraft to boise for maintenance
Post-Flight inspection revealed a hydrulic leak in #2 wheel well, due to acracked hard line.  Line replaced by company mechanic.
Transmission chip light came on during flight to fire location

At 1400, August 7th 2019, while conducting a reconnaissance of a new fire start, the avionics system {specifically FM1 & FM2 radios: Technisonic TDFM-136B model} onboard the aircraft began to intermittently shut off during transmission. After several attempts to reset and restore normal operations to the FM1 & FM2 radios, they ceased to operate. After a discussion with the pilot in command and flight crew the decision was made to land at the nearest airport to inspect the aircraft and potentially identify the disruption. The HMGB was able to text the Zone FMO in the area who communicated the situation to the dispatch center. Inspection revealed that the helicopter would need to be taken to base facilities to be correctly assessed and repaired. Pilot in command and the HMGB determined that a safe flight could be made back to the Helibase facilities without FM1 & FM2 radios {flight following via AFF, positive cellular service, functioning AM radios and notifications to local dispatch center}. A flight path following the highway was flown until positive communication was made with the tower at the airport, this was expressed to dispatch prior to the flight. The flight was made back to Helibase } with no additional incidents or issues.

Dispatched to  incident and cancelled enroute, upon returning to our base I called to make contact telling our position and to get conditions on site on the Victor {VHF AM} on Com 2. I got no response back after initial calls. I switch to FM 1 and with same call and got a response then ask to try on Victor once again, still with no response. Then I tried our second Victor Com 1 and got a response. Upon landing the pilot and I had the mechanic come and look at the victor on Com 2. He ran some tests and informed me that the control head for that Victor was bad. I put the ship out of service @ 1500 hrs.

During takeoff from fire had a split in the two torque guages all other instruments were reading normal. Due to remoteness of incident and having no radio coverage from the ground decided to continue flight to 36S (approx 5 min). Once aircrat landed put aircraft unavailable. Mechanic troubleshot and discovered loose wire at terminal board behind the instrument panel. Tightened wire and did two ground runs Torque gauges behaved normally. Contacted RAMI and discussed problem and fix, he returned aircraft to contract availability at 1900, Faxed copy of log book entry to RAMI. Explained problem to RASM on 08/16/2005.

Returning from shipping and retrieving supplies off the fires, while in route back to the helibase for fuel the chip light came on.Mechanic/ A&P qualified worked on the C-box, the cause of the chip-light.  Installed a new C-box. Did a run-up for 5 min. Everything checked out ok.

Pilot reported low torque, inspection revealed fuel stream from P1 port in the inlet.  P1 bellows cracked.  Removed fuel control, installed fuel control with Allied Signal 1330.2 manual, chapter 73.  Put back into contract availability by the Regional Aviation Maintenance Inspector.

Utilizing Flight Following Protocols. helicopter was ordered for the fire by the IC to perform bucket operations on a slop over that occured.  The dispatch center copied all information and identified the helicopter positive AFF utilizing the 2.0 version of Automated Flight Following. Within about 5 minutes the helicopter identified they were over the dipsite and will land and reconfigure for bucket drops. The aircraft dispatcher then noticed that the aff icon for the identified aircraft was still located at the airport. The aircraft dispatcher then refreshed the screen and the program was frozen, which caused the dispatcher to shut down the program and restart it. In the events prior to the initiation of the dispatch of the helicopter the aviation dispatcher tried approx. seven times to log into aff 2.0 only to realize that after about 15 minutes of operation the program would freeze up. The aircraft dispatcher tried to utilize both internet explorer and google chrome. It was noticed that on internet explorer the program would take 15-20 minutes to be able to pull up the aff maps and would not show any aircraft. It was also noticed that on google chrome it would freeze after about 15 minutes and would have to restart the program. During the incident the aircraft dispatcher continued to restart the program to establish position locations of the aircraft.

We were dispatched to a fire on the Sequoia NF from the San Bernardino Airtanker Base. Just prior to arrival at the fire, we were cancelled by the air attack at the fire. The ATS on board the aircraft was scheduled to return to his home duty station the next day and his vehicle was at the Fresno Airtanker Base. After conferring with dispatch, it was decided that we would recover to Fresno to facilitate getting the ATS to his vehicle for the return trip to Redding. After receiving the order to land at Fresno, I obtained the current weather for FAT. Due to drift smoke from fires in the bay area, the visibilities were varying at FAT and at the time of our arrival, they were were just below VFR minimums. I contacted approach control and requested an IFR clearance into Fresno. I received a clearance and approach began vectoring us for an ILS approach to runway 29R. I proceeded to set up the avionics and loaded the approach into the GPS````s. During this phase of the flight we had excellent ground contact/visibility and what appeared to be much greater than a few miles of forward visibility. After getting established on the inbound course I recognized that I did not have a glideslope indication. We were approaching the point at which we should begin to intercept the glideslope and begin the decent phase. While I was trying to figure out why the glidesope indication was missing I allowed my altitude to vary and began a decent. I still had good visual contact with the ground and was beginning to pick up the airport environment. The approach controller alerted me to my altitude being lower than it should have been for my location and i began to correct back to the proper altitude. While climbing back to the required altitude I realized I had bumped a required selector pad {on the gps touchscreen} one too many times which was the cause for the glideslope missing. I corrected the selection to VLOC and all indications were proper. We followed the approach with no further issue and landed on the selected runway. Shortly after we parked at the tanker base we were dispatched to a fire just southeast of the airport and the visibility had risen back to VFR and we departed under VFR conditions. After operating at the fire, the airport had dropped back just below VFR minimums and we requested another IFR approach clearance and completed that approach with no issues and it was end of the duty day when we parked at the base. I was remiss in not filing a safecom in a more timely manner and should have made formal notification to share my experience with the appropriate individuals. My ability to see the terrain and the airport environment at the time of the event inappropriately lessened my concern about my mistake{s} and deviation from the proper altitude for the profile being flown.

On 05.19.12 at approximately 1305, Helicopter was attempting to lower his bucket into the Heliwell. The bucket dropped outside the Heliwell, swung into the west side of the Heliwell breaking the plexiglass sight gauge. The bucket broke the sight gauge from the Heliwell. Helicopter successfully completed his dip and completed the fuel cycle. The sight gauge was broken at the base of the tank.

On the morning of September twenty sixth, Helicopter 0FG was requested to lift from the Gill Helibase for a water dropping mission on the Castle fire. 0FG started their engine, but the generator failed to supply sufficient voltage to the aircraft. 0FG had recently received a thorough engine cleaning by the flight crew. AMU was contacted and 0FG was placed out of service.

A near miss occurred between a SEAT and a helicopter with a bucket on a 100 foot longline. The near miss occurred during the exit phase of the SEAT after dropping retardant along the left flank of the Gun Club Fire. Air Attack {Nxxxx}had just transitioned with the initial ATGS {Nxxxx}, the helicopters were supporting ground operations on the west and east ends of the left flank (north side). The fire was aligned west to east with a prevailing west to SW wind. Retardant operations were happening in the middle zone of the left flank. The each helicopter had their own water dip site, one was a ½ mile north of the left flank on the west end, and the orher was one mile south of the east end of the fire. During the air attack transition 2 SEAT drops were made, but the relief air attack did not see the south side helicopter make actual water drops in its’ area of work. Soon after the ATGS transition a third SEAT {T-xxx} arrived and was cleared into the FTA. The air attack intended to instruct both helicopters {Nxxxx & Nxxxx}to hold but evidently called twice to the north side helicopter {Nxxxx}. The south side helicopter {Nxxxx} pilot heard the calls and did not think the hold was for him because he thought the tanker ops would be on the west side of the fire. The air attack did not catch the mistaken hold call to the south side helicopter when the north side helicopter pilot replied to the second hold call that he had already said he was holding and had not recieved a hold confimation from the south side helicopter. The SEAT pilot had seen both helicopters during his arrival on scene depart the fire for the dip sites. When he heard the call for the helicopters to hold at the dip, he thought the line was clear. The air attack thought the line was clear and proceeded with the drop. There were no ground personnel in the drop area to clear. The SEAT {T-xxx} made the drop, flew through some smoke on the exit and encountered the helicopter {Nxxxx}. A helitack person, on the ground, saw the SEAT approaching and called to the helicopter pilot, who then started a right hand break. The SEAT pilot saw the helicopter and broke right. Separation was estimated at horizontally 200 to 300 feet and vertically at 50 feet.

Tanker 10 inbound to Pueblo Air Tanker Base attempted to extend right main landing gear. Landing gear did not extend. Pilot pulled up sharply on nose and landing gear extended as advertised. Tanker 10 had a normal landing at Pueblo, Co. Aircraft proceeded to Neptune's maintenance facility in Alamogordo with landing gear in down and locked position.

During flight, the pilot noticed that the snorkel hose was leaking retardant. Upon arrival back at helibase the pilot notified the manager trainee of the problem. The hose was inspected, and a small crack in the plastic was identified as the issue. Area maintenance supervisor was notified.

Was informed by the night ramp supervisor at NIFC there was an aircraft parked at the ramp that was assigned to one of our fires that had a fuel leak. He needed to get in touch with the pilot to inform him of the problem. That aircraft was assigned to the Red Mt. fire on the Boise N.F. and had flown that day on the fire. I got the information and passed it on to the ramp supervisor. The next morning I went to the ramp to see what had transpired. After talking to the pilot about the leak and what had been done to correct the problem, I contacted Gil Elmy the R-4 maintenance inspector to let him know what transpired. After Gil and the pilot talked, Gil informed me that the aircraft was not in contract available status until the problem was fixed. The problem was an inoperative auxillary fuel pump. The replacement part was ordered, was delivered today 8/18/2006 this am. Pilot informed me the wrong part was sent, right part should be tommorrow in the am. At the time of this submittal situation is unresolved.........

In preparation for departure the pilot initiated the starting process for the number 2 engine. Smoke came for the engine compartment and the start was terminated. There was a strong electrical smell, and after inspection the starter generator was determined to be fried.

We recently purchased two Red Dragon aerial ignition machines and had some issues when we used them for the first time. First, we installed the exit chute incorrectly so that the spheres could not drop out. We had placed one of the securing nuts on the inside instead of both being on the outside which caused the chute to be misaligned. Unfortunately we bench tested without the chute so were not aware of our mistake until the PSD operator experienced a jam. He attempted to clear it manually and noticed smoke coming from the machine. He immediately activated the emergency water system which extinguished the fire, and the helicopter returned to the helispot, where we discovered our mistake. After correcting our error the machine worked fine for a fuel cycle. During the next fuel cycle, however, the PSD operator experienced 3 jams in one chute. The first time, he was not able to clear the jam and the aircraft returned to the helibase where we were not able to duplicate or solve the jam. We were aware of the jamming issue caused by removing the hopper and then not removing the two spheres that block the chutes when this occurs: this was not what had occurred in this case. The aircraft returned to the unit where firing continued until he experienced two more jams in succession. He was able to manually clear both jams and complete ignition. Upon examining a random sample of Dragon Eggs, we discovered several spheres had a sharp, jagged piece of plastic protruding from the seam area. We had noticed a large number of shavings in the hopper and wondered if some of these protrusions broke off while the spheres were agitated in the hopper. We suspected that these hard plastic protrusions might be causing the eggs to jam in the chute.

On July 7th at approximately 1600 during the second cycle of a water dropping mission on the fire, the pilot received an indication of a measurable gas temperature {mgt} exceedance on the diamond j 61000-092 mgt gauge. Thunderstorms began to encroach on the fire and the pilot informed air attack he needed to retrieve the crew and return to the helibase. After returning to the helibase, the pilot discovered the mgt gauge indicated that a mgt exceedance had occurred, 6 degrees for 37 seconds. The Diamond j mgt gauge does not confirm an exceedance has occurred until the aircraft is shut-down. After the crew had completed an AAR of the initial attack, the pilot notified the Manager/COR of the exceedance and that the aircraft was out of service until an inspection of the “hot section” of the engine could be performed. Notification of the exceedance occurred an hour after the aircraft had returned to the helibase. Pilot’s account of the incident: during the flight, I did notice that the mgt gauge flashed and then stop flashing. This can happen if the temperature reaches a warning point. Typically, the flash would be accompanied by an aural warning, however, the aircraft is not wired for the aural warning. If there is no exceedance, the gauge will then stop flashing once corrective action is taken. The gauge will also flash if an actual exceedance occurs, but then stops after a minute. Without the gauge flashing and without having seen the actual moment of exceedance, the next time the pilot has an indication is when the shuts down at the end of the flight the gauge starts to flash again. I’m assuming the exceedance occurred while drafting water or during climb out, and that I saw the last couple of flashes on the gauge. Weather started to get worse and I chose to stop water dropping ops and pick up the crew to return to helibase.  Once on the ground, I did confirm that an exceedance had occurred. Research was done to determine the next steps and the Manager was notified.

Aircraft entered the Bonita incident TFR at about 2500 agl to within 2.5 miles of center point without authorization.  Incident air operations was not impacted as air attack 210 was the only a/c over the incident at the intrusion time.  AA 210 notified Ft. Myers approach which eventually supplied the intruder N #.

NXXX was dipping water on the fire.  After the fourth fuel cycle the mechanic noticed one of the tailrotor blades was delaminating.  Aircraft was put out of service at 1800 hours.Replace tailrotor blade and inform maintenance inspector.Dave Bergerud phoned the vendor's mechanic and got detailed description of the problem with delamination of the tailrotor blade and confirmed that a log book entry was faxed to Donna Shope R-8 Maintenance Inspector and returned to service by Dave Bergerud.  Donna Shope had also returned it to service.

The benefit of using S2 aircraft on the Xxxxxx fire goes beyond risk managment for the type strategy used to halt the spread of the fire without the use of heavy air tankers and ground support. Day after day the retardent lines became ineffective because of not being completed (open line) by the end of the day. This allowed the fire to advance over night to where new retardent lines would have to be established the following day. Three to four S2s and one or two Seats with 30 minute turn arounds can only do SO MUCH!

The morning of June 23, 2017, Person 1, Person 2, Person 3 and I arrived at XXXX {KXXX} airport around 8am MDT.  We were of the understanding we were to return to KYYY.  Person 1 informed me he neede to return to KZZZ and he wanted to make a call to Region X.  The plane was loaded and all preflight duties were complete.  Between 0840 and 0850 we were told we would be going to UUUU {KUUU} airport, all we needed were written orders.  After talking to Person 4 at 0857 to inform him of the change in orders, I proceeded to complete my preflight paperwork file.  Since the temperature at the aircraft was cooler than the pilot building {airconditioning was broken} I waited at the aircraft, occasionally going inside to get water and check on the status of the orders.  The third time I went back I went back to the aircraft and refiled at 1147 MDT.  We finally were ready to board and the text was sent at 1207.  Once on board the engine was started.  The winds favored runway 26.  The outside temps were 36C and inside the airplane it was 38C.  I asked if the ABCs were ready to go and received a yes and informed them it was a short taxi.  I started to taxi and was asked to check the volume on the FM radio.  Since it was an uncontrolled field and there had been no traffic I chose to check the volume.  When I looked up I checked downwind, base and final and realized I had gone too far and opted to turn on the runway and back taxi as it was too narrow taxiway to turn around.  I then departed runway 26.
APU would not start. Found no voltage to Starter. Found illogic in logic relays. Replaced bad logic with good logic. Unit tested Okay.

At 20:35 on 06/09/2013 the helicopter was dispatched to the old incident. The pilot, HMGB, and crew started to move back up to the aircraft after just returning from another incident and began to discuss the current time, the area of the fire, and what our cutoff time {pumpkin time} was for the day. We discussed that we would be able to support the fire with the 7 firefighters on board if we could identify and safe suitable landing zone near the fire, but would not be able to configure for bucket support since shut-down time for the aircraft was approaching. The helicopter was the first resource on scene, we contacted the interagency command center and notified them we were on scene and gave the initial size up of the incident. At this point they gave good intel on the resources responding and asked for an updated latitude and longitude since the original coordinates were a mile off from the original given. We gave an updated latitude longitude to the dispatch center then contacted the battalion chief who was not yet on scene. We gave him an additional size up and asked to be released. He asked that we stay on scene and relay radio communications with incoming resources. We stayed for another 5 minutes until relays were made and the battalion chief and additional engines came on scene. At that time the helicopter was past the pumpkin time. The next course of action was to get an ete to the local airport and an ete to the helibase. There was less than 1 minute difference so we elected to return to the helibase and advised dispatch of our intentions and gave our eta back to base.

Helicopter Nxxxxx was reqested to Div J for bucket work @1500 the pilot made one water drop at that time he advised air attack that he had a flight control problem and was returning to helibase. when the pilot advised helibase that he needed to jettison his bucket and longline he was directed to the emergency pad. after he jettisoned the bucket and long line he was able to make a safe landing on his assigned pad.
Air to Ground CommunicationsBlackhawks only able to communicate on VHF and with Tennessee Division of Forestry.  National Guard will not allow VHF-FM radios installed at this time.

While loading water bucket into passenger seat (front right aft facing seat of back cabin), the fuel truck driver lost control of the bucket, causing it to strike and break the window. A basketball size hole resulted.

Smokejumper ankle sprain during parachute jump.  Jumper came straight down during parachute landing and hit on his heels.  Jumper hit hard and sprained his ankle.  Jumper stated that he may have landed on the lea side of a small ridge line that may have contributed to his hard landing.Jumper worked all night and most of the day before returning to Redmond.Jumper suffered soft tissue injury only.

While flying air attack missions on the Orleans Complex, an aircraft flew into the Orleans TFR. The aircraft continued to fly approximately 700 feet underneath the air attack platform then continued northwest. Pilot tried to see the tail number but was not able prior to the aircraft entering the Eclipse TFR. Air Attack contacted the Eclipse air attack, the Air Operation Branch Director and local Dispatch Center to report the incident.

This narrative is submitted by XX XXXX AREP for State FS assigned to the XXXX Fire in XX State. The description of the incident below was submitted to the AREP by XX XX of State Forest Service.  The incident involved 2 CL 415`s and the ATGS.  Multiple water drops were carried out that impacted State Forest Personnel on the fire.  Multiple attempts were made to stop the unsafe actions.  Narrative On 11-23-16 around 1545, the Super Scoopers began to fly low to the state fire lines and dropped a load close to the burnout operation to the north {orange circle}.  I reported this to the XX State DIVS and requested that State-XX be informed of this.  The personnel on the line were notified by radio to be heads up on other possible drops.  Around 1625, I tied in with a XX State Dozer Boss {XX} and the State-XX DIVS {designated by the State-XX Team} that we were to begin out burnout operation on the highest point possible near to where they had constructed a dozer line heading down a ridge and tying into a stream {located on the western edge of XX FS operations, denoted by an orange circle}.  At this time the main fire was within 75 yards of the state fire lines near this location.  The State Task Force began a burnout operation by tying into a dozer-constructed safety zone {for four dozers} and carrying fire to the north, away from State-XX resources.  At this time I asked DIVS Echo to inform Air Attack to not drop near the burnout operations.  I received an affirmative over the radio from DIVS Echo.  At approximately 1650, the Super Scoopers dropped two loads on the northern part of the burnout operation, impacting the two Type 6 Engines and the BRIDGE Crew.  I reported this to State DIVS Champion immediately.  Shortly thereafter, the Super Scoopers dropped very close to the State Task Force to the south, and perpendicular to the fire line.  I reported this to the State DIVS Champion immediately.  Then, the Super Scoopers dropped directly on an Oklahoma Type 6 Engine and its crew.  The crew leader informed me over the radio “They are bombing us.  Please ask them to stop”.  I reported this to State DIVS Champion and informed him that this was a No-Go situation and that I was prepared to ask XX State resources to pull off of our lines.  DIVS Champion asked that I try to contact Air Attack on my radio.  I attempted to do so on a channel that the planes and Air Attack were using.  I attempted to inform Plane XXX that drops were hitting personnel on the line.  No response was given.  I attempted to contact Air Attack that drops were hitting personnel on the line.  No response was given.  Shortly thereafter, communications between Air Attack and the plane pilots continued on that channel.  No other drops occurred near XX State personnel and around 1725, the Super Scoopers were overheard to be released from the fire.  At approximately 0100 on 11-24-16, I informed XX XX about this situation and he said that these issues would be brought to the YY State-Utah Team.  At approximately 1330 on 11-24-16 I overheard radio traffic between YY-Utah Air Attack and their ground resources on the eastern part of the fire.  Air Attack was ensuring that personnel were not close to planned drops by a helicopter.  The ground resources responded that they were clear of any drops.  Air Attack responded “Just wanted to make sure we don’t have any more Super Scooper incidents”, followed by on-air laughter by the Air Attack pilot.
During run-up test from maintenance of power turbine assembly the {#}2 generator control panel failed.

While conducting water scooping operations Scooper 260, on its last scoop of the fuel cycle, impacted floating FOD damaging the left scooper probe bucket. Neither pilot saw the FOD upon entry to the scoop and saw the piece of wood after approx. 10 seconds on the water. The impact was not felt or heard on the flight deck, the only indication was the left tank was not filling. S260 completed the scoop, dropped the right hand tank on the fire and returned to PAAQ for inspection by the A&P. The A&P inspected the bucket upon landing and determined the bucket was not repairable and a replacement was ordered. The following day a new probe bucket was installed, function checked, and after discussion with the WO AMI the scooper was returned to contract availability.

HMGB/PLDO- While conducting aerial ignition operations with the Red Dragon PSD Machine on the Red Lake Reservation Highway One Rx fire unit 27A, the Red Dragon was not dropping eggs from both sides of the machine. The helicopter returned to the helispot and it was determined that a deformed dragon egg {see attached picture} had become stuck in the hopper chute. The crew looked through the rest of the eggs in the hopper and found several more deformed eggs. The rest of the boxes of eggs were examined and only one box contained a few deformed eggs.

Due to last minute changes in mission assignment, helicopter 109MA was required to remain over night in Hamilton instead of previously arranged return to assigned base (Lone Pine Helibase).  When reservations were made they were not guarenteed and were not available following shut down on 8/18 at 2100.  I discussed with the pilot and the pilot and driver decided it was the same distance back to their prearranged rooms at West Fork and home to Missoula.  They decided to go home.  With these changes, the duty day was extended by one hour.  The return trip in the morning from Missoula also increased duty day.I failed to make the decision that the pilot was not to come back on duty until 1100 hours and therefore he started at 0830 in order to be at the Blodgett Helibase at 0930.  The rest period did not meet the current duty day/rest guidelines.

After arriving to Cascade, ID from completing a mission on the bolder creek fire, the pilot and myself were advised that a potential hail storm was moving into the area. After refueling in Cascade to potentially fly to Boise, our alternate landing base, we received a mission from Cascade ID BOF to deliver food to the bolder creek fire. After discussing the incoming weather with the pilot, we decided we could complete the mission as it would take us out of the area, away from tracking storm, and allow us to circum navigate to Boise from the east/southeast. After the cargo mission was completed, we flight followed with Boise dispatch and asked for a weather update for the Ola helibase, our originally destination. They advised us of the same storm and suggested we not fly to Ola helibase. After discussing this with the pilot, we both concurred that the best course of action would be to continue to circumnavigate the storm to the east/southeast and continue to Boise. As we continued to circumnavigate the storm, we received an inflight weather briefing advising us of the storm tracking over the Ola helibase/Cascade area. During this time the weather was bumpy, there was no precipitation, and the visibility was 8-10 miles. About 40 miles out from Boise, we had a sudden on set of heavy rain. The exact words out of my mouth were “I hope that’s not hail,” and no later then finishing that sentence did we get hit by hail. The pilot immediately maneuvered the aircraft to the east and to a lower altitude, we continued to receive heavy rain for about another 15 -30 seconds before it ended. The whole incident lasted about a minute, from onset of rain to getting out of the hail. The flight continued to be bumpy but no other forms of precipitation was encountered for the rest of the flight. The first noticeable damage to the aircraft was the broken bubble window on the left door of the aircraft. After landing at Boise airport, the pilot, mechanic, and crew looked over the aircraft for damage. Damage to the aircraft consisted of the broken bubble window, divots in the skin on the nose, primarily isolated on the batter hatch cover, minor divots on the horizontal stabilizers leading edge, and divots on the upper vertical stabilizer. I notified my COR and Boise dispatch of what occurred. The pilot notified the company and further inspections by the OAS AMD’s will take place before becoming available for fire assignment.

T-xx called base right after departure stating they needed to return to base as the had lost power in the {#} 2 engine. They preceded to the jettison site, got rid of the retardant load and landed safely at RAP. Maintenance was performed as stated below and the aircraft was put back in service at 1746 per Rick Howe USFS ASI.
Aircraft Dispatcher lost capablity to contact aircraft because of continual problems with radio consoles and software with Orbacom system.

While departing the Pine Fire on the Modoc NF, 08/27/99 @ 1945, the right alternator light came on.  The 15 min flight from the fire to Kingsley Tanker Base occured without further incident. Maintenance Inspector for North Zone was consulted, and it was decided that the airplane was safe to return, with Air Attack crew, to Fresno on 08/28/99 and then on to Porterville, that same day, for both the alternator problem and a 100hr. inspection and maintenance.  This trip was made without any problems.08/29/99 the airplane maintenance and repair are occuring as scheduled and the plane is anticipated to be available for Air Attack assignments on 08/30/99.

On 10 August 2019 I was PIC on C-208 on a backhaul demobe mission out of DCK {Dahl Creek}, AK. The first load of backhaul was delivered to PAFB uneventfully @ 1727. We landed back at DCK @ 2022. We loaded the second load of backhaul destined for PAGA. Discussion ensued concerning fueling issues for the medium helicopter that was bringing backhaul from the fireline. Over the course of the summer helos have been using fuel stored in a park service fuel tank. Apparently fuel tracking methods are at best, marginal. The helicopter pilot was unable to get the amount of fuel needed to return to Galena. Options discussed were landing Huslia where I could deliver two barrels of fuel or landing Hog River Mine, which is 50 nm closer to DCK. I expressed concern about duty time issues with me attempting to return to Hog River, the decision was made to meet at PAHL {Huslia} with 2 barrels of fuel. As we started the 208 the helicopter was still shut down with doors open. I made three separate radio calls before takeoff: 1. “Dahl Creek traffic C-208 taxiing from the ramp for takeoff, any inbound traffic please advise.” This call is imperative as the runway cannot be seen from the ramp due to foliage/trees and vice versa. 2. “C-208 back taxi for departure to the west runway 26 Dahl Creek” 3. “C-208 rolling now runway 26 Dahl Creek departure to the West” Time noted 2042. I had just completed the takeoff roll and was 20’ +/- in the air when I heard the radio call ``helicopter departing Dahl Creek to the South``. I did not have time to respond to that call before the helicopter rose from the trees ahead and to my right and crossed the runway north to south maybe 500’ in front of me. I made the radio call “Breaking right” and turned right behind the helicopter climbing behind and above him. I flew to Galena, unloaded cargo, loaded fuel barrels and landed in PAHL @ 2224. After fueling operations we returned to Galena landing 2337. The Galena zone FMO was on my aircraft and the UAM was on the helicopter, both were witnesses to the events described. I would best describe this as an Incident with Potential. As is generally the case a chain of events lead up to the incident. We must stay vigilant and aware. Situational awareness is fundamental. “Hurry hurts and patience pays”.

AFTER FLYING A 7.9 ON THE ARAPAHO AND SQUIRREL CREEK FIRES ON 07/01/2012, THE CHIEF MECHANIC {WHILE DOING A POST FLIGHT INSPECTION} DISCOVERED A CRACK IN THE FREE TURBINE OF THE {{{#}}}1 ENGINE. THE MECHANIC INFORMED THE MANAGER RIGHT AWAY AND THE MANAGER INFORMED THE HELIBASE.

Helicopter T-2 W/ Bucket was ordered for Greyrock Fire on Tues Morning, March 15 by the Incident Commander. Arriving for inspection helicopter was configured with a Fixed Tank. Helicopter support truck did have a bucket available for use. Inspection did begin after noon and the helicopter was available at 1300. In speaking with the Operations SC of the Greyrock fire, there were two options, 1. Fly one fuel cycle with the fixed tank and evaluate the need to remove the fixed tank and use bucket, or stick with the fixed tank. 2. Wait aprox 1.5 hrs for the tank to be removed and myself be in place at remote helispot to hook the bucket up to helicopter. The Pilot had some ``reservations`` about using the bucket as he hadn`t performed longline work since his carding in May of 2010. My personal feelings at the time were to support option 1. This, to me served two purposes, 1. give the pilot a good evaluation of the fire area and remote helispot, allowing some time for familliarity before immediately performing some bucket work, and 2. give the fire the support of water drops while I repositioned to hook the bucket. The fire choose to go with this option and the helicopter was launched to perform fixed tank drops and evaluate effectiveness and de-tank the aircraft for fuel cycle {{#}}2 if needed. During water dropping mission pilot made 4 drops of mixed effectiveness. The helicopter was requested to be on standby for a new start and was then sent to FNL for refueling and information on the new fire. At aprox 1430, the helicopter was stood down for new fire and requested to return to the Greyrock fire for Bucket work. I relayed this information to the piot and requested that they de-tank the aircraft and fly to my location and I would hook the bucket up. I recieved a radio message @ aprox 1500 from our local dispatch that I needed to call them. They relayed from the pilot that he did not feel comfortable performing bucket work and would not be able to perform the requested mission. I then phoned the pilot and had a good conversation, we talked about the decision to recognize that he was not feeling comfortable about the mission and that the ``perishable``skill of long-lining was a little bit rusty. Rather than proceeding and risking himself and others it was better not perform the long-line bucket operation. The helicopter remained at the airport available for inital attack for the rest of the day. The company mobilized a relief piot to be on shift the next day and this did occur.

During PLDO operations, a feed chute blockage occurred, followed shortly by fire coming from the bottom of the exit chute. There is no clear causal connection between the two events. A PLDO trainee was operating the Premo machine, with a qualified PLDO on board to observe. The PLDO-T noticed that the second feeder chute was blocked, but the other three chutes were still feeding. After a brief discussion, it was decided to land at a nearby large meadow to investigate and resolve the blocked chute. En route to the LZ, and approximately 2-3 minutes after the block was observed, all personnel on board smelled something burning from somewhere in the machine, and the pilot could see flame coming from the bottom of the exit chute. The PLDO-T immediately applied emergency water, and the flame changed to smoke. The decision was made to continue with the plan to land at the meadow, but to shift over and land in a patch of snow. After landing, The PLDO-T removed the hopper and saw that there was no ball in the slipper block of the blocked feeder chute. The hopper was replaced and the decision was made to return to helibase to look more closely at what may have caused the fire. At helibase, the feeder chute blockage was identified as being caused by a broken sphere. Half of a sphere was pressed onto a full sphere, making it too large to pass from the chute. The needle of the blocked chute was fairly clean, while the other three needles had buildup. The needles and exit chute were flushed with water and scrubbed to remove buildup before returning to operation. The reservoir for emergency water was checked but did not need to be topped off because little water was needed to extinguish the fire. Another 2000 balls were dropped without incident. On this PLDO operation, a total of 11,000 spheres were dropped. An unusually large amount of ethylene glycol spray was found on the skids and back to the horizontal stabilizer. A previous prescribed fire on the unit had similar results, and with the needles being wet at the area of injection. The spheres used for both projects were from the same cache shipment. The box showed the spheres to be from xxx and showed expired on the cache tags. These observations were logged in order to monitor a possible correlation.

After landing on fire 130 and about hour of being on the ground pilot did pre flight check for departure and prior to start up the pilot noted that the amber ``GOV`` light was illuminated. After multiple attempts the pilot was able to get the light to go out prior to start and the aircraft was returned to helibase for service.

Performing fire detection flight for Arizona Strip BLM at 11,500 AGL when an impact was felt in the floorboard region of the pilot and ATGS seats. Pilot immediately turned the plane north towards Richfield {29 minute ETE}. All gauges and both engines were functioning normal showing no fluctuation. ATGS trainee sitting front seat contacted Color Country Dispatch and advised that something had happened with the plane and we were inbound to Richfield to inspect but the plane was operating normally. An emergency was not declared nor warranted. Within 30 seconds of impact an odor was detected within the cabin. The odor was not electrical in nature but we looked over all the circuit breakers to see if there was a fault. All circuit breakers were engaged and there was no fault. Began a visual inspection of the parts of the plane that were visible from the cabin. ATGS trainer in backseat observed blood on the inboard side of the right engine nacelle. ATGS trainee from the front seat looked back and could also see blood along the underside of the wing on the inboard side. Assumption was made that it was a bird strike and we landed safely in Richfield.

During first start of the day and for the previous few days, the Transmission Oil Pressure Guage occasionally dropped to a one bar indication during the first 5 minutes of runtime. Resetting the gauge circuit breaker would reset the gauge and it would return to a normal indication within one minute. After the initial glitch the problem would not re-occur and would operate normally during subsequent starts and flights throughout the day. Transmission oil temperature indications remained normal throughout the pressure indication glitch and the XMSN Oil Pressure warning light would not illuminate: both indicating that the issue was with the guage and not an actual pressure problem with the Transmission. The guage had been in service for around 30 hours after being replaced during annual inspection for a dim backlight on the previous guage. The guage did not remain failed for more than a few seconds during the first few minutes of operation.

At approximately 1629 on the Pole Creek Fire, the Pilot walked away from the aircraft after the engine was shut down while the rotors were still turning. The rotors had already lost some of their velocity but there was still movement.  This act was witnessed by both managers, two members of the ship’s crew and both of the new managers taking over the ship the next day.

After approximately 40 minutes of flight, a fighter jet appeared at our 12 o'clock, about a mile out.  Within a split second, it veered off toward our 9 o'clock and got within 1/4 mile of hitting us.  We had no time to respond, luckily it saw and avoided us.  We were approximately 12 miles to the east of the Restricted R-5107 C & H Areas and approximately 8 nautical miles to the northwest of the Beak A MOA.  We received a inheads upin from helicopter N669H who was also in transition from Alamogordo (KALM) to Double Eagle (KAEG).  N669H was ahead of us (by 10-15 minutes).  Neither the pilot or myself were able to identify the aircraft.

While enroute to the dip site, the bucket with longline released from belly of helicopter. Bucket was empty when it hit the ground. Helicopter landed, shut down, and retrieved bucket from ground personnel. Helicopter then returned to Helibase. Helicopter was shutdown so that the bucket, longline, and mechanics could be checked.
APU failed to start.

The helicopter was getting ready to start and depart for the project site.  The pilot tried to start the helicopter and it did not.  He tried a second time and was uncessful.  He motioned to the fuel truck driver to bring out the APU and hook it up.  The pilot then tried a thrid time and determined the ignitor had gone bad.  Pilot called the office and had a mechanic dispatched.  A maintenance inspector was contacted and he said that in order to put the helicopter back in service the ignitor would have to be replaced and make a entry in the log book.

During bucket operations, bucket was torn by an underwater obstruction.  Water source was approximately six feet deep with opaque clarity.  The tear occurred near bucket weights.  Pilot shut down operations at this time.  Pilot and crew discussed preventative measures to take when working out of water sources.  No stumps, fences or other obstructions were visible at this site.

On Thursday July 10th, at approximately 1700 I witnessed the helicopter release water from his bucket while flying above his helipad at the 25 mile helibase after returning from fire suppression on the 25 mile creek fire.  I was parked and standing outside my vehicle in the parking area up slope from the helipad at the time the pilot released the water from his bucket.  I am certain the release of water was intentional because the water that was released came out the bottom of the bucket.  In addition to the water releasing from the bottom of the bucket, the flight path from the water source to the fire had been altered during this drop.  I had been watching the aircraft for about 45 when I watched the aircraft deviate it`s flight path towards the helibase and over top of the landing pad.  At the time of the drop I knew I was going to get wet from the water because the wind was blowing up slope towards my direction.  Although I did not receive a direct hit during the drop, it was enough where I turned my back and covered the ipad I was holding at the time of the drop.  At the time of the drop the bucket was approximately 50 feet above and approximately 50 feet down slope from my position and 100 feet above the landing pad.  In addition to witnessing this drop I also felt that the pilot was flying at a very low altitude while in route to and from the fire area.  At times it appeared to me that the bucket was only 50 to 100 feet above the terrain, power lines and/or trees while the helicopter was climbing from the dip site in route to the fire area.

Immediately after takeoff the pilot experienced a loss of power. He jettisoned his load of retardant adjacent to the runway (500 gallons). This was his first sortie of the day. After inspection the engine appeared fine. SEAT flew the rest of the day without problems. Temperatures were hot (+ or - 110 degrees F.)
While on a recon over the Suwanne Complex, the left rear door came open.  Possible cause is the rappel scuff plate is not allowing the door to shut completely.

H-NXXX had been assigned to the Peterson fire.  It was suggested by Dino FMO that a helicopter out of Dutch John might be available, then H-NXXX could be released for IA.  Craig Dispatch followed up and ordered H-NXXXX from UBIFC. IC was surprised another helicopter was coming in and was not awareof the swap out.  I assumed Dino FMO had worked this out with the fire prior to placing resource order.  Dino FMO assumed North Zone FMO had advised IC.On resource order I neglected to write other aircraft on fire (H-NXXX).  While talking with the IC on the phone, H-NXXXX called on the radio with a lat/long no ETA to fire.  Craig Dispatch (CRC) didn't receive any off times/ETA's from UBIFC. Therefore CRC didn't advise helibase that another helo was coming in before it was already there.  Helibase didn't know what the plan for H-NXXX or H-NXXXX was.  Another contributing factor to this situation, was that the assigned aircraftdispatcher was busy/pre-occupied getting orders into ROSS and unable to devoteall attention to aircraft.  Therefore, I jumped into the middle of aircraft and dropped the ball.  ROSS has created additional workloads for local IAdispatch centers and now is affecting the safety of the field firefighters when important details get dropped.

The fuel filter light came on while on a scooping mission so Fire Boss 1 headed back to Fairbanks and Fire Boss 2 flew with him for safety.  The filter light went out partway back but they continued to Fairbanks and had the mechanic check it out.  The aircraft was placed out of service on landing at 1525.

While loading retardant, the flight crew was notified that there was an issue with the pumping systems.   Retardant load was stopped at 1200 gals.   The crew was then informed that the aircraft was loaded with straight liquid concentrate.

N1048Y was doing fire suppression bucket work on the Togo fire.  Ship was dipping water out of a 15,000 gallon heli-well with a Griffith bucket, at an established dip site about 2 miles south-east of the fire.  Ship had dipped out of the heli-well, and was beginning to depart the dip site when winds changed unfavorably. Consequently, ship had insufficent power/lift, so pilot dumped part of the water cargo.  The bucket came near (6-8 feet) to hitting ground as pilot was trying to regain lift, but the bucket did not hit ground.  The bucket was still part full (1/3 to 1/2) when pilot regained sufficient lift.  With a partially loaded bucket, pilot maneuvered ship back to the heli-well to again fill to capacity.  As pilot was positioning bucket over the heli-well to top it off to capacity, the partially loaded bucket came down on the rim of the heli-well.  The weight of the rigid bucket and water cargo buckled two panels of the heli-well, bending the panels inward, causing a slight overhang in the dip tank diameter.  Resulting damage may require replacing these two panels, if they cannot be bent back into shape.Note that damage only occurred to the heli-well, with no damage to N1048Y ship.

After being dispatched to the fire near, the pilot noticed a binding/grinding feeling in the aileron controls before take off. The mission was canceled and plane brought back to the pit at SBD then put out of service for repairs.

During fire operations with airtankers working out of xxxxx ATB in support of the yyyyy fire. ATB Mgr was called by one of the Helitanker Base Mgrs  requesting if yyyyy has room to accomadate the washing off of retardant from two helitankers towards the end of the day. The HT mgr was advised that yyyyy can accomadate one at a time and to cycle them one at a time and to have the HT land on the main taxi way and to taxi roll into the designated area for washing. Local FAO called Helibase and was advised by the local HT mgr that there are four HT that need retardant washed off. HT-zzz was first to arrive at yyyyy, the HT decended directly over the aircraft parking area then landed, did not follow the directions given to the HT mgr.. With the wind coming out of the NE and the rotor wash blew dust and debis into pits 3 & 4 directly into T-ww and T-uu that were being loaded and preparing to taxi out of the pits. No sooner than HT-ccc landed HT-bbb was two minutes out from xxxxxx, HT-bbb landed on the main taxi way and then taxi rolled into the designated area as directed. There were no issues with HT-bbb approach and positioning into xxxxxx ATB.

Practice jump one mile north of Ladd Field. Upon dropping the last stick and confirming with ground crew that all jumpers were safe, departed area and relayed to pilot that I was going to put door on, pilot remarked that we were in the pattern to land, and to leave the door in place. I complied. After landing copilot opened tailgate, wedging side door into structural rib. Minor Damage done to rib, and side door.

While working on the Frye Fire based out of Safford, AZ, a Rappel Module was loaned out to assist with IA for the surrounding area. Before launching it, the manager was made aware that they would be following the Frye AA to the fire by the HB, but it turned out we would be ahead of him after launching. Enroute Tucson Dispatch told us of 3 SEATs that were working on the fire which was approximately 28nm from the Safford Airport {KSAD}. Halfway to our destination one of the SEATs was spotted at a slightly offset intercepting path with our aircraft holding the same altitude. Approximately 1/2 mile separated us. The distance was enough for both aircraft to change course of flight ever so slightly upon recognition of each other. If not caught as soon, it would have been much more drastic in flight control manipulations for both parties.

On 5/13/00 Helicopter 210 was on a scheduled recon of the Outlet fire departing from the Grand Canyon NP South Rim helibase.  Upon launch Helo 210attempted to contact Outlet Air Attack on Victor 119.50 and 123.95 to no avail.  Helo 210 then landed @ North Rim Helibase until air attack could becontacted.  Air Attack then requested 210 remain on the ground @ North Rim HBuntil all airtankers over the fire were clear.  Helo 210 remained on the ground for 10-15 minutes.  At approximately 13:00 Air Attack cleared Helo 210 to launch for the fire recon.  Helicopter 210 requested to start a recon up the North Flank and clockwise around the fire perimeter returning to North Rim @ the end of the recon.  Air Attack approved the pattern and advised a Lama and a Lead 53were over the fire and there were no airtankers due for 10 minutes.Helicopter 210 proceeded up the North Flank at 500' AGL (8800 MSL).Helicopter 210 had a visual on the Lama who was making location calls in the blind while doing bucket work.  Helicopter 210 also sighted Lead 53 4-5 milesahead just as he flew into the smoke drift.  At that time the Lead 53 was traveling in the same direction (Northeast) as Helicopter 210.  Helo 210 proceeded up the North flank staying wide of the perimeter and the smoke. At approximately 13:10 Helicopter 210 pilot and manager sighted Lead 53 as it appeared out of the smoke approximately 1/4 mile to starboard at the same altitude as Helicopter 210 on a recipricol heading (Southwest).  Lead 53 banked left as he sighted Helicopter 210 and reported to Air attack that an unknown helicopter was in orbit over the fire.  Helicopter 210 identified itself as being the ship involved. Separation was estimated to be 1000' to 1/4 mile.Lead 53 pulled into an orbit out of the area as Helicopter 210 verified itsorbit altitude with Air Attack.  Air attack requested the helo remain at 500'AGL.  Helicopter 210 then requested to move to 1000' and was cleared to do so by Air Attack.  Helicopter 210 finished the recon and returned to North Rim Helibase at 1320.  At the time of the incident there were no airtankers in orbit over the fire.  Helicopter 210 was not notified that the Lead plane would be making low passesor dry runs on the North Flank.  From subsequent radio conversation on Victorit was apparent that the Lead plane was not aware of Helicopter 210's presenceor position on the fire.

Air patrol departed the airport at 1326 in a Cessna 182 under contract with the US Forest Service. The aircraft contained agency carded pilot and an aerial observer. They were approximately 1.5 hours into the patrol flight when they heard a “pop” in the forward engine compartment. The engine began running roughly. The pilot adjusted engine controls and trim and then proceeded to diagnose the problem. Engine oil began to cover the front windscreen of the aircraft. The pilot issued a mayday call over the radio. The pilot and observer began to assess and discuss potential landing areas for emergency landing. They selected a pasture in river drainage as their best option and began a gliding descent. Engine oil continued to completely cover the windscreen while descending. They had sufficient altitude and airspeed for a single pass by the pasture to scan for hazards. They set up for a 180 degree approach turn to a landing heading and began to lose some airspeed and altitude A large tree in the center of the field was identified as an obstacle they would have to avoid. Winds were gusty and variable generally from the west.  The crew was not able to identify wind direction. They turned for final approach to the East,  and the wind was at their tail. The pilot added some remaining power to clear the tree and noticed a power line he needed to descend under to avoid it.  They cleared the tree and descended under the power line touching the ground just past the power line. They bounced upon impact. The front landing gear was torn off upon the second touchdown. They began to slide on the rear landing gear and nose of the airplane,  the right wing impacting the ground. They continued to skid nearly straight until coming to a halt 75 to 100 yards from the tree line at the end of the pasture at approximately 47 38.948N latitude, 115 59.912W longitude at elevation of 2377 msl. The occupants of the aircraft emerged with bruising on their arms and sore backs and necks from the forward and lateral forces in the cockpit after impact.Damage was determined to be substantial and the accident is currently under investigation by the NTSB

T-14 Mechanical safecomT- 14 was working the La Jolla Fire on the Cleveland N.F.  On departure from Ramona airport T-14's landing gear would not retract.  They returned to Ramona.  Upon examination of the aircraft, the flight crew found a loosepoppet adjustment in the landing gear control valve.  They set same as perthe DC-4 maintenance manual.  Operation check was O.K.  Gerry Burney was informed of the situation, and they were put back in service at 1244 hr.The repair documentation was sent to Gerry Burney via FAX.

Helicopter received a dispatch to the fire in @1730. Helicopter began start up procedures after mission planning with HMGB was completed. Upon the first attempt to start #1 engine, pilots experienced a sharp rise in engine T5 temp. forcing them to abort the start. Due to strong winds blowing into the exhaust of the aircraft, lead Mechanic decided the aircraft needed to be repositioned to avoid the wind. Pilots attempted 2 additional engine starts, both attempts were again aborted to avoid hot starts. HMGB notified both dispatch centers of aircraft status. HMGB then notified local FAO and R-2 AMI.

After one ferry flight and one cycle water dropping on initial attack, mechanic noticed a pocket that was loosened on a blade of the tail rotor system. No vibration or change was noticed in last flight. Nothing was struck, but high winds omequalsn ferry and initial attack...Tail rotor blade being replaced and balanced. RMI notified. Helibase and Air Support made aware and aircraft made UA until repaired and test flight performed.

Pilot Statement: During first bucket drop of cycle the bucket failed to deploy it's contents, upon landing and inspection it was found that both of the bucket's internel support chains had been unscrewed and left undone. Both the anchor pins had been left in place. One of the chain clasps had been screwed back in while the other had been left undone. This appears to have been deliberate tampering. Manager Statement: The manager agrees that this is deliberate tampering. The odds that even one of the clasps would come unscrewed is extremely low.

While the helicopter was performing bucket drops on the Xxxxxx Incident at an elevation of approx.7500 ft pilot noticed a significant split in ITT and NG in the engines along with a rapid loss of power in the #1 engine. Pilot released the load of water and returned to helibase. While in-bound to helibase pilot notified helibase of the problem and requested the deck area be kept clear he released bucket on first approach into helibase flew around one orbit then landed without incident. This is the third time this problem has occurred with this helicopter. The first time was on June 13 with passengers on board TCU unit was changed out and problem seemed to go away. Second time was June 30th, again TCU unit was changed out and problem went away. The contractor is currently working with factory tech reps to correct the problem and helicopter remains out of service.

this was an incident with potential. 08-01-2007 bucket work on the lightning fire was performed by xxx. retardent was used. pilot returned from fire and shut-down for mandatory break. when asked how things were going with missions, pilot informed me that something inside of rinse tank ``snagged`` a bucket support cable and broke it. we informed helibase immediately of the problem and the mechanics proceeded to fix the broken cable. cable was fixed quickly and no loss of availability was incurred. day was close to ending, no more missions for the day. we were informed at evening de-briefing that nothing was out of the ordinary with the inside of the tank. 08-02-2007 over morning coffee and before helibase briefing my trainee and myself drove to the retardent site to see and inspect the tank ourselves. we inspected the tank and shot some pictures and this is what we think. when ship nears the end of its fuel cycle, they wash the buckets in a rinse tank. this is what happened as far as i can tell.....the bucket was lowered into the rinse tank, the control head was lowered past the top of the tank and hung down the side of tank. as bucket filled, bucket sank, pilot began to lift. the cables of bucket snagged on the corner of a ``sight window`` on side of tank. helicopter kept lifting and cable was snapped. pilot flew back to middlefork helibase. none of the personnel at the retardent site saw this happen.

Since 6/25/08 we have been flying air attack missions on both the Peterson Complex and Cub Complex. During that time our primary VHF-AM radio frequency {Primary Victor}has been usurped by the aviation resources on the Lime Complex. For the past three days, the Cub Incident Comm. unit has procured a new Primary Victor frequency for our use. Every day, we have found the new frequency being used simultaneously by the Lime Complex. Several times their transmissions have covered our radio traffic. It is only a matter of time before a critical situation is the result of a lack of poor radio frequency management.

At approximately 0915 helicopter XXXXX was on the ground shut down awaiting its first mission of the day. There were water tenders out on the deck doing dust abatement. The pilot looked out at the helicopter as the water tender rounded the front of the aircraft and noticed the main rotor blades turning and the water tender come to a stop. The pilot and helitack crewmembers went out to the deck and found that the water tender driver had struck the end of one of the main rotor blades. The impact occurred on the water tender driver`s left windshield. The blade incurred a 1 inch gash on the outside edge. The water tender incurred a broken windshield and dented cab.

Upon returning to MWH tanker base T-xxx reported a chip light on engine #2.  Company mechanic removed and cleaned the chip detector and screens.  Sludge was removed from the detector and the screen was clean.  Engine runup performed and no other problems were found.  The aircraft was placed back in availability status by XXXX XXXXXX, R-6 Maint. Inspector.  XXX

On 9/11/2017 The helicopter was doing bucket work on the Black fire. The pilot received an engine chip light. He immediately returned to the helibase. Metal was found when inspecting the chip plugs, MO 3 had the majority of the metal debris. The companies DOM as well as the Maintenance inspector were both contacted.

On July 27, 2019 a fire boss was supporting a fire and scooping water from a large lake. When the pilot landed at the airport after the mission the support vehicle driver noticed a wrinkle in the metal on top of the float. The location of the wrinkle is where the forward cross member connects the float to the plane. This section of the float is reinforced since it takes the majority of the force of impact when the plane scoops water. The pilot noted rough conditions on the lake while scooping, including white caps. The winds were 30-39 mph at times and aligned with the lake. At times crosswinds were present during scooping runs. The pilot also noted that he has flown in worse conditions. It is not known if these floats were showing this damage before this mission or not.
Loss of torque in the #1 engine. Trouble shooting indicated governor change needed.

Assign to lighting recon flight at 1050 Hrs. At end of planned flight, pilot noted right engine HP would not come back below 250 HP. Made landing at SBA at 1200 hrs. Mechanic worked on aircraft with test flight being OK. SZ Aviation Maintenace Inspector was called and aircraft was return to availability status. At 1549 hrs response to SB co fire #5209. 1615 hrs right engine would not come back below 250 HP, landed at SBA at 1641 hrs. SZ Maintenance Inspector was called on the situation, log book entry will be fax to Jerry when aircraft is returned to availability status.

While offloading gear from a crew shuttle, the manager noticed that the baggage door in the B212 tail boom had started to delaminate. He informed the pilot, and operations were paused until the mechanic could inspect it. The mechanic deemed it an airworthiness item and the aircraft was temporarily repaired and ferried back to the designated base 25nm away with essential crew only.
While the airtanker was performing engine run-up, the left mag on #2 engine developed 300-400 RPM drop with rough running.

Pilot and ATGS had both come off of days off for the first flight of the day. Pilot and ATGS did a walk around and pre-flight before taking off for the mission. Plane took off from KSLC and flew a 4 hour mission over the fire. The flight was very rough with moderate to severe turbulence, that eventually led to grounding of all airtankers and helicopters. After the mission plane landed in KPVU for fuel. While fueling, the pilot noticed that the center fuel cap was missing. The fuel cap was in place during the morning pre-flight inspection.

On August 6th Helicopter -XXX, an exclusive use type 1 helicopter {Kaman K-1200,} was dispatched to the a fire on the Eldorado National Forest for Initial Attack. At the time of dispatch H-XXX was positioned at another helibase located off HWY 16 approximately 20 miles west of Woodland, CA. The IA Fire was approximately 70 miles east near Placerville Airport {KPVF}. The contractor was equipped with a 660 gallon Bambi Bucket which is capable of being stowed on onboard while in flight. However, due to the buckets weight the pilot is incapable of unloading or loading the bucket without assistance. This creates a challenge when responding to initial attack fires when unloading assistance is not available near the fires location. Before departing the current helibase the HMGB contacted a member of a Helitack crew {HECM} who was also responding to the IA Fire and was enroute to Placerville Airport to see if they would be able to provide assistance with unloading the bucket. It was determined that the HECM would not arrive at the airport in time to assist. A call was also made to the airport itself, however KPVF had down staffed for the day. After further discussion between the HMGB and the pilot, and finding no other options that would result in H-XXX being able to take action on the fire before the end of the operational shift, the decision was made to fly with the bucket and longline deployed on the helicopter. The flight path was adjusted from a direct route to one that would take H-XXX further north of Sacramento to avoid more potential air traffic and ground structures. Ground traffic avoidance was also discussed. H-XXX then departed and responded to the IA Fire where it performed bucket work before returning to Placerville Airport at the end of the operational shift.

Mission: Bucket Work with 150'' long line at 6000 feet MSL, in steep terrain. The UH-1H followed the S58T into the dip, to become familiar with the area. The S58T returned for fuel and the UH-1H did three drops without incident. Around 1700 hours, on the fourth bucket {into the drop} he flew along the opposite {south} slope from the fire at approximately 40 knots. He began his right turn to the drop area when the bucket contacted the top of a tree. As per pilot ''I simply let my situational awareness down and was lower than I thought. I focused on the drop area as opposed to the high terrain I was over''. Once the pilot acknowledged the bucket was not operable he set down in a field, loaded his bucket into the aircraft, and returned to the helibase. Air Attack was in contact and informed throughout the whole situation.
While assigned to the Zaca incident, Nxxxx unintentionally jettisoned it''s long-line and bucket on approach to a water drop.

The aircraft was assigned to HLCO and landed at Santa Ynez to drop off the HLCO and return to Live Oak Helibase. During the unloading of the HLCO gear from the right rear cabin door, the door was apparently closed. Then, the helicopter returned to Live Oak Helibase. On approach the helicopter manager on the ground noticed the right rear door was open and ajar approximately 12 inches. After landing, I discussed with pilot and helibase manager about the incident and corrective actions. This model aircraft does not have a door ajar indicator light that could have warned the pilot.

On assignment for the Lonesome Complex the aircraft was ordered up with a bucket. The Helicopter is equiped with a fixed tank under the exclusive-use National Helicopter contract and within section B-12 is necessary to have a variable capacity collapsible bucket as an addition or back-up with the fixed-tank helicopter. The contracted fixed-tank helicopter has along with it a FAST {Fire Attack Storm Tank} Bucket, manufactured by Absolute Fire Solutions, INC and distributed by Simplex MFG. While making a dip at the dip site, one of the purse string wires hooked underneath the bolts rubber stopper and nut on the metal frame; this resulting in the frame bending under the added stress to the frame itself rather than the anchor points as intended. The frame was bent in a twisting manor and the purse string wire had groves {ware} along it showing that it caught on ''something'' with an edge.
While dipping out of a dip site one of the four (4) eyebolts on the Griffithbucket broke due to metal fatique. Pilot put bucket down, saw the problem,released water and returned to helibase.

We had a normal takeoff and climb out. As we were about to level off we recieved a Master Caution light associated with a Right CSD Oil Pressure Low annunciation. We leveled off, checked the gauge, which was pegged, and then began to get into the QRH when lights, screens, etc. began to flash intermittently. The generator was immediately tripped and the CSD red guarded disconnect switch was accomplished after that. We turned on the APU and finished the checklist in the QRH. We then determined the best course of action was to return to base with the load. An uneventful landing was next with a taxi to our maintenance personnel finishing of the event.

Enroute to Fire, T-xx lost an engine and shut it down. The load of retardant was aborted and the tanker returned to MSO for repairs (engine replacement). The tanker went to the ramp for the repair process. Will be back 08-13-03 maybe.

On takeoff fuel pressure gauges read normal, 10 minutes into the flight the right engine fuel pressure gauge was reading high. So the pilot decided to terminate the flight on return to the airport. aircraft was placed into contract unavailable status. Company maintenance chief decided to replace the right engine driven fuel pump and do the scheduled 50 hr inspection at the same time. During the inspection the mechanic found the right engine driven hydraulic pump had failed. Hydraulic pump was replaced 8/8/07.

This incident occurred during operations on a prescribed burn on the Ava district of the Mark Twain National Forest. The Mark Twain Helitack Crew and Helicopter were supporting the prescribed fire with firing operations using the Premo Mark III PSD machine. During the second set of helicopter firing operations that day, while spheres were being added to the machine from one of the refill bags, the PSD operator noticed a half sphere come out into the hopper.
