This can be a hazard as there have been a number of previous safecoms written where broken sphere halves have stuck to another full sphere resulting in a chute or slipper block jam {which could ultimately cause a fire in the machine}. After noticing the ball, the PSD operator removed the half broken sphere from the hopper and informed the Pilot and Firing Boss in the front of aircraft what had been observed. Together it was decided that the firing operation could continue, but that the PSD operator would take extra caution to watch for any other broken sphere halves to ensure that they could not jam the machine. This was accomplished by loading the spheres more slowly into the hopper, as to observe every sphere coming out and ensuring the proper condition of each. By the end of the mission after all the spheres had been emptied from the refill bags, no other halves were found and the mission was completed without incident.
After takeoff from helibase cockpit BIM light illuminated.  Returned to helibase.

While on an Air Attack mission to Fire #846 on the Ochoco NF, I overheard Central Oregon Dispatch telling T-xx the contact on the fire was Recon 1.  T-xx made several attempts to contact Recon 1 on the VHF-AM frequency 132.475.  T-xx then contacted dispatch who then contacted Recon 1 on the FM frequency to call the airtanker on the VHF frequency. I then could hear Recon 1 coordinating the drops between T-xx and the ground.  As the ATGS Coordinator for the Pacific Northwest Region, my records indicate the observer in Recon 1 is a trainee ATGS and has not completed the task book.  From the radio conversation between Recon 1 and T-xx, the coordination was satisfactory with no problems.  My concern is where do we draw the line.  If it is ok for a Recon observer to coordinate one airtanker drop, is it ok to add one helicopter?  Then perhaps a load of smokejumpers?I am not sure what all was envolved in the request to have Recon 1 coordinate the drops. I do know the Captain of T-xx is carded for Initial Attack.

Mechanical Problem -- S.E.A.T. was on a fire retardant dropping mission for the Pahcoon Fire. When the pilot informed dispatch he was returning to the airport with an electrical problem. The generator light had come on. While inspecting the engine the pilot found everything in working order except one wire that had come loose.
T-XX had moved to the run up area and a chip light came on. They came back to the base and explained the problem to the Base Manager. AMI was informed of the situation.

Air Tactical Group Supervisor of the Mollie fire reports a inKatanain aircraft in the airspace over the Mollie TFR. Local knowledge determined that the local college trains pilots using inKatanas'in in this area.

Tanker was assigned to the Fire on June 15th, 2013. The aircraft arrived at the Airtanker Base for a load of retardant to bring to the fire. After taking the active runway and beginning the takeoff sequence, the PIC noticed that a warning light was illuminated. The aircraft had not lifted off the ground and was traveling at approximately 80 knots. Since the aircraft was at or below the 80 knot threshold {the low speed regime}, the crew aborted the takeoff and safely stopped the plane on the runway. It was quickly determined that a switch for the de-icing had not been activated which was the cause of the warning light. The switch was turned on and the warning light turned off.

While inspecting the A/C at Prescott ATB a .25 inch crack was located on the lower left wing skin between fuselage station 40 and the engine nacelle.  The A/C was flown to ALM for repairs. Repair to this skin has been accomplished wtih the procedures of NAVAIR 01-75EEB-3 figure 2-6 Structural Repair Instructions, Advisory Circular AC 43.13-1B Chapter 4, section 4 and FAA form 8110-3 dated August 30, 2002 by American AeroStructures by the installation of an external doubler placed over the effected area. The A/C was put into service per FS National Maintenance Manager @1630 hrs MDT on 08/30/2002.

A Gen 2 FRDS Fire Gate failed to operate in auto mode. Pilot reset and tried the second time and still the gate failed. Notifications were made to DOI and USFS AMIs when aircraft was taken out of service.
TFR incursion at 1345 by a single prop fixed wing headed north to south directly over helibase at 9500 ft msl. No aviation resources were up at the time of the incursion.

Long line mission of a 55 gal. blivet and tuna net of sleeping bags, MRE's, and water.While setting the 55' load into the fire (9700') the pilot noticed a fir tree close and punched off the load including the longline.  The wiring pulledout of the 9 pin plug and the liner for the blivet broke.Pilot stated he should have utilized the 100' line with the slope.

#1 engine input coupling observed running hot.  Noticed grease drying out permaturely.  Removed and replaced input seal and bearing housing assembly with serviceable unit.  Inspected and repacked input coupling.  Ground test run-up checked out OK.  Maintenance inspector advised/approved return to contract availability a/c (o/s) N/A 0800-1400 hrs.

Blade 60 flying water drops on Spanish Fire SBC-4140.  Helicopter said they were going to fuel at Santa Ynez Airport, I asked if they could leave the bucket on the fire at a safe place.  This would have saved time rather then returning to Helibase.  I assumed that they would return to the Helibase, if they were unable to locate a safe location, however they dropped over the ridge and I could not communicate with them.  I informed the Helibase Manager of Blade 60 flying to airport with bucket under ship.Wes Shook AOBD Comments/ This flight was over the San Rafel Wilderness and then over various ranches and parts of the community of Santa Ynez Wilderness. Along with the return trip.  The pilots were not aware that they should have left the bucket and then flown on for fuel.
Airtanker called with a jet problem. Jet would not start.

With the helicopter shut down the 100' longline was attached to the bellyhook to fly a 72-gal. blivet to fire Q718. The release mechanisms for the bellyhook and remote hook were checked and functioning. The helicopter then started and lifted off. At about 5' AGL the electrical cord came undone inferring that tension was being placed on the electrical cord. At about 10 to 15' AGL the cable fell to the ground. The pilot landed and the mechanic/fuel truck driver inspected the components and found no damage. The longline was reattached, checked and the load flown to the fire without incident. Problem: When the helitack person hooked up the longline to the helicopter he may have pulled in too much slack resulting in a bow being placed on the cable between the hook and the ground. The built-up tension in the bow of the cable probably caused the cable to twist up laterally resulting in the pear ring slipping over the tip of the hook and past the security gate.

While dipping out of a double high 3500 Gal Foldatank, Helicopter hooked one of the top metal frame support crossbeams of the tank, ripping it off the tank and laying the tank over. The bucket and helicopter were undamaged.  The tank set up: was not level, close enough to some buildings and trees to require a 100 foot long line, and winds were a factor.

SEAT was landing for third load and return of the day from PDT SEAT base. Upon landing, nose of aircraft moved to the left, and pilot made aft stick and rudder corrections. Tail wheel hit runway and bounced back up, and pilot inadvertently applied too much brake while attempting rudder corrections which caused the tail to raise enough for the propeller to make contact with the runway.  The pilot immediately turned off Engine and electrical power, and aircraft was moved by airport personnel from the active runway. There was visible damage to propeller system but unknown damage to engine.

I have the radio interference report form and will fill that out as well and forward on through our Forest radio techs.Please pass on to SWCC Coordinator as I have discussed these problems with him.AIR GUARD INTERFERENCE ALONG THE MEXICO BOARDER. Air Guard is receiving interference from a source in Mexico.  When this interference occurs, it is overwhelming the frequency and causes the ATGS to turn down the Guard as far as it will go.  I have noticed it periodically while working in and around Silver City, N.M. and along the Az./Mexico border of the Coronado. I thought I could program both the transmit and receive on the ATGS aircraft to minimize the impact of this interference, but found that is not possible.  I’m not sure if a software or a hardware fix is needed to allow a tone on the receive side. This interference is not constant, but is enough that you are adjusting the volume on a continual basis.FAA ASSIGNMENT OF VHF AM FREQUENCIES FOR EXTENDED ATTACK.On the merritt fire I requested and was assigned extended attack VHF frequencies for Air Tanker and helicopter use.  The frequencies assigned have been common air-to-air frequencies.  I have had interference from Tucson and Phoenix area airports, medivac flights and other private pilots using these frequencies for air-to-air use.  I asked the pilots that I happened to be flying with at the time and they said that these frequencies are common air to air frequencies for anyone to use and we have no right to tell someone to get off, it’s what the frequency is for.This is not satisfactory for our intended use.  We have to have a frequency that is ours alone.  Even if the ATGS is the only one being impacted by this interference the chance that important transmissions being blocked or walked on are too great to continue to use common air-to-air frequencies. This has the same impact as the Guard interference in that it affects the safety of air operations. The three frequencies that were assigned to me for the Merritt fire are; 123.050, 123.025, and 122.750.  All had varying degrees of interference from common air-to-air use.

At 0830 over the Grandad Fire, OR-BUD-2501, the DIVS advised that an intrusion of TFR 6/7719 occurred in which the Division Supervisor saw a local rancher fly his aircraft at approximately 500 AGL thru the TFR, in what appeared to be a recon of the fire. The A/C was described as a Super Cub, white with maroon or blue stripe flying to the NW then North. There were no firefighting aircraft over the fire at the time. Notified UAO and FSDO.

XXXXX XXX had their mechanic inspect their Fire Bosses per a directive from Air Tractor. The inspection involved an air pressure test of the structural tubing in the tail section of the fuselage. XX-XXX failed this test. As a result it was made unavailable at 1326 on 7/26/2019. The cause appears to be a crack in a weld joint {see attachment}. .

As ATGS, the Lead Plane and I were using air tankers {SEATs and LATs} to re-enforce retardant lines that we put in the day prior that the fire had burned through or were getting close to burning through. During this operation we had multiple helicopters doing bucket work and recons. There was one recon helicopter, that we had positive contact with, and were cleared in at 9,500 and below with an altimeter of 2992. They were instructed to avoid the retardant drop area and remain in one division area, which they complied. After orbiting for some time, they informed me that they we returning to helibase. I acknowledged and asked them to stay wide of the tanker drop path which they did. The air tankers were being cleared in by the Lead Plane at altimeter 2992 and 10,500 feet. After initial clearance and target identification they were then cleared to maneuver low level to complete their drops. After completing the mission, I returned to the airport and the aircraft was returned to initial attack responsibility. While en-route I received a phone call from air operations that a SEAT had overflown the recon helicopter while he was orbiting near Helispot A. I went to helibase and met with the manager of the recon helicopter and discussed what had happened. The pilot was not available to discuss it because he was flying, but he did call me later and explained that the SEAT overflew them and he was flying at 8600’-8700’ and the seat was not above the 10,000 ceiling that he should have been to provide for the 500’ separation that is required.
AFTER PREVIOUS EVENT WITH CONTRACTORS OTHER AIRCRAFT THE COMPANY DECIDED TO TAKE OFF THE REAR ROTORHUB FOR CLOSE INSPECTION.

On 06/10/19 While on a initial attack fire the right seat pilot noticed the tank was not filling from snorkel. Left seat pilot cycled the collective snorkel fill switch to insure the hoist pump was “stoking” up to pressure. The system appeared to operate properly but still not filling the tank. We then aborted the snorkel operation and pulled up to 75 foot hover to troubleshoot. Upon pulling the snorkel out of the pond we noticed that the snorkel pump head had slipped off the snorkel tube and was hanging by the safety cable and hoses. We announced to air attack that we needed to return to tanker base. He said he was releasing us and all aircraft as we were no longer needed. We returned to tanker base for repairs.

NXXXXX departed Warm Springs helibase at 1503 went recon for approximately 39 minutes into flight NXXXXX turbine out temp. gauge started bouncing from 6.5 to 7.0 to 7.5 back to 6.5 while out on patrol.

On the morning of the second day of an aerial ignition operation, it was discovered that the manual release cable was broken and it and the electrical wires had been heavily wrapped with electrical tape. The HECM immediately notified me and the pilot of the problem. The pilot felt that it was no big deal as he still had an electrical release. I immediately removed the aircraft from service and was informed by the pilot that the mechanic had already flown from Salt Lake City, Utah to Minneapolis, Mn and was currently driving to Ely with the parts to replace the manual release assembly. On the afternoon prior to this the pilot informed me that he needed to phone the company immediately or it would cause big problems down the road. He offered no further explaination. I believe that the maintanence deficency was discovered by the pilot the day before. The helicopter manager was never informed of any of this and the problem went undectected by the crew until the hook checks were down prior to starting the helitorch operation.

On the daily pre-flight the pilot noticed fluid leaking onto the nose tire from the nose strut. Also, the nose strut was entirely deflated. The pilot notified her company xxx Aviation and they arranged to have the airplane checked out by xxx Flying Service {xxx}. xxx provided a certificate of drug testing program before work commenced.

On 7/13/2025 T-XX was load and return to the South Omak Lake Fire, WA-COA-0087. The retardant loader after he was signaled in to start the loading, proceeded to hook up the hose and start loading. The normal procedure for loading a P2V is to hook up the hose and wait for the go ahead signal from the copilot who monitors the loading procedure. The copilot immediately had the operation stopped. It was explained to the retardant loader that it is important on this type aircraft to wait for the word to start so as to make sure that all valves are open and tank is ready. The retardant loader later said that he made a mistake, the last three loads he loaded were on a P-3 and that he realized afterwards the need to be more observant to the type of aircraft he was to load.

While conducting retardant operations I descended below a ridge crossing altitude. This was NOT on purpose. I tunnel visioned the drop, and continued down. This was a little fill in spot and I was really focused on finishing the line. As I stated, this was NOT on purpose. We{crew} debriefed and talked about what happened, and of course, how to prevent this type of screw up. Thanks

Two Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System (MAFFS) aircraft at the Hill Air Tanker Base located at Hill Air Force Base received launch orders to the Danskin Fire located at North 44 degrees 04.27 minutes, West 115 Degrees 49.53 minutes. Inflight both airtankers were diverted to the Horse Skin Fire located at North 42 degrees 26.8 minutes, West 115 degrees 09.8 minutes. After dropping their retardant loads, both aircraft landed at the Boise Air Tanker Base, reloaded and returned to the Horse Skin Fire. Air Attack 64E/Leadplane 49 advised MAFFS 1 & 3 to hold in pattern as weather conditions over the fire was experiencing a sand/dust storm preventing any drops. Air Attack then released MAFFS 1 & 3 to return to Hill AFB loaded, as wind conditions were gusting due to a passing front.MAFFS 3 on downwind leg of landing pattern to Hill Air Force Base had a fire indicator light on #3 engine illuminate. Pilot declared an inflight emergency. Crew performed emergency checklist procedures and shutdown the engine. Light remained illuminated and both fire bottles were discharged. Engine indications were normal and visual inspection of #3 was normal. On landing the aircraft cleared the runway and stopped on the taxiway. The crew egressed the aircraft and moved away. The left main tire began to smoke. The base fire crew sprayed the brakes and tires. The left main brake seized.The Hill AFB Crash and Rescue emergency vehicles responded to the inflight emergency. Military maintenance worked with the emergency crews to remove tires, unlock brakes, cap brake lines, reinstall tires and move aircraft off of taxiway.

While flying the fire at 1815 pilot observed an aircraft in TFR flying NE at 8,000 feet , 500 feet above us on TCAS. Aircraft was shown as N-XXXX . We visually spotted a yellow and black A-Star heading NE. dispatch and AOBD were notified. We were observing a large burnout at the time and no other aircraft were over the fire. It was determined by AOBD that the intruder was a XXXX Air Medical helicopter flying from Tucson to Show Low AZ.

Flew out to start an air attack mission on the Little-Camas Fire. Approximately 20 minutes after arriving on scene the alternator out light illuminated for the left side alternator, and the battery voltage meter showed the battery was discharging. Pilot informed me we needed to return to Wenatchee and he tried recycling the alternator switch a couple times. As we started back towards the airport the alternator out light went out and the voltage meter showed the proper voltage. After landing pilot inspected the alternator and saw no issues. I called the regional maintenance inspector and explained the situation. He was good with us returning to the fire, but told me to keep an eye on it and let him know if the issue occurred again. We completed our shift over the fire with no issues and as the pilot reduced power descending into Wenatchee the alternator out light illuminated for the right side alternator. The voltage meter again showed the battery discharging. Once on the ground the pilot contacted his mechanic and on further inspection found each alternator had a broken wire. I called the regional maintenance inspector back to inform him of the situation.

After being dispatched to a fire, as aircraft was spooling-up, the marshaler noticed a small amount of fuel leaking out of the drain port under the aircraft and onto the concrete pad. Upon receiving the marshaler''s message about the fuel leak, the aircraft was shut down and everyone exited the aircraft. The leak was not evident until the aircraft was started up. Pilot investigated the cause of the leak and found that as pressure was put on the fuel pump hose during start up, the cock valve did not close and this caused some fuel to purge out into the drain port where the leak was noticed. The valve was correctly positioned and this fixed the fuel leak problem. The small amount of fuel lost was mopped up and dried off the aircraft, and the helicopter was restarted while the marshaler observed the fuel port to make sure no more fuel was leaking. No further problems were encountered.

During proficiency drop, oil cooler door trip light came on.  Aircraft landed without incident.  Mechanic checked and cleaned electrical connection.  Pilot performed engine test run - all systems normal.  No loss of availability.

While attempting to load a SEAT in the East pit a shut off valve broke and rendered the pit inoperable. Aircraft taxied to the West pit and loading procedures began. When loading SEATs in the West pit, hose end read-outs are inoperable. Confusion and lack of communication lead to the SEAT being overloaded.
During water dropping operation on the Cow Camp Fire the {#}1 Generator fail. Light illuminated and the aircraft return to the helibase. I contacted the Aviation Maint Inspector.

While performing a long line mission to personnel at a spike camp located near H-22 on the Farewell Fire, a daisy chained load was lost in transit. The load consisted of food, water and fuel at a weight of 1945 lob, and was in a standard, 2 net daisy chain configuration. The nets were made in adherence w/IHOG policy, and were not swinging or flying irregular according to cargo personnel and pilot accounts. 3 minutes after leaving the cargo loading area, the pilot felt the load release while flying up  a drainage toward the fire location north of the helibase. Upon returning to helibase, the pilot radioed to the pad, and asked for a visual inspection of the hook before it was placed on the ground at his pad. Visual inspection of the remote hook was done by myself and chief mechanic of the aircraft. All remote hook operations (checks) were performed, and found to be operational. The keeper gate also was found to be operational, which was thought to be the cause of a previously lost load during a previous mission w/a relief pilot (7/28/03). After a discussion w/pilot, mechanic and helibase manager, trouble shooting scenarios were discussed. The remote hook in question was tested and overhauled in March of 2003, and both lost loads ((7/28 and 8/2) had been several loads into the cargo missions. Both pilots (relief 7/28 and primary 8/2) reported that hand position on the cyclic did not correlate w/an inadvertent release of the loads. Upon further discussion of both scenarios, it was stated that both loads were lost in approx. the same location from cargo area. I also showed several scenarios where cross loading of smaller diameter rings will open the keeper gate of the remote hook. At the time of this writing, a call is in to MTDC specialist (XXX XXXXX) to the likelihood of this scenario, and the remote hook has been replaced as a corrective and/or preventative measure. Additional info will be provided at a later time.
The victor radio in N 51953 stopped transmitting on one of the victor freq's during the first fuel cycle.

Pilot of AAXXX noticed a commuter airline plane (Dash 8 ) at 10,000' msl over the Julian VOR. The Julian VOR is at the northern boundary of the Pines Incident. AAXXX was at 7,500' msl and briefing the relief AA310 who was at 8,000' msl when the pilot of the Dash 8 contacted So-Cal approach to proceed through the area. A TFR was in place by CDF through So-Cal for this incident, with a 12 NM radius from the town of Julian up to 11,000' msl. The smoke column was about 18,000'at the time over the fire.

Internal cargo operation from ABC to XYZ. The plan was to off-load cargo onto the back of a utility truck and drive over to cargo and build, and slingload the cargo to a sling site. The utility truck approached the aircraft from the front in full view of the pilot and proceeded under the rotor arc of the aircraft. Immediatly after entering the rotor arc of the aircraft the driver of the utility truck backed up and away from the rotor arc.

Helicopter xxx was inbound to land at the airport after completing a crew shuttle mission to the Fire. They landed at 2043, which is 16 minutes past pumpkin (night) time (2027 for July 13, 2006). The manager was unfamiliar with the area and relied on local personnel assessments for the time requirements.  The crew shuttle pickup location was modified to fit within the time frame available at the time to complete the mission (Sunset + 30 minutes) within limits.  The time limitation on night time was known by the crew on board, but they weren’t able to plan for conditions or contingencies.

A smokejumper experienced an ankle fracture as a result of his canopy hitting a snag on the edge of the jump spot, collapsing his parachute and falling 30 ft. to the ground.  A low pass was made over the jump spot, and hazards were identified prior to jumping.  The spot was about 3/4 of an acre across a very moderate slope with alternate spots available, and upslopes winds at ground level.  Wind drift was determined to be approximately 250 yards.  Single person sticks were utilized.  The injured jumper was second out and exited after ground conditions report from the first jumper cleared further jump operations.  The jumper was turning for final approach over the edge of the spot when his cnopy hit a snag.Follow-up: Final approach could have been made from the other side of the spot.  The importance of making final approach and set-up into the spot, over an area with least hazards, and consistent with the wind, was discussed with the jumper crew.

When returning from a recon flight the tail boom strobe was noticed to be working intermittently. Upon Landing the pilot was unable to get it to come on again. The Following morning the lights were checked and working but upon return from first recon flight the light was again intermittent so the aircraft was put out of service for repairs and returned to Tamiami.

August 2, 2003To Whom It May Concern:	This letter is written to document an event involving ground resources and an airtanker.	Recently, the Pagosa Ranger District endured a lightning bust, which caused multiple ignitions over a 3-4 day period.  Precipitation on the zone contributed to a low spread potential in the fine fuels, although there was, and still is, a high probability of ignition and spread component in the heavy fuels.   	As district personnel coordinated initial attack on multiple ignitions in the Ant Hill area, with the assistance of county and local fire district resources, air attack arrived on scene.  Air attack was dispatched by Durango Interagency Dispatch Center.  Radio traffic between Durango Dispatch, air attack, and ground personnel staffing fires made radio communication difficult.  At the time, District personnel, with the assistance of county and city resources, were initial attacking three fires, one of which was East Ant Hill, located on Forest Service land.  Neither district personnel nor ground resources ordered air attack, and district personnel only realized air attack was on scene after air attack arrived and indicated the fire location.	Initial attack personnel began working on the East Ant Hill fire and determined that a tree on fire had to be felled.  Coordination had been made with the local fire department, which was taking action on a nearby fire on private land.         As all of these events were occurring, and in addition to the district answering calls from the public and dispatching resources to other fires, we overheard air attack request a heavy air tanker.  No district or ground personnel, as we discovered later, had been contacted about the retardant drop.  The IC on the ground tried to call air attack on forest net and air-to-ground, with no success.  Fire staff in the office also tried to contact air attack on forest net, with no success.  We were trying to determine air attack’s intentions, all the while trying to coordinate efforts elsewhere.During this activity, the sawyer on the East Ant Hill fire had placed a face cut on his tree, and began his back cut.  The sawyer felled the tree and began bucking up the top portion of the tree, which was on fire.  The remainder of the IA squad was clear of the felling operation, but started back to assist the feller after the tree was on the ground.  These personnel saw the sawyer drop his saw on the ground and begin to run from the area.  He commented to me that “After dropping the tree, which was on a knoll surrounded by flatter ground, he looked up and saw, at eye level, an air tanker coming in on him so he ran out of the way”.  Apparently, the air tanker pilot saw the tree fall and was able to abort the drop, even though he was on low-level approach.  If the drop had occurred minutes/seconds earlier, the pilot would not have seen the sawyer under the tree.  With the tree already being cut, the retardant drop could have caused the tree to fall in a direction other than the intended lay, which could have caused serious injury, or worse, to the sawyer and/or other crewmembers.  Later, it was determined that part of the retardant drop was intended for a fire on private land, which consisted of a burning fence post.  The local fire department did not want retardant applied on private land.  The other target was the East Ant Hill fire.  However, the IC was not aware that retardant would be dropped on this fire. The following day, immediate action was taken by the Forest and District FMO.  A detailed, formal After Action Review is planned.  Issues that need to be addressed include;1.   The forest radio system easily becoming overloaded with traffic, and poor performance of the radio system overall, especially during inclement weather.2.	Personnel not directly working local fires saturating the forest net with conversation.3.	Air resources arriving on scene and executing actions without first contacting ground forces or district fire staff.4.	Multiple decision makers, both in the air and at Durango Dispatch Center, who are unaware of local weather, a fire’s resistance to control efforts, resources in the local area, or local coordination with private landowners and local fire departments.5.	Lack of adherence to LCES.  If communication is not established with ground resources, or at a minimum with district fire staff, all actions should cease.

On shut-down from the first fuel cycle of bucket work on the fire, I exited the left seat and visually checked the left side of the aircraft for any leaks. The co-pilot exited the right seat. Since the fire was still active and more bucket work was needed, I did not open any cowlings, as we frequently do when we shut down this model helicopter for refueling. I then went to the right side of the aircraft to monitor refueling. Some time during the refueling procedure, the co-pilot opened the left side engine cowl and left it open. After the refueling was complete, I checked the fuel cap, looked at the right side of the aircraft for any leaks and asked the co-pilot if he was ready to go. He indicated he was ready to go, so I walked around the nose of the aircraft and climbed in the left door to strap in the left seat for the start. The co-pilot strapped in the right seat. The left side lower engine cowl, when open, cannot be seen from the front door without stepping away from the aircraft a few steps, which I had not done. After a normal start, we lifted off and proceeded toward the fire, about 4 miles away, to resume bucket work. Firefighters on the ground called on the radio and informed us that there was an open cowl. Apparently, the co-pilot had forgotten about the open cowl until the radio call was received. I immediately landed, inspected the cowl to make sure it was not damaged, secured it and then uneventfully continued the mission. As pilot-in-command, I did not adhere to a vital safety precept that I usually use, which is: Always make one quick walk-around inspection around the whole helicopter prior to climbing in to start it. Deficient communication and inadequate Crew Resource Management (CRM) between the pilot and co-pilot also contributed to this incident.

During otherwise routine detection flight, pilot noticed that left engine temperature gage was showing engine to be cold or that gage was not working.  Engine seemed otherwise to be in normal operating order.  Landing was made at Alamogordo and during taxi to the ramp gage appeared to return to normal operating temperature.  Phone call was made to company mechanic who said that gage had possibly temporarily malfunctioned and that it would be checked during scheduled maintenance in 2 days.  Pilot mentioned that he possibly could also have not 'squared' the engine mixture properly causing the temporary problem.  Aircraft was left in service.

On August 21st while returning from a recon of the Williams Butte fire on a Type 3 helicopter assigned to the fire, we spotted a jump ship flying up valley over the Foster Helibase. Immediately following, we saw a parachute in the trees below and another chute in the air at about 11 o’clock ahead. The pilot took immediate action turning to our right to avoid any additional conflict with the jumpers. Our flight path between Foster Helibase and the Williams Butte Fire was in constant use by as many as 11 helicopters on that date. The Williams Butte Fire had 4 type 1’s, 4 type 2’s, and 3 type 3’s. No communications were made by Wenatchee Dispatch (CWICC), the Smokejumper Base (NCSB), on a victor frequency by the jumpship to Foster helibase regarding the NCSB mission. Corrective Action: When a team is managing an incident on a Forest or other jurisdiction, close communication must be maintained between that jurisdiction’s aviation resources and the incident. Local jurisdiction on Initial Attack activities in the flight path of IMT aviation activities must be closely monitored. Frequencies need to be shared and commo exercised to ensure all aircraft are aware of others in the area. Somkejumpers should be assured that no other aircraft are in the same airspace

While on a fire mission after flying approximately 1.3hrs and completing 12 tank drops, we started to hear a “buzzing” sound from the forward transmission. All indications inside the cockpit were indicating normal. As we were coming out of the dip, I looked at the hydraulic pressure gauges and noticed the {#}1 flight hydraulic pressure gauge was starting to decrease to approximately 2400PSI {3000 PSI- normal operating pressure}. We dumped our load of water and almost immediately after that the Master Caution Panel {#}1 Hyd Press caution light illuminated and the pressure on the gauge went to zero. We then turned on the {#}1 PTU and the pressure returned to 3000PSI on the gauge for about 3 seconds. The pressure then dropped to zero again. We notified Air Attack that we had a {#}1 flight hydraulics failure and that we would be returning to helibase. Was about a 7-minute flight back to helibase due to the fact that there were no other landing options in the area we were working in other than the trees. {#}2 Flight Hyd pressure was rock steady through flight back to service. Landed with no other problems.

During fixed tank operations on the fire the pilot {also an A&P carded mechanic} noticed an abnormal vibration while en route back to the dip-site. The pilot decided to land and shut down the aircraft in a nearby meadow to perform a visual inspection. He notified the manager immediately via cell phone after shutting down that he might have a problem. After performing the visual inspection, he did not notice anything obviously wrong. He started the aircraft and the vibration became noticeably worse, he shut down the aircraft and called me again. At that time the aircraft was placed out of service.

At about 1909 hrs., the helitanker aborted/jettisoned a load of water upon departure due to being heavy and crowd encroachment in the departure path. Rotor wash from this manuever was the probable cause of two injuries. One seven year old girl bumped her head on a table and one elderly woman sustained a laceration from a flying chair. Both declined immediate medical attention and the elderly woman received stitches (#13) from her health care provider. The area was declared clear prior to use and crowd control measures were in place. After this event, the pilot returned to the pond and took another load and departed without any further safety issues. The following statement was from the pilot: ''''On 06 August @ approximately 1800 during a dip of water I started take off. We had more water than I felt I needed during take off. Prior to leaving the pond & crossing over land, I elected to release the load for safety reasons due to a crowd in the departure flight path. With the water gone, I returned to the pond and took another load of water. Take off was completed with no further issues.'''' A current risk analysis concludes that all water point operations will cease except during fires when the facility is vacated.

Flight departed Prineville for lightning holdover detection. Radios tested out fine while on the ground and in the air. 15 minute check-insnormal until A/C switched to another mountain top (repeater) at which point contact was lost with dispatch. A/C could hear us(dispatch)but we could not hear the A/C. A lookout reported within seconds of our routine check-in that recon was replying. A/C switched to another frequency and commo was restored. We decided to return the A/C to Prineville to check out radio system. Examination of the radio (King EPH - Alpha-numeric and Sigtronics intercom system) revealed frequency and tone were properly programmed and intercom working fine. Radio techs notified of possible problem at repeater site.
During flight left engine turbine intake temperature light came on intermitently. Other engine instruments indicated normal operation. Returned to Cody airport to investigate problem.

While returning to Caliente from dropping two personnel on fire K115 aircraft experienced generator failure. Ship continued to Caliente and landed with no further incident. Ship is out of service until generator is replaced.

The air craft spooled up at 1615 to lift from the helibase for passenger transport on the fire. The pilot was going through his pre-flight checks when the transmission chip light indicator turned on. The Pilot spooled back down and shut off the aircraft and immediately notified the mechanic and helicopter manager.

Helitack personnel noticed a small amount of orange fluid coming from the passenger side weep hole the morning of the 30th. The pilot was informed of the orange fluid and said he would keep an eye on it. After two fuel cycles of bucket work helitack personnel and the pilot noticed the amount of orange fluid from the weep hole had increased. The pilot was notified and the decision was made to remove XXXX from service at 15:30, until a detailed inspection could be performed. Contact to the helicopter`s home unit HOS was made immediately following the decision to remove XXXX from service.

While conducting Air Attack operations on the incident observed an F-18 at low level transit north to south down the Owens Valley (approx 2700 MSL) thru the TFR which I believed was in place (5 mile radius to 12,000 MSL). No conflicts with aircraft operating on the incident occurred though another F-18 flew over Independence Airport where the helibase was located but out of the TFR. Advised Dispatch of intrusion, who checked with the South Zone GACC and Edwards AFB and for some reason the TFR was canceled by FAA Los Angeles. No other explanation was available on why this happened. Requested that TFR be implemented again . A similar cancellation occurred on the Source Fire Sierra N.F. in 2004 by FAA with no explanation offered.
Upon entering into the approach to landing stage of flight: during the gear down procedure the gear failed to extend.

On two separate occasions, with the same Birddog, I was put in a situationwhere I was not sure how conduct the aerial supervision over the fire.  Ihave worked with over 10 Birddogs, and have never had any thing but a positiveexperience, and a very positive feeling about working with them.  While working with Birddog 9 he conducted business much differently, I feltuncomfortable working with him, and did not feel the fire was the place toestablish how we would do business, so I deferred to him.   Safety wasnever a issue, but I feel that when there is not a established SOP, we could compromise safety.  I feel we need to establish a common operatingprocedure, and make sure everyone who may be involved with inter agencyoperations are familiar with these procedures.

On July 6, 202 at approximately 17:08 PM at Buchannan Field, in Concord, California, a firefighting UH-1H came in close proximity with a departing Cessna Caravan from runway 19R. The helicopter was returning to an incident after refueling at the Pacific States Aviation (PSA) ramp. The helicopter pilot announced the intentions of taxiing from the PSA ramp to the adjacent taxiway, "taxiway Alpha." After a pause on taxiway Alpha to look for traffic, a second broadcast was made stating the intentions of departing taxiway Alpha into the wind with a right turn to the west, crossing the departure end of the 19 runways. The helicopter executed a normal takeoff from taxiway Alpha and turned on course as stated. After completing the initial departure (southerly) then turning to the westbound course, inflight, the pilot checked for traffic from the 19 runways. Once observing the Cessna Caravan departing runway 19R, the helicopter pilot immediately lowered collective while turning away from the departing traffic. After completing a full turn and back on course to the westbound heading, the helicopter pilot resumed normal flight operations and departed the Buchannan Field airspace without further incident.

On 7/21/12 at approximately 11:50, while performing water dropping operations on the XXX fire Helitanker pilots reported a rotor blade brake warning light indication. Pilots notified air attack of the maintenance issue and returned to helibase without incident.

While on a Recon flight of the NF, the radios went haywire. Then there appeared to be the odor of electrical burning. At that time the pilot shut down the entire electrical system. We headed back to the airport and the pilot pumped the gear down. The pilot did not have the phone number for the tower so he called the Coordination Center to get the number. He then called the tower and got permission to land. The Aircraft was landed without incident. After letting the ATGS out the pilot taxied the plane to a maintenance facility on the field. I called the AMI and left messages on her office and cell phone concerning the incident. The Instructor Pilot also call another AMI to apprise him of the situation. The aircraft was taken out of availability at 1100.

After returning from fire to helibase for refuel and pilot swap, the fuel truck driver noticed that the exhaust stack was damaged. The aircraft was shutdown for further inspection. The mechanics discovered that not only was the exhaust port damaged, but the tail rotor had been damaged as well. They believe that part of the exhaust stack came off and made contact with the tail rotor, causing damage to all four blades.

During initial bucket drop while performing bucket support on burnout operations, the 270-gal FAST bucket released from H-XXX onto drop area. Ground contact indicated bucket was still full of water when released from aircraft. H-XXX immediately returned to helibase where mechanical systems were inspected. Mechanic determined mechanical systems to be functioning properly. Secondary bambi bucket was put in service and after several successful practice drops, it was determined acceptable and bucket support on burnout operations resumed

While lifting off from fire encountered unidentified single engine fixed wing aircraft at a low elevation. pilot was unable to raise aircraft on fire communication frequencies. The incident occurred inside a TFR for the Monture/Spread fire. Pilot was instructed to set down by the manager until situation could be cleared up. Pilot proceeded to Seeley Helibase until he could verify safe operation.
While performing routine maintenance at the end of shift, mechanics replaced M/M filters and notified the pilot in command.  The flight crew did not communicate the repair to the helicopter manager.

0900 hrs the aircraft landed, the helicopter manager intructed the trainee to approach the aircraft and talk with the pilot, myself and another crewmember were then instructed to board the aircraft and load our gear inside. We were then flown out to a remote site to retrieve a remote automated weather station. This aircraft was never shutdown for an inspection by either helicopter manager. The operation did however get completed without incident. It just concerns me that the helicopter manager is training a trainee in this fashion.

During bucket operations while on approach for a drop the pilot recieved a transmission pressure caution light with no other guage indications of a problem. The pilot elected to release the load of water and land the aircraft at the closest landing area. Once on the ground the pilot checked all digital readings with no anamolies. The contract mechainc was flown to the site by the vendor to perform a maintenance check of the system. Transmission was full of fluid and no signs of leakage. The aircraft computer system was downloaded and showed no faults in the system. The mechanic checked all the cannon plugs to the transmission and found one to be slightly loose and have a film on the contacts, it was determined that this may have cause the light to occur. The plug was cleaned and reinstalled on the aircraft. Aircraft had made a maintenance check flight with the pilot and mechanic with no problems. Due to no Sat or cell phone coverage the contract maintenance inspector was called upon arrival at S Rim Helibase, he cleared the aircraft for return to service.

While dropping water on a fire near Coalinga CA a CH47-D helicopter had a programming problem with a flight control component. The cyclic trim actuator had failed in the extended position requiring a return to base for repair. All appropriate emergency procedures were followed and the aircraft was successfully landed at it`s staging airport at Paso Robles CA.

On Aug. 20th the detailed Unit Aviation Officer (UAO)observed the helitack crew departing from the aircraft with rotors spooling without wearing either flight helmets or hard hats. The detailed UAO counseled the Assistant Crew Supervisor on the IHOG PPE requirements in chart 9-2 for an operating deck safety circle.The UAO attended the crew morning briefing the following day and the PPE requirements were covered by the Assistant Crew Supervisor. In the afternoon, the helicopter returned to the Unit Helibase for fuel. With the aircraft sitting on the ground and rotors spooling, the detailed UAO witnessed a helitack crewmember approach the aircraft to attend with the bucket and cargo without wearing a flight helmet or hard hat as well no nomex shirt.
19:00 hrs on July 7 2009, After Flying 4.4 hrs durring the shift the starters on the S64E failed to engage long enough for the engine to start. Failure of the electrical interlocks to stay engaged.

Upon being ordered for bucket work on division golf on the Bison fire the exclusive use helitack crew hooked the 240 gallon bucket to the belly of the aircraft. All the checks where done properly and the pilot was given the go ahead to begin a scheduled power check of the aircraft. During the power check the winds at the helibase were very gusty. When the power check was completed the pilot was given the go ahead to lift for his mission. Upon lifting the marshaller of the aircraft noticed the safety cable being pulled tight. The mashaller then notified the pilot to put the aircraft back down. When the crew came in to assess the problem, the crew noticed the powerhead of the bucket had cracked into two pieces, leaving the clevis still hooked to the belly of the aircraft and the rest of the powerhead hanging free form the safety cable. The electrical connection to the belly was not affected by the breaking/crack of the powerhead.

Near mid-air report: 7 August, time 1855, left downwind runway 35 at 1,000 feet AGL, at the Airport.  Aircraft involved were Lead “A” and Air Attack “B” both working fires near the airport.  Estimated near miss separation distance was 100 to 200feet.  Narrative: There were two Initial Attack fires in close proximity - Fire “AA”, less than 1 Nautical Mile {NM} east of the Airport using 2 SEATs, 1 T2 Helicopter, 2 State DC-7’s, with Aerial Support provided by Lead “A” and Air Attack “A”.  The second Fire “BB” was 7 NM northwest of the Airport using 1 SEAT, 3 Heavy Air-tankers with Aerial Support provided by Lead “B” and Air Attack “B”.  Each Fire Traffic Area {FTA} had its own distinct Air-Air VHF frequency assigned.  Additional “non-players” to the FTA and airport traffic pattern, at about the time of incident, were a medevac helicopter {Life-Link} enroute to the hospital and an unannounced Type1 Helicopter prepositioning to the airport.  The FTA pattern for Fire AA was exactly coincident with a left traffic pattern for runway 35 at the airport.  Both Leads A and B were periodically monitoring each respective VHF frequencies.  Lead B coordinated with Lead A on how to sequence Fire BB’s SEAT aircraft into the airport traffic pattern to Load retardant and Return to the fire.  Lead A directed a standard Left downwind entry to runway 35 at or below 4,300 feet: which was 500feet below the flight pattern Lead A was flying on Fire AA.  This was working well with the SEAT from Fire BB.  At approximately 1845 Air Attack B left Fire BB for a fuel stop at the airport. He flew 10 NW to the west of the airport and turned back east to set up for landing.  Air Attack B contacted Air Attack A to advise of intentions to enter Fire AA’s FTA and land at the airport.  Air Attack A acknowledged that Air Attack B was inbound for the airport to get fuel.  There was no acknowledgement from Air Attack B that he had received the transmission from Air Attack A.  At that time Air Attack A was sending the acknowledgement, Air Attack B was picking up the call from the inbound Life-Link on Unicom and was concerned for his safety inbound to Fire AA’s FTA.  Radio traffic was very heavy at the time. Air Attack A assumed that Air Attack B would switch to Unicom and that all aircraft were monitoring that frequency.  Lead A was unaware Air Attack B was inbound for fuel because he was monitoring both FTA VHF frequencies and not Unicom.  In hindsight, the communication loop was not completely closed between the two Air Attacks: however Air Attack B switched over to Unicom and announced intentions to join the airport traffic pattern.  At approximately 1855 both Lead A and Air Attack B unknowingly converged and saw each other in very close proximity on a Left downwind for runway 35 at 4,700-4,800 MSL.  It was the classic high wing below and low wing above pass over where both aircraft took evasive action. Both pilots in Lead A do not recall getting a separate TCAS advisory on Air Attack B.  There were many aircraft actively running on the ground at the airport resulting in the TCAS screen being flooded with overlapping symbology.  Air Attack B does recall receiving a separate TCAS alert and was immediately outside scanning.
Fox 5 TV news helicopter entered restricted area.  N143MD was unable to get tail number.  Radio contact was made with the news helicopter and they were instructed to leave the area without incident.
On take off at a hover, it sounded like one engine spooled down.  Pilot returned helicopter to the ground.  On further conversation with the pilot, one engine was not at full power setting.

Submitters Comments: While taking a sling load of water into a deep valley winds were multi-directional five to ten. Descending over the spot while lowering the load power demand was to high and pilot was unable to hold altitude. Five to fifteen feet above the ground the load was dropped. No injuries.

We left the Airtanker Base at 1046 to do a requested Recon mission over the Galeuros and the Chirichua Ranges. We finished the Galeuros and were at the Dos Cabezas Mountains enroute to the Chrichuas when the pilot alerted me that the right engine tachometer needle was falling. I looked at the gauges and was a slow descent to 0 rpms. The pilot checked all the other gauges and they were all in the green. I visually looked at the right engine which showed no outward abnormalities. The pilot said that the xxx airport was close and we agreed that we would head the aircraft to there. Once that decision was made I called Dispatch and informed them that we had a malfunction with one of the gauges but operations were good and we were proceeding to the airport. We landed and went to maintenance facilities. Once parked, I notified Dispatch we were safe on the ground, and then notified management, and the OAS Maintenance Inspector of the situation.

While repositioning from summit hospital {after medivac drop-off} to show low airport for fuel the pilot noted that the fuel pressure light came on right before landing. Upon landing at the airport the pilot shut-down the aircraft and checked the panel to make sure the switches were fully depressed. The warning light remained on with both fuel pump switches fully depressed in the on position.

During ongoing Fire Operations on the Limerick Fire local law enforcement spotted an individual remove a drone from their personal belongings and begin to operate the drone 1/4 to 1/2 mile East of I-80 in the vicinity of the Fire. Law Enforcement approached individual and made them aware of the dangers/violations of flying a drone near Fire operations and had them ground the drone and vacate area.

Airplane was conducting a Fire detection/reconnaissance mission over the Gila NF. Approximately one hour into the flight the Pilot began to notice issues with the left engine and inconsistent RPMs. Pilot was unable to properly adjust and maintain consistent RPMs for the left engine. Pilot began to trouble shoot issue in flight, with all gauges showing in normal ranges. The prop governor for the left engine was suspected as faulty. The mission was aborted and crew returned to Grant County Airport without incident. The cowling for the left engine was removed for inspection, and the linkage for the prop governor was found to be disconnected from the governor. All the parts were found in the bottom of the engine cowling. It appeared that the keeper pin was inserted into the linkage nut but was not bent over to secure the nut and the nut vibrated loose in flight. Both engines for this aircraft were recently rebuilt, and it is assumed that the company did not connect the linkage properly. There was no obvious mechanical failure of any of the linkage parts upon inspection.

Pilots heard a noise in the aft rotor system and a vibration upon returning to helibase, the aircraft was shut down while it was inspected by the mechanics, after inspection the mechanics advised the manager that the aircraft was out of service. There was a scheduled maintance to change the aft transmission the next day. The aircraft was made unavailable for the remainder of the afternoon.

Bird strike on engine number 1 noticed by crew chief on walk-around and discontinued reload for fire. Operations shut down. Pilots did not notice any engine concerns. Do not know the altitude, coordinates of strike or time it happened.

Helitanker xxx, N116AZ departed helibase at 1000 to the yyyy fire and Deadman Creek. Mission was water drops. A/C landed back at helibase at 1130 to hot fuel and report to the ZZZ Complex.  The mechanic noticed the right side of the mid-sliding door window was missing. The pilots did not know the window was missing. It is unknown when the window became missing during the water drop mission. A/C shut down for 10 minutes to check aircraft, no damage reported. The aircraft is able to fly without the window. A/C usually takes the same window out during the summer for airflow. At 1145 A/C departed helibase enroute to the zzzz Complex fire.

During takeoff Tanker started trailing retardant off the top of the tank. Tanker took off on 17L to the south and the retardant started streaming off the top of the tank at the end of 17L runway. I notified Tanker that retardant was leaking out of the top of the tank. The leaking of retardant continued as the plane flew out of site towards the North Western part of the city.  The air crew and mechanics both said it was because the floats stuck on the tanks allowing retardant to come out the top of the tanks. I noted that this incident occurred on the 16th. I thought I had submitted a safecom the next day but I did not get it submitted. therefor I can not remember if it was the 16th or 17th when this incident occurred. I did notify both the FAO and RASM when the incident occurred.

Enroute to division L from 25 mile helibase with a cargo load of gasoline, boxed batteries, drip torches w/oil the load accidentally cross shifted and came UNDONE. After review possible cause is the size of the ring on the swivel.

During routine snorkeling operations, pilot noted increasing ``pylon rock`` with heavier loads of water. Pilot suspected transmission / pylon damper and brought to the attention of the maintenance staff.

On the afternoon of August 12th, Helicopter XXX made a fuel stop at BNO while enroute to ONO in support of fire operations near Juntura, OR. During the stop, the pilot noticed a difficulty in switching the {#}1 battery bus switch to the on position. After pre-flight inspection on August 13th, the mechanic identified that the {#}1 battery bus switch had seized in the off position and determined that it was a mechanical switch failure and not an electrical failure.

Helicopter was being moved to Ohiopyle State Park in western Pennsylvania. The pilot arrived with the Bambi bucket slung beneath the helicopter. He was to demonstrate an operational drop, however; he filled the bucket upon arrival with no radio communication with PA Bureau of Forestry personnel. After filling the bucket, the aircraft circled the heliport and attempted a drop. The bucket departed the helicopter (filled with water) and landed on the asphalt heliport approximately 50-60 feet from ground personnel. The pilot then landed the aircraft to inspect the destroyed bucket and helicopter''s switches.

During a HLCO mission on the Hog Incident the helicopter encountered a radio communications problem from their TDFM 136 radio. This radio had a previous communication problem the day prior and a SAFECOM was filed. AMU was notified.

On July 29, at approximately 1545, the Militry Blackhawk was working a hot area in an island on DIV FF. He had made several drops and was continuously coming in too low. I informed the pilot multiple times that he needed to gain 100 to 150 feet of elevation. I changed my location on the ground but he was still working the same spot. As he lined up for the drop he came in low again and he bucket struck a tree. He knock out the top 30 feet of the tree. I then notified the pilot he had struck the tree. When he returned there was still a section of the tree hanging from the bucket. As he made his drop that section of tree fell out with the drop. He did land in a meadow to check the bucket for damage. There was no damage to the bucket or helicopter. Contributing factor: There is a lot of radio chatter on the air to ground channel. Several helicopters are working within same area talking to different ground contacts.

While performing pre-flight inspection on the morning of June 23, the pilot discovered that the oil bypass indicator was tripped. The mechanic inspected and cleaned the oil filter and the helicopter was removed from service. A run-up was then performed and the bypass indicater tripped again. The mechanic replaced the entire filter base, filter element and bypass indicator with manufacture modification. The helicopter then performed a satisfactory run up and ops check. Regional mechanic was contacted and log sheet was faxed, the helicopter was returned to service on 6/24/05.

On Sunday August 2, at approximately 10:30 hours I was doing bucket operations on the North Rim of the Grand Canyon (AZ) on about the 13th or 14th dip from the water source (Pumpkin) bringing the load out the IDDS (Integrated Instrument Display System) gave an indication the left engine was losing power. I dumped the water, did a 180 degree turn for the dip site, released the bucket and line from about 10 feet and made an uneventful landing.

Aircraft was returned to service after repair/replacement of a hydraulic line that ruptured in the baggage compartment.  During an Air Attack mission another failure in the hydraulic system occurred so we returned to the airport.  It was discovered this failure was on a line in the left wheel well.  It was replaced with rigid tubing consistent with what was removed, and returned to service 9/11.  We were dispatched to a fire on 9/11/14 and 1.2 hours into the flight another hydraulic failure occurred: so we returned to the airport. After inspection it was discover the failure was in the same line that had been replaced.

At 1646 local time, two Panavia Tornado fighter jets passed through the Bear Fire TFR at low level (<500 feet AGL) at a high rate of speed (>250 knots estimated) travelling west to east. The two jets were painted in a dark gray paint scheme much darker than the USAF gray paint. Air attack was just entering the area. Ground personnel including the AOBD and team ATGS witnessed the intrusion from Bear ICP which was overflown by the trailing jet in the pair. The Bear Fire was covered at the time by NOTAM Number : FDC 6/0867 .

Original Text:This is in regards to a fan for for this aircraft that has gotten bad in recent flights. It sounds like the bearings in the fan are going out and makes really bad noise when on. This fan is for the cooling the transmission fluid.  I`m told from the pilot, that if he were to hover, the temp is going to spike causing severe damage to the engine. This noise seems to have gotten really bad, suddenly, from the day before, therefore, we agreed to put the aircraft un-available.

While flying air attack over the incident, Pozo Helibase inquired whether I knew Helicopter XXX was inbound and landing at the helibase. I looked over  and saw the aircraft approaching the helibase.  Attempted to call the aircraft on Air Tactics 4 151.280  and 123.075 helicopter air to air and did not get a response. Called on air guard 168.625 while directly over the aircraft twice with no response.  Advised the helibase to find out why the aircraft did not make contact at 12 miles and continued to enter the incident having not made contact at the 7 mile point where aircraft are not supposed to enter without clearance from the air attack. Helibase advised that the frequencies given to the aircraft by the forest dispatch center where not the same as those being used over the incident.  In addition, the manager advised the helibase that he was not aware that there was an air attack over the incident. Discussed the frequency issue with the forest dispatch center and confirmed that the frequencies provided by the center to Helicopter XXX were not the same as being used for aircraft for the last two operational periods. Advised Forest FAO of incident and confirmed that the Helicopter Managers assigned to that module were aware of the newly adopted contact procedures for entering airspace.While the activity over the incident at that time was minimal had the aircraft entered the airspace the preceeding day may have created conflicts  with fixed wing operations due to the base being close to the incident. It is not unusual to have the wrong frequencies when entering an incident airspace, but my main concern here was the aircraft failed to answer me on air guard twice.

The following statement is one of four statements received regarding this incident:On Wednesday evening at approximately 2010 an order for all airtankers and a leadplane to launch immediately for the Hungary Fire, which was only 5-7 miles from Reno-Stead Airport.  I was the last airtanker to depart the airport due to refueling.  I could tell from the radio traffic that the situation was confused.  I flew to the inactive side of the fire to hold.  I orbited on the east side until I thought I was nearing my turn to drop.  I proceeded to the west side of the fire and approached the area where the other airtankers were working.  After a short time I decided to exit the area once again due to the difficulity in distinquishing aircraft from all the emergency vehicles on the ground with their beacons on and rotating.  At this point the leadplane called for the tanker to the south to come in for a drop.  As I was south and going south I thought it meant it was my turn.  I started following the leadplane only to look up and see another tanker closing rapidly with me.  It was apparent it was his turn not mine.  I immediately broke hard right to avoid a mid-air collision.  This forced me into rising terrain.  I should have dumped my load and proceeded to the airport to help clear the conjection over the fire.  Instead I saved the load and eventually did drop before returning to Stead.  There were numerous factors that lead to an ever increasingly dangerous scenario.  They were increasing darkness, smoke, the close proximity of the fire to the airport, the large number of aircraft on the fire, the insufficient altitude of the air attack aircraft, the lack of an understood tanker sequence, no overall aircraft control, no holding instructions with assigned altitudes, failure of all participants to call off the operation, and a general panic situation exerting undue influence to act.

On 11 June, 2005, Helicopoter was dispatched to a smoke report on the eastern side of the Forest. Upon departure to the fire, flight following was established through Forest Dispatch via radio and AFF. On arrival at the fire I attempted to contact dispatch through the local repeater. Communication was difficult throughout the fire and attempts were made several times on the other local repeaters. In this area two repeaters were in line of sight from the fire and we could tell we were keying the repeaters. While the lookout, ground forces and chase trucks could hear the helicopter clearly, dispatch could not. The pilot and I checked our radio''s twice to make sure we had the proper tones and frequencies programmed and found no fault with the Helicopter. On the ground the IC also had difficulty establishing clear radio contact with dispatch. Finally I called dispatch on my cell phone from the inside of the helicopter and gave them a size up and other information on the fire. This has been a continuing problem with dispatch this season. Our pilot has also voiced his concerns with the communications system. It can sometimes take a few calls to dispatch before getting a response. In the event of an emergency, such as a mayday call, dispatch may not hear or respond in a timely manner.

After the morning shift on 8/18/03, pilot and ATGS observed oil dripping from left engine cowling and overflow tube.  After brief inspection of oil lines, pilot contacted company mechanic who recommended to plug drain line to confirm location of leak.  Pilot completed maintenance work to plug over flow line.  Pilot completed check flight in aircraft morning of 8/19/03, experiencing significant temperature rise in oil temps, and powersurge on left engine.  On landing pilot noted loss of oil from front portion of oil pan on left engine.  Company recommended to ground aircraft.  Company mechanic obtained seal and fuel pump shaft assembly and replaced on 8/21/03.  Run-up on aircraft resulted in no oil leakage but again a significant oil temperature rise on left engine.  Further inspection of oil showed some potential metal filings of material, and company has removed aircraft from service until engine removal and inspection confirm problem.  Note:  Left engine on this aircraft has less than 100 hours following significant maintenance and refurbishment.

While snorkeling water the pilot turned on the windshield wipers to remove the rotor wash/spray from the windshield. The motor fried itself producing smoke in the cockpit. There was a field adjacent to the dip site and the pilot made a precautionary landing there. The pilot assessed the situation, called the crew chief describing his findings and disconnected the wiper motor. No other aircraft systems were affected. After a thorough inspection of all wiring near the motor, the pilot and crew chief decided to fly the aircraft back to the HB.

After completion of retardant drop and on climb out, the pilot heard a loud bang from engine #1.  The TIT and horsepower fluctuated and crew started the engine shut-down procedure and returned to the tanker base.  After further inspection, pilot suspects potential trubine or compressor problems.  The aircraft was approved for 3 engine ferry back to home base for further inspection and maintenance repair.
T-xxx experienced a loss of #1 engine while returning back to Jeffco for a reload.  After successfuly dropping on the fire the crew of T-xxx made an emergency landing in Laramie, WY.

Fueler finished fueling one plane and then was givin hand signal by pilot of 1st plane to turn and cross ramp..second plane already on ramp was in fuelers blindspot but was watching and waited on ramp then signaled for fueler to pass.. no injuries or damage incident reported7/22/13 BLM Aviation Safety: Fuel truck pulled in front of 2nd tanker during taxi, 2nd tanker was aware of the fuel truck and watching it, the tanker  stopped ahead of time and let the fuel truck pass.

On start up, engine {#}1, ops normal, engine {#}2 fails to spin prop. Two additional attempts made. Suspect starter/ generator malfunction. Upon inspection, a shear to pinion gear shaft is found. Repair center replaces starter/ generator. All notifications made. Vendor A&P places A/C in return to service status. R5 AMI returns A/C to contract availability.

NXXXXX was assisting with a crew shuttle on the Gratton Fire of the Cooney Ridge Complex.  The mission was scheduled for 1800 on 9/03/03, and the objective was to fly a replacement Type 1 (Hotshot) crew to H1 and retrieve the intimed-outin Type 1 crew.  One helitack member (myself), was sent with the first load to H1 to assist two helitack members from Elliot Helibase who were already staffing the helispot.  The manager felt it was important to have a crew member familiar with the SOP for the helicopter to conduct briefings and ensure safe loading of personnel.  Upon arriving at H1, the crews were positioned on the UPHILL side of the ship.  Helitack on scene approached the helicopter from the UPHILL side to offload.  The pilot was not comfortable with the approach and signaled to wave-off the approaching people, but with no success.  The pilot then asked that I offload and take charge of the people to ensure safe loading was conducted from the downhill side at the front of the helicopter.  When making contact with the first load to leave H1, I briefed them on the particulars of the helicopter and loaded them safely.  I was then met with conflict by one helitack member about changing the approach.  While discussing procedure with the Hotshot Superintendant of the departing crew, he relayed to me that no pre-flight briefing had taken place (they had NOT been briefed prior to the mission).  The remaining people were briefed and all were loaded on the safe, downhill, front side of the helicopter.

Fire dispatch was notified that a SEAT needed to be moved from the ramp of a tanker base due to reloading large air tankers in support of an initial attack fire. Dispatch was asked if the SEAT at the tanker base could be added in the rotation. Dispatch stated they would need to ask and receive approval from air attack. Dispatch relayed to air attack the SEAT was available. Air attack informed dispatch there was no need for an additional SEAT. The information was relayed back to the requesting party. Dispatch relayed the information to the duty officer and aviation manager. Both were in agreement with dispatch that without a request from the incident commander or air attack the SEAT cannot be utilized without being ordered. Dispatch suggested relocating the SEAT to another base and passed the information on the adjacent dispatch center. The SEAT departed the tanker base minutes later and flew directly to the fire without proper dispatch procedure being followed.
Pilot observed that the prop RPM, on both engines, at idle, was below the placarded minimum RPM. He called Forest Service maintenance inspector and the contractor.

Wildcat I.C. requested 1 helicopter for bucket work, PIDC dispatched H-xxxx from the Medano incident. Per local agreement between PSICC and U.S.Army Fort Carson, PIDC called the number listed to see if the LZ in the agreement were active. PIDC was unable to get a direct answer to the question if LZ {{{{{#}}}}}11 Badger Flats was active. We were told to call different numbers then that listed in the agreement. We were finely told at 1542 that the LZ was not active. This has been a on going issue with dealing with this agreement. When PIDC calls we end up having to call mulitple numbers and talk to people that advise they have no idea what we are talking about.

After landing at Helibase for fuel, oil was observed leaking under the helicopter. Notification was made to the pilot and the aircraft was shut down. The Mechanic and Pilot began troubleshooting and found that a braided hydraulic line had rubbed against the transmission oil filter line causing a small hole in the transmission oil filter line.

After completing a bucket cycle using a long-line the pilot in formed me his bucket had hit up against a tree. I asked the pilot if we needed to do anything to mitigate it from happening again. The pilot informed me that it was just a mistake. It happened again on the next cycle, the pilot returned and after a discussion we elected to belly hook the bucket. After that there were no reports of the event happening again. There was no damage to the bucket.

During the Camp Creek Fire, on 8/03/04 at 1545, A POGO MINE official came up to the helicopter to ask for assistance on a medical emergency. The Official ask if the Lama NXXXXX could transport a EMT 3 plus gear to the scene of the accident along the Pogo road, 1/2 mile west of the Shaw Creek Bridge. The Manager ask the fire IC if the helicopter could assist. The IC said okay. The EMT 3 did not wear proper PPE for the flight. He did have a hard hat, ear protection, glasses and leather boots. He was not wearing a Nomex shirt or pants. The EMT 3 boarded the patient and ask if the helicopter could transport the patient and the EMT 3 to the local clinic. The pilot and the helicopter manager removed the front seat to place the back boarded patient into the helicopter. The helicopter seat was left at the scene. A HECM from Shaw creek helispot drove a truck to the accident site and retrieved the seat. The patient , EMT 3, and the helicopter manager were flown to the Delta helibase. The Ambulance meet the helicopter to continue the transport the patient and the EMT 3 to the clinic. The mechanic, manager and pilot flew to Shaw Creek helispot. The mechanic installed and approved the front seat. The helicopter resumed normal operations.

The Pilot and I were at 7500 ft. directly over the Boulevard Fire No. 271.  We were flying right-hand turns.  At 1135 hrs, a Meyer 200 fixed wing aircraft passed directly over the top of us, flying west to east in a straight line, at approximately 8500 ft.  We could not get an identity number for the aircraft.  We tried to contact the aircraft on 122.9AM, we received no response.  We continued our Air Attack mission. The intrusion was not a critical safety factor.  Our Air Attack platform was the only aircraft in the area.  It was, however, a violation of the Temporary Flight Restriction which had been in place the afternoon of the day before (09/01/01).  The T.F.R. was established as a 3 mile radius at, and below, 9000 ft MSL.  My Pilot and I agreed the Meyer aircraft was definitely below 9000 ft MSL.

The helicopter flew from Prineville Airport to the Crescent Airstrip with two helitack on board. The crew landed at Crescent Airstrip and hooked up the bucket. The pilot took off from the airstrip, and did a radio check with the crewmembers on the ground. The crewmembers heard the radio check and responded. The pilot did not hear a response. He looked down at the FM radio and the display was blank. The pilot was unable to transmit or receive on FM. He returned to the airstrip. The pilot could not fix the problem with the FM radio.

At 1434 air attack was off the ground and en route to the fire. When they called in to let dispatch know they were en route, their radio transmission was unreadable on a local repeater. I let them know this and asked them to try a different repeater. They tried a different repeater and they were still unreadable. They tried transmitting off national and were still unreadable. They could hear us but we could not understand them. We told them that we had no radio communications with them and asked them to turn around and head back to the airport.

Helicopter lifted off from Willow Creek Helibase enroute to the Ahorn fire for bucket work. While taking off the marshler noticed a fluid coming from the belly of the helicopter. The pilot was immediately notified. Coincidently the helicopter had just been washed prior to the mission in which a water tender was used to wash and rinse the entire helicopter. The pilot said it was probably just water coming off the deck, but he would watch it. About a minute later the pilot called back that it had not stopped and he was returning to helibase. The helitack crew was notified and two fire extinguishers waited the return of the helicopter along with the water tender. The helicopter landed without incident. If was found by the mechanic a pepcock for the external fuel filter had stuck open.

While doing bucket work on a small fire, the pilot felt an abnormal jerk after releasing the bucket of water on a target. He made a call to the manager on the fire and said that he had felt something strange when he released the water but that the bucket was still in place. The decision was to land the helicopter and inspect the bucket. Upon inspection it was confirmed that the primary release wire on the Bambi Bucket (model 1214 / 144 gallon) had sheered. The bucket was replaced with the secondary Bambi bucket carried on the fuel truck and the mission continued. Later upon further inspection of the bucket it was determined that the cable had gotten pinched between the pulley and the bracket holding the pulley. This did not allow for the control head to retract the cable, thus exerting intense force on the cable and the cable broke. The bucket was relatively new with only a couple seasons of use. No one was injured, and the last load of water carried by the bucket released from the bucket prior to the cable breaking (thus there was not an unexpected release of water from the bucket).

While transporting four 55 gallon blivits to an incident pilot was switching frequencies on radio and brushed the release switch to the remote hook and released the load. The 4 blivits landed in a field and were destroyed.

During cargo letdown operations on intail attack rappel fire, a saw pack came out of the tuna net during cargo letdown.
