The pack fell out of the tuna net at the point the tuna net was released from the belly hook of the aircraft, the saw pack came out of the tuna net and fell approximately 150 feet.  Two sigg bottles broke on impact with ground and the pack rolled another 50 feet down the slope.  Spotter informed the pilot and both rappellers of the incident.  The decision was made by all onboard to proceed with the rappel.  The remaing portion of the rappel operations was completed with out error.As the aircraft lifted from helibase, spotter noticed the saw pack near the opening of the net.  Spotter informed pilot and both agreed that the pack would fly alright to the fire.  It was relized that the jolt from being released from the Belly hook is what made the pack come out.In the future spotter realized that he would set the load back down and secure the cargo better.
1620 Tanker returned to Air Tanker Base after the second retardant drop on the Fire. Upon entry to the ramp, aircrew became aware of a hydraulic leak. Mechanic discovered a crack in the varicam line.

On the afternoon of August 19th we were requested to Div A on the Lake Fire to support El Toro slowing down some fire pushing towards their dozer line.  When we arrived on scene Air Attack was over head and briefed us that the Scoopers X and Y were also working in the same area and that H-XXX a CH-47 would be joining us.  He briefed us about the Scoopers flight path, their check points, as well as the dip site (Castaic Lake) and the check point (Wires Check) we would be using.  We had flown in Div A several times and were familiar with the routes and checkpoints.  After several drops working with the Scoopers and helicopter, air attack announced that he would be departing and that it would be 10-15 minutes before the replacement air attack got on station.  The outgoing air attack checked with the scoopers and both helicopters working in Div A about their comfort level working together without air attack overhead.  All were ok with it and continued operating.  The outgoing air attack had mentioned he had an inbound tanker but the tanker was instructed to hold until the new air attack got into place and the new air attack would direct the tanker.  
We made a couple drops and we had noticed the tanker holding above the fire.  Inbound to the drop when we announced “Wires Check” I noticed the tankers holding pattern had shifted slightly.  We continued inbound and tried to raise air attack.  We got no response from air attack and started to turn out from the area checking the tankers flight path.  The Tanker began turning in our direction and we noticed on our ADS-B traffic display that the tanker was descending and coming in over the top of us.  We continued our altered flight path and watched the tanker continue onto the drop in the same vicinity that we had been dropping water.  A few moments later being downwind of the flight path we encountered the wake turbulence from the tanker.  We again tried to reach air attack but weren’t able to make contact.  
Checking that the area was clear we continued to the drop and returned to the dip site.  We notified the scoopers and H-XXX to be on the look out and that we had a tanker drop nearby that was unannounced.  After getting another bucket and checking in at the “Wire Check” we were finally able to reach air attack and he briefed us that he had another tanker on the drop and to hold.
We briefed the air attack that the previous tanker was brought in without our knowledge and we needed positive communication if tankers were going to be working in the same area.  He responded that we had stepped on him when he made the call.
The new air attack had mentioned several times over the radio that this was his first time on the fire, he did not get a good transition, and had got a late dispatch to the incident.  
The only instruction we got from air attack was to stay at our below 5000 ft.  
Helicopters operate low to the ground especially in the dip sites and can’t always receive radio transmissions in the low canyon dip sites.  Air Attack may have made a call for us to hold at the Wires Check but we didn’t receive it.  Hold instructions need to be confirmed by the aircraft required to hold.
A flock of Cathartes Auras (Turkey Vultures) were on the approach end of the runway and flew up as I landed.  The left main hit and killed one of the birds.
On initial start up the Fadec degrade light came on. Proceeded with a normal shut down. Then began to problem solve the error.

Pilot exceeded the 8 hour flight time limit by 9 minutes. Based on recent trips to and from the reload base{Rawlins}and the Roach Fire, the PIC calculated that he had 20-30 minutes to spare in making his last trip to/from the fire. While on the fire, a severe thunderstorm developed between the fire and the reload base. Enroute back the PIC informed dispatch of his decision to divert and navigate around the thunderstorm to avoid the adverse weather. On reaching the reload base, a solo student pilot was doing take off and landings in a piper tomahawk. The student was established in the air traffic pattern and entered a large, slow and extended traffic pattern. The SEAT pilot then entered the traffic pattern behind the student when there was sufficient spacing. The student pilot landed, and stopped at the end of the runway, after a short delay the student announced he would back taxi down the runway to the ramp. The SEAT pilot extended his downwind and base to adjust for the students back taxi. Once clear the SEAT pilot landed without further delays.

At 1110, rotor ____ was working a MOB fire (urban interface with homes, structural engines in close proximity and mutiple access points). The rotor was directed to make drops adjacent to homes along a street and at low altitude due to wind and visibility problems. Rotor was told to extend previous drop and there two engines in vicinity and other rotor told pilot that the drop zone was clear. Ground personnel also were directing the drops. The rotor came out of the dip site in a valley up over a ridge and the drop zone was on a flat just a few hundred feet from edge. Pilot came into zone and was preparing to drop when a different vehicle emerged from the smoke directly into his path. The pilot tried to gain altitude and veer away but felt a lurch as he released his water. He circled back and saw the water behind the truck and other rotor said he thought the bucket was ripped. He returned to helibase and found the bucket damaged. The fire truck had been hit in the windshield and it shattered the glass but no injuries had occured and the crew persons were wearing goggles. The incident was recorded on video phone.

Pushing sunset at the end of the day we received fuel and retardant. The intention was to drop one more load on the fire and recover in Kxxx where we had mechanics, cars, hotels,etc. After starting engines, dispatch called us and put us on hold. We were now in a new base late in the evening at the last minute with no logistics set up. Not out of the ordinary. This SAFECOM is to say thank you and how appreciative we are as a crew to the xx tanker base in helping us with rooms and transportation to and from the hotel. Anymore the logistics has become one of the toughest parts of this job. This little bit of help goes a long way. Thank you!

Helicopter was completing a recon of a prescribe burn from the previous day when the pilot noticed a transmission chip light. Pilot notified the manager and dispatch of the problem and returned to the Mount Ida airport.

While on recon mission of Broad Fire with operations sec. to look for new spike camp location; the engine chip light went on. Pilot immediately aborted mission and returned to helibase without further incident. Inspection of plug found a metal sliver. There was also some non-metallic flakes found in the oil filter. Mechanic suspects #2 bearing may be starting to fail and ship is removed from service at 1000 hrs.

Over the Fire, on two separate occasions, we received a TCAS visual and audio traffic alert for an aircraft at our altitude or 100 ft. lower, in our exact location. There should not have been any other aircraft in that location at that altitude. We were operating on the southeast corner of the fire, at approximately 6000ft MSL. There were helicopters 1.5 miles to our west at a much lower altitude. We did not observe any aircraft.  I observed a small dark object pass under our aircraft very quickly, but I was unable to make a positive identification of the object. There were many large birds over the fire during this mission. We were also over the black, and the object did not show up well enough for positive identification.  I believe this object could have been a transponder-equipped UAS, but I cannot confirm that. We were not informed of any fire-operated UAS aircraft operations by the team.
After dropping retardant on incident pilot noticed oil temp gauge showing extremely high temp. In order not to take any chances, he decided to land at nearest air strip.

Upon release from the EMMA FIRE, flight following information was not relayed appropriately to the Southwest Coordination Center in regards to NXXXXX. The primary breakdown occurred during the transfer of information between the two dispatch centers: Grand Canyon N.P. Firebase and Williams Dispatch Office - Northern Arizona Zone.

When I was dispatched from Pubelo to Grand Junction to a fire 8 miles from GJT, I called Pubelo Dispatch to advise them of my ETE/ETA. I advised my ETE and told dispatch I would use FAA flight following. The response from dispatch was that I was not allowed to flight follow with the FAA, I was to flight follow with dispatch. Dispatch does not have radar nor trained traffic controllers, nor in this case a knowledge of flight following prescribed in FS policy. The failure of dispatchers to realize that other aircraft are operating within the airspace and the enhanced safety provided by using the FAA's facilities, is amazing. Using the FAA only helps our ability to see other aircraft and provides us with current weather, and of course an opportunity to be vectored around hazards and other air traffic that are not fire related.To create pressure or demand that we not use the FAA option, only impares our ability to accomplish the mission safely.

While enroute to the Murphy fire, the number one engine was shut down and feathered in flight due to the inability to govern engine RPM with either the master lever or toggle swith. Tanker notified Show Low Dispatch and Winlsow ATB they needed to turn around and return to INW. The retardant load was jettisoned at high altitude in the designated area and the aircraft landed safely.
While overhead of the River Fire in the Paso Robles area myself and the pilot spotted a UAS flying around the fire area at approximately 200-400 ft. AGL.

On 8/21/20018 at approximately 14:00 during a routine fuel transfer, a fuel truck was over filled and spilled approximately 15 gallons of Jet A fuel onto the roadway adjacent to the Helibase property on the Boyd’s Fire Incident. The fuel truck driver using a measuring stick and fuel logs as a guide assumed that the fuel truck could receive 1800 gallons of fuel and failed to visually verify that the amount of fuel entering the tank was within the tank’s capacity. As a result, the 2500-gallon capacity of the fuel truck was exceeded resulting in an overflow of fuel out the top port of the fuel tank. The fuel truck driver immediately reversed flow on the pump and placed absorbent towels on the spill {area 10ft x 15ft}, cleaning as much material as possible off the gravel surface of the roadway. All contaminated material was collected by the fuel tender, placed in a hazmat container and brought back to the fueling facility for disposal. The fuel truck driver then returned to duty without notifying the helicopter manager or Helibase Manager {HEB2}. At 18:00 the land owner notified the Air Support Group Supervisor {ASGS} that there was a large fuel spill on the property and requested that no more fuel be spilled on the property. The ASGS immediately notified the HEB2 and HMGB who then met with the fuel driver and pilot to gather information and inspect the spill site {Note: The AOBD was notified at this time}. The ASGS and AOBD then inspected the spill site and relayed back to the HEB2 and HMGB their expectations on how to mitigate any further issues with fuel transfers.

Pilot ran the helicopter up this morning, which was not normal operation and the Mechanic told us at 735 that the helicopter was grounded because of a kinked hydraulic line that runs to the reservoir. The mechanic told us that he had been keeping an eye on it for a few days and did not say anything about it to us.The relief pilot also knew and did not tell the regular pilot when he came back yesterday. Pilot said he was not told about it until last night when mechanic informed him. The maintenance inspector was called and told about the hydaulic line and the mechanic not telling us about it, since we have been flying and doing prescribe burns (PSDO operations) and we should have been informed of the mechanical problem.
During start up to respond the the Fire the Intermediate Gear Box chip light illuminated. Pilots shut down the aircraft.
While copter NXXX was warming up for a recon flight at Rancho Helibase, a transmission chip light came on and the pilot shut down prior to lifting off.

Copter xxx was dispatched to the Little Fire, North of the Iron Complex for insertion of Rappellers. After locating the fire and sizing it up, Copter xxx''s C-box temp light illuminated on the Master Caution panel. Although the light was illuminated, the gauge showed 2 degrees below red line, but 3 degrees above normal. The rappel mission was subsequently ''aborted'' and Copter xxx returned to Helibase.

On July 20th at approximately 0916 air attack departed Redmond Tanker base to respond to Incident #0521 with pilot, air attack trainee and air attack instructor on board. Immediately after take-off, pilot in command informed air attack that we have a mechanical problem and we are returning to Redmond. After landing pilot informed air attack that the fuel flow gauge was inoperable and that he will take the plane to the local A&P mechanic to inspect faulty gauge.

On approach to Sno-Park Helispot the low Engine Oil Pressure warning light began to flicker and the oil pressure gauge began to fluctuate. The pilot promptly and safely landed the helicopter. The mechanic came over and observed the issue prior to shutting down the helicopter. On 7/31/18 while performing a recon flight a similar issue happened. The pilot found that as she lowered power the light would flicker and the pressure again would fluctuate. She immediately returned to helibase to have the issue checked out. In both cases there were no secondary indications of a problem {e.g. no rise in temperature, change in noise level, or vibration

PILOT WAS ON A BUCKETING OPERATION. MASTER CAUTION AND HYDRAULIC WARNING LITES ILLUMINATED. #2 HYDRAULIC PRESSURE GUAGE READ ZERO, SO PILOT TURNED OFF THE #2 HYDRAULIC SYSTEM AND RETURNED TO HELIBASE. MECHANIC FOUND A TINY PIN-HOLE IN THE LINE LEADING TO THE #2 HYDRAULIC NOISE DAMPER. PIN-HOLE WAS CAUSED BY ANOTHER HOSE CHAFING AGAINST THE HYDRAULIC LINE.

While enroute to the Duke Fire and West of Midland Texas the pilot tried to adjust the pitch on the {{{{{#}}}}}2 engine prop. The prop control failed at 2200 rpm. The pilot made the decision to return to Midland International Airfield to have the prop control checked. He then contacted the company mechanic who was enroute to meet the A/C in Midland. The mechanic found a broken wire at a solder point.

While doing bucket drops on the Grand Island fire in a stand of Cottonwoodtrees helicopter NXXX caught its bucket on a small tree branch. As the helicopter lifted the bucket out of the trees, the plug on the bucketend was pulled from the wire. This left the bucket inoperable, sincethe release could not be activated. NXXX set down and attached itssecondary remote line, which allowed the bucket to be used again and resumed bucket drop work.

During crew shuttles, after the second load of passengers offloaded at the helibase, the helicopter picked up approximatley 3 feet off the deck during a normal lift off when the helicopter experienced a compressor stall. The pop sound was heard by the helitack crewmembers on the deck and the helicopter pilot immediatly set the helicopter back on the pad. The helicopter was shut down and made unavailable. After a look over by the mechanic the pilot flew the aircraft back to base, non-revenue. Helitack returned to base via the Helitack Chase truck.

During a longline/sling operation the longline inadvertantly was released from the belly hook of XXXMA. XXXMA lifted off the pad and set his remote hook over by the load. I was the radio operator and when he was stable I signaled my crew member to hook the swivel to the remote hook. When my crewmember came out from underneath the helicopter I signaled the helicopter to pull the load up. When tension was applied from the helicopter to the load the longline released from the belly hook. The wires pulled out of the pigtail.       We had completed our hook checks in the morning and had completed three missions before this event. The pilot did not hit either releases during this event. The mechanic had been doing routine mainenance and inspection of cyclic, pedals and he may have inadvertantly hit the manual release. In any case the mechanic, the pilot, or myself(HEMG) did not do our hook checks before the mission.

During initial attack the helicopter landed in a field located in a public fishing access point to configure for bucket operations. Upon landing a bystander stopped in their vehicle on a road adjacent to the helispot approximately 100ft away. They were promptly waved away by one of the crew members and drove off. At some point during the configuration the bystander returned, exited the vehicle, and approached two of the crewmembers that were un-packing the bucket and longline. This happened in a short amount of time when the crewmember's heads were down looking at their equipment and did not notice the bystander approach until he was about 5 feet from where they were working. The bystander did not respond to hand signals telling him to leave as the crew approached him. He was very insistent on "helping" and was not initially responding to verbal instructions to leave the area and suspected of being intoxicated (A crewmember smelled alcohol) It took two or three minutes to convince him to return to his vehicle and was escorted there by a crewmember who stayed with him until the helicopter took off. This event took place while the rotors were turning and the man came within 5 -10 ft of the rotor arch when he initially approached.

A recon of the fire was ordered. Bravo-XXX was ordered for the incident. He left the ground at 1150 hrs, arrived over the fire at 1204 hrs. He did 2-3 laps around the fire at elevation. As he was doing his last recon lap, he dropped down, around 500AGL, banked hard to the right and went by the ICP, and proceeded down canyon, directly over the fire. I estimate his elevation was around 500AGL or less and at a very high speed. He dropped down to the bottom of the canyon, executed a steep roll to exit and banked hard to gain altitude and proceeded back to where he landed. Bravo-XXX did not communicate to the IC that he was planning a high speed, low level pass, nor was it necessary to fly directly over the fire at a low altitude. His previous reports form a much higher elevation indicated that the fire was looking good, with no spots outside the line or over the spur ridge.

While preparing for lift off at Ely Airport Transmission chip ligth came on. Pilot shut aircraft down and inspected plug. Found two very small metallic pieces. Pilot Conducted test flight for two tenths and light did not come back on. Helicopter has sence flown 9.1 hours without any problems.MI was contacted after light came on and pior to putting back in service. MI put back in service 0830 hours.

Immediately following take off from Runway 22, the front engine shut down. The pilot went through emergency procedures and made a radio call on Deer Park unicom to inform airport traffic that Cessna had an emergency and was turning around to land on Runway 22. The pilot was able to maintain altitude with rear engine and landed on Runway 22 without further incident. Once on the ground the Air Attack made contact with North East Dispatch and the Colville National Forest Unit Aviation Officer.

While approaching the sling site for the first time, the pilot corrected for a slight wind shift and briefly nudged the top of a tree with the cargo load with the 150 ft. long line attached. He continued his decent to the sling site and gently placed the load on the panel marker on the ground.

During waterdrop mission on the Creek Fire. Aircraft experienced 3 indications at the same time ( No 
Transmission pressure the gage showed 0 with transmission pressure caution light, Collective Limiter failure, and Rotor tack dropped to 0). Immediately Pilot contacted HLCO who was near by advised of the situation, HLCO was local to area and found an LZ approximately 3 miles away. HLCO stayed overhead till landing was assured. The LZ was a helispot that had road access to it, which allowed the mechanics to gain access to aircraft for repair.
Left engine boost pump inoperable. Could not start engine.

Dispatched out to an initial attack late in the day dropped off two personnel on the fire. Afterward, the helicopter relocated to the dip site and reconfigured for bucket operations. The manager and pilot decided to leave the cargo basket attached to the aircraft while performing bucket work instead of attempting a single person removal of the basket. During the first bucket drop with an uphill approach, the pilot grazed the top of a Ponderosa pine that was roughly 60 ft. tall with the side of the bucket. When bucket operations commenced ground personnel moved away from the line and were congregated in an open area in view of the pilot. From this location, the hand crew that was assigned to the fire also observed the strike.   During the approach, primary ground contact and pilot believed bucket would pass over the treetop. However, firefighter further downhill saw that contact was possible from their angle of observation but did not interject. When the strike occurred, primary contact saw the strike and made the call out but the pilot had already realized the issue and pulled up and to clear the tree.  The pilot returned to the dip site, contacted the manager and the bucket was inspected for any damage. Bucket strike occurred around 1920 in a narrow drainage with shadows becoming an issue for both ground observer and pilot in regard to depth perception. 

No damage to aircraft, equipment, or human life.
Lack of radio communication caused two aircraft to depart at the same time, on different runways, resulting in potential near miss.
{{{#}}}1 Spinner lug failed test causing low fuel flow on takeoff. PIC requested 1 hour maintenance break, Jeff Holwick was advised by ATBM.

This safecom concerns fuel contamination on N3310 and N351WM. The story starts on 6/26/99 when N3310 had a fuel filter light on lift off from Jerome Airport. It was landed immediatly and a Idaho Helicopters mechanic was flown over and changed out the filter. N3310 was put back in service after a check with Jim Morrison and dispatched to the Massacre Rocks fire. No further problems until today 6/27/99 and 5.8 flight hrs. later. At 1300 hrs. N3310 had another fuel filter light. Mechanic for the company was in the area and was soon there. It was suspected that the pressure differential mechanism on the fuel filter was faulty as fuel samples out of the truck and helicopter appeared clear and bright. Mechanic had brought along a different whole fuel filter assembly and changed it out. Fuel samples out of truck and helicopter again checked and appeared good. Mechanic was suspicious of fuel in the filter cannistor, however outside the filter. N3310 was test flown and then fuel was sampled directly out of the filter. It appeared clear and bright. As this was going on N351WM had fueled from his truck and went to do tank work. After one drop he also had a fuel filter light and came back to helibase and shut down. N3310 was put back in service and flew about one hr. and fifteen minutes at which time he had another filter light and came back in and shut down. It became very apparent that both ships had been contaminated. They had each fueled out of their own trucks the whole time. It appears that both trucks, being set up the same, had done the same thing. Beyond the filter at the hose reel there is a grease zerk that was greased on HT 20 (for 310) at a previous time and on HT 10 (for 351WM) this morning. Somehow this allowed grease into the fuel hose, thus into the aircraft fuel tank and fuel system. One sample of fuel was intentionaly contaminated with grease and allowed to set for a couple of hours. After that time grease could obviously be seen in btm. of the jar. After second light on 310 I was unable to contact R-4 inspector or H.O.S. but did talk to C.O.R. and told him what had been done and we agreed to put helicopter back in service. Now F.S. and O.A.S. tech. reps are fully informed of both helicopters out of service. Awaiting fix to the problem. Fuel was also recirculated through both trucks so there is a possibilty that the tanks on both trucks could also be contaminated.

Departed airport and manifold pressure gauge stuck, 15 min. into flight. Continued flight to nearest airport. Once landed, the local UAO, Owner, and aircraft dispatcher were notified. Additionally the Regional Aviation Maintenance Inspector was notified. The mechanic looked over issue at 1030, sprayed lines out, problem was not resolved.

After initial attacking a fire on forest, my pilot and I went about providing bucket support with the aircraft. I rolled out the line and bucket, rigged it to the ship, and went through the checks. The ship lifted with no apparent problems and dipped water at an adjacent dip site. After taking on a load of water, the line came free of the ship and went to the bottom of the small lake. The pilot landed the ship and we located the bucket in 15 feet of water and we were able to recover the bucket to shoreline. There was no damage to the contractor hardware. The electrical coupling came apart with no damage to the aircraft. After reviewing the events of the afternoon, it was determined that the ground conditions at the landing site were not suitable for a reliable hook check. The ground was soft enough that the belly hook tongue was in contact with the soft mossy surroundings we were parked in. I was mistaken in thinking the hook was reset and locked.

On 7/16/2020 Helicopter N625CK was assigned a water dropping mission on the Mineral Fire in FKU. While on it's initial dip and extracting water, the Pilot noticed the tank was not filling via snorkel. Upon return to helibase the assigned mechanic inspected the snorkel and tank doors. The mechanic found a sheared rod and a sheared bolt which controlled one of the tank doors. The sheared rod did not allow the retraction of the tank door and thus the helicopter was unable to retain water. The aircraft was placed out of service.

Just after T-XX announced his roll a military C-130 with a CH XX on the tail was spotted doing a low level approach approx. 150` off the deck, and the roll was aborted. T-XX informed me he had not heard anything from the C-130. The FBO was contacted and confirmed he had heard T-XX and the C130 on airport frequency 122.800. He also said he {FBO} was not monitoring the radio at all times so could not confirm when he had heard them. T-XX continued on with his mission and I informmed him I would follow up with a Safecom.
Landing gear disagreement light remained on when gear was selected during landing. Aircrew visually checked down lock indicators which showed safe and landed aircraft.

After dropping off a load of passengers to H-1 the helicopter was returning to  Helibase to pick up one more load of passengers to go up to H-1. The pilot noticed the engine chip light was on. He notified Helibase that he needed to land on pad 4 for a mechanical inspection.

At aproximately 2030 hrs on the evening of July 25th a firefighter on the Stein Incident radiod Yreka Interagency Command Center reporting that a firefighter had been struck by a falling snag and had sustained critical injuries.  Helicopter 502 was working a series of lightning fires on the Westside complex out of Happy Camp at the time of the event.  Yreka Interagency Command Center contacted the helibase and requested helicopter 502 to respond to the incident.  At 2047 hrs. helicopter 502 with a manager, 2 FS helitack Emergency Medical Technicians and an FS helitack First Responder departed Happy Camp Helibase enroute to the incident. Air Attack 06 and Air Attack 05 were over the incident and a life flight helicopter was also enroute.  Helicopter 502 landed at the Stein Fire Helispot at 2103 hrs.  Helicopter 502 remained on the helispot for 8 minutes waiting for the life flight helicopter in order that they could identify the helispot location. At 2111 the life flight helicopter arrived and helicopter 502 departed the incident and returned back to Scott Valley Helibase.  The helicopter landed back on base at 2122 hrs. 14 minutes past shutdown time.

This is for tracking purposes only. At approximately 1330 we lifted from Browns Bottom LZ en route to Pear Orchard Loop Rx for aerial ignition mission. We were conducting initial recon of Rx burn when a transmission chip came on. We landed immediately at Browns Bottom LZ. After landing I called all parties involved and gave update to the situation. Company mechanic was dispatched and arrived.

While performing bucket operations on a rugged piece of line on the Clay Springs Fire with a 100` longline the pilot experienced a ``lee side wind/downdraft`` that caused the aircraft to lose altitude. While arresting the rate of descent the bucket contacted the ground causing light damage to the bucket. The pilot promptly released the load of water from the bucket after the aircraft was stabilized and flew safely back to helibase ceasing operations for the evening. There were thundercells aproaching the area of operations. The pilot explained that he was unable to see the aproaching weather due to a ridge that blocked his view. Helibase wasn`t able to see the aproaching weather nor where the aircraft was working. The terrain was steep and rocky with low schrubs and grass for vegetation.

On loading T-01 at Siskiyou Tanker Base, the pilots noted the #2 propeller was leaking oil and one blade was loose.AeroUnion mechanics changed propeller with one shipped from Chico, Ca.Aircraft test flown Friday morning, 9/21. Bill McVickers, USFS, returnedaircraft to service.

I was working as an ATGS out of Central OR and was dispatched to the XX Fire in Eastern Washington to relieve the ATGS currently on the fire. On arrival and making radio contact with the current ATGS, and receiving a transition briefing things just did not appear right. The fire description fit what I was seeing on the ground, however I could not see other aircraft that were working the fire. I contacted Dispatch to confirm the fire location and other information and was informed that I was diverted to another fire which I was presently over. I contacted the XX Fire ATGS and we sorted things out to some degree: he was confused that his relief had showed up so soon and was expecting it to be someone else. I continued to work the new fire YY. When finished with the fire and being released we departed, refueled and returned home. This order was first given to another ATGS working out of the same base, but because we were rotating assignments and it was my turn he gave it to me.

During shutdown of the aircraft, the pilot turned the aircraft off accidentally and then immediately tried to restart.  This action caused the engine to overheat.  The aircraft was taken out of service and the engine is being pulled and inspected.

1217 Returned from the Yakima Complex to and had to jettison load due to a mechanical problem.  Upon landing mechanics found a number 2 engine oil leak, and number 2 RT hand Kidney sump vent line fitting broke.  The maintenance inspector advised.  Aircraft put in day off parking for repairs.

Helicopter XXXX was enroute back to S39 from a fire near Bachelor. XXXX landed at BDN at approx. 1822 for fuel. A NOTAM issued on 07/20/08 advised the airport is closed between 0600 hrs. and 1800 hrs. Monday through Friday until further notice. XXXX personnel were unaware of the NOTAM. XXXXX assistant foreman approached employees of the airport upon arrival at BDN and was told to land at the fuel pumps to refuel and take on additional personnel. While walking down to the pumps after XXXX landed the assistant foreman talked to several personnel that all confirmed that the pumps were an ok place to land but that there was a NOTAM in place.No personnel that were talked to knew the exact details of the NOTAM. Upon landing the crew was approached by XXXXX who advised that the airport has been closed for the last 2 weeks. He took down the aircraft information, allowed the aircraft to fuel and told the pilot to depart to the West when ready.

A SEAT was dispatched to a smoke near the MT/CO boarder. At around 1640, T-xxx contacted the Dispatch Center to report a fire. T-xxx could see some vehicles on the ground but they looked like private personnel. T-xxx recommended a drop on the fire. Dispatch asked T-xxx to standby so we could contact the County to confirm that they had engines on scene. Also, asked if T-xxx was IA Carded, which he confirmed. Dispatch was in contact with the county IC when T-xxx called back recommending a SEAT drop to control the head of the fire. Dispatch again asked T-xxx to standby until we confirmed with the IC on the ground and gave him the frequency to contact BLM fire personnel on the ground. The County IC confirmed that they had some engines and personnel on the ground and they would take the load of retardant. At 1658, T-xxx called back that he did not have radio communications with the ground and reconfirmed frequency, he then stated that he would drop on the East side of the fire to slow the spread. The BLM engine was in the process of putting the frequency in the radio when the SEAT made his first drop. The next transmission that Dispatch received was at 1700 and T-xxx was headed back for a load and return. Dispatch then called the IC back and asked if he would need a Load and Return and that it would be about a 48min to 1 hour turn around time. The IC was okay with the load and return. On the return flight Dispatch had contact with T-xxx at 1738 to reconfirm the frequency. Dispatch tried again to contact T-xxx at 1756 and received a negative contact. At 1800 T-xxx called and said that he had made his second drop and was headed back to tanker base to hold. During this time there was no contact with Dispatch to let us know that the SEAT had contact with the fire or was preparing to drop. However, talking to the BLM engine after the fact, they were in contact with the SEAT for the second drop. A contributing factor was the assignment of an A/G frequency from one of several versions that had been sent out and then changed over the last couple of months. Thus the reason the BLM engine had to field program in that frequency.

On 8/8/97 a Single Engine AirTanker from Mesa, AZ was ordered to be in Caliente, NV 0900, 8/9. PHX BLM Dispatch processed order and was informed that pilot would file with FAA to Caliente via Prescott, Kingman and St. George. On 8/9, after the flight had commenced, the pilot made agency radio calls enroute even though not required with FAA flight plans. PHX and Arizona Strip Dispatch offices agreed to provide radio flight following, however the pilot repeatedly missed check-ins and arr/dep calls. Although the pilot was briefed by the company and dispatchers enroute, flight following continued to occur poorly all the way to Caliente. CAZ, SWCC and NICC all expressed their concern and displeasure. On return trip 8/14, a similar sequence of events occurred: the pilot said he would file with FAA but made sporadic radio calls to ASD and PHX dispatch making location/status of aircraft unknown at times. Also, AZ dispatchers were unaware of release until T-402 made radio calls enroute.

While flying ATGS mission during the evening hours, Pilot noted an erratic battery voltage indication. After trouble shooting & trying a few things inflight that were not effective, he recommended we abort the mission & return to base as a precaution. He suspected a loose wire/connection or the need to possibly replace a part. As we were returning to base, the issue stabilized. Contacts were made with aircraft mechanic to troubleshoot & inspect the issue in the early AM.

At 0935 on 4/28/14 XXX departed the Panther Helibase enroute to the Orange Blossom wildfire for a recon. At 1038 contact was lost between Panther Helibase and ground resources and XXX on the park A/G. Panther Helibase was able to regain communication through the Victor channel. At that time the decision was made to cancel the rest of the flight and XXX was to return to the Panther helibase. XXX arrived and landed at Panther helibase at 1050 and at 1100 became unavailable for any operations. At this time we had a Communications Tech from the Southern Area Type 1 IMT {Blue Team} look at the radio as well as the helicopter`s mechanic. Through a couple phone calls another identical radio was located at Oasis helibase. In an effort to mitigate the problem and impact the operation as little as possible the decision was made by the pilot to fly over to Oasis, with his mechanic, and swap out the radio. This flight was documented as a maintenance flight, the pilot submitted a flight plan through FAA. After installing the new radio, it was tested and it worked properly. At 1300 XXX became available and conducted several more missions with no problems.

While doing longline water bucket operations on the Goose Gulch fire N398M experienced loss of hydraulics. Our pilot informed me of the situation.It was decided that he would drop the longline and bucket at the Drummondairstrip then continue to Riddick Field (paved strip)for an emergencylanding. I immediatly contacted 911 and informed them of the situation.The appropriate emergency personnel were dispatched to Riddick Field.The pilot maintained control of the A/C and made it to  Riddick Fieldwhere he successfully performed an emegency run on landing. All the emergency response eguipment and personnel were on scene. There was no damage to the A/C.

During the course of operations of the Ash Creek helibase on the Sequoia fire on the Dixie National Forest, several TFR intrusions were noted.  They were small, single engine aircraft flying either north towards Cedar City, or south towards St. George at 1500 to 3000 feet AGL.  The intrusions were mainly in the morning, with two occuring in the early afternoon.  They occurred on July 22(2), July 25(2), July 26(2), and July 28(1).  These aircraft were all flying along the west side of Interstate 15 up and down the valley, their normal flight path as described by a couple of local pilots.  These intrusions were over the helibase, not over the fire.  As each intruder was spotted, all aircraft on the fire were notified of the location, direction of travel, approximate elevation, and color of the intruder for awareness.  The TFR did not include the area east of I-15.

Upon post-flight inspection, a chordwise crack was found in the left hand blade, Serial # 163A. Blades had been installed on 06/21/2007 after an overhaul and had 121.1 hours of time. Company maintenance logs verified the installation. HELM contacted the R4 maintenance inspector and the aircraft was made unavailable. Contractor ordered new blades and aircraft will be inspected by R4 maintenance inspector on 07/15/2007 at 1000 hrs.

While conducting prescribed burn activities on 6 different days the Premo PSD machine experienced a blockage of at least one of the chutes on each of the dates. The blockage was from separated spheres that had become attached to another sphere {see photo}. On the first occasion the PSD operator noted that the bag of spheres seemed to have some residue on the outside of the sphere, seemingly from the potassium permanganate of the broken sphere.. The other dates this did not seem to be the issue, as the spheres were clean on the outside. Noted when cleaning the machine on these dates the PSD machine had a fine covering of potassium permanganate on the slipper blocks, cams, and needle area. The broken sphere becomes attached to a viable sphere and this larger shape allows the unit to enter into the chute but then becomes lodged in the chute. The only way to vacate the chute is to remove the hopper and to push the sphere unit from below.

At approximately 1050 on July 20, 2005 while flying over the Dammeron Incident, the right engine of the aircraft suddenly began to run rough. Engine indicators were normal, the RPM began to fluctuate causing further vibration. Procedural checklist was followed and the right engine continued to run rough and vibrate. At this time the engine started losing power. Engine was secured, prop feathered and shut-down. Flight from the fire (Dammeron) to St. George was approximately 7 miles. Landing of the aircraft was successful with no incident. After mechanical inspection a faulty magneto was determined to be at fault.
This morning, oil was leaking in the {{{{#}}}}2 PRT on the {{{{#}}}}1 Recip engine. A/C was placed into unavailable status.

After start up for a water dropping mission on the High Park fire, while still sitting on the ground, the pilots noticed the rectifier light came on, which also made the oil cooler light come on. The pilots shut down and mechanics discovered the RCR reverse current relay would not close. AMI inspector was contacted.
Enroute to the Sellem Incident (NV-ELD-Q750), electrical smoke, followed by pilot instrument voltage light.Turned off all electrical power and returned to Minden, NV.

At 1500 a UAS was spotted over the Rock Crusher Fire {NM-MEA} by Air Attack. Lead XX was the only other aircraft on scene. The UAS appeared 300 - 400 ft below the Air Attack and approximately 500 – 600 ft above the Lead Plane. Air Attack followed the UAS protocol by notifying the Lead Plane and Incident Commander. The Incident Commander notified agency law enforcement who happened to be on scene of the fire. Air Attack proceeded to widen the aircraft orbit outside of the FTA and initiate a left hand pattern, in order to track the UAS for the purpose of deconflicting the airspace. The crew lost sight of the UAS. The Lead Plane also widen their pattern beyond the FTA. Within ten minutes of the sighting, the Air Attack and Lead were diverted to another initial attack fire. No firefighting aircraft worked the incident after the divert.

523 was working the Empire fire when the low fuel caution light came on{10 min Fuel}. Pilot made decision to land immediately, with 400lbs of fuel, light usually comes on at 200lbs with this model. Relief pilot was not briefed that on this machine the fuel light comes on at 400 instead 200.

At Approx 1900 hrs. July 13th BC-13 was in the vicinity of the Paradise fire located in T 24N, R12 E, Sec 20.  He observed an air tanker drop a load of retardant on the incident. This drop was not ordered for this incident and there was no radio contact with either the air attack or the air tanker from BC-13.

Pilot dis a radio check on Nat. Flight Following onto the ramp. During the first checkin dispatch lost contact with the ship. Attempted to contact on NFF, AirGuard, and local -- no contact. While the senior aircraft dispatcher was making contact with the HEMG at the airport the pilot called in on cell phone, that dispatcher lost contact with him before asking him to return to airport. Off and on contact was made on NFF and broken cell never long enough to inform him to turn around. Ship returned for a second recon. Radio checks were made again, again dispatch lost contact with ship on NFF, HEMG made contact on cell and turned ship around and cancelled the mission.The pilot was spoken to after second flight by the HEMG. Pilot didn't seem concerned about the bad communication. Appeared to be very mission focused --not the safety issue of communication.The senior aircraft dispatcher in dispatch attempted to shut down the mission after the first check in with bad communication until better means was worked on, AFMO on unit advised not to, for the ship had not gone over the 15-min time although the dispatch explained they did not have good communication or position on the ship.

Pilot failed to untie main rotor blades before start up. Pilot noticed that he did not untie at the same time he attempted to start engine. Immediately aborted start. Total time was approximately one second. Pilot untied blades and started helicopter.

As we were coming in to the LZ, one of the crew members on the ground noticed something leaking by the fuel tank. Once we landed and shut the helicopter down the pilot came and examined the leak. He said it was for sure fuel and we needed to find out where it was coming from. The pilot looked into the engine a little more and found out it was leaking between the electric fuel shut off valve. The pilot pressurized the system with the boost pumps and could not recreate the leak. He returned to base without the helitack crew.
Pilot cancelled mission due to visibility, lighting, and fatigue. Pilot pushing over 360 hours for the fire season.

Helicopter 94M was doing bucket work on the Bray Gulch Fire and landed at 2045 for fuel. The helicopter was back in the air about 2055 to do more bucket work and the pilot had been informed that the flight times ended at 2125 before refueling. Helicopter 94M landed at 2107 to pick up manager and then fly to pick up helitack crew. The helicopter was on the ground at the Helena Airport at 2127.

Air Attack 430 was scheduled for relief by Air Attack 07 at 1730 over the incident when South Operations ordered AA-07 to respond to the Creek Incident in Tuolomme County. Sierra ECC advised the GACC of the relief required over Musick Incident.  South Zone GACC ordered SNF ECC to send them and they would replace AA-07 with another Air Attack.  Air Operations Director was never consulted and the replacement air attack did not arrive for approximately 40 minutes which forced Air Attack 430 to exceed the 7 hour CDF flight time policy limitation by about 13 minutes.  Personnel assigned on Division U were at a critical support both for communications and for retardant drops which AA-430 canceled due to lack of aerial supervision.  430 grounded fixed wings and returned to Fresno.  AA-430 had Helicopter Coordinator launched to supervise rotor wing until AA-410 arrived. While the need for an air attack was evident for the Creek Incident, and the diversion of the AA-07 solved that problem it caused a situation where aviation management was compromised over the Musick Incident. It is unknown as to the time that the Air Attack order was received by the GACC for the Creek Incident. It is unknown whether AA-410 could have been sent directly to that incident even though it was farther (approx. 15 minutes more flight time) to the Creek Incident than the Fresno based AA-07.  This would have possibly avoided the situation.  Rarely does the South Operations consult with or check with incident management personnel before they move assigned aircraft around to meet other incident needs or to anticipate the negative outcomes of those decisions.  In this case there were ground personnel who were in a hazardous situation that needed fixed wing and close support.  Incident management personnel were not afforded the opportunity to provide this information which could have caused a different response.

On July 23 during rappel operations a rappeller dislocated their thumb. All standard checks were performed and proper PPE and sequence were followed. After receiving the descend signal and leaving the skid the rappeller went to double brake during the descent. In the course of the double brake when the rappeller moved left hand from the device to the rope the right hand left the hip creating slack and a loop in the rope between their two hands catching the left thumb and pulling it to the base of the descent devise dislocating the thumb. The rappeller used the right hand to free the left thumb and continued to the ground and notified the spotter of the incident.

At approximatley 1400 on 09/04/01 Flight Follow when out.  Jumper 59 and Helicopter 70B where both on Initial Attack missions at the time.  Established contact with both aircraft on Air Guard, switched both aircraft to local repeater and completed missions.Contacted local USFS Communications personnel.  He confimed that flight following was broken and would look at it on 09/05/01.Unable to determine when flight follow will be operable due to Communications personnel's response.

The AC was off contract after dropping off the ATGS at MSO. After takeoff the pilot said the aircraft was running rough and would not climb. He turned the aircraft around and made an emergency landing at Missoula.

Tanker XX departed LMT at 1442 loaded to the Annie fire. At 14:55 notified LMT airtanker base of problem with {{#}}1 jet and needs to jettisson retardant and return for maint. Gave Tanker XX coordinates for jettisson area. Tanker XX proceeded to area and aborted load. Came into LMT at 15:16.
After landing pilot reported he experienced a problem at touchdown and roll out with the right prop rpm. It would not come into high RPM and was lagging behind the left engine prop.

While enroute to the fire, The right hand B panel cracked and delaminated{Panel to right of windshield}. Crew followed aircraft manual emergency procedure and jettisoned load at low coverage level at approx. 1000 ft. AGL.

While the mechanic was in the process of pulling out the auxiliary fuel tank and doing a preflight inspection after ferrying from Alaska to Washington, he discovered that the lower lift link bracket had a fracture running through the aft flange. Helicopter was grounded and made unavailable at 0800 PST.

Upon touchdown at Helibase, the aircraft bounced on wheels and skidded approx. 15 feet before coming to a stop. Crew was unloaded along with gear at Helibase. PIC did a walkaround of aircraft looking at wheels, landing struts, etc. inspecting for any damage, none found. Aircraft was later inspected by mechanics at airport and no damage was found. Upon review of load calculation it was found that aircraft was overloaded approx. 450 pounds for conditions at site. The Helibase was an inground location. Pilot directed aircraft into the wind for landing as per normal. Performance planning was not accurate for actual conditions at Helibase. This responsibility lies with the Helicopter manager who accepts responsibility for incident. We did not confirm actual conditions before landing as is normal SOP, I believe we were mission focused as the fire was in close proximity.

On July 8 2016 19:10 a Temporary Flight Restriction {TFR} intrusion occurred on the XXX Fire near Pine Valley Utah involving an Unmanned Aircraft System {UAS} or drone. This TFR intrusion resulted in a near collision with Air Attack XXX. XXX was at an altitude of 11,000 feet when they passed the drone 30 feet off the right wing of the plane. The incident occurred on the XXX Fire at approximately LAT/LONG 37 23 .104 113 31.149. Geographical location of Lloyds canyon and Forsythe Canyon on the Pine Valley Mountain range. This is the forth confirmed UAS intrusion on this fire.

Earlier in the morning we were requested to a fire that we had completed that morning. We returned to base and refueled, after refueling we were then requested to complete a lighting recon of the Forest that we initiated in the early afternoon. The lighting recon was uneventful and returned to base. Upon landing at the base we refueled the plane and upon refueling it was discovered that one of the fuel caps was missing and could not be found. The fuel cap was replace with a spare fuel cap.

While conducting cargo sling operations in support of a prescribed fire it was noticed a few items were missing from a delivered daisy chained load. The load in question was configured at Helibase and consisted of two nets, one being fresh and canned food contained within fiber taped boxes, the second net contained 10 PG bags, two medical bags and a stretcher. The net containing the food items was configured as the top load with the PG bags and medical equipment as the bottom and heaviest load in the daisy chain. All loads, seven in total for the day, were inspected by the Qualified Helicopter Crewmembers assigned to the cargo operation prior to flight with no issues being detected in the construction. Once all the loads were received a call was made to Helibase to notify of the missing items, two medical bags and the stretcher. The missing items were not left behind at Helibase, and not witnessed departing the net once the load was lifted and in flight. There was a ferry flight of 10 miles and 5,000 feet in elevation gain to the receiving end. During the transport the pilot did report an oscillation in the load about mid-way through the flight while crossing a ridge line, however was thought to be minor turbulence as experienced throughout the day. Perhaps once the oscillation started with the load the missing items departed the net, though there was no eyewitness to confirm.

The IC had two qualified guys for the longline operations for backhaul.Both told the IC that they where also ex helitack and could do the job.The IC and one of them worked the loads on top of the fire just fine but the longline remote hook specialist rigging the load of backhaul at the bottom of the fire had problems.We slung a net with a cargo bag inside to him for the loose items he had.He was told to load the cargobag keeping it inside the net ,slinging the load with the net.The pilot noticed that the net was hooked up to the remote but the cargo bag was outside the net loaded. The pilot told the hooker to put the bag inside the net but it was attached to the swivel.When the load was lifted the pilot seen that the support straps of the bag did not look right so flew the load slow the short distance to the helibase.He set the load and landed to investigate.The straps of the bag where directly attached to the remote hook.

A medium helicopter assigned to the fire complex experienced difficulties while dipping with a bucket and long line which lead to a close call for the relief pilot. The first fuel cycle went smoothly according to the pilot, having chosen a dip site he was comfortable with. When he returned from a hot refuel, the aerial supervision platform had transitioned and specific dip sites were identified as appropriate. Upon attempting to use one of the new dip sites the aircraft `turned` due to erratic winds at which point he was able to recover. Having been shaken by the event, the pilot continued to attempt approaches at other dips but had difficulties in understanding where AA wanted him to dip. Due to the misunderstanding of directions and his unease with previous events, he made the decision to return to helibase and make himself unavailable for external load missions for the remainder of the shift. Erratic winds were present along with poor visibility creating less than ideal conditions. Other aircraft/pilots were successful with the dip sites and were more familiar with the local area and conditions.

On the way back to cascade airport from doing bucket work on the burnt fire. The tail rotor chip light illuminated. The pilot landed at cascade airport, without incident. The mechanic pulled the plug and found a sliver of metal.
FM radios would not transmit. They were NPX1360-070.

Upon landing #1 prop remained in reverse. Attempts to adjust pitch failed and the aircraft was placed out of service by the pilot and mechanics were called.Mechanics replaced the feather pump and run-up was performed and no problems were encountered. The aircraft was placed into Contract availability by XXXX XXXXX, R-6 Maint. Inspector at 0910 on 6/20/01.

Two large fires with adjacent boundaries managed by Incident Management Teams in the AFS Tanana Zone were aware that aircraft supporting the two incidents would have some common operating airspace near their boundary. The AOBD````s proactively acknowledged that there was potential for some airspace conflicts due to the amount of recent aviation operations and each team````s incident response action delegation. Within those delegations the Hay Slough Fire was split by the two teams creating this common space. The AOBD````s developed a notification procedure to inform each incident helibase of aviation operations in this common space. On July 15, each incident ICS 220 had special instructions directing the helibase managers to inform each other when aircraft were launched to the vicinity of this common space which was identified by latitude and longitude. The information to be provided was aircraft tail number, mission type, and frequency to be used. On July 16, two water scoopers were ordered by the Spicer ATGS to deliver water to the Spicer Fire. The water source for the water scoopers was Fish Lake which was within the common space. A fixed wing performing another mission landed at the airstrip next to the adjacent fire````s helibase and informed them that the water scoopers were using Fish Lake. No resource from the Spicer Fire had notified the adjacent fire````s helibase following the established protocol. The AOBD and ASGS subsequently informed the adjacent fire that the Spicer Fire did have water scoopers drawing water from Fish Lake.BLM Aviation Safety,WS,7/24: The two Fire Bosses were dispatched from Galena to the Spicer fire.

While flying air attack over the Trampas Fire at 12,000' MSL Trampas Branch called us to report a Beech 18 over the Trampas fire. We imediately saw the  Beech 18 silver in color with airforce stars at our altitude approximately .5 mile to our southeast over the east side of Trampas fire. Aircraft proceeded on course to the northeast.

Enroute to the Borrego Fire, T-48 notified Albuquerque Zone Dispatch shortly after take-off that engine trouble was being experienced. T-48 safely returned to Albuquerque International Sunport and parked at Cutter Aviation to determine maintenance needs. The need for an engine change was identiifed. An engine was to be transported from Minden, Nevada. The number one engine was successfully changed and the aircraft returned to contract availability on 05/25/02 (1700)per the Regional Aviation Maintenance Officer.

PUT ELECTRICAL POWER ON A/C (NO ENGINES RUNNING) FIRE WARNING INDICATER ON # 2 ENGINE.  TROUBLE SHOT THE SYSTEM. TRACED PROBLEM TO AN IR SERVER WITH FAULTY GROUND. REPAIRED END OF GROUND WIRE. SYSTEM CHECKS 4.0. CONTRACT INSPECTED BY TERRY CULLIN.  GOOD TO GO.

Battery Temp light came on while doing bucket work.  Outside air temp at the time was over 100 degrees.  Mechanic adjusted the voltage regulator and allowed the battery to cool. After running a short while, the light came on again and voltage had rised a volt.

While returning from bucket operations on the Fawn Peak fire,the bucket brushed the tops of a clump of 20-25 foot high aspen trees.  The length of the brush was about 30 feet.  The pilot immediately gained altitude and set the bucket on the pad without incident.  The trees were about 200 yards from the designated landing spot(pad 6). No damage to the bucket, wires or any broken branches in the trees.   Pad 6 was the western most landing spot on the helibase, next closest helicopter on the ground was over 350 yards away. I talked to the pilots:  They had just come on to relieve a crew that day.  XXXX had many hours in 61's and I had worked with him in tough areas without incident during the 2002 fire season.  XXXXXXXXXX was new to 61's and XXXX told me he was allowing XXXXXX fly at the time.  XX said he would fly in and out in the future and use the bubble windshield that would enable better reference.  I said I would more closely monitor take off and landings, and be ready to call if I saw anything.  I was on the fire and worked with them for the next several days and they flew with percision and skill the entire time.

During bucket deployment training, a quarter inch (1/4) hole was noticed in the fuselage.  The hole is located on the rightside, 9 1/2 inches forward from the edge of the rear step, at the base of the fuselage curvature.  The Pre-use inspection  did not reveal the damage (hole).  An examination of the hole and what previous helicopter activities occurred prior to the hole discovery, indicated the damage may have occured during rappel recurrency.  The thumbscrew allenhead on the Sky Genie matches the diameter of the hole.  Various mockup simulations failed to indicate any situation that could indisputably be determined to have caused the damage.  It is theorized that the damage may possibly be attributed to one of the following actions:1) Approaching the aircraft with rope bag with genie on top, the bag was swung into the fuselage with enough force to cause the damage.2) Genie struck side of ship if rappeller swung unnaturally beneath ship.The damage is basically cosmetic, and the contractor has sealed it with tape temporaily, and will do a permanent fix at he first opportunity.

On 8/23/00 at 1830 hrs. while conducting smokejumper operations on the Cameo Fire, BLM Grand Junction District, a smokejumper landed in an inactive portion of the fire.  The jumper was the first person of the second stick when the incident occurred.Jump conditions at the time were; winds @ 7mph, jumpspot size @ 2 acres and upwind of fire with no hazards in the spot, slope flat, thunderstorm @ 2 miles to the east, first two jumpers landed in spot and informed plane that jump conditions were acceptable.  Fire behavior was inactive with retardant inhibiting fire spread.  Fire size was 3 acres.During descent, winds increased and prevented the jumper from making the intended jumpspot.  Jumper was forced past the jumpspot and landed going backwards into the black, where some embers burnt several small holes in the parachute before removing it from the burned area.  No other equipment nor the jumper received any burns.Jumper suffered a left shoulder sprain during the landing and was taken to Grand Junction for examination.  Jumper has been placed in light duty status and should be able to perform full duties within 5 days.

A fixed wing aircraft flew over the helibase at 1600 heading north during a firefighter shuttle.  The aircraft was identified as a white Ryan PT-22 with a red tail.  The aircraft was later located at Gallatin Field, with tail # Gxxxx.  No contact with the pilot of the fixed wing was made.  One helicopter pilot said the fixed wing passed him at approximately 1000'.  TFR was in effect at the time and this was a violation of the TFR.

While flying Air Attack over the Megram Fire at 9500', the air attack pilot noticed another fixed wing flying approximately 1/4 mile and 500' above our position.  The aircraft appeared to be a Cessna 206.  The aircraft executed 2-3 orbits over the area we were working, then exited the area.  The pilot of the air attack ship contacted Seattle Center and reported the TFR intrusion.  Other incident aircraft in the fire area were a HLCO and other rotor wing aircraft working at 6500'.

Upon landing at Boise, three smokejumpers were moving in the aft of the aircraft and accidentally knocked an unclipped PG bag out the open jump door on the left rear of the aircraft. The pilot was not informed until the aircraft had exited the runway and had contacted ground control for taxi clearance. Upon learning the bag had fallen out, the pilot was cleared to taxi back and retrieve the bag from the runway. The ground controllers were fully cooperative and stated it was ''no problem''; however, the pilot apologized for the seriousness of the occurrence.
Upon clearing the Class C airspace I attempted to contact Dispatch Center five times on National Flight Following to establish flight following. I received no answer.
While climbing to the fire #4 engine developed a high fuel flow and had loss of power. Load was dropped at a safe altitude and location. Returned to RDM ,changed carb.

On 7/31/2014 while on the Carlton Complex, xxx dislodged a limb that struck an individual during water dropping operations while working in the South Zone of the fire on Division 3I. The individual was not injured. The pilots for xxx said they repeatedly asked if the area was clear before they dropped and were told that the area was in fact clear. The pilots were notified by the ground contact that the limb was dislodged but were told that everyone was ok. The pilots continued to conduct water dropping operations and then returned to Helibase at the end of their fuel cycle. The pilots did not notify the HMGB of the incident. The HMGB and the Helibase Manager did not learn of the incident until after shift when South Zone Air Ops notified them that the incident had occurred. The HMGB followed up with the pilots the next day {8/1} and got their account of the incident as explained above.

While doing an operational rappel on the fire to cut in a heli-spot: after both sticks of rappellers had reached the ground and moved clear from the rappel site and cargo site, The helicopter made a couple of laps around the spot while the spotter configured cargo {two fire boxes and one 5 gallon cubee}. The pilot and spotter got set up over the cargo spot well away from the rappellers on the ground. The first load of cargo got to the ground without incident. The pilot felt good with the spot so he held hover as the spotter got the second load of cargo ready {two fire boxes and one 5 gallon cubee}. Once the cargo was rigged and ready, the spotter checked the spot to ensure the ship had remained over the site. After confirming power was good, the spotter started to deploy the cargo. The cargo was out of the door, with both fire boxes clear of the outside of the skids, but the 5 gallon cubee got hung up on the inside of the skid. The spotter then locked off the let down line on the ears of the figure 8 and worked to free the cubee from inside the skid. When the spotter was finally able to pull the cubee up and over the skid, both the cubee and the saw box came undone from the let down line and fell to the ground about 150ft. The spotter then unlocked the let down line and lowered the remaining cargo box to the ground without incident.

On 6.16.2008 at approximately 1730 airtanker Lockheed P2 Neptune tail number xx was in the blocks and was under supervision of fixed wing parking tender. Aircraft had just completed loading retardent, loading crew was cleared, and airtanker was given permission to start engines. Pilot signaled to FWPT to clear him to start engine {#}2, clearance was given. As engine {#}2 was starting the suction from the propeller sucked a collapsible fabric and wire sunscreen out of the copilots window. The sunscreen disappeared with the engine blowby smoke behind the aircraft. Clearance was asked and given to start engine {#}1. As engine {#}1 cleared of smoke the sunscreen reappeared and swirled with the engine turbulence, threatening to be sucked into engine air intakes of both engine {#}1 and engine {#}2. Parking tender gave the pilot an emergency immediate cut-engine signal. Pilot responded immediately. The sunscreen fell to the ground in front of engine {#}2 and was retrieved by FWPT.

Pilot was supporting Fire #146 on the Willamette National Forest with bucket drops. At approx. 1245, the pilot indicated master caution light was on and was returning to base. When in route back to Santiam Airport the light went off. Once at Santiam Airport the mechanic inspected light and determined that one wire was chaffed and touching another wire which caused the master caution lite to go on. I called Jeff Holwick, Aircraft Maintenance/Saftety Inspector to discuss the problem. Jeff talked with the mechanic (Danny Popscu)and cleared the helicopter to return to service.

While picking up out of a dipsite {pond} at 7150```` the pilot, noticed the bucket was unusually ``tipped`` indicating a harness attachment point failure. He began to release the water {Variable fill} and the 7 other attachment points failed and the bucket fell {detached from the longline} into the water and disappeared from sight into the pond. The A/C returned to helibase with longline and bucket suspension harness only. Bucket type: Non-standard {not Bambi nor Fast} variable fill. The powerhead and Variable fill valve are one unit located at the bottom of the bucket.
Experienced intermitant prop fluctuations on the #1 engine

At approximately 1200 Dispatch notified the Tanker Base that a heavy airtanker was going to arrive to hold or possibly reload. SEAT aircraft T-XX and T-XXX were relocated from the loading pit area to the East side of the taxiway, tie down area, in preparation for the arrival of the Heavy Airtanker. They were repositioned by contract personnel via vehicle tow. An adiditonal SEAT remained in the lower loading pit, which allowed room to accommodate the passing of The Large Airtanker. The Large Airtanker arrived at the Tanker Base at approximately 1250 PDT. They contacted the ramp and were instructed that a marshaller would direct them on the taxiway to the upper loading pit. The Large Airtanker successfully made it past T-XX. There were two SEATs and a C-182 parked in the East-side tie-down area, to the left of Large Airtanker. This created a situation that caused the Large Airtanker to taxi well to right of the taxiway centerline to avoid the parked aircraft. Because they were so far to the right of the taxiway, the Large Airtanker`s right main landing gear wheels had traveled off the tarmac and the pilot adjusted the aircraft back onto the tarmac. The pilots’ attention was also focused on the taxiway light pylons as there was some concern that the right outboard propeller might strike one of these. The marshaller continued to marshal the aircraft past T-XXX. The position of T-XXX did not allow adequate room for the Large Airtanker to pass as it was parked slightly more forward than the other aircraft. The left wing fairing of the Large Airtanker rolled through the propeller {not in motion} of T-XXX. The Large Airtankerwas directed into the pit and damage was inspected. The left wing fairing of the Large Airtanker and the propeller blades of T-XXX were damaged.

Helicopter XXX {XXX Helitack} and YYY {YYY Helitack} were both dispatched to the Mercur Fire. Air Attack was able to talk to both aircraft on the assigned VHF-AM frequency. In addition, Air Attack could talk to the Incident Commander on the assigned VHF-FM air-to-ground frequency which had a transmit tone of 100.0. However, as both helitack crews engaged in the suppression operations, Air Attack was not able to communicate {after several attempts} with the helitack crew of XXX. A radio check with the YYY helitack crew confirmed that the correct A-G frequency {w/ Tx tone}. After removing the tone from the air-to-ground frequency, Air Attack successfully communicated with the XXX Helitack crew which had already engaged in the suppression of the fire. It is critical that suppression resources ensure that they use the assigned frequencies for an incident. Without ensuring positive communication with all aircraft on the assigned frequency {including the Tx Tone}, the helitack crew should not have actively engaged in suppression action on the fire: air attack was not able to communicate with them in the event of an emergency or critical change in fire behavior.

On Saturday 7/9/2011 there was a loss of communication between an exclusive use helicopter for the Okefenokee refuge and the Helibase that the aircraft was flight following with. The Helicopter was on a mapping mission for the Honey Prairie fire. Do to the loss of communication a search for the aircraft was initiated. According to AFF the aircraft could have been on the pad Bergansa helipad at Dixon Memorial state park. Air attack went to this location and found that the aircraft was indeed on the ground with no problems. The pilot had closed out with the refuge dispatch but not with the fire dispatch.

Aircraft was being refueled by a new refueler.  The pilot followed behind and checked each fuel cap after the refueler filled each tank.  After checking the first 3 tanks manually, the pilot observed the 4th cap visually and determined that the cap was locked in place.  On climb out, the pilot looked to the left to determine that the area was clear.  It was at this time that the pilot noticed the fuel cap was dangling from the tank inlet on its chain.  The pilot then came back in and landed without incident.  The pilot then reattached the fuel cap and continued mission.

We mis-calculated the flight time from the Bitter Creek Fire to the Santa Fe Airport. Distance is 75 kt miles. Resulted in landing at 24 minutes after sunset in single engine aircraft. Contributing factor was an unexpected 50 knot headwind.

While attempting to drop on Tom's Canyon fire, doors on drop system failed to open or close properly.  Jettisoned load in designated jettison area and returned to Grand Junction Tanker Base.  Vendor mechanics checked system and found 2 of the electrical wires which supply power to the hydraulic system had failed.  Repairs were made by vendor mechanics.  Returned to Service by vendor at 0700 on 3 July 1999.
During start-up Pilot noticed a malfunction in Hydaulic system.  After inspection the 1st stage Hydraulic pump shaft was shearded.

We, the smokejumper aircraft took runway 24 for takeoff and made our departure call on UNICOM.  Helitack helicopter said on UNICOM they were lifting from the ramp and would hold for our takeoff.  We started our takeoff roll and the helicopter departed to the north crossing runway 24 approximately 4,000 feet in front of us.  We called on UNICOM that we were already on our takeoff roll and the helicopter stated that they had us in sight.

During an initial attack flight, 10 miles out from the incident, the pilot noticed a right fuel boost pump caution panel light illuminated. A precautionary landing was determined necessary, Air Attack was notified of problem and landing location. We landed in an open field close to a road to determine the problem. After landing the pilot pulled left circuit breaker to confirm no fuel pressure on right fuel pump. After consulting the flight manual the crew off loaded and the pilot flew back to base for repair.

On 9/4/12 the xxx Helitack crew arrived at xxxx Helibase for an assignment on the xxx Fire near xxx, Wyoming. We received an adaquete briefing which included several details that we considered aviation ``red flags``. Our concerns were that the fire was between 10,000 and 11,000 feet and it had been burning for approximately three weeks and was essentially unstaffed with the exception of some helitack that had been pulled off the fire that morning but had been unable to be picked up due to high winds which are common on the xxxx. The forecast for the day included a red flag condition for high winds up to 50 plus mph. We were then given a mission to do bucket work after briefing at around 1000 hours. Both myself and the pilot were reluctant to take the mission and talked about the many concerns we had and decided the risks far outwayed any benefit.

Intermittent Radio Problem in the Plane:* Radio check of aircraft radio on ground, inScratchy, but readablein.* 1st checkin after takeoff- aircraft radio was not transmitting out, but  reception was good.  Radio check on HT was, inLots of background noise, but  readable.* The HT was used to notify Dispatch and the Radio Tech that the Recon would  be using the HT for flight following.* 15-min. checkins using HT continued to be readable with lots of background  noise.* Approx. 45 min. into flight, background noise in transmission from HT seemed  to worsen. Reception continued clear.* At that tifme Observer and pilot made a decision to cancel the mission and   return to the airport* Disptach was unable to read Recon's transmission about returning to the Air-  port and requested that the mission be cancelled.* Recon landed without incident.

The helicopter was trailered to Boise, ID. A new fuel control system was installed. This problem had occurred at Cottonwood, Idaho two weeks earlier. A fuel governor was replaced. This did not solve the problem.

Upon landing at the tanker base T-XX was required to abort a landing cause of a aircraft still on the runway. It was noticed on his second attempt, his landing gear was not in the down position. Calls by the RAMP mgr, and base radio was made to notify T-XX his gear was not down. A last attempt was called to T-XX to ``abort, abort, abort gear is up`` call was made. The tanker responded and a gear up landing was adverted. The aircraft was reported to have been 10 feet or less over the runway. After the the next landing, T-XX was asked if he needed a break and his response was he was all right and continued operations.

POSSIBLE UNAUTHORIZED ENTRY OF AIRCRAFT.DURING PREFLIGHT OF --- AT THE METOLIOUS HELIBASE THE PILOT NOTED THE RIGHT FRONT DOOR AJAR AND ALSO TWO SWITCHES IN THE ON POSITION THAT HAD BEEN SHUT OFF THE EVENING BEFORE.THE PILOT CONTINUED THE INSPECTION OF THE AIRCRAFT, SUMPED THE FUEL AND THEN CONDUCTED A TEST FLIGHT AND FOUND NOTHING ELSE WRONG.THE AIRCRAFT THEN PROCEEDED TO THE NEXT FIRE WITHOUT PROBLEMS. THE RECIEVING FOREST WAS NOTIFIED OF THE INCIDENT BY TELEPHONE.NOTE THAT TWO HELIBASE PERSONELL WERE SLEEPING WITHIN 200 FEET OF THE AIRCRAFT AND HEARD NOTHING DURING THE NIGHT.
